text: had on-tap at the red lobster in hickory , nc . nose was a bit sweet but there really was n't much there .  blood red color with a thick pink foamy head the color of blush wine .  tingly in the nose which is common with sour ales but this is n't sour at all t. sweet with dried fruit , malty m. has a biting quality , a bit to carbonated .

the aroma is composed of citrus and yeast . i detect the slight prenence of hops in the aroma . the flavor is slight on the front of the tongue , but the hops are prevelent on the back of the tongue .  pours a pitch black dark into snifter glass with a rich , creamy head that lasts a great deal of time and a heavy lace remains . probably the darkest looking beer you will find and a wonderful head .  very astringent .

s : not a lot of aroma . mainly sweet , bready malt . t : quite earthy , probably from the yeast , as well as the hops . d : very drinkable .  a- glourious golden yellow with a fluffy and foamy white head that retains well in the tulip glass . dies to a fluffy ring and nice cloud that leaves thick lace all along the glass .  the mouth feel was hindered a bit , as the bottle had n't been sitting in my refrigerator long enough , the ale could have been a little more carbonated .

amazing smell ; right in line with what i expect from stone .  a : black on top , fades to reddish/brown at the bottom when held up to the light . nice lacing . a real gem .  taste is light and airy , a tad sweetness is overpowered by barley and water . this stuff does n't dry out the mouth , which is good . then again , that 's because there is nothing in here except water and barley . i will take a soda anyday , but i guess i can see why people trying to quit alcohol but still like a cold `` beer '' here and there will spend money on it .

this is a good beer . it poured a nice light amber with a small head . the taste was surprising and full flavored for the style with a good balance between hops and it 's great sweet malt backbone . the mouthfeel was exceptionally creamy .  a : black with a huge tan head , great retention & lace .  its sucks to know that in a different format this could be so much more . body and carb is okay , but by this point i 'm already at the meh stage .

not a bad smell , quite malty at first but there was enough hop aroma to keep it interesting . the was great - full bodied , very malty , but bitter enough to achieve a balance .  appearance 5/5 clear dark brown with a good dark tan colored head that stayed around , and left good lacing as well .  this is an excellent pilsner . number three on my list , only behind konig and pilsner urquell . just as crisp and refreshing as both of those , but a little lighter in taste and body . very clean , top quality .

rather subdued smells of hops and citrus and i 'm getting a bigger than expected malt .  pours beautiful dark brown with red edges , almost black with a huge tan head that sticks around and leaves walls of creamy lace .  a surprisingly great beer from a brewing giant . it could have been a little less punishing when guzzled , but hey it 's a dark beer and we are not dealing with coors light here . i think the beer is buitiful to look at , and is rather smooth . but the lable and beer fit perfectly ph

smells of loads of caramel , vanilla , sugar , lactose . basically like dessert . far too sweet .  it 's bronze , perfectly bright . it 's foamy , with a good head and strong laces . this beer shows that a beer made to please the most people can still be made with great quality .  mouthfeel is a little too carbonated and light but i still enjoyed the beer in-spite of those tow minor complaints .

to be honest , the aroma is the worst part of this beer , because i love the taste .  poured from a bottle into a pint - exceptionally clear , copper colored with a one finger head that was almost latte colored , enough carbonation to keep plenty of lacing and a little bit of a head until the end .  m/d : the mouthfeel is a tad low on this for my liking of an oud brune .

s-the nose is light , nutty roasted malts with hints of herbal ester in the back . t-the taste is more full , lots of nutty flavors up front , roasted bread rolls , notes of dough , lightly roasted malt , faint herbal hop in the back .  poured into my big family guy mug and was greeted with one of the best looking heads i 've ever seen in that mug . perfect ruddy brown with a hint of mbver red , just like a bock should . nice and opaque too , hard to see any bubbles in there .  the feel in my mouth was medium and it was a bit syrupy .

the day after i review the bottle : i walk into my local and it 's on a cask hand pull , what a lovely surprise . the smell was , like the bottled one , it 's weakest part and although there were hop and malt esters they did n't excite or bother the nose at all . the last paragraph is almost the same as my bottle review : really liked the mouthfeel and taste , good blend of ingredients to produce a fine beer .  a clear copper ruby when held up to the light with brilliant head retention and honeycomb lacing .  a watery texture and lighter body than i expected from the nose , with a moderate amount of carbonation .

really nice looking brew . s : apricot faint apparent , hops overwhelm the fruitiness making for a very odd nose .  appearance : hazy golden orange . effervescent body with a thick pillowy , white head that just wo n't quite .  the palate is thin but ok .

smell : cocoa , as expected , along with some good roasted malt . smells like a promising porter .  a-black as hell , 2 1/2 '' incredible light brown cappucino froth head . this beer looks fantastic . s-roasted malt aroma is so subtle it 's barely there .  this beer has a lot of flavor for a light . too bad its not a good flavor ! nothing impressive at all here . i 'm not sure what they are putting in this beer but its not worth the 7.99 they are charging for a six pack . i would recommend pabst blue ribbion over this any day !

a - clear , ruby red , aggressive poor produces no lacing s - not a lot going on here , maybe some figs or plums and vanilla or caramel t - wonderfully subdued representation of the same aromas in the nose m - very smooth and creamy with just enough carbonation for a clean finish d - impressive for 10 % .  a - beautiful amber body with intense white huge head and sheets of lacing remaining for an insane amount of time .  under carbonated .

smell : malt and flowers , some pine . not getting the citrusy blast that i like from an ipa , but otherwise pleasant enough . overall : very good ipa for those who prefer balance over hop bombs .  summit horizon red : a : appearance is exceptional , great amber-red color to it with exceptional clarity ! nice 1 '' head that develops yet depletes half-way through .  the mouthfeel is a bit harsh with the 8.0 % alcohol , but i have found very few tripels that can hide the alcohol content .

the aroma was quite lax , nothing really going on in the nose , it smelled a little spicey and nutty , but that 's all i got ? the taste is solid ; nice mix of unique spices and a grea tmalt taste with a sweet tone as well , i found it hard to grasp what exactly was in here but it was dispersed throughout very well .  pours out blackish with a big fluffy tan headskie . looks amazing !  it it a bit on the carbonated side , so the mouthfeel is a bit more bland than i had expected .

there was very little nose to speak of , just a bit of a sweetness , like caramel . it was very drinkable , and as with newcastle you can often find this when theres nothing else in the bar/restaurant worth drinking and it would certainly get the job done .  a : hazy yellow with a frothy head that has great retention ; what a hefeweiss should look like s : grainy with the typical banana and cloves poking through the hay/earthy/straw graininess t : a nice balance of earthy grainy yeastiness and banana and cloves ; subtle spice nodes ; a tiny bit thin on the way down f : pretty good mouth feel but a tad thin at back end d : wonderful drinkability ; the quintessential hefeweiss beer ; great especially for a hot humid day .  m - the mouth feel is spritzy and aggressive with a dry finish .

s : smells like vegetables ( must be the beets ! not particularly pleasant .  bottle acquired through recent secret santa swap w/ alohac pours absolutely beautiful brown tinged amber . fluffy , long lived , tan head with loads of lacing throughout .  the mouth fell was a little thin for stout .

smell was odd ... something seemed off ... unbelievable the difference between smell and taste ... the taste was great..sweet on the front , rounding into a tartness and a very nice overtone of alcohol . drinkability is very good for the high abv ... very easy to drink .  appearance : this one pours a very dark mohogany with an incredible red hue . great head rentention very frothy .  the mouthfeel is thinner when compared with other stouts , merely decent .

the smell is very mild with a bit of toasted bready malt coming through . while the smell was a bit small the flavor is the opposite , very big . huge fruity malts up front with a bit of sweet apricots and a touch of raisins , toasted malt and bread qualities linger as a strong juniper and grapefruit bitterness take over and linger on the tongue .  a : this pours an entirely transluscent orange color with red hues and a finger and a half of slightly off-white head that laces better than any beer i have ever seen .  the mouthfeel is quite thin , verging on watery .

interestingly , taste is unlike the smell ... and that 's a good thing . aroma is typical lager , run-of-the-mill beer .  has my favorite froth for this style , thick and sticky , goes nowhere fast and the color looks bread .  m - medium body , fair carb , etc .

nice crisp pils aroma . smells nice and bready but not very complex . tastes great . very crisp and refreshing .  poured from a bomber into a snifter a - exceptional ! dark , almost ruby like color when held up to the light .  smooth , medium body with a palate almost entirely made up of bitter , herbal hops ; perhaps trace notes of biscuity malt can be detected , but they are virtually non-existent . finish is long , dry , and bitter , and leaves you wanting more , which leads to a great level of drinkability , especially for a hophead .

the aroma suggests yeasty caramel cream and maybe some grassy hop but overall a pretty neutral effect , with some rubbing alcohol , nothing too alluring but it 's okay . the tongue detects lots of stuff ( unlike the weak aroma ) including earthy pine and dr. pepper medicinal sweetness .  the lacing is astounding . pretty appealing .  the only complaint i have is that the texture left much to be offered . overall i great beer .

the smell is hops , almost bitter , and faint malt .  a : pours a cascading nitro-foamy head in a black background . the beer itself appears black at first blush , but upon close inspection is actually a very deep ruby/mahogany . it is a gorgeous beer .  on my first stop on my michigan beer tour . the grand cru on tap was a very nice start to my tour . the first taste was wonderful , but , the flavor of the beer left my mouth looking for just alittle more .

although it had little aroma , it had a very good taste .  this beer was poured a very dark rich chocolate brown with a thin tan head . with this beer being pushed nitrogen , it had a ton of lacing and the head lasted the entire beer .  mouthfeel : low carbonation , light-medium body , slick texture . a bit flat all in all .
aroma is very yeasty and bready . nothing really outstanding here , but a pretty solidly made beer .  terrific retention and lots of lace . stunning .  feel is kinda harsh .

first it poured a very clear medium amber , just beautiful and it 's clarity reminded me of many cask beers i have enjoyed in england . aroma was a bit of a surprise , i was expecting , or hoping maybe , for the citrusy hop character of bear republic racer 5 or el toro 's agressive interpretation . i found it very restrained and almost tea like .  nice tight eggshell head . nearly brilliantly clear .  it had a light feel on the palate with mild carbonation .

i am a hophead and i might as well have ordered a lite beer . no hoppiness at all- very bitter and a poor lingering aftertaste .  a- dark brown with an off white creamy one finger head that laces nicely to the last drop .  mouthfeel - rather bubbly , fairly thin .

aroma is faint , but of roasted malts and some nutty and fruitiness . for such a mild beer , this is very impressive . full of flavour .  it poured with a huge , frothy , clumpy , and sticky head that was the darkest brown i 've ever seen .  the feel is smooth , suprisingly light for a beer that seems so heavy . while i feel that this is one of north coast 's better efforts ... though none are really bad , i do wish that it had a bit more body .

it reeks of pumpkin pie without being too aggressive with it . the pumpkin pie aroma does n't dominate the taste and it actually tastes like a beer instead of some kind of pumpkin pie flavored wine cooler .  appearance/pour : nice dark amber with a surprising stream of carbonation rising from the glass bottom etch . head which dissapates to a nice ring with small foamy clusters . thick lacing and a dense sound while pouring- sounds thick .  taste is more of the same ... some wild floral flavors , hints of citrus ... seems like the dominant flavors have switched from the citrus to the floral characteristics . i like it , for sure , but could use some balance . i 'm not a big fan of the bitter taste left in the mouth ... but it 's still plenty drinkable . a definitely above-average ale , but not the best .

the dortmunder style is one of my favorites , easy going , not an everyday ( though it could be ) and thisone is done well . a frothy , pillow-like white head that stuck around and laced oh so well . the aroma was not overpowering , maybe alittle grass-like . this homebrew could be a great macro `` try-this '' offering great job , great beer !  nice clear copper color with a decent tan head , nice active carbonation , and nice sheets of lace .  carbonation is a little much in my opinion and cuts down on the smooth/velvety texture .

s : honestly , smell like vomit . maybe some passion fruit and maybe some wheat , but it 's bad and smell liked some puked up a beer .  motor oil black with a head like you would see on a rootbeer float .  m- the weakness of the beer - moderately light body feels a little weak to me . light carbonation does n't add much .

however , i got a very unpleasant smell that i can only associate with used diapers . unpleasant for me , and i do n't really mind barnyard smell usually . smell faded after a while but it really got me off the bat . the only thing that really threw me was the smell , it was unusually unpleasant !  pours a fluffy , thick , white , three-fingered head , fades very slowly and leaves gobs of lace .  had one warm just to see what the flavors were really like , and blllaaahhhh corn up the ying yang ! honestly , if youre going for the light beer on a budget , i 'd go with bud light just because it has no flavor , this is like a bad , adjunct-y lager that 's been in storage for a year . i 'm just wonder if miller has some weird process that makes their beer taste stale , because i notice the exact same thing in mgd , yet not high life , maybe its just the filterization . anyways , about twice as yellow , piss looking as a heineken , yet actually produces a decent mouthful . and the smell seems to get better when there is less of it , so the finish is actually pretty satisfying . overall , decent for why people drink it , but for a light beer , i 'd go with amstel , even for its price .

smell is a little flat ... some burnt caramel and a little bit of orange citrus . taste is off the rocker , though ... this is basically dogfish head 90 minute without the bitterness .  pours a nice bright yellow orange with a massive , almost overflowing white head . head sticks around indefinitely as bubbles continually rise in an energetic fashion .  palate : medium body and higher end carbonation .

its about what you would be expecting from a mexican lager .  appearance - you can immediately tell from pouring that this beer has exceptional carbonation . it also has phenomenal lacing capabilities that do n't want to let go of the glass .  the mouthfeel is just average . also , carbonation is lacking enough to make this feel sticky .

smell was strong with bananas , sweet , bready malts . an interesting beer , and one that 's good as a crossover beer .  poured into a tulip a nice dark brown color , nice carbonation , awesome fuckn ' head , never seen a head like this from a bw , two-finger creamy tannish head , tons of sticky lacing and islands through out the drink .  i picked this lager over the ale 's offered , due to the miserable heat wave here in no . cal . it was an appropriate choice . saaz hops seemed to be prominent with good malt base . a nice refreshing beer . nothing spectacular but very acceptable when in the mood for this style .

nose is cherries and sour funk .  pours a crude oil black with a phenomenal caramel tan mocha head that is incredible , the cake laced froth will coat the glass throughout the session .  m-its a little undercarbonated but the balance of the sweetness with the malt and subtle hops make for a relitivly complex october beer . d-easy to drink and very nice to have this time of year , easy to session .

i actually smell this beer about 2 feet away when opening . very citrusy and piney , a small amount of orange juice sweetness is present . a very nice extreme beer , i may be afraid to try fresh .  appearance - jet black in color with a very nice one finger light tan head that lingers while drinking . perfect for keeping in the flavor and smell of the beer smell - very light on the malt smell , but somewhat heavy on the bitter hops .  i did notice after a while that it has been pulled from tap that it acquires a lack of a better word , a buttery taste that really dos n't go good with anything . i do like this beer and i 'm not bashing it . the buttery taste in my opinion did not take effect until thirty or so minutes after pour . i do keep some in my fridge . i have shiner before to make burgers with , which turned out great . good beer for beer lovers .

s : grapefruit hoppy smell is strong but good , looking forward to the drink .  poured with a huge frothy head . brilliant white in color , the head lingered and then left some amazing lacing . looks great .  the body becomes thin on the mid palate and that 's my primary complaint .

light-medium carbonation . medium bodied . starts and finishes sweet this could be mistaken for a belgian . the high abv ( 9 % ) is not really noticeable . pricey - $ 4.50 for a 330ml bottle from wine society tyngsboro , ma .  a : nice bright golden color with a nice creamy head that you dont usually see on these american witbiers .  the mouthfeel is a bit too watery and perhaps a bit chalky .

-- horrible ) . beer does not have much of a smell to it . maybe a mild roast , some malt , not much at all . beer is super smooth , beautiful full bodied beer . for some reason the first time i ordered it i expected some smoke but was pleasantly surprised by the lack of it .  the appearance was a perfect deep color with a incredible head .  i wish the carbonation was a little more noticeable in the mouth .

not too sure about this . some notes of spice , cinnamon stands out . slightly lactic . no real hop character .  a brown top with long legs to match . awesome . a beer that is overpowered and buttered with palo santo wood is one that attacks the palette . not a fan of the hints of sweetness here either . mouthfeel was average , but feeling over carbonated for this suite of flavors .  m - light body , with a carbonation level that is probably too sharp for the style .

it did n't smell like much , which is dissapointing . i look forward to the roasted and hoppy aroma of russian stouts , but this one did n't come through very well .  pours deep burgundy/ with 3 fingers+ of sand/tan colored head . superior lacing & head retention s : chocolate & coffee ( ?  the carbonation is heavy and it adds harshness to the palate . medium-full body .
poured a dark orangish brown , great balance of citrus hops and a roasted malt .  great retention and lacing !  way too thin in the mouthfeel category , however .

s : not much in the nose at all . a hint of roasted malts is about it , and that 's faint . not completely unexpected for the style , however . m : creamy , as you 'd expect from a nitro pour , body is on the light side , also about what you 'd expect for this style . easily quaffed . worth checking out .  22oz brown bomber without bottling date , 11 % abv a lovely , lighter shade of amber crowned with a snowy , white lasting head that leaves wonderwalls of lacing . a beautiful brew .  mouthfeel was moderate , not super heavy or light .

light nose of little consequence . the taste is very nice with limited and pleasant spiciness and a nice bread sense .  looks great with a two finger thick off white head , and has a nicely filtered copper colored body .  the body is pretty light though and clean .

my first beer with agave added . smell : hints of honey and orange blossom , slightly muted .  pours jet black with 3 fingers of brownish , mocha head that just screams ice cream float . tons of sticky lacing & very good head retention s : roasty malt , rich , dark & fruitty with woody hops , & booze once warm t : roasty malt , dark choclate , herbal hops along with molasses , leafy & minty hops up front .  mouthfeel is thin for a stout imo , but not bad .

smell is pretty mild with just a hint of roast malt and caramel .  presentation : poured into a tulip glass from a 750ml brown magnum . a : mahogany brownish-red with light tan head . almost blood red when held to a light .  nice chewy mouthfeel , but significantly under-carbonated . the only thing it lacks is carbonation and a decent head .

the smell is sweet and lightly spicy this lightly floral and more hoppy than a typical ale of this style .  a busty foamy cap on top ... head is monstrous ! not only is the head big its retention is just as good . head was a soft tan ( cappuccino ) color with craters , mounds , and dense chunks forming all the while leaving a bleary coating of lace . a very good look to this one s : i am having a bit of trouble grasping this one but had no problem realizing this one is sweet and rich .  a rather thin aqueous body with less carbonation than expected , but otherwise nothing wrong with this brew .

the aroma is promising -- it smells like it could be a rich but balanced stout .  amazingly attractive .  as for the go-down : thin & lightly carbonated , not aggressive but not annoying either & no aftertaste .

s - strong citrus and pine/juniper nose on it . very fragrant making you expect a delicious taste to follow . m - lots of bitter tangy sensation at the back of the tongue following a few sips , but strangely lite and unsatisfying . d - decent drinkability , but not exceptional . it 's a strange beer : starts off great with an impressive hops-laden nose , but then does n't really delivery .  this alt looked fantastic ! has a rich , deep , clear chestnut color , with a very fine light tan head topping off at about 1 '' . the head dissipates at a very slow rate , and leaves top-shelf lacing .  m : surprisingly on the more carbonated side with a slight fizzy mouthfeel .

s : nose is very subtle for a -bal aged beer . muted chocolate , cocoa powder , and roasted malt .  appearance - i really like this one , a rich caramel color and moderate foaming taste - hmmm .  m : sharp carbonation is pretty overpowering , and any refreshing aspects of the smell and taste are lost .

a hazy copper pour with a sustaining head , the beer smells sort of indistinct for the hops and malt you 'd expect .  looks amazing . s : very nuty , caramel malt , lightly roasted coffe , dark chocolate , mild booze .  out of all of the blueberry beers i have had i would have to say this is probably my favorite . very fruity with a somewhat dry finish to it . the blueberries are definitely the star of the show . overall this is a very drinkable beer and makes a great summer brew .

small white head that dissipates quickly from my tap pour at the airport taproom . lack of noticeable smell , which i find from most tap beers .  looks great on a goblet . amazing retention and lacing .  bought this over a month to two months a go and decided to give it a go . it is an ipa so it does have a nice bright orange to copper color . the taste and the smell are sweet and fruity , the only bad thing i have to to say about it , is the taste of tea is very lacking . i cant pick it up but , other than that i wish that stone , ishii and baird made this more as a yearly offering , cause its really good

smell & gt ; average . notes of grain and honey , but slightly metallic .  this beer reminded me an awful lot of duvel , but niot quite as good . poured to a highly carbonated golden yellow , with thick pilowy white head that lasted the entire beer , and left excellent lacing .  as readily available as bud , and a whole lot better . a great fall-back session brew , which is good with a meal , or having several at a baseball game .

s - was not very aromatic although i could faintly detect some coffee maltiness . t - while i am not a frequent drinker of porters , i found this one to be good . very tasty . d - the overall effect of the smooth taste and the unexpected light-medium body made this porter very drinkable . i think porter fans will appreciate its coffee/chocolate characteristics and more casual porter drinkers will find it very approachable . very good on its own and would probably pair well with a hearty stew , a roast or possibly a chowder .  a wonderfully thick head sits on top of an incredibly amber colored beer . my favorite look easily .  mouthfeel : the body is oddly thin , and crisp .

deep black in color-nice slight tan head that lingers down the glass.subtle aroma of malt.slight chocolate smell.roasted flavor dominates.hints of licorice.very subtle sourness in the backround.full bodied mouthfeel.a very drinkable beer-comes off more as a stout then old ale to me.very enjoyable none the less .  pours a pitch black color with a huge brown head into my glass .  mouthfeel is a bit thin and somewhat tannic , but the overall effect is quite interesting .

the smell was fragrant and very boozey . it wafted cough syrup memories .  huge sticky head alone has a personality all its own . gorgeous golden haze pour that has no room for improvement , while in a class all its own .  went down smooth with no after taste . not bad , but could include a few more hops to round out the beer . i would recommend even without . it was very good between 45 and 55 degrees .
when smell is present , it is pleasant . taste=good taste .  the appearance was impressive , very black with a nice brown head .  mouthfeel : a little watery , but not terrible .

t : hugely ( and distractingly ) sweet . almost medicinal o : a very complex sipper of a beer that i found overly sweet . enjoyed the non-ba version much better .  this ipa is perfect specimen as far as appearance . it is a cloudy gold in color with a nice foamy long lasting head that sticks perfectly to the glass .  medium thin body manages a bit of creaminess .

aroma was a bit lacking .  tremendous head and a deep , dark brown body . the lowly brown ale usually isnt going to win beauty contests , but this is about as good as one will look .  mouthfeel , i would like it have been a bit more carbonated , but it did fine .

the smell was a very solid , but not incredibly inviting cocoa presence . the mouthfeel was incredibly lucious and creamy , just like a porter should be .  pours a dark brown with a healthy sandy light tan head that lingers at a fairly thick level and laces the glass heavily .  the mouthfeel is fairly overcarbonated and dry .

laces well throughout process s-smells like a coffee stout ( what a shocker ) . smell the roasted coffee up front with a slight chocolate malt i think t/m-eh , it does its job well , it tastes like it should .  been looking for this one for awhile ... a- pours a crystal clear shade of orange with a three finger , very puffy offwhite head . well , it looks fantastic to start ... it can only go downhill from here s- smells very citric ... no coffee coming through on the nose .  i 've always liked this beer , and if they beefed up the abv and gave it a little more body , it would be the perfect porter . why grant 's beers share these characteristics i do n't know , but if they ever did beef 'em up a little , they could truly be a contender .

no noticable odor of any kind . this aromatic absence was confirmed by others at our table.tasted like someone burnt the malt .  poured beautifully , an opaque red mellowing to a rose at the bottom of the tulip glass .  it was creamy with an average carbonation level and also average alcoholic strength ( 6.0 % abv ) . overall : awful .

though , if i had to guess , i would not have picked this out to be a saison . smells of bready malts , with some 'sharp ' somewhat earthy notes , - hard to describe .  poured from bomber into my stone irs snifter ( 2010 ) a - pitch black with a big persistent dark tan head . the head is beautiful on this beer . what an appearance !  a bit thin , but a very good stout flavor develops in the mouth . i 'd have preferred a bit fuller body .

not much else and not too complex , but it had nice depth and smelled good . mouthfeel : medium-bodied , getting close to edging towards full bodied .  a= pours a nice looking hazy golden amber color with a nice cap on top . great looking beer .  nicely carbonated .

majestic sniffs . taste is equally multifacited . one of the maltier versions i 've encountered , laid out in a doughy , bready fashion . this is a very fine hefeweizen  the 2005 is a brighter copper , with the most beautiful , nearly unbroken sheet of off-white lacing on the other side of the glass . gorgeous . on the 2010 , no lacing , bigger bubbles , thinner cap .  the carbonation is nice throughout . thinner than expected also .

some rich roasted malt aroma is prevalent if you can get past that head that acts like a aroma seal .  the reserve special black bier was a beautiful sight resting in a dark horse souvenir pint glass . it was black as night with a dark tan head indicating the level of roast of the malts used .  initial taste of a sparkling mouthfeel with a puckering sour cherries that coat the mouth incredabily . the palate duration is average . medium body .

groggy hazy brown color in the body . a little sour , but the malt comes through in the aroma . flavor is a superbly sweet caramel malt , but with a kick of almond .  a - black as thick midnight hanging over a field , with subtle touches of chocoalte milk . lacing levels out nicely in turn . from now on , i 'll head straight to those black 6 packs with their odd violet label anytime i feel like a remarkably solid showing , probably .  tart and dry feel , but not overly so . lower carbonation detracts a little , really the only flaw in my mind .

s : not much going on hear , some toffee and yeast t : very malty , toffee sweetness , some spice .  pours pale gold with a massive crown of stiff white foam .  mouthfeel : surprisingly thin body , full carbonation , fairly thick coat after the swallow .

a trace of lacing & head retention s : dates , raisins , steel & port soaked raisins t : rich dark fruits , herbal & leafy hop bitterness up front . started strong , but the dryness & oakyness detracted as this warmed mf : slightlty overgassed , medium bodied & with fair balance drinks easy , but this one could use at least 12-18 more months of aging , not a bad take on the style  on tap at ebenezer 's 2/13/11 a : pitch black and completely opaque . massive 2 finger mocha colored foamy and rocky head that was there to the finish . i ca n't recall many big stouts with such an impressive looking head .  too much carbonation for this style ( -1.0 ) .

s : citrus hops that had a sourly strong detergent scent that was a slight turnoff at first .  the head is a huge and fluffy 3 fingers high cloud puff with great retention and excellent lace .  if i had to log a complaint , it would be that this stout is too thin and less of a cream offering . however , it is full of flavor and easy to drink despite being 6.5 % abv .

nose is slight with hints of fruit , apple in particular . mouthfeel is very carbonated with a light citric tingle .  a- pours a splendid black color with a thin milky looking head that lasts the entirety of the beer and copious rings of lacing .  m : flat , slick , and that 's it . not quite watery , but pretty close .

very bitter citrus smell . sweet to the taste .  sampled @ strong ale fest san diego the beer pours the color of onyx with the head creamy light chocolate brown and portly in size with the resultant lace a fine curtain to conceal the glass .  it went down smooth with a little bite in the after taste .

not much in the nose . coffee and maybe a hint of lactose .  appearance- beer pours a wonderful looking amber golden with a thin wispy head one finger high of whipped cream foam . this is about the most perfect appearance i 've seen for a marzen . very impressive from an impressive brewery .  this is very malty at the opening with a twinge of caramel . upon downing it , the taste resembles a very dark beer . very malty with heavy caramel presence that makes it a bit sweet . it also gives a bitter character that mellows into a sweetened deal . i 'll have to try it from the mug in the near future . it may turn out differently due to more carbonization released , making it less bitter , dare i venture to say . but , straight from the bottle , it is easier to imbibe if you 're used to dark , bitter ales .

some old , musty , leafy type aromas . smells like fall .  clear copper with orange accents , forming a large , pillowy peaking light beige head atop fine bubbles . moderately strong carbonation .  light feel with lots of carbonation .

smells strongly of banana and bubblegum , with only a touch of clove . a candied note and a bit of white bread as well .  pours an opaque darkness with a huge stiff dark brown head that decomposes like an ice cream sundae , massive 3d lacing present .  mouthfeel is a little bit stingy , but from the carbonation and not the alcohol , otherwise the liquid is the right viscosity and creams up ok on the tongue .

pours a light brown with a reddish tint , it dosnt have much of a scent to it except for a slight cirtus .  the beer i poured into my goblet has a creamy merengue head , and itself is a rich , effervescent amber . almost like a river-worn globe of amber .  m. a little too sticky , it feels syrupy , but without a sweeter taste it fells a little off .

smell was very mild . malty and slightly peaty with a bit of fruit .  this beer pours a majestic golden pale color with a very large white head that sticks around for quite sometime . this beer looks amazing , it 's paleness reminds me of that duvel color minus the slight yeast haze this beer possesses .  wow this has to be one of the worst ideas in beer history . trying to cross a pale ale with a belgian and what you got is something that is a distant cousin to both . instead of leveraging the style 's strengths this beer doubles down on their worst attributes . a very hoppy tatse that fights like a strong ale . not a fun beer and a true shame that it might discredit weyerbacher 's other great beers .

smell is hops and very very little floral notes .  a - extremely dark brown body topped by a frothy bark tan head standing a couple inches tall . the head has some great stamina ! the lacing this beauty leaves is also worth noting .  the mouthfeel of the beer was , like most porter and ale styles , very average . however , the mouthfeel did not detract from the overall feel of the beer .
kinda skunky with that typical marcobrew taste .  pours a luscious and very tempting opaque sable with a thick , frothy tan head that leaves a fair amount of lacing .  m - slightly thin and sweet .

smell : varies as it warms : bacon , chocolate , hickory , raisin , wood and more ... taste : dope .  a : pours a clear golden with a massive frothy , rocky head with great sustain .  m/d - mouthfeel is nothing special , the steely hop bite takes a bit away .

smells grainy w/ a slight aroma o piss .  a : this beer pours a beautiful hazy red color with a fluffy off white head . the color of this beer is amazing .  ambrosial start , lots of malt , the top skimpy in feel with the finish having a delightful hop spicy bite , the carbonation moderate and the aftertaste droughty and long lasting .

musty aromas and smokey grains come in strong with this one . this aint no fru-fru grand cru micro .  it pours with a clear amber body topped by a medium thick off white head with a good amount of lacing left on the glass .  rich flavor in a thin body -- well not that thin , but certainly less than most bocks ( not to mention doppels ) .

smell : not much smell , the small amount i am getting has nice coffee and mocha notes . taste : this really shines in this category , like the smell suggests this has strong coffee flavor with a nice mocha after taste that really becomes apparent several seconds after tasting . the light mouthfeel and the carbonation make this very drinkable ; almost scary drinkable for an oatmeal stout !  bomber bought at total wine a - dark black , 2 fingered head , dissipates slow and leaves a nice lacing .  perfect carbonation but that thin , light mouthfeel is where this beer falls a little flat .

the aroma was clean , woody , spicey , and fruity .  a very nice hazy orange color with a huge off-white head that subsides slowly and leaves lots of nice lace .  not sure if our north american brethren appreciate this but this is , as far as i can tell the first fairly widely available american style ipa brewed in the uk . the american craft brewing industry which has been accused of being derivative is really starting to influence europe which is great . i am all for my uk brewing industry but i do get a little board of the vast variety of often samey real ale bitters populating manypubs . we definitely have a shortage of hopheads brewing in the uk ! and before anyone shoots me down , greene king ipa is not an ipa ! ! !

s : nice sweet smell , but not too complex .  pours a beautiful bright burnt orange color with a hefty tan head that bubbles up at first and leaves lots of lacing .  flavor is absolutely nothing like an oud bruin .

a heavenly delight of a smell taste : 2.5 this beer is incredibly sweet . loads of candy sugar in this , i am sure . this beer has crazy sweetness its very cloying .  poured from 22oz bottle into `` balloon '' glass the darkest ebony color in the body with a rocky massive foamy/sticky dark tan colored head .  m - medium/light body with little carbonation good with spicy food .

chocolate covered malt balls , roasted barley , brown bread , molasses , shoyu , and a touch of oxidation ( sweat , cardboard ) in the nose . letting it `` breath '' for a while seems to help dispense with some of the undesirable aromatics ... old coffee grounds , and an almost sour hop flavor greet the palate . pleasing spice-like astringency . reminds me of nitro-tap but in a good way ... a well balanced and enjoyable example of the style , though it does n't seem as robust as the label claims - i 'd be nervous to age this except at a very cool temperature - as it tastes just a hair past its peak already .  appearance - pours with a nice , clear golden head , some dark reddish hues provide a little tint . two fingers of whity rocky head with a crusty top and lots of good stick .  less fizzy than anticipated in the mouth .

great lacing & head retention s : musty grain , herbal & woody hops t : follows the nose , rye peppery notes & crispness , plus a whisper of smoke & some grassy hops climbing up as well up front .  it pours as close to a pitch black without actually being pitch black . great head retention so this really has it all going on in appearance .  had this during o'briens wet hop festival . pours clear orange with a white ring of bubbles . lots of caramel with some tropical hops in the nose . kind of like a fruitcake . earthy , yet citrusy in the taste . bit sweeter than your normal ipa . grapefruit and blood orange . good stuff .

aroma seems a little incomplete , with yeast smells and a touch of leather .  crystal clear golden color with the thickest white heading i have ever seen on an ipa . fantastic lacing . a great looking ipa but the taste is just like many .  the mouthfeel , i was not so impressed with .

very subtle hop aroma , flowery , old lady soap smell ( dove ? ) .  pours a rich opaque sable with a fine-bubbled light tan head .  i found that the beer smelled and tasted rather skunky , unlike most other beers that i had tasted and was deeply disappointed by it . it felt ok in the mouth and looked very nice in its green bottle but was not worth my time .

smell is very faint - a little bit of strawberry , and not much else . the taste , however , is just fantastic . the wheat beer flavor is at the forefront , but the strawberry smooths it out wonderfully .  the pour is ebony in color , the head inconsequential in size , the structure patchy clumps of large bubbles , the color a light chocolate .  heavy hops , but not totally unbalanced . very quenching .

glass : generic goblet appearance : light copper color , thin head smell : sweet , fruity , strong sour grape , notes of cinnamon taste : light , dry , light malt profile . overall : the taste didnt quite hold up to the huge bouquet .  true amber in color with perfect clarity .  m - not as thick as i 'd like it to taste considering how rich the smell is . d - very drinkable , with the lighter mouthfeel it 's easier to forget how much you 've had .

light whiffs of fruit sweetness and sprinkles of hop . very bad stoned !  bourbon colored with an excellent 3 finger head that rises a good 1/4 inch above the glass . very foamy head that last a long , long time .  thanks to ncvbc for this great extra best by 12/31/08 bottle poured into my sniffer produced a good fingers worth of tan head that turns into a ring of lace around the glass on top of a jet black body aromas of toasted malts , coffee and chocolate with a slight funk ( i 'm glad i am not the only one to pick it up i though my nose was going ) earthiness , sweat malts , light chocolate , molasses good balance of flavors the only real complaint is it is a little thin for a stout good drinkability i could drink a few of these a night easy .

ample lacing left on the sides of the glass . really not a big nose imo , lihght traces of roasted malts , earty and homey .  what a beautiful beer . it 's bright gold in color with a large sticky white head .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied with likely carbonation . that , and the over carbonated pour make this beer a something i would not recommend .

smell is rather subtle actually , for the hop taste i would would expect more however i would never hold it against this beer .  pours a dark brown colour with a frothy thick tan head .  m : mouthfeel is decent , goes down reasonable smooth even with the slight burning sensation .

the smell was earthy and of tart fruits .  tasted nov. 21rst 2011 ( from notes ) tulip a - very nice translucent blood red , 1/4 finger off white fizzy head and minimum lacing s - peat , smoke , nuts , alcohol , slight wine , lots of yeast and oak t - so much peat , wow ! sap , wood , lemon , citrus , alcohol , sauvignon blanc , more peat , some nice hops and the peat kind of peats ( haha ) out all the other flavors m - medium body , medium acidity , low complexity , not balanced and very long finish d - while at first few sips the peat is overwhelming and almost nasty , after a bit the peat is more in the background of a smokey , citrus , alcoholic ale .  it was a little thin .

aroma is a little chemical , but there is also vanilla and yeast .  probably the most impressive head i have ever seen on a beer .  hate to say it , but the bottle/case i have is absolutely awful . other than a hint of coriander spice all i got was an overwelming sourness that made this one of the few i had to pour down the drain . they obviously put wayyy too much orange peel in their mix . if you can get past the sourness it is par for a wit bier course . i 'm hoping this was a bad/expired batch because ... .as far as mill street goes imo , stick to the coffee porter ...

aroma is some spice , toffee .  on tap at the pub ... the body is bright dark orange , but totally clear , very cool . an off white head leaves a thin cap , with great lacing , stellar ... the aroma is really successful in that the citra hops come across as orangey and sweet but they are literally cut but the balance of the other hops which reigns it in with some nice bitter pine .  very pleasant indeed . great hop character . this is a fairly balanced ipa . hard to say , it might just be because this particular bottle is more on the room temp side , but i would like more effervescence . a good beer all in all . i will be sure to drink it again , only a little colder and faster . more drinking , less typing ... .

the taste is pretty good , it 's leaps and bounds ahead of the smell . big sweet malts , chocolate , coffee , hops , some slight smokiness , and almost an artificial banana flavor .  22-oz bottle opened at local beer tasting ( underground bluz ) . a beautiful brew . this beer can do some damage because you wo n't want to stop drinking it !  could use both more body and carbonation .

smell is beautifully complex & bright , like i just walked into an herb garden : really picking up on the rosemary , floral notes that are big but gentle , something kind of savory like oregano , maybe some basil or mint notes in there . seriously , this is fantastic , i do n't think i 've ever smelled a beer like it .  appearance : pours a beautiful dark amber with a finger of light tan head that leaves some lacing and a ring around the edge of the glass .  mouthfeel is pretty good , but a little on the watery side for a chocolate/dessert beer . with the abv at 6 % and the body a little thinner than other chocolate stouts , one could have a couple of these in one night .

aroma is by far the best part of this beer . a veritable tropical drink in this beer ! flavor does not follow through from the aroma- surprising . i detected minimal hops in the aroma , but they are there quite blatently in the flavor .  thick dense white head with great retention .  there 's a bit of a hop presence in the finish as a lingering bitterness runs along the side of the tongue . finishes pretty clean , with a little lingering of the hops present , but otherwise very dry . a very drinkable , light beer . perhaps more of a hop presence than other beers like this that i 've had .

o : the aroma was just unpleasant . flavor was n't too bad , though .  great white head that left a really nice lacing .  the flavor too is ever so slight wine barrel aging with a weird and awkward type sour . it 's really off putting . this barrel aging was awful . this beer is weak and severely overrated . it was awful both times .

the first thing i noticed was the head , which was average.it had an average amber color , but the taste was quite different than others i have tasted so far.i tasted chocolate.i understand this to be from the malt flavor being intensified.i have read that the kolsch style of beer should have a stronger hops taste , so maybe this is put in the wrong catagory.i liked this beer , probably due to my chocolate affinity.it has a pleasant disposition and is unoffending to the palatte.it has a sticky taste , like chocolate.i liked it.i would buy again , probably with a piece of chocolate .  this beer looks perfect . pretty gold color , with a nice big fluffy head .  m - ok and average .

this is one hell of an opaque beer , with minimal carbonation to boot . it tastes a bit chocolate-ly , and it 's rich and smooth without the boozy effects . this drinks supremely easy , just wish it is available easily in ca so it would become my daily session beer .  giant billowing white head . the dense creamy , soapy head leaves giant lacey patches and a tantalizing heavy layer for the duration . color is a thickly hazey amber red with a big old carbonation tornado at the center .  m - lots of carbonation maybe bordering on too much .

i really miss schlitz . schlitz has more of a hops flavor than any other american lager that i 've tried . but i think that schlitz is the best american adjunct lager out there today .  pours a dark copper with a large , foamy white head that hung around forever . large amounts of thick lacing left on the glass surface . this is one beautiful beer .  5/5 m : medium body and smooth . the lighter body makes it sit not-too-heavy , and it would be easy to partake of a few of these on a cold night .

the smell was really subtle for me and i could n't detect anything more than a slight sweetness like burnt caramel .  the pour is beautiful . intense rich brown/black , with a two finger dark brown head .  the carbonation is moderate high . i think it is a bit high for the style but the carbonation does not take anything away from the beer .

pours golden with a very light floral aroma , pure white head .  the beer itself pulls a pitch black into the glass and lets no light through . darkness is right . head retention is decent , leaves a perfect lacing behind .  the first time i had this beer , i distinctly remember it being among the worst i had ever had . apparently my ba colleagues disagree , so i 'm giving it another try . there is some faint grassy hops , but this beer is mostly about the malt character . overall , this is way better than i remember . i might have to make this a regular part of my beer fridge ! or perhaps they had n't figured things out when the brewery was just getting started . glad that there 's another quality beer in e-town .

can into pint glass a - big 2 finger eggshell head , slightly hazy medium orange/brown coloring on the beer , relatively large bubbles s - quite robust hops and citrus control the doughy scent , surprisingly bold smell t - bready start transforms smoothly to a citrus to a bitter and a slightly sour finish .  pours a completely opaque pitch black . light brown head with some big bubbles around the edges .  m : medium viscosity , acidic early and slightly syrupy on the palate , with moderate carbonation .

draft beer in a bottle is as good as it gets with mgd . nothing fancy , this is a great bbq beer . throw some burgers on the grill , crack open an mgd and have a great day out in the sun . not the best beer made by miller , but a great cold filtered brew .  pours a deep , hazy amber hue , giving rise to a humongous light tan head that fills half the vessel .  medium-bodied , maybe just a little bit thin .

s : very feint smell , chocolate note , but a bit of roasty malt as well .  this beer looks wonderful . a beautiful mahogany red , cloudy and rich topped with two and a half fingers of rich foam . the beer leaves textbook rings down the glass as you drink it ( rather quickly ) .  mouthfeel : hoppy and rough , but a bit fuzzy .
smell is small , hints of fruit .  pours jet black with thick mocha head .  mouthfeel : pretty thick and a little syrupy . i 'd actually like a little more carbonation .

s - pretty good aroma . chocolate and coffee are both strong but not overpowering .  bottle in 16oz.sierra nevada glass leaves a beautiful 3/4 inch head . a-tremendous color , nice floaties , great lacing on the glass .  small bubbles , slightly thin .

the aroma is pleasant but muted , with a nondescript sweet and somewhat tart character .  poured from 12oz bottle into trusty milwaukee brewers pint glass a- deep lushous brown with nice 1/2 '' head that sticks around a while to keep me company s- some faint malts , all in all not much going on in the smell department t- a lot of different but very faint flavors . it looks amazing and feels great but the taste is kind of lame and i detect little to no smell .  i think if the mouthfeel was better it would have made a world of difference imo .

on cask at glouster arms in oxon . the aroma was subdued but featured some malt notes , rasin and a bit of esters on warming .  pours dark amber-brown with moderate clarity and a nice and thick light tan head .  cons : the low carbonation level does hurt many factors of the beer , but it is such an exquisitely brewed offering , it 's only a minor issue .

extremely malty bready nose for a beer this hopped-up . very clean hit .  drank from a gouden carolus goblet a : black as darkest night -- - i held it up to a light , and nothing passed through . if dark beers scare you , do n't go here ... otherwise though , it is a thing a beauty .  somewhat smooth feel , moderate-medium body for amber , but still feels a little thin .

s - modest hints of wet wheat and grains with some hops and a bit of citrus . no much here . t - nice .  22 oz bomber pours copper to orange with a 4 fingers+ offwhite head with effervesence . great lacing & head retention s : fruit & oak-like notes taste : apricot & oakey notes up front .  m : somewhat thick , bread-y . but smooth .

the smell was n't nothing spectacular -- very malty and that 's about it . i could n't smell the fruit at all . it was just a hint of cherry , nothing overbearing , and very delicious .  a : yellow , straw hues , slightly hazy , enormous whipped meringue head , long lasting retention , nice lacing .  m - i did n't think the mouthfeel enhanced this brew . too softly carbonated ; not flat , just a bit wimpy .

the smell is a bit skunky , and not at all what i expected .  it has a great thick fluffy dark mocha colored head perched upon a jet black body . the head was still present a good 5 minutes after pouring .  the mouthfeel is a little off , too light and thin .

s : citrius hops , not the strongest aroma . t : bitter finish .  very big head on this one . very big and fluffy ... looks like powdery hills of golden snow .  m - a bit high on carbonation and thin in body .

smell was alcohol and burnt malt .  poured into a goblet carefully to leave behind the yeast sediment . nice thin creamy head , that leaves great lacing all down the glass .  the mouthfeel is thiner but still good .

very faint smell . medium body , medium carbonation . easy to drink for such a dark and strong ale .  the pour was very good and this is easily one of the best looking beers i have ever seen with its excelent head , color and champagne like bubbles .  mouthfeel is slightly thin for the style or maybe just thin for how much is going on there ... .like you are expecting more of a stout mouthfeel .

a touch of hops and sweet malts in the nose , but there is an odd , vegetal aroma in there that is pretty offensive .  pours a slightly hazy amber body with a good inch or so of off-white head that persists and leaves great lacing .  the only knock here is that it was a little thin . m = is it possible to be creamy and watery at the same time ?
but overall still a nice dipa and one you could drink a couple of .  a unique looking beer .  under carbonated and somewhat thin bodied , there is a coffee flavored finish that is truly amazing .

the smell is amazing . like i stated above , i 'm not big into coffee , but even this is appealing , and impressive to pull off . this porter does nothing but give off an intense and clean cafe au lait aroma , straight to the point . it 's greatest attribute is the aroma however , that is really phenomenal .  poured out of its short and stubby white painted 11.2oz bottle into a tulip glass . body is dark brown with a monsterous head with great retention that produced lacing throughout the duration of the drink .  trying to think of a sweet red wine , not one i can place , but its defintely tannic , bitter and sweet ... the taste is super interesting , not say its good , but interesting . chocolate wine comes to mine , light feel though . what i do know is that 8 months is too long as it totally changes the beer into something new losing almost all stout character .
smells piney and malted .  the beer pours out a very dark brown that is almost opaque expect for the edges .  body is very thin for a dipa , medium carbonation .

smells alright nothing spectacular just a sort of generic beer smell .  excellent retention . something you could stick your finger in and feel the foams welcoming grasp .  m : mouthfeel was alright , moderately carbonated and a medium body . nothing too special .

s - roasted malts faint grassy hop and dark fruit smell . t - nice balance .  a - dark , almost black with a beautiful one and a half finger head that is very creamy , love the cascade effect .  m - very thin body , decent mouthfeel , but not great for the style .

s- wheat , slightly hoppy , somewhat faint . d- i find this beer to be extremely drinkable .  classic pride look - inviting transparent brown body with a reasonably large head , albeit casked up suds . leaves superb lace on the glass . awesome .  blue moon gran cru is a great choice for all blue moon fans . tastes similar to blue moon , but with a much bolder taste . its a shame its a limited edition brew , and it was quite pricey as well , but somehting worthy to pick up once to try . appearance : it was the golden color of blue moon , but appered to be unfiltered , but there was much more sediment then most unfiltered beers smell : not a bad smell , but nothing speical either taste : great taste , similar to blue moon , but much stronger , what is there not to love about that

s : herbaceous and slightly spicy , with some suggestion of lime citrus and fresh berry fruit . overall intensity of the smell is weak , giving an impression of vacancy . t : begins off-dry , with pithy grapefruit peel and crackery pilsner malt .  got this one in trade , thanks eric ... a : perfect look . thick 1 and 1/2 inch off-white head that slowly fades leaving nice lacing around the glass .  m - it 's a bit thin for the style .

purchased a growler of this for $ 6 on a wednesday . a- growler makes nice popping sound when opened which is real nice . s- very sweet and malty , but not so much hoppy . the hops presence began to show as i was drinking . m- well carbonated but drying on the finish .  pours a golden orange with lots of suspended floaties . it has a huge spongy white head that retains well and laces the glass .  m - nothing special . just a regular lager thing .

appearance : straw color , effervenscence , good head , awesome lacing smell : this is blasphemy but it smelled sorta like mgd .  very still with incredible lacing s - dry roasted malts , sugar and bread , a touch of spice t - earthy roasted malts , dry corn , very malty with a mild hop finish m - nitro tap gives a creamy smoothness that makes it super sessionable o - really great !  m : a bit light in the mouth , but it kind of coats your mouth as well .

s - unfortunately it does not smell like hefeweizen , or at least not like the ones i like . there 's an off-putting sweat and sulfur aroma mingling with phenolic yeast , and some standard hefe flavors well in the background . t - taste is thankfully better , without as much of the off flavors . d - one of revolution 's rare misses . with so many superior offerings at revolution , i ca n't really recommend this one at all .  ) pitch black colour , moderate brown head . the appearance is top notch , a very fine and lasting brown head .  feels quite creamy at first , almost in a draft-stout kind of way , which struck me as odd . would rather it be crisper and a bit more carbonated , though .

aroma was appropriate for the style - hoppy , not much malt .  a perfect pour into an oversized wine glass with rich deep amber body a tightly formed thick white head , i could not find any reason to not give a perfect score.tropical fruity hops in the nose with a little boozy and caramel sweetness , overripe mango and pineapple on the palate with again some sweetish booze , the malt base is quite dry underneath the hops and sweet booze.a nice dipa , one of the best pours for me ... ever .  i know some ba 's knock this onw because its not rare or amazing but i love it . if i am in a bar that i do n't think has a lot to choose from sam adams is the first word out of my mouth . its not too expensive and tastes good for what you pay .

at first i was turned off by this beer because of its bitter aftertaste but after about half the 22 oz . beer the bitterness was less noticeable . i think if i was eating something sweet with this beer it would have been more palatable and i definitely enjoyed the sweet sent of apples and the abv of 7.7 % over all this beer was drinkable but not something i personally would get again right away  pours a light , burnt orange , very clear . the beautiful amber-orange gives it an amazing radiant quality , looks delicious and refreshing . also great for the beach , on a deck or patio watching the sun set to match the color of this gorgeous beer , especially since it will go great with chips and salsa .  m - decent body with a bit more carbonation than i 'd like from this style .

smell : not too much on the nose , i get a little toffee .  bottle poured into a tulip glass . brilliant clarity . thick white crop of foam with good retention and moderate lacing .  the body was light and there was not enough carbonation .

i absolutely love the smell on this beer , but i also love peaty islay scotches . the smell reminds me of a campfire on a beach , with the peaty campfire smoke , wet wood , and leather aromas . the complex aromas are a little subdued on the palate . tons of different flavors in this beer , but none really stand out in front .  the foam was wheat in color , bubbly , thick , smooth and left a ring around the glass til the end . the color was a dark burgandy/all most black with an orange red highlight in the light .  mouthfeel : medium and semi-smooth . bottom line : this is one of the most bland beers i 've ever had .

truly great drinkability , malty and full-bodied . in what concerns oktoberfest beer , i found this to be a very good one : smooth taste , good looks and very , very drinkable . definetely worth a try .  definitely one of the best looking beers i 've ever seen .  i am starting to view the boston beer co. as a-b or miller taking a stab at the craft market but still wanting to appease the masses rather than being strict to beer styles . a big dissapointment for an apa

smells of burnt toast , nuts and vodka . fortunately the taste is so very much more than the smell .  one beautiful looking barleywine here . it almost glows a nice dark amber color .  slight hint of the hop flower but the malt dominates , sweet , crisp , fresh and pleasing to the senses with the start lightly sweet , satisfactory malt presence , and top light to middling in feel . this is a style where i like the lighter body , as it lets the flavoring hops shine through , quite quaffable , a damn fine session beer me thinks , and i thank royalt for this bottle .

s : very little other than a light , roasted aroma . t : more taste than the nose was led to believe .  a : the finest bubbles i have ever seen in a beer cascade through the auburn colored beer to leave a creamy off-white head with great lacing and retention .  on the thin side , and i dont get much carbonation .

s : here 's my one complaint : light citric hops , light caramel malt . good , but way too light . my nose was wet before i picked up anything .  appearance- beautiful aroma- smells like raw dark chocolate and smokiness taste- bitter chocolate and smoke overpower at first . one of the less complex stouts i 've had .  the taste is a bit light for a dunkel but definitely not as light as a typical hefewiezen . there is a malty undertone that one would expect with this type of beer . honestly , i 'm not sure why this beer is n't getting better reviews , i had a weihenstephan dunkel after it and it stood up quite well .

the smell : hints of caramel and raisins with some citrus , faintly in the background .  pours a hazy golden-orange with a rocky , fluffy 3 finger white head which recedes to a dense blob resembling an orange soda and vanilla ice cream float . solid ring of retention and loads of soapy lace .  lighter mouthfeel than expected . d - full flavor and light mouthfeel .

s - big aroma of cherry juice , some apple juice , molasses , malts , just a great smell . t - a nice balance of molasses , licorice , malts , some cherry .  this looks absolutely beautiful .  crisp taste - not heavy as expected ... hints of smokey , woody flavors - has the appeal of a coffee porter ... mouthfeel is average .

the aroma was very subtle with a floral haze .  this beer looks absolutely perfect .  s - some grassy hops paired with caramel malt t - slight hop bitterness resolving into some serious roasty malt , but then it 's all gone fairly quickly with just a hint of woody bitterness m - quite light with just a hint of carbonation on the back of the tongue ; the slight bitterness endures for a whlie d - quick drinkable , though the excessive roasty malt will probably get in the way ; little to no alcohol warmth nice drink ; did n't expect it to be as dark as it is - listed as an american porter , but it 's almost a supercharged brown ale .

smells just a bit on the rank side . nothing too strong , average ingredients .  based on notes poured into a thistle glass with an effervescent amber with 4 fingers of rocky eggshell colored head . great lacing & head retention s : ever-so slight sweet berry smell t : malty , fruittyness , a hint of warming boozeyness up front .  m full but not as full as i thought that it might be .

a nice , cloudy copper with a light ring of a head very faint floral hops on the nose initial biting hops , with a light malt backbone . good hop belches afterward very drinkable , one of the best squatters had to offer  color is a nutty brown color and very crisp . the head is full and pillowy and stays pillowy and the head and lacing combine and only the middle falls into a thin layer .  feels thin .

the nose on this one is about a mile deep . i get tons of nutmeg , chai tea , cinnamon , vanilla , ginger snap best describes the aroma . i ca n't stop smelling it . most , if not all the aromatic qualities come through on the palate . very creamy and spicey . overall the drinkability is good . great aroma , great flavor and mouthfeel .  appearance : deep , rich , amber red . poured semi-aggressively to yield 2 fingers of nice , tan , creamy head which started to reveal some interesting pitting after a bit . moderate lacing .  mouthfeel : i 'm a bit disappointed by the mouthfeel .

where the smell was certainly nothing to write home about , everything else was quite impressive , especially for this style . the smell was a nice mix of malt and hops , but again , typical . not striking or unusual in anyway .  in a chalice , 50f : very pretty beer ; opal and ruby . head is on the darker end of the brown spectrum , but fades quite quickly . the lacing that remains is quite attractive . bourbon hits pretty hard in the nose , swiftly eclipsed by coffee .  the head vanished quickly , but the carbonation level remained high . the aroma was overwhelming sour cherries ... mouthwatering sweet aroma that shows a huge proportion of cherries used in this brew . definitely on the sugary sweeter cherry beer side .

very good smell . taste- there is a good amount of alcohol and hop bitterness on the palate for this one .  this brew is really gorgeous . nice hint of red , obviously , but the cloudiness swirls around and give the beer a nice look . head is off-white and puffy ; almost too big even with a careful pour .  mouthfeel is fullbodied , and slightly cloying .

s- corn ... a little bit of lemon in there as well . not much . nothing outstanding here d- good , easy drinking beer .  cloudy pale copper color and of hazy reddish tone nearer to the top which is adorned by a rich creamy head of froth about an inch high and colored of dark ivory . head retains its thick body to settle a bit with a lumpy top and lots of lace in big blotches , looks scrumptious !  i think i 'm a bit parial to this beer for 2 reasons . it 's not by any means a `` specialty '' beer , it 's your typical lager and since it 's been around since before any of us were born it 's got a nostalgic feel . excellent beer in my books , average for most .

a fragrent nose brings about thoughts of raspberry chewy candy and a bit of candied malt . enters the mouth with a long creamy tart feel . notes of crisp apples , fresh raspberries , and even end a nice mellow malty sweetness is faint on the end of the palate . i speak a lot of the sour and tartness of this beer but it is not to harsh but well balanced with a touch of woodsy malt sweetness . enjoyable for the style but drinkability says i still need to share the bottle with a friend .  in a snifter at falling rock in denver on 9/12/11 a - exceptional head , white and everlasting . decent lace .  with the name , you would think that this is an amber with english hops , but the banana fruitiness dominates any other flavors , even the hops disappears under the bananas . this is the mystery of rhodell 's , how can mark produce such great dipas , ipas , imperial stouts , barley wines , german style ales and lagers , but when it comes to scottish ales or amber/red ales , they all have this same . stupid , banana phenol , making them undrinkable . i dont get it .

s-smells of heavily roasted coffee , a bit of chocolate , and that 's about it on this one . t-roasted coffee upfront with those nice characteristic porter notes : chocolate and roasted malt with some vanilla notes .  poured into a fluted glass around 6c a : copper and crystal clear , with a nice 2 finger tan head that lasts a long time and laces nicely .  flavor is more of the same with enough body to keep the brew honest . good mix of sweet and bitter and a weaker mouthfeel that allows for more on a warm summer day .

after a hard day 's work the enjoyment of any beer is enhanced , yet this one is upsettingly average for a cooper 's ale . there is noticeably less yeast suspended in the beer than most cooper 's ales , which is one thing i love about the brewery . it is fairly mild , but i just noticed some faint but pleasing roast coffee characteristics .  absolutely pitch black from the middle of the fluted part down , with a gorgeous caramel brown cascading head up to the rim . excellent head retention and nice lacing . held directly in front of a bright bulb , no light passed through the pour .  yack ! i 've had this lots over the years , but this time it got a major problem with butterscotch . aroma smacks me down wth that butterscotch - ugh . but , somewhere in there is some malt and a little chocolate , good malt . flavor is butterscotch - blaaahh . ca n't finish it . draft lines are clean here too . no more , pleeeeze

faint roasted malt aroma , perhaps a hint of sweetness .  bottled april 22 , 2009 poured into a pint glass amber with a very thick white head . very good retention and lacing .  m-medium bodied with slightly more carbonation than i prefer in a porter .

smell : the aroma of the beer is full of hoppy promises . oily pine tar resins combine with a citrus and tropical fruits explosions of grapefruit , lemon , mango and pineapple bombard my nose .  as for the head , it stood about an inch in height when it first came out . the consistency is foamy and the color khaki . amazing retention and cobweb-like rings of lacing .  ) m. ok mouthfeel .

the smell is hard to recognize at first light hops and a bit of a bready taste . the taste followes right along with the smell but i get a bit more of the fruit .  poured into a pint glass , this turned out to be a really beautiful beer . it was an amber color with a thick off-white head that persisted throughout the time it took me to drink the beer . there was an amazing amount of lacing .  mouth feel is thin pretty characteristic of bbc 's beers which makes this a really drinkable session stout with a lot of flavor .

s : pretty muted , a little malt , some faint hop and a little toasty bread . t : big caramel malt , some crisp pine resin hop , and very toasty .  a tall , tan , thick head that lasts .  t & m : for a doppelbock a little thinner bodied than is usually expected .

s : hay , citrus zest with light fruits on the background . crackery malts come through more as it warms .  poured into michelob celebrate glassware ; awesome head retention for several minutes . fantastic lacing .  mouthfeel - this seems a bit watery for my liking , and a bit light too , it does n't take away from the beer too much though luckily , still great . the carbonation seems pretty good , maybe a bit overcarbonated .

s - oh no ! wrong turn - dirty water with a zest of citrus . t - decent hefe flavors - wheat , citrus , coriander , but overall just weak .  appearance : very dark with a thick foam head with good retention . very good lacing .  the taste is ok. it seems a little flat coming out of the can compared to the tap . nice clean finish , no lingering aftertaste . definiteley a session beer if drinking from the tap .

the smoky aroma was evocative of a tantalizing backyard bbq wafting my direction , but that merely hinted at the in-yo-face smokiness of the brew itself .  pours a deep chestnut brown , with a layer of foamy white goodness on top . laces amazingly . the more beers i try from this brewery the more i realize they sure know how to make a beer look good .  mouf & gt ; nice , nothing special drinkability & gt ; sure thing

very grassy on the nose with a touch of pine and skunk . also a bit of a musty smell , and a hint of smoky sweet malts .  enjoyed in a pint glass a : moderate pour yields 1 finger of thick dark brown head that sticks around .  this is an enjoyable , smooth but tasty strong polish lager . the aroma is fresh , toasty sweet bread , hint of lemon , pine , and rather nice . it has a bit of a czech lager taste to it and the alcohol is essentially unnoticeable . the taste is clearly alcholic , but very smoothly so , with nothing rough opr unpleasant . it has a light caramel quality , bread , and nice , warm spiciness , it 's a bit rasiniy , sweet and spicy with a light bitterness coming to the fore in the finish . it does not taste quite as strong as it is .

a-pours a ridiculously clear straw color with a finger of white head . s-as soon as i open the bottle i 'm blasted in the face by really skunky aromas . i 'm also able to discern some light , sweet grain notes .  on a fairly gentle pour into a pint glass this pours with a huge ( 2/3 of the glass ) of white billowy slightly tan head .  in the glass , the elderberry dominates . the taste just off , sour in a nasty way , more like rotten fruit than any sort of pleasant tartness which might be expected from the berries . we gave this a decent try to see if it would get better , but in the end just could n't drink it .

aroma of caramel , sweet malt , some alcohol , mild nuttiness and not much of a hop component . wow , flavor is suprising given a fairly unassuming aroma . a pretty decent to heavy hop bitterness gives way to a fabulous hop backbone and a floral hop flavor , with slight spiciness and maybe a hint of pepper .  this is the first tripel i 've ever seen that does n't pour like a homebrew . it is pleasantly clear with a rock-solid white head . then , after perfectly maintaining its integrity for five minutes , i look away for two second and it completely collapses for form a nice ring-around-the-beer with some craggy lacing left behind .  this beer tastes like candy hearts mixed with medicine . it smells like sour bubblegum or something to that effect . coloring is actually pink.. which is unusual . definitely trying to appeal to females with the label , but even as a female.. i thought it was gross . that 's all i 'm going to say .

muddled malts are rather roasted and somewhat sweet . some coffee , perhaps . not the best . t : this more than makes up for the subpar flavour . the flavour is full of smoked chocolate , soft roasted malts , and nutty notes . d : quite drinkable , warming , filling , and satisfying . i 'm impressed .  poured 45 degrees fahrenheit into a tulip glass . comes a deep amber-red with a thick off white head above a vortex of champagne bubbles . gorgeous .  the largest macro beer in the country is very disappointing . the feel of this beer is somewhat thin but i liked the bock feel that it had .

lots of yeast sediment in the bottle . smell - not much just a little bit of citrusy hops , candy , a bit of alcohol , and a bit of sweet caramel malt . smells of cascade hops . taste - starts out with a sweet caramel malt taste , followed by some grassy and earthy hops , a bit of citrus twang mostly as graperfuit and then the bitterness .  huge rocky off-white head with good retention . carbonation bubbles rise to the top which makes the head more active than a tornado in a trailor park . fine looking beer !  m : the body is light but sugary and grainy with a moderate carbonation .

smells amazing ! t - not too much smoke , bet definitely present .  great lacing that lined the entire glass . cloudy .  mouth feel was pretty average , smooth , not very complex so i expected a little more from it in that department .

smell : it smells a little strong , perhaps hops .  a- pours a brownish color with red hues noted against a white background . the clear nature of the beer allows me to see the carbonation , which is modest looking at best . the head is plentiful and puffy looking , retaining well and leaving behind a thick film of dense foam on the glass .  seems a bit thin , with very soft carbonation .

the smell is faint spices , notably cinnamon .  glassware - imperial pint appearance - dark amber/red in color , which makes sense . nice two finger white head that leaves a lot of really great lacing on the glass .  i feel that it felt a little light on the tongue after it went down .

the smell was a disappointment , as it was hardly even there . i only got a whiff of a little alcohol , malt , and a faint lager-like aroma . the taste , however , makes up for this . a little more complexity would have driven this beer into the upper echelon of great tasting brews , but i thoroughly enjoyed it nonetheless .  2009 vintage a- deep violet , crimson red just a beautiful awe-inspiring color and massive towering head that seems to be independent of the beer and an entity all onto itself .  m - the mouthfeel is a little light , with little carbonation .

definitely a good looking beer , but the last one i tried from hoppy brewing looked good but tasted pretty bad . not a very strong aroma ... what is there is the typical winter warmer spice bouquet . very good , certainly a step up from the weak aroma . i really like the creamy mouthfeel ... just a hint of bitter aftertaste leaves it a mark or so down .  bear republic tribute ale is a very clear , very lively , deep crimson brown berr with a huge , lumpy , beige head .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied with low yet sharp carbonation .
