nose is mild malt with a hint of floral hops and maybe some citrus .  pours out to a very milky pale golden , forming a rocky white head with superior retention and very nice lacing .  the mouthfeel is a bit astringent .

while this beer was pretty much a by-the-books saison , it does n't seem to make much sense to not even give this beer some kind of hops characteristic or impart some small signature that we have come to know and love lagunitas for . basically , this bomber is an orthodox , nice saison , that hits all of the right flavors on the nose but is disappointing overall -- mild , thin , bland in color and not complex .  appearance- pours a crystal clear brownish red , almost cognac , with four fingers of beautifully structured soapy bubbles . the head peaks well above the rim of my glass , and compacts to a creamy , hefeweizen-like consistency . outstanding lacing leaves sheets behind . excellent .  the body is okay for a stout , but is more like a porter .

s : slight peach aromas that may be enhanced by the hops . on-off scent , i ca n't really explain , just different . t : the pecan flavor combined with the peaches jumps at you immediately , not in a good way .  pours a very nice amber , just the slightest bit of haze . nice thick , dense , head . excellent lacings .  mouthfeel - foam is scarce and small bubbles and light caramel that fades quickly . slightly thin .

from tap into a pitcher , then into a frosty 16 ounce mug at brick house pizza in west richland , wa . s- dark malts . t- nice rollercoaster in the mouth : started only slightly sweet , built to a robust dark malts , maybe a hint of charring , then dissolved with a touch of hop bitters . finished nice and clean with the alcohol completely concealed .  appearance : rich frothy head , close to 3 , hangs around with very sticky lacing .  mouth is fairly prickly and somewhat detracts from the tasting . i wish there was a little less carbonation and foam here .

found this ipa in hillsboro oregon in the fred meyer two days before thanksgiving bought the whole 12 pack cause the parents in from out of town were paying , so why not . this beer was good , a good session ipa not too bitter more like a pale ale , good color and taste , although not hoppy enough for me .  the beer arrived at the table black with a tan head .  m : light bodied and well carbonated .

smell is suprisingly light . some malts and a citris hop profile , but not in big quantities .  pours a very dark brown , black in the glass , with a nice tan head that maintains down the glass . excellent rings of lacing .  this is a bad beer . not only that , but its a very overpriced bad beer . it smells like grain , aluminum , and malt liquor , and tastes about the same . there 's a tea-flavor going on in there a bit as well . head was pitiful even though it came from a nitro can . a waste of money . please save your tastebuds and dont buy this garbage for 7.50 a 4-pack .

not a big nose on it , but the taste is quite good . i get an almost nutty , roasted , and woodiness to it too .  pours a clear amber , nice thick white head forms , as it drops leaves some pretty epic lacing , settles to a nice layer , great retention . looks great , smells good , but the alcohol takes too much of it .  this beer was purchased at cyclone liquors , in ames , iowa . the beer was very dark in color and tasted very well . i drank the beer warm and i think it was a good beer . i would try this beer again if it was presented to me . it had a very nice sweet taste for a german dunkel , which i am not a huge fan of .

aromas include coffee , some cocoa , and some berries . it 's not highly intense , leaving very little of a mark . overall , this is a highly drinkable , highly refined porter .  look : dark brown with a good solid 1 inch head with great retention and some spotty lacing smell : smoked pork comes to mind .  mouthfeel starts lite , then fullbodied . alcohol and carbonation are a little over-pronounced .

smells slightly sweet , grassy and floral notes , some fruit maybe ... pleasant enough , but nothing spectacular . nice . this is probably not what a hardcore hophead expects in an ipa .  a - amazing grey color s - yeast , very slight citrus , wheat t - plain in a good way , kinda thick and sweet bready coriander turns to a dry slightly bitter finish .  mouthfeel : the carbonation seems oddly low , but the body is medium light which gives the beer a little bit of oomph that it needs .

the brew is a clear amber , looking a lot like a munich oktoberfest . aroma is mild , with little indication of the beer 's hoppy palate . wisconsin amber has a lot of the drinking characteristics of a pilsner jazzed up with some medium-roasted malts .  very poor and lazy design with 3ded fonts . extraordinary head towering above the glass , great retention , surface memory , and frothy lacing .  md-light body and sharp moderate carbonation . foamed pretty good going down the drain .
the smell is weak but nice and beery .  beautiful looking beer .  mouthfeel is a bit of a problem for me . the carbonation level is also a factor , making it hard to enjoy in gulps .

very nice and clean aroma , even with the `` funk '' .  pours copper in color , red hues and gets lighter the more you drink ... how surprising . a massive off-white head , tight bubbles of carbonation and superb staying power .  the mouthfeel was the only thing that detracted from the beer in my opinion , as i found it to be a little to watery for my personal preference .

s-not much going on in the nose . mostly some caramel and malt , with a faint hoppiness . t-very similar to the nose with some caramel and perfect balance between hops and malt . d-for me this is extremely drinkable .  reviewed 11/16/2008 ( tap @ the stables , st. louis , mo ) : very cool presentation in a kasteel glass with a castle on the stem of the goblet-like glass . pours a very dark blood red body , with a lasting frothy pink head .  mouthfeel is medium thin , with a little less carbonation than i would have liked .

strong vanilla notes , sugar , and faint chocolate aroma..southern tier really has a knack for completely nailing the nose on their brews t - do n't know if i could drink any more than the 9oz i was poured . this is incredibly sweet , and extremely rich . a perfect dessert beer .  a great effort from smutty ; this bp pours a saturated opaque espresso brown , leaving a rich dark bronzed brown head . very well bittered and rounded in the mouth with sweet roasted malts , carob and tongue tingling acids .  while the champagne-like extreme dryness may put off some , i think it makes the beer truly unique and tasty as opposed to unblanced .

not that i have anything against pale ales . smell : very lager-like with some pungent hops .  a - brilliant clarity , orange tinged gold , rocky white head , effervescent s - spicy lemon/lemongrass esters , low sweetness , hay , earthy , t - very perfume-like , flowery bitterness , tastes sweeter than it smells , which brings out a fruity character ( apricot and pear ) , peppery , aftertaste is alcohol and spice m - somewhat boozy and astringent , dry finish , high carbonation is very creamy d - pretty good american take on a saison , just some minor miscues this is not as boozy or astringent as the first sample i had of this beer .  mouth feel : a bit thin on the palet , or maybe the aroma and taste make you expect more in the way of mouth feel .

appearance : a very clear , amber , a decent off-white head with moderate head retention.. aroma : nothing to write home about .  stunning ruby red/black beauty with superb head retention .  mouthfeel is a bit of a letdown.. crisp but not as crisp as i had hoped . overall drinkability is good , the taste makes up for what it lacks in mouthfeel .

not too much in the way of the aroma department , kind of dissapointing .  pours with a hefty amount of two finger thick light tan head , and has a clear copper colored body .  i can feel it in my cheeks . it does n't have any off aromas specifically , but it definitely has the acidity for it . undrinkable , i 'm pouring it out .

now , for the bad : the smell is awful , and i mean really , really bad . i drink plenty of malt liquors and this is one of the worst smelling beers i 've ever come across .  a- damn sexy looking in my pilsner glass . it sits atop a slightly hazed , deep red almost apple cider colored body .  the beer must have been very old , but it 's the brewery 's fault for the green bottle . i took one sip and thought of pouring it out , but then realized i could pretend it was really good and get my friend to try it . he promptly ran to the sink to wash his mouth out . yes , it was that bad . unless you 're positive it 's fresh , do n't buy this beer . i have never had a worse experience .

aroma is mainly of brown malts with a slight roastiness and nuts . nothing else to note here . kinda boring really , but right there with the style .  looks really good- reddish amber body , nice pock-marked cream-white head , and active carbonation .  my first impression was the color . the color was an impressive dark brownish ruby . the smell was sweet malt and fruit . the taste had definite apple/apple peel flavors going on .

smell : there is very little coming through to my nose . a hint of fruity smell , somewhat like apples and oranges . coupled with very nice hops .  appearance is very much like celebration . orangish amber color with a very nice head - great retention , lots of lacing .  a : solid black , modest lacing even at the beginning , but once the beer was gone so was the lacing s : malty , chicory , lingers nicely t : dominated by coffee ; bitter stout ; the oak comes through nicely ; not very complex m : casked , so it does n't really buzz in the mouth overall , a really good beer , but not as complex as i was hoping ; still , very worthwhile

the smell is that of a traditional lager with a little roasted malt to it .  i got this beer from the local gas station and thought i should try it because im a big fan of seasonals . the appearance is great just like every other goose island .  perhaps another way to explain the feeling would be a textured shandy . noting the high praise this saison received , i have trouble fathoming such a bad experience .

smell : aroma of herbal hops is very strong and almost totally dominates the malt . not what i expected at all . ) i found the huge hoppy aroma off-putting , but that 's my only major knock .  bottle enjoy before month notched-sep served in a pint glass the beer poured a crystal clear , deep , orangey-amber color . a two-plus finger tall crop of light beige froth topped the liquid . the head had excellent lasting power and it deposited a thick , drippy blanket of lacing along the top half of the glass .  body seems quite thin for an imperial stout .

not much aroma at all to speak of , which is fairly common among the tripel 's , largely due to the clear candy 's which do n't impart much of a smell . great flavor , a creamy , full body full of a chewy malt and some fruit notes , yet clean with the clear candy .  appearance : pours a crystal clear dark orange color with a huge 3 '' + fluffy head that lasts a long time .  mouthfeel - smooth , yet a litle effervescent .

s - all i could really seem to pick up on was the hops . pine and floral tones , but none of the malt that the description had hinted at .  beautiful amber color gives this lager a real boost .  m-lots of carbonation -- almost too much actually . a little more watery than you 'd expect .

s - mostly pine , citrus smell coming from hops . not as strong most ipa 's go .  opaque black chocolate under a tall creamy mocha head .  again , dried dark fruit seems to be the dominating taste , and as it warms , a sweet cherry-like flavor comes in m : at first i found this beer a bit too prickly and highly carbonated for my liking ; i purposely agitated the beer by swirling and enjoyed it a bit more when carbonation was less severe great beer that i would drink anytime i needed a belgian fix .

s : sweet malts , pine , not that aromatic .  hopback pours a beautiful cloudy dark copper with an ample beige head .  the nose is caramely and very malty . a little too carbinated for a traditional barleywine but lines ones gut like the best of the bunch ! being a sucker for barleywines i have to give this beer high remarks .

not much of an aroma on this but picked up some slight floral hints and a bit of caramel .  beautiful , clear dark copper color . excellent clarity here . a moderate cap of light whipped cream , tiny bubbles mostly , sits at the top . this is as pretty as an ipa can be .  a bit watery on the body .

s : fresh cut grass scent is present up front which is followed by a grainy malt sweetness . rather simple scent , but i was n't expecting anything complex . pretty average straightforward .  750ml corked and caged bottle poured into my snifter pours an opaque color with a very huge four inch mocha colored head . tons of tiny bubbles can be seen on the side of the head and on top leaving to show a decent amount of carbonation .  a bit more body would 've made this an excellent brew .

a : reddish amber color , clear , no head retention or lacing s : although you get the belgian yeast banana and spicy notes , in the background you can notice the subtle blueberry aroma of real blueberries , not some extract .  pours into my new belgium globe with very dark brown body that looks almost black in the glass . thick creamy tan head tops the beer and looks stable enough to stick around for the duration .  just the right amount of hops . even though you can taste the fruits and spice , you can also taste the high alc % . drinkability : very drinkable , but if you more than one in a session , watch out : ) overall : a better than average tripel .

s - smelled like a quality stout.though i really could n't smell any coffee like odors . t - sweet toffee & coffee with some bitterness .  served in a pilsner glass a : pours a deep mahogany color that looks thick . pours with very thick white head and leaves considerable lacing s : very sweet smelling brew possibly of cherries .  not amazing but for everyday you ca n't beat it . its good year round and drinking a bunch of them . it is n't expensive either . amber coloration , ok head and lacing , some hops but mostly malt . not overly heavy but not watery . i know the beer snobs disparage it but it does n't have to be sophisticated to be enjoyed .

smell a singular whiff of grain is all to be had on the nose of this one .  12 oz bottle poured into an '08 osa pint appearance- pours a deep brown with a large dense tan head , sticks around forever . incredible head retention and lacing .  there is a very little carbonation factor in this beer .

s : malty , bready , yeasty and a bit hoppy . t : caramel sweet malt with toffee flavors , great malt/hop balance .  thought this beer had a really nice color . an excellent color . i 'm thinking mahogony , but i 'm not sure exactly what color that ... but i 'm thinking like a deep deep wood varnish color ... really nice .  the body is light but somewhat creamy .

the aromas are a bit bland , mainly dominated by wheat with a hint of citrus .  a - only a sliver of red around the edge . tall very tight light brown head leaving considerable lacing .  4.5 m - lacks body . a bit thin but spritzy carbonation .

leaves some real nice lacing on the way down . i smell the hops , but nothing too disctinct .  this one is jet black with an enormous off white / light tan head . this head is quite frothy and laces incredibly .  mouthfeel is average , with enough body to carry the flavors , but is approaching watery at times .

s : smells of lightly toasted sweet malts , bready with a faint note of hops . t : bready/biscuity malts balanced very well by a clean , slightly citrusy hop profile .  new holland mad hatter ipa 12 oz bottle recent bottling , tumbled down the rabbit hole 10/06 medium pour in a tulip glass . poured a hazy copper orange with a frothy mostly lasting white head with excellent lacing .  m. feel is not bad , light crisp well carbonated .

smell mildly sweet with a slight hop skunkness .  a gorgeous midnight pitch-black , with luscious creamy , light-tan head , almost a finger thick . impressive sticky lacing .  mouthfeel is a little too weak for my tastes , and is the only fault i can find with this brew .

this poured a typical pilsener pale yellow with a decent head that quickly subsided , smell is a tad skunky but not terrible . this one makes up for that really quickly in the flavor department , bitter in the initial flavor , finishing with a beautiful aromatic barley malt finish .  pours a very hazy orange-amber with a massive , pillowy , long-lasting head and great lacing .  well , so ... if it 's a barleywine or imperial or whatever , well ... then it 's probably thin on the mouth , eh ?

surprisingly the aroma is relatively uneventful with some roasted malt and dark fruit .  bomber picked up from the brewery , opened after some months aging into goblet : a : quite nice hazy light-golden orange color with a substantial , creamy , lasting head .  mouthfeel was a bit thin , but the taste was clean and minty on the tongue .

smell : very sweet aroma with a caramel note to it but really very weak in the nose . very impressive flavor for a beer with such a weak aroma . mouthfeel : smooth , clean on the palate with a nice roastiness that lasts on the palate even after the beer is gone . aside from the weak smell i was very impressed with this beer .  nice white , foamy head with great retention .  actually thought it might be bad but when i drank it there was plenty of carbonation . smell : a toasted malty smell with an almost cardboard smell . taste : very strong toasted smell but more of a bitterness then a sweetness . note : no date on the bottle but wondering if this beer had gone bad . will try another attempt at it but not really looking forward to it .

smells of some heavy brown malts , some toast , a bit of spiciness underlined with a hint of booze . overall , a fantastic and robust offering from a favorite producer . puts countless other pas to shame and raises the bar in an excellent way .  wow , what a good looking beer . dark dark , dark body and small light brown head ontop .  m - pretty watery and thin .

the aroma is sweet grain and yeast . it 's not a strong smelling beer by any stretch . i really had to get my nose in there to pick up any aroma . the flavor is delicious .  i poured this one from a 12oz brown bottle into a tulip pint glass . a= this stout poured black as night with zero light penetration . with a very aggressive pour , the dark tan head rose a full 2 '' and took a long time to settle to a thin cap .  thanks walter a-a nice rich amber , good head , some lacing that turned into a small bubble ring s-a slight bready smell , some citrus ( makes me think of citra hop ) slight sweetness and then tart t- close to the same as the smell , there is a slight tangyness in the middle of the drink , it 's a good thing m- it 's moderately lively not as much bite and tingle i was expecting , a clean wet finish o/d- overall i really like this , it 's not the craziest ipa but it 's more than just decent , drinkability , i can see myself finishing this growler , this is a tasty beer and one i really like

s- some roasted coffee malts , a little peat ?  a : poured perfectly dark brown with an abundant creamy light brown head . great retention and fantastic lacing .  decent palate , a little thin like the others in the series , but fairly smooth .

s : mainly a malty scent . some light floral honey , but smell is almost non-existent , the only disappointing thing about the beer .  from notes , reviewed 09/09/10 a - fluffy , snow white head with large bubbles . formed a perfect plateau in the middle which remained . dark , lemon yellow beer .  very good . sort of on the thin side , but still ok. a good drinker .

s - muted floral notes , a certain meaty quality , and some of the malt is coming out in the nose - hints of nut and bread .  bright transparent golden hue with a two inch frothy white head . lots of bubbles and good lacing . perfect appearance .  nothing to write home about when it comes to mouthfeel . kind of a club-soda feel to the beer , tingly . though there seems to be a strange `` romanian roulette '' effect where every sixth beer is kinda soapy .

s : toasted cereal grains , earthy and a bit nutty . very light sweetness with some light caramel and toffee notes . d : pretty drinkable and tasty . hits the spot if you 're looking for something malty but not toasty or heavy .  this looked wonderful ! ! !  the wood tannins come across and make this beer texturally difficult . it 's rough and gritty for a mouthfeel .

very little aroma , has a slight grassy smell i thought it was a drinkable beer that has a much different taste than it american counterparts .  a : beautiful clear rich copper color with creamy tan head . m : smooth o : a very aesthetically pleasing beer . really beautiful to look at and smell .  taste is weak but odd at the same time with a mild rice-sweetness . this is the kind of beer you can share with your friends because most do n't appreciate the imports anyway . i drank plenty of this is my younger days ... when you look up headache in the dictionary it reads `` drink 12 budweisers and take a nap .

smell is fairly muted with a noticeable amount of citrusy hops . the hops in the smell are much more present in the taste . a light body and pleasant flavor make this very drinkable . all around a very well executed ipa .  a : pale straw , great carbonation , crystal clear , and a lovely full head .  this is almost as good a stout as they come . i like guinness extra stout better because it has more bitterness . but this stout is smooth and easy to drink with a nice bitterness . if you are looking for a stout to bring to a party this is a good one because it is not too bitter . almost everyone i have served this to has liked it .

nice straw gold , big rolicking white head . nothing special . grainy at first , gives way pretty quickly to caramel . finish could use some work , it just sort of ... ends . needs some hopping to bulk up the backend . very drinkable , nice for a hot summer day .  a - pours a dark , cloudy copper with an amazing two finger light brown head . the head on this beer was huge and crated with never ending retention and thick , gooey lacing .  ) my only qualm was the the body seemed a little thin .

the smell was nice . tobacco , chocolate , caramel , molasses , dried plums , brown sugar , and a hint of soy sauce .  beautiful looking beer .  mf- raw resinous and sticky , becoming oily , medium carbonation , slightly astringent , dry and grainy in the finish d- well rounded ipa , but not the best around .

smell : not much , some yeast , some fruit taste : nice cherry flavour , not overly sweet by anymeans . mouthfeel : starts creamy and thick but finishes crisp with the carbonation coming in on the finish dinkability : quite good , i could certainly have more than one .  pours nearly pitch black with a big frothy , creamy mocha colored head . looks similar to a ris . great lace , great retention .  taste : sweet malt , raisins , a lot of sweet nutty flavors like pecans , sour/tart dark cherry flavor , ending with a nutty malt characters mouthfeel : really light body , low carbonation , pretty basic .

roasted barley and nuttiness are present , but not overwhelming . the nuttiness is reminiscent of some yeast esters found in other styles of beer , though i ca n't say that is the source . very little hop aroma . taste .  this brew pours into the glass with a black body topped by a thick creamy , light brown head with a good amount of lacing left behind .  finishes with a sweet malt taste m- medium bodied with decent carbonation , not as full for an octoberfest as i 'd like but still good d- very drinkable and easy to use to introduce others to a seasonal beer

i couldnt detect much aroma , but the flavor was a tasty mix of vanilla with a hint of malty chocolate .  a - wow , the gentlest of pours brings forth a beautiful ( slightly clouded due to my misjudgment ) light orange brew with the most ridiculous pillowy head i have ever seen , four fingers to start , sticks around for what seems like forever , and leaves great lacing s - pear and apple , along with a little cut grass , lemon zest , lots of yeast , clove and pepper t - smooth maltiness , slightly tart , with a lot of green apple , a little fresh hay , some yeasty goodness .  the taste is awesome m : medium bodied , perhaps a bit too heavy , with decent carbonation , not the best , but is good enough for an apa .

the nose comprises chocolate syrup , roasted malts , dark chocolate powder , molasses , and a touch of vanilla bean . the taste holds notes of darkly-roasted malts , very bitter dark chocolate ( the kind you 'd bake with , rather than eat straight-up ) , vinyl , anise , rubbing alcohol , charcoal , and molasses .  i was first impressed with the color - almost black ! big , creamy , frothy head .  m : not as creamy as the better oatmeal stouts out there . still above average for a dark beer , but expected more from the style .

a - perfectly clear , fresh honey golden color . s - wow . piney citrus . loads of hop aroma . with the nose , i expected a haymaker of hop bitterness , but it was actually fairly subtle to me . m - medium-bodied , nice feel .  makes an excellent appearances , pours a cloudy rich amber with a large foamy tan head with good retention and lots of sticking .  magic hat usually disappoints me , not that their brews are n't good , it 's that some of them just are n't tasty- till now . magic hats roxy rolles is right up there with ithaca 's cascazilla and troegs hopback amber . a definite seasonal must have for me . great ! ! !

light aroma of malt and some hops , nothing earth-shattering . hurry , get some at the brewery before it 's all gone !  the beer looks great ! s : i get some notes of honey , grass , caramel , and light seasonal summer fruit .  it also takes a hit because while it looks thick , it feels a bit thinner than it should be .

s - lacking a bit in this department . roasted malt is about all is decernable .  it 's black as the devil , not a hint of light going through this , and a thick brown head which lingers for awhile .  in my opinion , flying dog brewery has created a great seasonal , smooth-tasting beer with very little bite or after taste . i would definitely recommend it to any self-respecting beer drinker who might be having an end-of-summer party this or any october .

not much smell what was there was slight maltiness . great kolsch flavor , really nice for the style .  jet black in color with a huge , coffee colored head on top . just a clasic looking stout if there ever was one .  m - a little lighter and sparkly than i 'd like at first ... the more it warms and dies down , the better it gets .

the nose is very mild , with just a hint of malt .  pours black , black black , with a big , dark , thick cloud of a head .  taste : mirrors the smell , but the flavors are weaker than their aroma counterparts because of a thin mouthfeel .

on pouring there was a slight fine head that dissapated very quicky . the pour was at about 50 deg f in a large goblet to hopefully release the promised aroma . while there was some faint aroma , i expected some richness and it just was n't special .  pours a jet black wth a huuge , really tight brown head that retains really well , beautiful !  m -- light carbonation . good body with a lightly soft mouthfeel .
very faint hops ... .  pours dark ruby with a gargantuan head .  the feel is a little odd . it does n't seem to be too carbonated , but the bubbles sting like sprite against your lips .

very raisiny and sweet smelling , yeasty , but not all that inspiring , really ... but the taste - where to begin ?  a beautiful site setting in the glass , this blackberry to almost brown elixir of life , the head gargantuan in size , creamy in texture , the color a light chocolate brown , the residual lace a thick clinging sheet .  malty and corny .

i picked up little nose wise . but again i am new at reviewing and i have a difficult time with this aspect unless the smells are very strong .  looks picture perfect . despite my allergies , i can actually smell floral hops .  medium to thick body , light almost too light level of carbonation with a sweet almost sticky mouthfeel .

s - very grape . almost smells like lighter fluid .  pours a bright , clear , light orange color with a nice looking head .  it 's light on body , and not especially interesting - but as fruit beers go , this was excellent .

aroma of burnt toffee - more like a brown ale to me . very tasty , hop flavor mixes well with the roasty , chewy grains . no yeast trub in this bottle .  makes a nice , thick head with staying power . deep , dark brown color with a lighter ( and nicely creamy ) brown head .  the last 2/3 of my beer was a bit thin , but this was quite refresing and very easy to drink .
the first whiff is all peanut butter .  poured into a tulip . billowing head , color to the amber side of golden and nicely hazed , outstanding lacing .  mouthfeel is a little thin , though .

smell - like cherry cough syrup ( i 'm scared ) taste - actually surprisingly ok for a style beer i usually do n't like much .  '' the appearance was awesome . huge head all the way down the glass .  m- thin to medium in body . highly attenuated with a soft carbonation .

smell is very mild , slightly musty and dry . sure sign of belgian yeast .  a - caramel-butterscotch gold with a thick off-white head , very nice looking .  overwhelming carbonation cuts through initial malt goodness , temporarily undermining a tasty complex malt profile .

smell : caramel and mild bitterness are detectable .  ( a great place ) poured a wonderfully rich yellow color . it was cloudy with a half inch of creamy white head . nice lacing with this beer .  mouthfeel is really my only disappointment , as the beer is overall pretty watery . the body feels thin , as the carbonation is there after pouring , but quickly disappears .

s : this beer smells like skunk . i 've heard of skunky beers , but this truly epitomizes the description . as my nose acclimates , it smells a little better , with grass and herbs dominating .  a big fluffy ice cream scoop of a head , eventually smooths out to about a quarter inch . for a lager this is a very good looking beer .  mouthfeel : both the carbonation and body are on the higher end of the light range .

s - first impression is sweet malt and diacetyl .  a - deep dark , opaque black color with a thick head , excellent retention s - gentle coffee-like roasted grain , malty , no hops noticed t - roasted grain characterized by coffee and tobacco flavors ; hop balance but no detectable flavors ; fairly clean for an ale , but faint hints of yeast esters noticed ( but appropriate ) m - medium-to-light body with moderate carbonation d - this is quite an enjoyable milk stout .  tastes like an aged beer , its very dry and cuvee-like . significant hops.its wierd but it does smell like a barleywine . a bit undewhelming mouthfeel.there was some problem with foam in the taps , and maybe if i had this in the wee hours . still good .

had an imperial pint at mac 's taproom , slighshot is a clear pale copper with a small off-white head that leaves moderate lace . smell is very muted , especially when first served a bit to cold , sweet soft cereals and grassy hops .  a absolutely beautiful looking beer .  it goes down smooth .

feeling inside the neck , it is totally smooth so i have no reservation about the safety of the beer , but the carbonation is another thing ... aroma - roasted grain , kind of woody , a touch of coffee beans .  poured into a chalice a- huge huge huge frothy merangue like , sand colored head rises way above the rim of the glass . it has incredible stay with incredible lacing . the beer is a murky and clouded dark brown/umber .  this feels thin for some reason . carbonation is good and proper .

s - nothing particularly special here , but what is most noticible is that there is no overpowering smell of alcohol ; just a bit of hops or some sort of plant material , let 's say it has a slight 'grassiness ' to it . aside from that there is a distinct fruitiness to the aroma which is most enticing , though mostly through its lissome appearance . nothing really jumps out at me for this beer ; though i must say the frutiness stays with me with an added dimension of spice .  poured a hazy golden yellow with a three finger white head that remained throughout the glass and even continued to grow if left to sit for long . insane ! maintained phenomenal lacing throughout the glass . first off , the appearance on this one was ridiculous for the style .  has a very light mouth feel , which makes it a more-then-one beer .

aroma : grassy and a bit metallic , also spritzy . taste : heavy toasted undertones slapped with a veneer of molten dark chocolate .  it looks fantastic . big foamy top , above glowing yellow base .  medium bodied and dry .

this beer is only available on tap in the boston area . its got a great color a deep brick red color ( hence the name ) . its got a nice malty sweetness to it with a mild hop finish . its a great red ale and one of sam adams best beers in recent times .  poured into a pint glass ... appearance-maybe the best head i 've ever since on a hefeweizen . considering many hefeweizens bodys look similar this is getting a 5 . frothy 3 finger head that i 'm enjoying just sit there and watching the bubbles slowly pop .  smell is a cross between musty and estery at first , then just corn . tastes like corn , but considerably worse than a typical macro . it has some off flavors , that i ca n't really identify . bad .

s : had no conception this was a strong ale . i found the smell to be mild with some fairly noticeable hop notes . t : hoppy but not overpowering . d : another reviewer noted a `` double pilsner '' and i think this is dead on . good thing i only had one .  a : pours a beautiful deep mahogany brown . a large beige head forms and sticks around . lots of lace is left behind .  like cheap malt liquor infused with citrus and nail polish remover .

12 oz . the nose is rather subdued , without much going on other than some faint piney/herbaceous hop notes and a little whiff of biscuit . wonderfully drinkable and overall an excellent apa .  great divide brewing rumble oak aged ipa : as you pour this beer in a glass you will notice a burnished copper color , a luxurious off-white head that laces and lasts to the end , and a subtle but complex aroma .  presentation 11.2 oz ''ceramic '' bottle with blue foil over the cap no date on bottle . pours with a think creamy head that dissipates as quickly as is rose . light brown with a hind of deep red . a smell of caramel and alcohol , taste is more of the same with a slight earthiness to it . finishes cleanly .

a - pours a nice deep inky dark color befitting a proper russian imp stout . s - dry biting hops come through with a dark roasted malt earthiness and just a touch of currant or other earthy dried fruit . not too complex or strong of a smell , though . d - incredibly well-balanced beer whose hops and malt come together in unison .  a : clear , pale golden color with two fingers of fluffy white foam that diminishes to a quarter-sized berg . extensive speckled lacing remains on the glass and tiny bubbles rise in many steady streams through the column .  m : medium body with no carbonation . this is pretty much tap water flat . the mouthfeel is sticky with notable warming .

dales ' has a mildly hoppy bite and leaves little aftertaste - due to storage , i think . all-in-all , an exceptional quaff , though i do prefer oskar blues scotch ale `` old chubb .  pours a deep copper color with a big creamy tan head that lasts forever and leaves a great looking lace all the way down the sides of the glass .  mouthfeel - the one noticeable drawback to this offering is the lack of carbonation . otherwise it felt very good in the mouth .

huh . ok , big punch in the mouth for flavor . lovely beer .  a - pours black with a nice light-tan head . looks great . sticks fairly well to the side , just about as good as a porter could .  its perfectly balanced and not overly done . m very medium , which i find most all stone beers to be and i dont really complain about . the carbonation is present and isnt overly aggressive or submissive .

smell : malt scent with some clear citrus and spice also . taste : malty taste with a slight hop bite .  cloudier than the surface of jupiter . a great looking , one finger head , sticks around for quite a while .  mouthfeel is ok. fairly light body , more than i 'd think it should be at this abv .

is 23 % and you can smell it , almost like a whisky nose . not much on the nose exept alcohol and a little molasses .  app : deep amber clear . very thick fluffy white head w/lace .  m : medium light body with medium high carbonation .

smell : pretty faint compared to what i was expecting . some burnt malt , stout-like aroma . faint hops aroma , crisp ut a littel disapointing . improved as it cooled revealing more burnt malts . wonderfully complex stout .  body was black as night with a tan head .  m - a little thinner than i imagined , though based on the aroma , i might have been expecting a double ipa .

aroma has that sweet peanut aroma as well as lager yeasty aromas .  poured into duvel tulip glass , half beer half very thick foamy head . very solid beer .  light carbonation and light-medium bodied . starts as sour apples becomes more sour like lemon juice , dry finish ; easily the least enjoyed belgian i have had . 750ml bottle - gift from vintage cellars blacksburg , va .

like most macros , its easy going down , and unappealing in scent or appearence .  pours an almost transparent golden/light copper with an amazingly fluffy 3 finger head from an extremely gentle pour .  had a typical pilsner mouthfeel .

the smell is quite good : belgian yeast funk , candi sugar , orange peel and coriander . it has more of the belgian yeast aroma than most wit brews . not as heavy on the orange peel and coriander as most wits ; which i find to be a good thing .  poured from my home tap , this one looks great in the glass , with a deep mahogany-amber color and a thick , creamy , foamy , sand-colored head .  i sent it back thinking it had gone bad , but the bartender tried it and assured me it was ok. m - average for a macro lager .

the head dissapated very quickly smell : initial aroma was a bit skunky .  a 1/2 '' medium brown head takes a very long time to fade to a thick film . lacing is impressive , lots of thick , clingy curtains stick around for a while and eventually fade to thin strings that were still there when i went to wash the glass off .  mouthfeel was somewhat on the thin side , but still quite acceptable .

no head to speak of i do n't really get much of anything off the nose , to be honest . the little i get is a fresh dark chocolate , with almost a rosy underpinning , and a subtle biscuit hint . luckily , the flavour does not follow in the footsteps of the smell . there is flavour there , and i 'm glad for that , because it tastes damn good . this beer belies it 's 7 % abv , and is not overly ... well overly anything really .  head retention was excellent , melting down to a slightly less huge frothy , rocky head . lacing was thick and plentiful ... .a beautiful looking beer .  mouthfeel is medium bodied with above carbonation .

the spices really compliment the berry smell . very unique and inviting . the highlight of this beer is the incredible aroma . t - not quite as impressive as the nose leads to believe .  this beer pours a gorgeous clear deep orange amber color with a 3 finger ( on an easy pour ) of offwhite/tannish thick sudsy head . the head retention on this was ridiculous !  the taste is fantastic , but the beer is a little thin and a bit hot ; not a good session beer , but great type of brew to have after a long day .
bitterness is very balanced and in the background . very drinkable lager ! clean tasting and pretty smooth .  a : black it is ! with a thick brown head .  mouthfeel is about average for an ipa .

smell : the alcohol is very evident , a sweet syrupy smell and raisins are the only other aromas i pick out . taste : the flavor profile is dominated by raisins and syrup , with warming alcohol in the finish . overall : one dimensional , and cloyingly sweet .  tasted in mid-may 2009. nearly opaque , black/brown , with reddish brown on the edges under the light . great lacing , forming curtains in the latter half of the glass .  overall , i quite enjoyed this beer . it 's got a fresh and interesting taste that makes it a decent drinking beer . deliciously fruity hops , nice malt sweetness , comes across as quite fresh . noticeable taste of apricots which i quite like makes this distinctive and something i look forward to drinking . disappointing finish however . lots of interesting things happening up front and then nada . nothing really lingers which is a darn shame , 'cause overall this beer is well worth a try . still tasty after each bottle . mmmm .

750ml caged and corked popped the cork with little trouble . most , strong dark ales have a slightly more scarlet color . husky , corn-like , slighty witte-like nose belying the yeasty belgianness of the beer . despite the nose , i would definitely drink this again .  this beer black and entirely opaque with a thick and persistant off-white head with flecks of tan in it - very nice looking beer .  it was n't as smooth as i expected because of a slight chalky feel in the mouth .

clearly a well-executed lager . a - i actually expected more maltiness in the nose . not that i expected an aroma that 'll knock me off my seat , a la your favorite ipa .  this beer pours opaque and colorless .  this feels a bit acidic , but not too much . medium mouthfeel with a dry finish .

scent is hard to get a hold of i ca n't seem to get what i am looking for in this style . i do get nice hops , citrus and sweet malt but it is not as pronounced as i would expect . drinkability is exceptional for this 9 % beer .  poured into a snifter , revealing rich black body and one of the thickest and darkest heads i 've ever seen on an ris , one which bubbles down nicely into a turgid foamy mess of a surface .  light bodied though , almost watery . in a way this is an ipa-light - some similar desirable flavors and aromas , but less bitterness , less alcohol , and lighter bodied .

mild aroma of bready sweet medium malts : crystal , munich , etc . very nice . light carbonation , full mouthfeel , quite chewy . this is a robust , yet refreshing and drinkable beer .  nitro-can encouraged frothy tan head , superb retention , some lace , almost opaque hue .  m : lightly carbed , thin , slightly oily , tannic finish .

tannish head sits heavy at first , fades and laces . rusty malt scent . deep and dark .  the brew pours a slightly darker golden color with a huge , creamy , rocky white head that sticks around for a while .  it is light bodied and enjoyable . it has a light hops aroma and a light bodied feel to it .

my sense of smell is not the greatest so do n't want to bash it on this but the smell is not strong enough for me to really pick out much , just a pleasant grassy aroma . mouthfeel is very good with quite a lot of carbonation [ or so i thought ] followed by quite a solid hops kick and lingerng bitter aftertaste . is actually very hoppy for what is meant to be a english style pale ale , which i have often found quite subdued . this really is a nice enjoyable beer , admitedly it cost about as a imported english pale ale & i do think they have played with the style a little to make it this bitter but very nice indeed .  a : very good looking brew - copper/red clear body with white head .  m : mouthfeel is a bit thin , considering how robust the initial flavor is .

smells solid . a nice malty backbone , a touch of caramel and some slightly toasted wheat .  really beautiful beer , pours a hazy golden color with a huge frothy white head that retains impressively and leaves nice lacing .  mouthfeel is a bit thin and resinous , this is really the only fault i can find .

s : moderate hop aroma slight malt . t : initial sweetness followed by strong hop bitterness .  pours a clear golden color with a thick , fluffy , off-white head .  mouthfeel is the only real negative to this one , medium bodied and a bit thinner than i 'd like .

not much smell , quite light on the hops , but still has a nice floral character .  on-tap at beachwood bbq , on to the beer : the head retention is great on top this coal black beer . great , thick lacing sticks to the glass .  mouthfeel was ok ; about the same as urquell .

you run the risk of getting a skunky smell . skunky smell until you get way down in there . floral hops with lots of cereal aroma .  light-sucking black with a monumental 2.5 finger head of a nice deep tan . great retention and lacing . ca n't ask for a better appearance than this .  nice flavors , with a nice two-row malty sweetness and a huge piney and slight citrusy hop flavor that is very much in front ; good overall , but very unbalanced , even considering the style . goes down fine , but there is quite a bit of hop scratchiness .

decent lacing left behind . s - wow , great aroma here . immediately there is a lot of pineapple and coconut aroma making it clear that this has been barrel aged . lots of stuff going on here .  the color is incredible . i 'm not sure how you give this appearance anything other than a 1 or 5 . excellent retention , settling to a thick film and rings of clumpy lacing .  m -- slightly too watery , does n't really coat the mouth like i would hope but it washes down clean with no bad lingering tastes d -- this is it here , i think this is the beer i would use to introduce someone new to ipa 's .

s- smells of citrus , pine and definitely has a little floral smell as well . t- perfectly balanced .  had great lacing and retention .  from the perfume river in vietnam ( no really , that 's what the label says ) , on to the beer : poured into a mug , it 's a clear yellow color with a soda-like head . this flavors in the beer do n't meld together well for me . there 's more cooked corn , a mild astingency , and a straightforward bitterness that battle each other for supremecy . even at ice cold , it took some work for me to stomach this beer . round off the edges and we might have something more tolerable .

s : aroma is reserved , with hints of dried fruit and spice . t : dried fruit , bananas , cloves , and ginger are well balanced .  very dark , nearly black , dark ruby edges , huge three finger head that falls slowly , becomes rocky , excellent lacing , and a cap that sticks around throughout .  decent carbonation , a little thin on the malt profile for the style .

s : lots of sweet dark fruit , candi sugar , and some sweet lighter fruits as well . t : prunes , figs , candi sugar , cinammon , and a little lurking booziness .  great head retention & lacing s : dark fruit , woody hop nosr==e t : cherry & herbal hops , some raisin & fig notes as well up front , plus a touch of candi sugar .  m-a bit watery for my tastes but the taste makes you forget about it being slightly thin .

the aroma has some piney hops and faint tropical notes , but it 's not too convincing .  called the skellig irish red on the chalkboard , but confirmed with watch city that it is their shillelagh irish red . magnificent , bulbous cream of head that frankly amazes with its ocean of white and a knifes edge cut ; huge stick and lace . dark red hue with a dead quiet calm and plenty of crystal clarity .  m/t : light to medium body , watery and a good amount of carbonation . however with the light body , low bitterness and virtually zero aftertaste , i could session this beer .

aroma is a bit muted .  on tap at iron hill north wales , pa . served in a pint glass ... a - jet black with a 1 finger mocha head brought out to me . the head was unbelievably thick with amazing lacing that coated the entire glass .  mouthfeel medium body for the style with sharp carbonation .

smell : a surprisingly faint aroma , which was somewhat of a turnoff since i love the big malty aroma of doppelbocks .  slightly opaque with a chilled haze , this brew looks damn inviting .  mouthfeel : there is a lot of bitterness .

smells of barley malt , with a hint of dark chocolate .  guinness is one of the worlds greatest beers , hands down . rich , tasty , creamy , heartwarming .  nice carbonation , but this comes off as a little thin . this should be more drinkable considering its thin body , but as this is a stout , the thin body is a bit of a turn off .

nice lacing as well . a seriously good-looking brew . smell : malt right off the bat , with a certain underlying spiciness . the taste is terrific & # 8212 ; for a pale ale . not the best seasonal , per se , but a really tasty ale .  pours a honey colored amber color with a three finger tight bubbled head with lots of wispy lace from start to finish .  the mouth feel is heavy with a decent amount of carbonation .

not a whole lot of aroma with this one but the sweet , milky , creamy taste more than makes up for it . and this thing is sweet ... .just what you would expect from a sweet milk stout .  pours a glorious deep , garnet-tinged amber color , with a thick , creamy , sticky , cream-colored head on top .  mouthfeel : slighty watery good .

aroma is the only thing that falls a bit short here as the hops are in the back somewhere . the aroma does have a touch of burnt caramels which is coming through from the rye . nice job on this one , just missing a little on the aroma end for what i was expecting .  this beer looks fantastic . orange side of golden , clear with a big white , fluffy head .  m-explosive carbonation . tough to gauge the feel over the bubbles . a bit too carbonated for me .

s : yeast hops and some sweetness from the malt . not really that great a nose on this . definitely it 's weak point . t : sweetness from the malt , citrus from the hops , the yeast adds a slight spiciness .  almost one-finger of fluffy dark brown head over an almost perfectly clear orange-brown liquid .  first pull provided a mouthfeel that was a little more smooth than i would have expected , just short of creamy .

great balance . t : upfront a blend of caramel malt and grapefruit .  dark , dark brown body sits below two generous fingers of frothy tan head that lingers until the very end of the glass .  very good light lager . hints of barley and hops , with a smooth slightly dry aftertaste . this brew had a short lived white foamy head and lower than normal carbonation . i would highly recommend this to any light beer drinker .

the aroma is a variety of differnet malts with a very slight spicy scent that i could n't identufy .  pours out like chocolate syrup , fills the glass pitch black with a very dark tan head . billowing foam despite a very cold serving temperature , thick chunks of lace , crazy retention .  it is a little bit sweet on the tongue . i could stand it to be a little bit more dry .

poured into a some big ass glass ... appearance-amber body , very dark pale ale . some skunk , not sure what the date is on this bottle ... taste-tart granny smith apple along with some sweet caramel malts .  drinking it in a pint glass poured from a 12 oz bottle ... huge , thick head . awesome . beer is opaque and black .  beer/brewery - old fezziwig ale/boston beer company ( samuel adams ) city/state- boston , massachusetts style winter warmer abv 5.9 % ibu 27 date 10 dec 2011 serving type 12 oz bottle glassware pub glass appearance mahogany in color with a thin head with a brownish white color aroma- fruity and winter spices , all spice , clove and nutmeg i think taste pumpkin pie without the pumpkin , a lot of clove , also has a bit a of a bitter ( non hop ) after taste mouthfeel very light and bland ob feeling conclusion other than the after taste this is a great christmas beer , not quit a winter warmer as they abv is a little low , but still a good flavor to think of around christmas .

i was n't able to pick up a great deal of aroma , only slight hints of malt .  this bock pours perfectly with a tight forming bright white head that stays around for a good duration .  mouthfeel the beer is slick on the tongue with strong carbonation . the body is a little lacking , medium-light .

strong roasted malt smell , but with some odd background notes .  poured a nice orange/golden color with a very large bubbly head which remained for a long time and left average lacing . an excellent looking beer .  s : candied pineapple , yeast , and hops well balanced t : a typical ipa taste with accents of pineapple ; yeasts and hops , well balanced m/d a bit thin , carbonation too small and too much , abv on the high side and quite noticeable good beer

smell was quite nice though , a great mix of wheaty goodness and raspberries .  its pale golden liquid is filled with lively bubbles cascading to the the bright long lasting white head .  the mouthfeel was medium with a syrupy sweetness on the palate .

poured a nice caramel reddish hue with a light white/grey head with miniscule bubbles around the edge and on the head smells like dough and sweet malt tasted very similar to aroma , sweet malt , doughy yeast and a very faint fruit hop flavor .  a- big , white head with plenty of bubbles on top of a crystal clear yellow/golden colored body .  it must be said that this beer is a bit astringent on the palate and a bit thinner than i would have liked , but it is still rather drinkable .

head drops to a finger weird smells coming out of this one : crisp lemon & raspberry , but also a strange savory flavor , like overly sweet ketchup , which is a turn-off . it 's a shame : the peripheral aspects ( appearance , mouthfeel ) were impressive , but there was something off about the smell & taste which would make me avoid this one in the future .  what a shame ... pours a pretty golden-amber color topped by a huge , thick , creamy white head .  feel left me a bit disappointed , however , as it was thin -- too thin for this big of flavor .

i love the smell of this stuff , there is n't a better smelling stout in the world , even if its from a can .  the pour reveals very fine de dolle bubbles . the beer is a beautiful copper color .  on tap this poured as a golden straw colored ale , clear and bright with less than an inch of head . there is an apparent hoppy aroma that followed with a similarly dominant slight-hoppy taste followed by the expected bitters - very tasty . i stopped with one . not to discount its drink-ability , there are just several others i wish to try .

the nose is nearly all sweet malts , some toffee and notes of banana esters . not too heavy or dark in the nose .  ths one poured a dream , you shoulda seen it , looked like a photo from a beer book . billowy head sticking out of the glass all proud and boastful , very cool .  the only thing i was not pleased with with this beer was the mouthfeel .

crazy lacing & head retention s : leafy hops , not much else t : leafy hops , biscuitty malt & some sulphuric notes , plus a bit of citrus hops up front . finishes fruity , dry , a bit chalky even & with leafy hops mf : medium bodied with low carbonation & nice balance drinks easy for the abv , wished the hops & or malt stuck out a bit more , but a solid effort , this is probably much better on cask , i 'm betting  this beer is beautiful . red/amber color with a thick rocky head that clings to the side of the glass . head disappears fast though .  the beer is a bit too thin for my tastes but is a good sessionable beer .

s - wow . i do n't think i 've ever smelled this beer before ... it reminds me of a locker room - sweaty cabbage gym sock smell t - there is suprisingly little taste .  pours into a nonic the darkest shade of brown , almost black . huge frothy tan head that leaves gobs of lacing around the glass with good head retention .  good carbonation and medium bodied . flavor is spicy , yeasty , hints of sweetness that gets buried by the yeast . lingering yeasty aftertaste .

aroma is mild , to put it mildly . a little caramel , a touch of yeasty bread and a hint of banana ( ?  a - pours a dark , murky brown with ruby highlights .  lively carbonation is a bit excessive , but the body is quite smooth .

s - it has a faint scent consisting only of grain .  stunning appearance . pours a clear reddish brown with a big and tight tan head .  mouthfeel : medium body , a bit chalky , tingly carbonation and a dry finish .

a-golden in color , completely translucent in clarity , about a fingers worth of white head n-not really what i was expecting at all , the nose is more grass and citrus than any funk , some hints of oak and white wine but nothing crazy t-the funk is a little more pronounced , flavor actually reminds me of squatter 's fifth element , there is light green apple , grape , and malt m-light and refreshing with an almost champagne about of carbonation d-not as memorable as the first time i had it , but still a notable american sour , as i noted in the taste , this beer reminds me a lot of squatter 's fifth element , would like to see some age and additional sourness on this  a - true definition of exceptional . great head that retains some of its head throughout the pint . lacing was also exceptional . a very attractive beer .  quite thin in my mouth .

i 'm not up on my tasting formalities , so i 'll forgo the usual format and say this : + extremely malty . not necessarily a bad thing on its own , but in this case it was overwhelmingly , sickly sweet .  a big frothy white head that sticks around forever , and then leaves some pretty sticky lace on the glass . a very pretty beer , love head .  it states `` the deep coffee flavors are created naturally during the brewing process by dark roasted malts . '' then later it notes `` stout brewed with coffee . anyway , i 'll refer to this as a steady drinking stout because of its thinness , otherwise it 's pretty enjoyable . not particulary complex but enjoyable taste of roasted malt with coffee . abv seems pretty low as i had two with no noticable effects .

s : faint scent of roasted malts , chocolate , and coffee . t : a combination of sweet roasted and chocolate malts with hints of coffee .  a -- this one pours with as much head as you want , and probably more . i must have had a little too much force behind mine because there was a fluffy white head up 3/4 of the glass . golden yellow with carbonation bubbles racing quickly to the top . tons of lacing .  thanks jpm30 . clearly sour taste that sweetens as you drink it . vineous and slightly rich , wood only detactable before the taste buds are overpowered.. great after salty fish . a slightly milder alternative to a cantillon , overpowering the mouth but not for the entire day .

this is a phenomenal aroma i ca n't get enough of ! t - sharp rye comes out in the flavor much more so than the aroma lets on . it actually overwhelms most everything else . d - very good take on the saison style that 's completely unique .  black with a solid 1 finger tan head with excellent retention and lacing .  the motuhfeel is moderately carbonated and slightly watery .
aroma - limited nose , a fairly standard pilsener aroma .  deep brown pour with a gigantic , rocky , tan head .  m- the mouth feel is a bit overly carbonated , yet not thin .

faint clean scent the malty base swiftly gives way to a spicy resin that lingers so long you can get lost in its subtle piney suggestions of cinnamon and nutmeg .  brilliant light gold with a solid finger and a half of tight foam . excellent retention .  apricots . hops undetectable above the jaw-clenching , eye-squinching , head-shaking sourness . awful . ugh . otherwise , it defintely seems to be beer , ( if in no way resembling any version of a contemporary pa ) , but with a sour and bitter fruitiness that pervades , annoys , and overwhelms . the originally enticing head cashed in early and diminished to virtual non-existence before i gave up trying to like this one ; very little lacing to wash out of the glass . wo n't drink the other two in the sampler , did n't finish this one , and opened a sn celebration ale to get the taste out of my mouth .

a great summer ale . taste is citrusy . all in all , this is not a complex beer or anything really special .  this beer has probably the best head i 've ever seen on a saison . saison de lente pours a massive 3 finger white head that has almost a pancake batter like consistency . the head retention is fantastic . the lacing is just magical . a thick french lacing accompanies the glass even when then the glass is empty .  m : thin mouthfeel with moderate carbonation .

a sweet malt . earthy hops , i sense not from dry hopping , but more likely late hops additions . i i had it served from a 12 oz bottle a bit too cold , which undoubtedly muted the aromas and flavors , tending them toward the bitter .  a - this is a beautiful looking beer .  start is lightly sweet , the top skeletal in feel , the finish lightly carbonated , hops shy in their spiciness , a bit medicinal , dry aftertaste , quite drinkable but a touch different than my normal american over the top beers , and frankly scarlet i dont give a damn , im ready for a change .

s -- light dms with some spicy hops back , very low aroma all around . a little disappointing . t -- the flavor makes up for the aroma -- big hit of that bready , toasty , malt character so expected in a bavarian oktoberfest .  this is obviously a schwarzbier or brazilian black beer -- not a euro dark lager . anway : nice black color with thick , foamy tan head , fades slow , very nice sticky lace .  it has little to no head on it with a soft pour . this beer has a good balance of spices that is not overpowering . the aftertaste is mellow . this is one of the darker ales that i have drank but all in all i would give it another try . especially on a snowy winter day .

comes a hazy amber with an off white one finger head . smell is nothing but a thin pine and some malty sweetness . the mouth is noticeably robust and round , neither of which was suggested by the smell . pine resin and some dark sugars meld with an excellent amount of carbonation to make this not unique , but definitely pleasurable .  appearance - deep muted red , like the embers of a fire almost . the head is light beige in color , extremely dense and creamy like melted marshmallows on hot chocolate . the lace is a full blanket all the way around the glass .  m - not much fizz , easy drinking if you like it .

s : this smells like heaven . endless raspberries , need i say more . it 's not as good as the legendary new glarus raspberry tart , but this beer is certainly fun and tastes great .  this beer looks amazing in the glass . extremely rich orangish-copper hue .  mouthfeel is a bit gassy .

the aroma is peaty smoky malts , leather and tobacco and maybe some vegetables . sweet toffee comes out as it warms . it 's unusual and odd and i 'm not sure if i like it .  still a bit of haze but not anything like a hefe . the beer looks great in this glass !  there is little ( hardly any ) carbonation here , and the mouthfeel really does n't pack a punch at all .

if you get it in a bottle it 's not as good since they distribute this beer in green bottles and you start to get some skunkey flavors . this is a very grainy pilsner with a slight hop aroma and taste . this beer is very true to style . that said , if you like a hoppy beer then pass on this one .  pour : 750ml bottle to tulip glass . tons of webbing shows how big the head had been , like the water line of a flood . beautiful .  mouthfeel is probably the most disappointing aspect of this otherwise excellent beer ; the carbonation promised by the head largely disappeared , leaving a slick , full bodied beer with very light carbonation . a nice , sharp bite of carbonation would have been welcome in this case , drying out the finish nicely , but that does n't happen here .

the smell was very faint , hints of breads and malts . great taste ; earthy , bready , and lightly hoppy .  a- pretty beautiful . a reddish amber color , just glowing .  m : a little thin in body d : good .

aroma is very soft a little bready malt , and pumpkiny but hard to bring forth . the flavor is nice definately my favorite sam seasonal .  pours a very inky black with a dark brown creamy head . very oily and sudsy , looks great .  m - fairly thin body and medium carbonation . nothing special on the mouthfeel .

s- it smells like molasses , raisons , and dates . smells much sweeter than it tastes .  appearance perfect looking . the frothy , sticky head is everlasting .  m - thought it was a little flat , but not bad .

s : man this beer smells doesnt have much smell to it . it has some chocolate and coffee with a nice amount of malt . t : i really enjoy the taste of this beer . just amazing o : i know on this site this beer doesnt get great reviews , but man it is very tasty to me .  11.2oz bottle poured into a chalice pours a murky , deep brown with a thick , one-finger head that has awesome staying power and leaves rings of lacing down my glass .  carbonation is a little light though .

aroma : very complex . banana , clove , butter , bubblegum , and hints of alcohol .  the beer poured a hazy golden color with a massive white head .  m : not too bad , there was a little bit of body .

s- perhaps it was my surroundings , but the aroma was very subtle . picked up a little roasted caramel mingled with unmistakably belgian sour yeast .  pours out to a clear copper color , forming a modest whipped yellow head with excellent retention and solid sheets of lacing . this is how i like my pale ales to look . beautiful !  my only complaint with this beer is that it is a little thin .

the smell is a little off putting , but once you take the first sip it is very easy to get over the smell .  as the beer was going down in the glass , it left an incredible , thick creamy lacing all over the glass . appearance was pretty cloudy , light copper color .  body is not as full as i would like , but this is one heck of a tasty beer .

taste s not as rich as the aroma , but still excellent . slightly warming alcohol if felt but not tasted .  a - black is right . the head is a medium brown and standing about three-quarter inches tall before slowly fading to bumpy and frothy top .  a soft , almost too light mouthfeel and a little weak carbonation , the only appearent downside of this brew in my opinion .

strongly flavoured nose with herbs and nettles .  poured a deep , uber cloudy orangish color with good carbonation leaving a nice white cap s : loads of faded hops , fruits..apricot and others with booze t : big faded hops powered by fruitiness and booze .  i wish the mouthfeel had a bit more viscosity ... .but i say that about every stout .
no discernable aroma at all - kind of weird .  one of the best looking beers i 've seen , almost black with a creamy head that stays for a good while .  m - heavy , with little carbonation .

the smell was almost completely absent .  pours a pitch black color with a tan colored head that fades slowly , leaving a thin layer of foam and some heavy lacing .  m - at times , a bit of a metallic feel to the beer .

decent lacing of foam s - grains and floral notes t - sweet malts .  beautiful looking beer to be sure , dark , dark brown with a very attractive frothy tan head . just looks so good in the glass .  m - surprisingly , its a bit thin and lacks carbonation .

the smell is pleasant , overall light and grassy , but not that potent .  a : this is a very beautiful looking beer . the head is absolutely amazing , with perfect color and form . the color is a very dark brown or black , depending on how much light is on it .  a little weak in the feel . tons of carbonation couldn'tmake up for the watery texture .

smell- bready with a light banana clove aroma . taste- light malt balanced with wheat/ yeast .  a : gentle pour creates a 3 finger powdery white head with incredible retention . a beautiful beer to behold .  sort of thin . inoffensive , but it really does n't do much for me .

s - has an aroma of apple cider mixed with a heavy dose of cloves and a very mild hint of pumpkin . also some mild banana-like esters . enough said .  a - hazy , orangish yellow body topped by a huge , rocky head with the most spectacular retention i have ever seen .  m : a bit thin d : incredibly drinkable .

2008 vintage , into tulip . the nose is utterly complex with interplay of sour , sweet , fruity and sherry aromas . the sourness takes after balsamic vinegar which is quite intense denoting an aged example , as do the obvious sherry-notes . the malt is quite rich with caramel and slight chocolaty character while fruity esters are reminiscent of raisins , plum and black cherries . a very faint mushroom-like bitterness indicates that brettanomyces has been used to add sourness to this one .  looks beautiful and inviting !  mouthfeel was a bit thick , and it was not quite as carbonated as i would have liked .

aroma , while nice , is on the more subtle side .  bottle into a pils glass pours a clear , deep copper orange with a one and a half inch off-white head which holds up well throughout from lots of carbonation release . it also leaves some nice looking sheets of lacing down the sides of the glass . ca n't ask for a better looking beer .  slightly sour , a bit thin , highly carbonated . quite drinkable .

s- the smell was very subtle . there was some sweet maltiness and some mild floral characteristics noted .  looks really nice with the carbonation streaming up all the sides . great retention with the full finger staying around the whole time . great rings of lacing .  fairly thin and smooth , mild to medium bodied . breckenridge definitely delivers a vanilla porter as i would expect a vanilla flavored porter to be . i suggest toning down the roasted barley and focusing more on bittering hops .

s - fairly dissapointing . for having lots of fuggles and goldings i was expecting a good hop smell . smell improves after drinking and warming also m - a little zippy with the carbonation but still well bodied .  this one gushed out an extremely creamy , frothy off-white head with a suprisingly long and stable retention . the bottom was also very appealing , golden orange-yellow hue that was opaque and reflective .  mouthfeel is not too bad , sharpness coming more from the carbonation than hops .

deep orange color , very hazy with very little head citrusy hops , ca n't believe there 's such an assertive nose for such a little beer [ 4.0 abv ] malt comes through in the taste . the hops are there , but a bit disappointing after the huge aroma . overall , it lacks flavor for the style , with very , very little aftertaste .  $ 3.99 lovelly cloudy orange beer , with a large thick creme coloured head . nice looking beer in my half liter germen mug aroma is of yeast , spices ..phenolic , leather and earth nice stuff .  m- light to medium , smooth but still missing a little depth here . d- this is n't what i was expecting , but the hops hit me huge here .
smell - nuts , caramel , malt , some hops .  very pretty two-finger head .  bittersweet finish . kind of think and syrupy on the palate .

this brew lacks any lingering nose , mouthiness or taste . mild in all categories there .  a very nice brew that started with an absolutely great black color with an outstanding head and lacing .  mouthfeel : pretty heavy for a porter but very drinkable even in the heat .

the smell was yeasty , with hints of spice and a little piney hop . it is a good drinkable beer , the taste and mouthfeel made up for the weak nose .  very dark ruby red colored body with tightly knit khaki colored head .  mouthfeel was a little thin , that 's my only complaint .

the aromas were inviting and very exciting . t : dark and sweet fruits at the beginning of the sip , hints of alcohol in the middle , ending in a pretty strong bitter kick .  amazing looking beer .  ginger is one of my favorite flavors . this beer has a wonderful ginger taste , which is exactly what i would expect from a beer with this name . further , there is a decent bitterness & a slight sweetness as well . i 'm not a huge fan of spiced beers normally , but this one is really nice . recommended .

looks fantastic in this erdinger weizen glass . smell the nose is of yeasty wheat and malt . drinkability this is a very drinkable beer .  appearance - pours a perfect , clear orange/amber color with an inch thick head that dissipates immediately .  mouthfeel - thin , a decent and sturdy body , carbonation is average .

s- nail polish remover with a hint of vinegar and dark fruits .  excellent , excellent , excellent bottle condition , hazy , champagne head pour .  body is medium , and perhaps errs to light every once in a while , which does n't help the flavours as much as it could .

smells very nice , with strong citrus/lemon/fruitiness , and a good dose of floral .  appearance : black as the abyssal depths topped by a hearty dark brown head that 's thick , frothy and slightly rocky . it sticks around for quite some time before settling down to a smallish layer of foam and then finally a ring of bubbles .  mouthfeel is a bit light , to me , for the style , though it seems appropriate for the flavors that this beer brings to the palate .

12oz bottle poured into a stemmed tulip . appearance- to be honest it pours out looking like old coffee . ( i thought maybe something was wrong with the seal on the first bottle , because it looked so flat , but the second bottle didnt fair much better ) smell- typical of a stout . very roasty with a nice hoppiness as well . taste- now , i like a roastiness with my stouts , but this tastes a little like burnt chocolate .  pour produces an impenetrably obsidian ale with better than an inch of fluffy and dense mocha foam that loiters on top and fades gradually , leaving thick lacing .  m - moderate carbonation , medium bodied .

a deep brown color gives the initial stout impression but a light citrusy aroma is present leading one to believe it 's and ipa .  pours a two finger , cream head that slowly fades to a thin layer leaving a good lace . clear deep amber color .  m- it is a thicker , heavy beer , with sweet taste .

smell : very , very faint smell of malt and floral hops . taste : very smooth , creamy , slightly sweet , with good balance and a nice hop finish . fairly hopped for this class .  poured into a 20oz pint glass has a hazy , cloudy straw colored body with a thick , just-off white head that leaves beautiful lacing .  feel is thin bodied overall , but well bodied for the style .

definitely a woodsy component going on , and i 'm thinking rosemary bark or dried thyme . not much funk , really , but the acid backbone is there making for a quite enjoyable drink on its own . phenomenal .  some of shakespeare 's stuff is pretty dark , but shakespeare stout a nihilistic black , with a big head the color of creamy coffee . the little black bubbles peppering the head make it look alluringly like a chocolate chip cookie .  i always look forward like most do the annual stone anniversary brews.poured a rich deep amber with a tight and sticky one finger off white head , big hops in the nose with a mix pine and herbal/leaf , there is a gummy , fruity-like sweet note as well.the mouthfeel is a bit sharp i will say it crashes down the gullett at first , it does begin to smooth out after a few sips but still seems a bit harsh.no holds barred hops hit the palate up front with big pine and big herbalness , a healthy does of sweeter alcohol gives a slight burn along with a bit of dark fruit.very good but seems like it something that should sit for awhile , still another fine one from stone .

a little roasted grain and a whisper of coffee . i 'm a little disappointed . t : i think this is the widest gap i 've encountered between smell and taste scores . the smell was a let down , but everything i was hoping for in the taste is here . m : this had the smooth silky body i expected from an oatmeal stout . the smell score was lacking , but this has it were it counts .  pours a dark black color with a nice tan head with very good lacing and retention .  first sip reveals a much thinner body than i expected and average carbonation .

good . t : watery banana upfront with some bitter sugared malts .  pours a cloudy yellow/gold color , with a huge thick fluffy white head . a good deal of carbonation helped this head hold for what seemed like an eternity .  if you aerate the beer in your mouth , it really releases the co2 . it would do well as a beer to server with medium to strong cheese .

not much nose , but what it lacks in smell , it makes up for in taste . hard to believe this brewery nearly bit the dust .  great retention , and lace as one might expect from a northwest ipa .  got this in an abita variety pack ... would be a great session beer if i had the quantity . in general , the abita 's have a really clean taste , little aftertaste ... is that the spring water that it talks about on the cap ? a good dark ale , malt flavor is tasty . pretty brown color . smell is very pleasing .

appearance - this gave up a beautiful , full white head that was very fluffy . the ale itself was a thin but pretty orangish-yellow . smell - this does n't smell anything like a bpa . the grain is retched and reminds me of a dirty ashtray .  pouring a deep black with ruby tinting around the edges , out of bounds also has a creamy , tan head which gives way to an attractive , spotted lacing .  it 's got a little bit of a piney finish that 's quite refreshing . maybe closer to watery , but not bad . d- very drinkable esb .

the aroma is very weak though .  poured this puppy into a duvel tulip , which helped to bring about an ample 4 finger thick fluffy and off white head . the body is very murky and peach in color . head retention is great , as well as the lacing .  i also find it a little thin .

-- slight smell of caramel , even slighter smell of fruit . i had no expectations whatsoever and will definetally try more of this style .  a : an outstanding looking beer . dark plum color with a pinch of tannish head and amazing coating lacing . stunning .  mouthfeel is a little bit thin .

nice and citrus spicey sweet which balances itself . i 'm not a huge fan of the style , but i found this to be a tasty brew nontheless .  mbc 's big jamoke pours up with a modest carbonation that creates a very creamy beige-khaki brown head that encompasses the very dark brown-mahogany body .  m- smooth , but a tad thin . carbonation is good , as is the thoroughly smooth finish with a tad of warmth .

s - slightly sour and horsey on the nose , somewhat saison-esque , with a brighter malt/hop aroma in the background .  pours with a beautiful amber body topped by a thick lasting head with a good amount of lace left on the glass .  it has a pretty high carbonation .
