color was a nice milk chocolate brown and the smell was pleasant . upon first sip i thought , `` oats , thick , pretty good .  poured from a 12 oz bottle , 2008 version a : pours a clear mahogany brown , with ruby hues , under a big slightly off white head . excellent retention and lace .  a delightful golden color graced by a pale yellow head . i did n't get much lacing , but i believe that was due to a freshly-washed glass ( served at a bar ) . nice hops come through in this one . it is a little bitter and spicy , but also has some good vanilla and tones of malt . not the most fantastic example of its style , but tasty and very drinkable .

on tap at de molen in bodegraven after the waitress walked the tap list board over to us after asking what was on tap . lovely . s - dark fruit malts obvious . bready with dark rye coming to mind . more mild than exprected . weak aroma but flavour is what counts for me , so this was good .  a- pours a deep black color with a huge , fluffy , brown head that leaves tons of lacing as it goes down .  mouth feel is reasonably rich .

simple light pilsner smell .  golden yellow with a full white head that melts to a quarter inch covering of sticky lacing .  this is a seasonal brew , do n't know if it is offered everywhere or if it was given adequate time to chill before serving so i 'll reserve final judgment for later .

somewhat light and delicate but still flavorful . very , very drinkable . hearsay is that the house yeast strain was not used in this beer which , in my opinion , is a good thing .  it poured black as a tuxedo in a dark closet . it came topped with a dense , dark-brown head that had a lot of staying power .  it 's ok. mouthfeel is a little heavy .
smells of smoke and burnt coffee .  pours nicely for a two finger thick tan head , and has a copper colored well filtered body .  feel is a bit coarse , but just a bit .

smells of sweet wheat malts , apples , and a bit of freshly cut grass or hay .  appearance : pours a beautiful hazy dark amber color with a finger of foamy off white head that leaves a little bit of lacing and good retention .  carbonation was fairly low , with thin to medium body .

the nose is doughy soapy water and yeast . spicy hops hit first chased by metallic sweetness with a soft-baked quality .  nice retention and very good lacing . clear amber color makes this an all around great looking brew .  the mouthfeel is a bit thin , spicy , moderately dry , and has a distinct saison flavor in the aftertaste .

the smell an enticing blend of bready malt , soft ripe dark fruits , coriander and pepper . the metallic burn lingered long afterward and was a real detractor .  impressive looking ale..bright clear golden yellow , with a rich , thick , creamy head and literally walls of lacing .  mouthfeel is poor due to the overdone carbonation .

smelled of carmallized apples and alcohol . nothing extraordinary .  looks perfect . mounds of off white maybe pretty much light tan head , and has a clear dark copper colored body .  drink this on tap at city beverage in durham . i like the color and mouthfeel , though a bit thin for a heavy beer aroma is slightly sweet and complex spices taste is toasted barley , spices , and slight caramel with little head . drinks easy for a heavy beer

the scent is a malty mix of grains and corn . very wheaty smell with a very slight hint of hops .  the way the carbonation and creamy foam mixes with the super dark body of the beer is gorgeous . through the glass , it looked like the bubbles were cascading like a waterfall , only upwards . anyway , the body is opaque and the head is super creamy and tan in apprearance . the head stuck around for a long time and left decent lacing .  mouthfeel was medium with a mild lager sweetness accompanied by loads of off flavors , including apples and grapes .

the smell was a little bitter but nothing overly significant .  one of the darkest black beers i have ever seen . the only one that compares off the top of my head is dark lord .  the mouthfeel is a bit watery and cool in texture , it goes down nicely and is a little bit better than water .

aroma is faint or nil . sharply carbonated and very little up front hoppiness . a welcome refreshment from over-oaked beers that have been popular with us craft breweries the past couple years . i would have guessed oak aged english brown as much as german dunkel , though .  look is beautiful . perfect 1/2 inch head when poured carefully into a surly pint glass .  the only thing that could be improved on this beer is the mouthfeel . a bit light for my tastes , but like i said it has incredible drinkability without making you get too full too quick .

smell-a little bit of that euro skunk that everybody loves , a lot of grain in there as well , slight alcohol tendencies , no different than any other euro lager . drinkability-very drinkable euro lager , much less skunk that some of its brethren so it definites trumps them in this respect . overall-if your preference is euro lager , you 'd be hardpressed to find a better one that st. pauli girl , very flavorful and not a lot of skunk while also looking nice and going down smooth . if you like euros , give st. pauli girl a shot , as it is among the better euro lagers in my opinion  ) , puckered 10/06 slow pour in a tulip glass poured murky pale orange with a huge rocky fully lasting white head with good lacing .  mouthfeel is a bit watery not much body to it , but on a hot day like today , i could take plenty of these guys down .

s - slightly sweet and caramelized with a non-specific bitter balance and a bit of minerality . t - lots of mineral flavor , some sweetness , and a sharp grassy bitterness that lingers on the finish .  amazing retention and lacing .  it 's almost too sticky and thick to be pleasureable , kind of like a toned-down bourbon county stout . i 'm not a big fan of the finish , which comes off like sweet wort of a stout ( oily and a bit thin ) . m : very thick , with some relief , but then a lingering silkiness .

lots of lacing that only adds to the beauty . smell - hoppy with a nice malt backbone taste & mouthfeel - let me just say that this one is highly biscuity , and i love it .  a : one of the most gorgeous beer i 've ever seen . head is tan and very very strong .  m : finish stays around for quite a while , almost too long , really coats the mouth .

s : sweet malty caramel upfront followed by earthy citrus banana with hoppy bitterness on the backend . decent .  pours a semi-cloudy , orange/brown color with a thick creamy head , that showcases some great retention and lacing .  thin on mouthfeel medium orangish-amber with a 1 finger offwhite head that leaves a respectable amount of lacing . taste : broad caramel maltiness with a warming alcohol changes over to a restrained english hop bitterness . notes : a nice esb , although the abv is much higher than say , honker 's ale . drinkability ranks fairly high but the alcohol content is above that of a session beer .

smell : i personally do n't smell much with this ... a little bit of chocolate and hazelnut .  pours a pretty decent dark brown , mahogany around the edge , but mostly black . head is beautiful - medium-thick , dense and creamy foam that sinks slowly , bubbling like soap suds .  pretty average mouthfeel overall .

smell : there is some notable hops ( not overwhelming ) and not much else . taste : the taste is quite curious , as i sipped away it at first tasted like a mild ale and about halfway through the bitterness asserted itself like a pale ale .  330 ml bottle , a : pours golden orange with an extremely long lasting rocky white head with nice belgian lace .  carbonation a little higher than i expect in the style but still manages to be exceptionally drinkable .

d - this is pretty good ipa .  i was up in hell 's kitchen for halloween and my buddy took me to this place scruffy duffy 's ( coolest damn sports bar ever , check it out if your ever in ny ) and would n't let me order anything until i tried a guinness on tap . dark and smooth , almost coffee like .  the mouthfeel is where this beer kind of fell apart for me .

light to almost no smell , about like the glue of a licked postage stamp .  pours a huge head with crazy retention that wo n't leave the glass .  i purchased this beer in a mix and match pack at the recommendation of the guy working at the liquor store = error . the look of the beer was clear and it drank smooth , but it was accompanied by the 'sour beer face . ' the taste was a combination of failure and shame ( with a hint of fruit ) all leading to the grand finale of a quick pour into the drain .

what struck me first is the aroma , very rich with a mix of floral tones and sweet caramel . lace forms readily on the inside of the glass and a thin layer of head is always prevalent . the mouthfeel is particularly noteworthy , and every swig leaves a viscous coating of robust barley goodness on the tongue . many have complained about the drinkability , but i find that the 9 % abv is well disguised by the complexity of this well-rounded brew . even if you do n't take to this beer as i have , read up on the intriguing history behind the name of this brew , and perhaps convince some die hard minions of mass-marketed swill to see the merits of expecting more from a beer .  a perfect looking stout .  mouthfeel is medium bodied with low carbonation and somewhat thin , disappointing .

smells kind of like homemade bread .  frothy tan head .  mouth : such a light and watery mouthfeel that it becomes distracting pondering the feel when you should be appreciating the tastes . drink : the nearly too-light mouthfeel is redeemed by the drinkability of this brew .

i was completely expecting to pick up on more coffee , chicory , malty scents however it is completely lacking any distinguishable scent whatsoever .  snow-white head was thick and pillowy , and lingered through the entire drink , and reduced to excellent lacing up and down the glass .  m - smooth going down , a bit thin , finishes dry .

hard pour gets a beautiful head to rise up , just a little more than two fingers worth of off-white frothiness . smells phenomenal . a bouquet of citrus hops , with a little bit of floral and maybe piney for good measure . so nicely balanced , just a little bit of bitter and the rest is flavor . the alcohol would probably catch me a buzz after just a couple , but it certainly weighs in a little lower than some comparable ipas , which is nice .  that little widget in the can sure does the trick : a majestic light tan head formed in my pint glass atop a layer of mesmerizing , cascading bubbles and a dark brown body .  the mouhtfeel was light and lacked body .

s : not a lot going on here . some pear , green apple , very minor tangerine . ethereal young wheat adds a gently malt background .  pours a gorgeous dark caramel in the glass , with a nice thick tan head .  m : starts off creamy , but i 'm pretty quickly struck by how watery this is . the carbonation is decent , but i find this surprisingly thin .

source/serving : 650ml bottle dated 2/19/2010 ( 6 months old ) smell : delicate and complex , but not dynamic . very nice overall .  pours a two finger cream head that fades slowly , leaving a good lace . nice deep amber color .  it is about a medium mouthfeel , with almost no carbonation .

this irish stout surprised me in all regards . the color is pitch black , with only a thin amount of head on top holding in a slight coffee/nutty scent . the taste is of toasted barley and coffee , and is balanced extremely well .  appearance : pours a bit 3+ finger thick tight off-white head with great retention . looks great all the way .  the palate is bland , sweet , and clean . the strongest aspect of this beer is its mouthfeel , it is medium , sturdy carbonation , very basic but appropriate .

aroma is of sour malt with a hint of coffee .  poured into a large wine glass , very dark , giant creamy brown head ( very enticing ) .  m : lighter than it should be and very creamy and smooth , decent carbonation . f : long creamy chocolate vanilla smoothness .

a touch phenolic in the aroma , but not too much so . slightly bready and grainy with an undercurrent of malt sweetness . a faint suggestion of pear . the most impressive thing about the beer was a sparklingly clean finish - actually made my mouth feel clean .  burnt copper color , with haze-of-yeast and a soft , bright white head that stays around forever .  rated as a stout the mouthfeel is a bit thin , the carbonation is a bit high , and the finish is a bit less than one would expect .

the aroma is a bit of wheat and sweetness but not much .  my bottle looks different than the picture ; guess they changed the label . appearance : clear light amber with a big frothy head of light tan .  the body is medium with decent carbonation .

it actually looks pretty good , but the soapy smell is a killer , and the beer itself tastes a lot like a light toasty mrzen ... they must be using those malts .  full black color with a thick , creamy head .  m : a bit thin , i was kind of expecting it to be a bit more viscous .

this beer looks great and smells bad . the distinctive packaging and the average taste add up to a drinkable beer if you choices are limited and you want to look ultra cool .  pours a three fingered cream head that slowly fades to a thin layer , leaving a good lace .  the mouth was a bit oily but not unpleasantly so .

nice grapefruit citrus taste . a nice malty front with the citrus and slight sweetness undertones .  beautiful looking beer : brown with auburn highlights ( no i 'm not a hair stylist ) . a pleasure to look at .  mouthfeel medium full for the style with carbonation that is a bit too strong for my taste .

unfortunately , the smell does n't measure up to the appearance . it 's ok , but nothing spectacular . well , the taste certainly is nice . complex , malty sweet , and again , i taste the cherries . for 8 % , this is extremely smooth and drinkable .  this beer has an amazing champagne look . it has a crystal clear brass body with damn near perfect white head and lace .  picked up a few of these `` oil cans '' at a local liquor mart . this is the only place i 've seen them . i like the regular fosters occasionally , and have fond memories of it from various parties and times in life . after looking at the color , noticed that the can said `` caramel coloring added , '' so nothing real to go by there . i liked this , i guess , but the drinkablility was hampered by a fakey sort of bitterness that did n't hold a candle to the fuller 's and young 's of the world . kind of caught in my throat . i pick up the regular if it 's on special , but for a real bitter , this ai n't it .

s-yeasty , wheaty aromas , slight citrus with minimal phenols .  as black as an overcast night in the woods with no light . thick creamy , milky , tan head .  kind of leaves your mouth feeling very acidic .

the aroma was nice , but nothing special .  batch 9359 packaged 9/17/09 a : pours an opaque black with a tight dark brown head which leaves much lacing on the walls of the glass as it fades to a thin layer .  a little too thick on the tongue , but nice .

ah , moosehead . the smell is typical of lagers packaged in green bottles : a bit grainy and a bit skunked . nothing more to say . it 's nothing that breaks the bank , but it 's better than any us macro , and probably better than all of the canadian ones as well .  pours with a short , brown head with melted caramel edges . really nice lacing .  im stoked i can try a beer from this brewery even tho it is a collaboration but ive got nothing but good things to say about mikkeller and heard good reviews on these other two so looking forward to it , it pours a very light honey hue with decent carbonation that leaves a one finger head with sporadic lacing , the aroma is floral hops , apricot , bananna and a nice belgian yeasty aroma too , it has an average mouthfeel for the style almost syrupy and has tastes of yeasty bread , citrus and of course a pleasant floral hop finish with the alcohol well hidden , this is definately an easy beer to drink and if it didnt cost $ 18 ( aus ) i could drink it all night .

s- huge cherry notes with wheat right behind it . this has that waxy taste to it that is just very unappealing . great smells and mouthfeel to it , but i can not get over that medicinal taste .  great color , substantial head on pour . beautiful appearance .  this has the syrupy goodness of the 90-minute , but with an added syrupiness ... robust and smooth , like a desert sauce , you could pour this over a bowl of vanilla ice cream instead of a caramel sauce , with its own french vanilla creaminess ... the only thing that detracts here is an odd light metallic twinge at the finish that didnt seem to fit . otherwise , this is a beaut of a big beer with a light profile .
it really fits the style .  bottle , a : a dark , black , almost pernicious looking brew , with a beautiful thick tan head .  m- just average .

flower essence , hop oil , a touch of malt balances out the smell nicely . taste and mouthfeel- much of the same that is in the smell is evident in the taste as well .  appearance is beatiful dark dark black with a fluffy , pale yellow head that laces nicely .  m - very carbonated , to the point that it almost stings on the way down .

the aroma is somewhat faint , i pick up some raisins and grains , pretty disappointing for a bsda .  the color is a beautiful ruby red , almost purple in the light .  the mouthfeel has a strange little zing that seems inappropriate for the style .
it smells faintly of roasted malt , and not much else .  simply great to look at .  more carbonation would go a long way .

the smell is quite pleasant , kind of like a forest with a lot of wet leaves on the ground .  wow , this beer really looks like it was poured from a bar tap ... great body . boddingtons is so unique for being a light-looking golden beer that pours like an irish stout ; those widget things work well .  the taste is also fresh but a with bit of watery mouthfeel .

it smells sweet , with pine and citrus coming through .  a classic looking hefe , a orange/golden color with a billowy , white head .  m : medium to light body with medium to low carbonation . would have preferred a bigger body by far .

smell is less then expected for a german hefe , little bit of wheat , a little cloves and yeast , no bannana like i was hoping for .  pours a oil dark black with a big brown head .  m_slightly below medium bodied and very effervescent .

a - pours a clear gold with a small head that lingers throughout s - pineapple is the main nose with some biscuit and some other tropical fruits t - spicier and less tropical fruit than the nose portends . hops dominate with a little bit of malt .  pours a big white head that takes up half a tulip glass , then settles to a half inch of meringue . body is dark yellow with some wit-like cloudiness .  m : very smooth , but seems pretty thin in terms of the body of the beer .

aroma is `` off the chain , '' as the kiddies say nowadays . rather than compete and muddle all these scents meld into a unified aroma of awesome . perfect .  perfect head retention and plenty of lacing left behind in the glass .  i was not a big fan of the mouthfeel of this one . i 'm all for thick imperial stouts , but somehow this one was much more syrupy than i liked , it felt a little to sticky sweet in my mouth .

smell : very faint nose until it gets warm .  plenty of bubbles could be observed rising through the body , in short , it looked great ! the head produced somegood laceing as the beer was consumed .  with all of the flying dog beers this one has the most bitter taste . yet it does remind me of my earlier beer brewing expreriences ! i always enjoyed the yeasty taste and smell of beer . and this one really has that aroma . flying dog is a great brewery that is slowly becoming a well known micro all over the country ! this only means that they will be bought out by a mega brewery or they will change their formulation all together !

s : quite vegetal , has a hint of agave syrup , fairly hoppy , not what you 'd expect .  looks amazing , as have all the jolly pumpkin 's i 've tried . basically looks as good as a beer can .  mouthfeel is off a little bit , maybe undercarbonated .

the nose is slightly floral , but to be honest , i failed to detect much .  a= at fridge temp , this ale poured a dark but clear mahogany brown color with a nice reddish glow . the first pour produced a light tan head that was only 1/4 '' but retained very well . retention was incredible and the stickage on my glass looked like emulsified foam ... beautiful .  m - thinner body , bubbly from both the carbonation the spice .

s : not really a pomegranate smell but a sweet smell is there . wheat is the dominant scent on this one .  ) tasted 10/02 : bronze/bright amber color with good tan lasting head .  mouthfeel is surprisingly tingly and sharp from the tiny carbonation and i suspect a hop i ca n't discern in either the aroma or taste . mouthfeel is unfortunately a little weak and thin for style to my mind .

it 's flavor is very rich w/ a slightly bitter finish . the maltiness is very enjoyable . another fine beer from victory  on-tap at the toronado . dark orangey brown with a nice 1/2 '' head of thick white foam that leaves killer lacing on the glass .  a little thin .

aroma : sweet , grainy wheat accompanied with apple , citrus , and a slight hint of floral hops taste : sharp lemon and apple over a tasty and grainy wheat backbone . drinkability : excellent , as you 'd expect from any wheat beer worth a damn . verdict : saint arnold has created a solid wheat beer , perfect for a summer 's day here in texas .  ) pours a beautiful glowing , hazy , golden color . really gorgeous and appealing appearance .  the mouth feel is medium bodied , smooth yet singular . a light presence of the carbonation followed by some bitterness .

good color - darker than i might have expected s - a little sweet .. i dont find this beer to have a pronounced smell of any kind .  this beer looks perfect . theres not as much smell to this one as others like it .  this is a man 's beer . none of this flowery wine swilling critique lingo . light color , smell and mouth feel , who really cares . outstanding dry & hoppy flavor without sweetness . when bought in the 30 pack , cost is about 50 cents each . the best macro being produced !

s : not much of a smell , some malt and some burnt notes . t : tastes like guinness extra stout up front but finishes with a sweeter chocolate taste .  well there is no way i can fault the look of this ale..its perfect for style darkest of black with a huge frothy light brown head..beeee-u-tiful .  body was very light and thin .
aroma is mellow . nothing super amazing going on here .  pours a dark black color with a large tan head , fades slowly and leaves lots of lacing on the glass .  4.5/5 m : crisp , medium body .

absolutely fantastic aroma , but let down by it 's flavours .  this beer pours a semi-cloudy pale orange color . the head is an impressive two and a half inches in height , and recedes very slowly into thick , chunky lacing .  m - medium body , not a lot of carbonation .
the smell is very weak with only a hint of floral wheat .  pours black with a dark brown creamy head . very nice beer to look at .  a really really long aftertaste in the nose .

the beer smells pretty good , very hoppy like one would expect from this type of beer .  pours a viscous black and creates a textbook appearance for the style .  this beer has a flavor i really like m- pretty thin and bubbly , almost reminds me of a bmc feel o- one of my favorite tasting pale ales .

s - a very light nose , almost imperceptible . the yeast spice does start to come through . some alcohol warmth . t - starts very smooth , grainy and sweet - seems like loads of pilsner malts are present .  a - very nice lacing left by a frothy white head with strong stamina on top of a copper colored and translucent body . i even witnessed the bartender pouring some head away .  a good beer . comes in a .33ml brown bottle , part of a 6 pack sampler from brouwerij van steenberge . a sweet and dark beer , where hops has taken a back seat to the malt profile . not light , but not heavy either . give it a try .

appearance - was excellent , as dark and opaque as any stout , very little head with no visible carbonation . smell - some mild sweetness from the malt with a hint of that coffee taste associated with dark beers .  the beer poured beautifully into the glass : a bronze-brownish coloured pint with a thick off white head . the main thing i noticed throughout the duration of the pint was the excellent retention and lacing that the head left .  mouthfeel is a bit fizzy , and another beer where bottle-conditioning would have a positive impact .

smell seems a little off not sure if bottle experienced heating etc .  a viscous pour and a deep black color , on top a beige head which collapses almost instantly . one of the most beautiful beers i came across .  mouthfeel : typical red stickyness drinkability : i love this beer .

smell is faint , dusty coco , hops and caramel .  light amber beer was topped by a thick head that left some of the thickest lacing i have seen in my career .  ripped some cd 's with itunes and did n't pay much attention to the rest of the beverage until i listened to `` parachute woman '' by the stones and realized my head was already buzzing , hey , is this really 7.0 abv ? even though lent is over , i could subsist on this brew until easter , especially if it is cold and damp outside , but it 's not , it 's warm and sunny , and i have to plant some hostas and spread some weed-n-feed . in theory this beer will go well with my lunch of cold leftover spring rolls ( heresy !

s : smells like corn but i just husked about 20 ears . it 's completely fresh but actually smells a bit stale .  a fairly large ( nearly two finger ) head of light brown foam sits atop . an ominous looking brew .  the body is sufficient to carry the 10 percent alcohol which is impressive by itself . some spicy notes and an effervescent type of feel to it .

minor lacing on the glass s : not impressed with this one at all ! kinda has a malt liquor smell to tell you the truth .  presentation : it was served in a tulip glass from tap at the pizza plant italian pub . appearance : looking into the glass it had a deep reddish brown colored body with a creamy light tan head . the head was long lasting , thick and it left tons of sticky lacing to cling to the sides of the glass in thick rings . ( very impressive ) smell : the aroma hits first with a bit of boozy alcohol .  tastes like , yeah , tart blueberries ( probably artificial blueberries ) . just sweet & weird & sweet ... really tough to finish one . much like a cheap , too-tart wine cooler .

s : the nose generally lacks aroma . some grainy bread notes emerge but the hops offer nary a scent . t : a sip makes up for the lackluster nose , lots of flavor jumps out from the get-go .  looks like a perfect ris : pitch black with barely no brown around the edges , even when held up to a bright light . an incredibly creamy , frothy and sticky dark khaki head forms and sticks around for quite a bit . impeccable .  the mouthfeel is a little thin but the taste lingers and somehow gets better after the beer passes through my esophagus .

the haze really detracted from the appearance for me ... ... but it made up for the look with the smell . i honestly smelled this for a few minutes before tasting . the smell was very citrus like , with lots of malt and hop spice .  a very good porter , poured dark ruby brown color with strong tan head that i impatiently dove into smelling its aroma of chocolate , burnt malt , sweet caramels and hops .  mouthfeel is medium with more carbonation that i expected due to no head showing up .

the aroma is a pretty subtle combination of lemony and herbal notes .  a pint of the black stuff , or the priest , looks as good as ever , enjoyable to watch it settle over a minute or so .  texture is smooth but only slightly fizzy , leaving a slightly sweet fruity finish .

s - nice ! grapefruit aroma with some hints of pine fill my nose . very attractive flowery hops , with some bready biscuity malt hidden along the way . nice co2 .  beautiful amber color . medium just-barely-off-white head that is nice and dense . very lasting lace .  mouthfeel : thin yet flavorful .

restrained aroma of toasted coconut and rich cocoa .  the appearance is amazing . it pours really really dark brown , safe to say black . it leaves a thick lacing around the glass that is very very intimidating .  i 've been waiting to try this one for some time now and it was well worththe wait ! i could smell it 's fruity aroma as soon as i opened the bottle , it has a nice dark cloudy amber color to it that is topped with a nice thick head . it goes down very smooth and just warms up your mouth , and you can really taste the spices in it .

s : light hints of baker 's chocolate , with malts coming in next . not very much more to offer here , overall it 's not very strong . t : rich , malty sweetness , with cocoa powdery chocolate flavoring coming in next .  a- pours a deep oily black with a three finger tall foamy brown head that has incredible retention ( after 5 minutes there 's still a finger worth left ) .  is this someones idea of a joke ? rotten peaches with a kick of dirty feet is not something i prefer in my beer . sour an nasty , she be . i should have know by the pour , cider apple yellow fizzy white head . cripe , im glad i only got 2 bottles of this overpriced ( $ 2.50 a pop ) sour peach soda geez , only 4.5 % . i would have kicked myself in the sack for buying this , but im no longer that agile .

lightest and sweetest helles yet -- perhaps even paler than a us macro . i like jason 's grape skin description . sidenote : bit of a clinical , soapy scent in the glass .  the beer arrived on the table black with a huge brown frothy head that was 2 fingers tall and lasted forever to coat the glass .  slightly under carbonated for my taste but not really a flaw .

the nose was lightly fruity , yeasty , and malty , but not pungeant enough for my preferences .  the white head is huge and pillowy and leaves wonderful fuzzy navel lacing .  the carbon dioxide is rich but not too aggressive .

as my first experience with a lambic , i was not sure what to expect from the beer . of course , i knew the facts : brewed in belgium , fermentation occurs when openly exposed to wild bacterium . my first thoughts were as follows : sweet , tangy , yet lacking in the strength of a full-bodied flavor . luke-warm , i discovered the very lack of flavor i had been missing !  a : pours a light golden with a couple fingers of dense white head that reduced very slowly into a thick frothy head . beautiful rings/sheets of lacing left with every sip .  mf : relatively light body with medium to high carbonation . would like a little more body , but the flavor more than makes up for it .

smelled of sweet malt and tart fruits .  a - in a word , beautiful . a rocky off-white rocky head sits atop a lovely ruby-red body . one of the prettiest beers i 've had the pleasure of drinking .  t/m - dense oak , leather , wet hay and barnyard notes , freshly cut grass maybe some dark fruits like apricot and/or figs ; short-lived citrus hops up front and a cloyingly long , drying finish . almost reminds me of dry vermouth . the mossy barnyard notes developed nicely . d - the drying effect would probably limit me to just one of these , a nicely developed saison for spring and summer .

- smell is almost absent . very light sweet brown sugar , very light malt ... all which traps a huge piney hop bitterness ... that just ca n't really be smelled . - fantastic light sweet malts ... .  the pour is black with a billowing light brown head with some very nice lace .  mouthfeel was the only thing i was n't too keen on- felt a little spritzer-ish .

s - slight malt and wheat but not much else .  pours hazy gold with a massive , fluffy white head . very promising appearance , but way overcarbonated if you 're shooting for anything lambic-esque .  mouthfeel is a little light for a beer this big , but that would likely improve with age . carbonation is a tad too prickly for my personal tastes .

appearance-golden bright yellow color , very white head grows to three fingers settles down at two and stays there . smell-malt appears in the form of dried bread , also light grassiness and the lightest bit of hop flavor , clean of any alcohol . overall-a very successful kolsch , easy to drink . a great first try for this beer style .  batch 77 a- a luminescent , cloudy , orange liquid with a thick and creamy bone-white head that is dense enough to dimple the surface of the liquid .  more watery flavored than i expected from this ... very light mouthfeel .

mild aroma in a black body with an energetic head of light brown fine bubbles . it is a very nice smooth stout that i found myself liking more and more after each taste .  a rich gold hue with white one-finger head , laces astonishingly well . looks like a good beer .  mouthfeel is light and carbonation fades to almost flat .

the smell is good , and in fact is the strongest attribute in my opinion .  poured into an imperial pint , formed a 1 1/2 '' dense beige head above the slightly cloudy orangey amber brew . head falls way slowly , leaving a tall monolith of froth in the center , and thick coating all down the glass walls .  mouthfeel : light/ medium body with excessive carbonation that somewhat hinders the flavor .

the smell is stunning . if i could bottle this and wear it , i would . just incredible . the taste is great , but does not live up tot he smell .  nice downward bubbles on pour ... dark brown to black with a slight ruby edge , a tan creamy nitro head , and lace like wallpaper .  mouthfeel features more carbonation than i 'd like for a big beer like a barleywine .

weak in every sence of the word , the wheat is to light , i can berly taste the blackberrys , i am not enteirly convinced that i am not drinking water , i loved this beer in the past , maby this is a bad batch . i do detect sour at the end , at least their is somthing i can detect . i could down this like water or funnel this beer if i wanted to get trashed in a hury , not a top sheilf beer  almost black with a cream colored head measuring maybe one finger . i love pouring it out of the gan into a pint glass and watching it mix and cascade turning from the color of mud to the color of .  the mouthfeel is decent , but could be a bit more robust to support the flavors .

smell is what you would expect , bannana and clove .  a- pours dark black . one of the prettiest beers i 've seen .  a wonderful beer . one i have had before , and thought it would be great for the new year . it 's dark brown hue and brownish colored head was delightful . the taste of cocoa and hops pleased my nose . the roasted flavors were soothing , but left a little bit of an after taste .

this widely available ale saved me from the tyranny of the irish dry stouts when i toured ireland a few years ago . it smells slightly of grainy malt , and not much else .  appearance - this beer arrived in a tall , branded pilsner style glass and was yellow-orange with a offwhite , two finger head exhibiting good retention and heavy lacing . impressive carbonation showed off the whole time .  medium bodied , highly carbonated .

aroma is tart and a bit earthy .  appearance : a wonderful amber color .  rolling carbonation augments the already full feel making seem more boisterous than perhaps it is . carbonation is too much for me .

the aromas were very muted . i picked up malt , cask , earth , and some very mild hops .  the beer pours beautiful . great head and retention .  m - light bodied , not overly carbonated , clean finish , mild fruity aftertaste fades quickly .

another head scratcher ... .a wheat beer made with oven roasted beets ? a-gorgeous , brilliant red copper with a medium white head that hangs on and leaves nice lace .  apperance - this beer poured from the tap thick and creamy . it was bright golden yellow once the body cleared up from the nitrogen . nice thumb thick head .  mouthfeel is a little too tingly for me with the carbonation .
s : smells like oranges and has a slight malty scent , like sweet smelling syrup . the sent is very light though .  pours the blackest black with no light coming through .  sticky mouthfeel .

s : not much of a nose on this . ethanol , some roasted malts , hops and citrus . t : what the nose lacks is more than made up for by the taste .  beautiful dark color , with good mapping down the sides .  the feel is the only drawback here . it was rather light in body , and thin feeling . carbonation was adequate , but it just lacked that `` near medium '' that i would expect from a dipa .

a : solid black , perhaps a bit of purple ; head dissipates quickly s : grape , barleywine , roasted or carmelized malt t : wow -- powerful start ; it 's very fresh tasting ; coffee is evident , but one must wonder what kind of coffee was used -- overroasted is my guess ; i loved the taste at first , but then it got old quickly -- it 's overly tinny , metallic and the coffee is not refined m : average i bought it as a single , and it 's well worth that investment .  a : beautiful pour from this 440ml nitro can . bright copper with a thick , creamy white head . great lacing left behind .  it was barely palatable : very little carbonation - full of sour , gone-bad notes .

aroma is quite light some dark malt and hop but too light and not nearly as aromatic as the bottle . all the key flavors are certainly present with same complexity as bottle-brown , scotch ale & ipa .  oily , thick , jet black with the one finger reddish tan head expected from a russian imperial stout . head fades quickly with light lacing .  m - this is like any cheaply made micro lager in japan .
malt scent with a feint fruitiness to it .  beautiful in it 's appearance , and a welcoming texture on the tongue .  m- low carbonation and very low mouthfeel .

nose is not what i expected . quite lacking especially in the hop department . but everything else is great . nice spicy and earthy rye notes with mild fruit and a touch of citrus . overall it 's a nice very drinkable beer . lacking in hop notes and characteristics for an ipa , but good . i do recommend this for the nice rye spiciness and earthiness that is really nice .  appearance - black with murky auburn brown edges . nice semi tan head with great retention and lacing . super sticky on the sides , just beautiful .  t : bitter chocolates and cold black coffee .mmmmm m : a bit thin in the mouthfeel , slight warming in the finish which i found dry .

it does n't really have any overpowering aromas . both the hops and malt are pretty subtle . it 's very drinkable , especially for a pale .  beautiful 3 finger head , caramel , frothy and persistent , reddish mahogany nice stream of bubbles , good lacing ; if this did n't look so inviting i would put it on a shelf and leave it there forever !  12 oz bottle poured into weizen glass , only glass i could get at my buddy 's house a : great pale golden color , light head with decent retention , great clarity s : great floral aromas t : not a pale ale that is actually an ipa , not overly bitter and slight maltiness m : good carbonation , could be a little thinner o : great pale ale , not just a copy of other american pale ales .

has an awesome color too it , good all the way around ... not very scented though but that to me is by far the least important qualty of a beer .  a - a very light straw color with great clarity and a large , thick white head . perfect . this looks tame like a corona but has loads of complexity .  m & d - the brew is a tiny bit watery , the doughy character is a tiny bit too small , and so the mouthfeel is n't as full as i 'd expect .
little uninspiring .  pours amberish black . nice pillowy head . retention and lacing are nice apples , chocolate in the nose .  the mouthfeel was a bit unimpressive too light in my opinion .

a very complex and inviting aroma . the taste really follows the nose , with a sweet melange of spices careening across the tongue . it 's very complex , but unfortunately does n't smell quite as good as it tastes .  black with reddish tints if you look hard enough . looks really good . fluffy foam settles to a thick , dense mass .  despite the nearly opaque black color , the flavor of this one is surprisingly light . there are sweet malt notes , a delicious fruitiness and some fairly rich yeasty , estery notes . i keep over-looking this brewery , but every time i try one of their beers im usually pretty impressed . this particular beer is tasty , refined and very drinkable . recommended .

this was hard to decide on , the smell was really intriguing , but taste more mediocre .  11.2 oz bottle poured into duvel tulip a : perfect . billowing tan head barely contained in this glass . settles to leave full layer of fine tan lacing . as you sip the soft foam coats the side of the glass in sheets not patches .  m- the mouthfeel is a little lighter than expected , almost watered down .
faint grain adjunct smell , mostly clean .  pours a beautiful red-brown with ruby glints , off-white head is large and thick .  mouthfeel- medium body with very little carbonation .

s - aroma is mainly bitter chocolate and a hint of brown sugar along with just a hint of hops .  pours with a beautiful long-lasting head and a very nice effervescence ; there is a constant stream of bubbles rising from the bottom of the glass till the last drop .  mouthfeel : a bit thin and watery .

5/5 s : light/medium aroma . hints of dough and hop , but not real strong . t : interesting . very faint on the malt end , but a hint of some dough and rye ( hence rye ale , i suppose ) .  this is the dead-on look for a pilsner ; pale straw color with steady streams of bubbles heading for the surface . the head is huge and sticky and clings to the side of the glass as if it were a life-or-death matter .  chocolaty to dark brown in appearance with a light head . great smell of toffee , roasted barley . taste conjures up images of coffee shops , candy stores , with the roasted barley presence as well as that bitter coffee taste , balanced by sweet toffee notes and a hint of hops . great tasting beer . my first milk stout , and it did n't disappoint .

smell is very strong , very tasty , and actually has a mouthwatering , rich coffee character to it . start is somewhat sweet but very oaky and heady .  pours dark amber with a large honeycomb coloured head and lots of lacing .  m - it drys out in the mouth a little too quickly for me .

s : fusel alcohols mix with creamed corn to create a rather unpleasant bouquet . it 's a good thing that the aroma is rather repressed from the cold serving temperature , because it is the worst aspect of this brew .  served cold , poured into a pint glass , it has a great amber red color with excellent clarity . the creamy head sticks around a good long time but slowly settles leaving a sheet of lacing on the glass .  could use more carbonation .

looked nice and had a nice aroma to it , but i just never got into it .  1-fingered extremely light tan head with very impressive retention , leaves rings of lace all the way down the glass .  mouthfeel : a little thin , medium body , low carbonation , medium flavor . underwhelming mouth .

as soon as i opened the bottle , i was smacked with a heavy hoppy smell , easily reminded me it 's an ipa i 'm dealing with . s : an amazing combination of hops , pine , citrus , maybe some grape . t : interesting , with the token ipa hoppiness being the most notable aspect of it all . d : daunting at first , especially for me , not a huge fan of ipas , but i have to respect this beer . the dynamic flavor-smell combinations are remarkable , and though it 's not my favorite , the never-departing flavor may be the reminder that it is something to be reckoned with .  a - deep amber in color . i think this was the creamiest , most wonderful head that i have seen .  there was a very light mouthfeel , but an extremely dry , crisp finish .

smell was subdued and malty . fresh , grainy . highly drinkable .  pours a very dark and opaque brown , almost black , very thick brown head forms , settles to a big thick ring around the glass , lots of sticky lacing , about as perfect as a stout can look .  mouthfeel is grainy and oily , body is medium to thin , carbonation is sharp .

i like a good pale ale and this one was just right . is paired very well with japanese food .  poured into a pint glass , this radiant beer had a crisp , clear orange body and a thick white head .  feel is also a bit thin and fizzy .

appearance - black with a little off white head smell - theres not too much to the smell , kind of a sweet roasted smell to it taste/ mouthfeel - has a chocolate roasted flavor , is very smooth and a little thick .  appeared orange-golden with a monstrous , and i mean monstrous , frothy head and excellent lace retention . this is a beautiful looking beer .  light body with a very active carbonation .

the smell is a little sweet and citrus-like . the taste is clean with citrus and the normal wheat malt experience .  a- a perfect golden look in the glass . looks great .  m : fairly thick , carbonation seems a tad high .

not much to say about the aroma . you have to work for it , but when you get the whiff , it 's nice . nutty taste .  bomber poured a clear dark reddish brown nearly black with a lasting brown head .  i had this beer at the great waters facility as we stop in often . i try to take notes on the beers i try but sometimes forget . the attack was very smooth and there was a sweet and smooth flavor with faint hops character at the finish . i do n't think i have had any cask beers at great waters that i did n't like .

s - crackery malts , english-style hops , with notes of herbs , grass , earthiness , and a slight vomit note .  beer is a dark , dark color , with just the slightest hints of ruby at the edges and a coffee colored head . beautiful to look at , and almost as nice to drink .  m : average , carb . levels are good .

smells not so much and like ripe guava ( combination of the hoppy cirtus and sweet frutiness ?  poured from a 750ml bottle bottled on november 10 , 2011 into a tulip . a : pitch black with a 1 finger foam head . exactly how a stout should look .  i 'm not getting much in the way of bitterness anywhere here , which combines with a medium thin body to provide very little in the way of a finish .

smell - light and hoppy with a moderate aroma of malt .  appearance : the look of this beer is exceptional . it is a burnt brown color with a huge pillowy head . there is tons of sticky lacing that makes this beer look geourgious .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied to me . could be a little thicker on the tongue .

my first instinct was that the aroma was very faint ; but as i adjusted , the roasted malts smell followed by a yeasty , brown bread and caramel odors .  appearance is near perfect for this style .  thin bodied , and just sufficient carbonation , but i suspect the growler is at fault much more than the beer .

i just about busted a nut getting the # $ # cork off in one piece..ahh make that several pieces that did n't fall back into the bottle ... but after a long and arduos process the cork was successfully removed.. poured a dark brown ... relatively clear..absolutely no head ... mouthfeel is very uncarbonated..i love the nose ... molasses ... .brown sugar ... .dark fruits ( plums , dates , even burgandy cherries ) ..a bit of oak ... just an awesome smelling beer.. the flavors are similar to the nose but much more tame ... .dark fruits ... molasses ... oak ... good taste to this ... my biggest complaint is the loose mothfeel ... very uncabonated which gives it almost a watery texture ... seems almost thin ... overall , the nose is great and the taste is very good but the body leaves something to be desired..definitely worth trying ... i wo n't be buying any more though ... .  the beer is an oil black , with no foreseeable brown hue when held to the light . the head is impressive , huge , sea-foam that stays around for a long , long time .  all of the good notes that a belgian has , with some american notes such as a much higher rate carbonation , more citric fruitiness . the high carbonation almost makes me question whether or not it 's natural , but i doubt stone would rape this brew with added co2 like the macros do .

smell was zesty , definite hints of citrus and wheat .  opaque pitch black , moderate brown head . '' apart from the looks and the aroma : very disappointing .  very basic but very good m= average carbonation and average weight .

aroma of mild citrus . it was hard to smell . had to stick my nose right down over the glass .  appearance : as poured the beer is a nice lightly hazed golden apricot color with a 1 fluffy off white head that leaves rings , legs and small patches of lacing as it recedes .  the mouthfeel is a little lacking in carbonation too .
no aroma .  pours a very nice black color with some ruby hues and a thick white head . i love to watch this beer settle .  mouthfeel is medium bodied . lots of carbonation , almost too much .

a- golden nearly opaque with a small white head s- light wheat and a little citrus . not a whole lot of fragrance going on here t- nice balance between the hops and malt . not sickening , just certainly present d- love it and i drink it quite often !  good head retention thats lasting the entire beer .  had to give it the maximum points for appearance , because even out of an imported bottle , it looks just right . comes in with an alcohol bite that 's almost like an imperial . pertty nice taste , though , and if you had some , i would n't refuse .

the aroma is very nice . taste - the taste is all strawberries as predicted .  essentially , but not quite , black , it has a large tan head , creamy and long-lasting , slowly shrinking to a permanent frothy head with some nice lace .  it is medium-bodied with soft carbonation and seems perhaps more watery than i 'd expect . it leaves the mouth feeling a bit astringent .

small amount of lace around the edges s : roasted coffee and dark chocolate hit the nose first . very sweet smelling , as well as the presence of alcohol t : initially it was more bitter then i expected from the aroma .  a : this thing has a huge head . a perfect billowy light-tan colored head with so much fluff , it might as well be whipped cream . the beer is a darker shade of brown when poured , and nearly black in the glass .  m : a little bit thinner than expected , medium-light bodied with low carbonation , lightly creamy .

sticking my nose into this thing there is a bit of pine , grass , earth tones , but not much else .  poured - beautiful dark color .  m - a little water , but it goes down smoothly d - this is a really good beer .

the smell does nothing for the beer , it is very light , made me not expect much from this beer .  the bottle popped furiously , and poured with a full head and glowing color .  mouthfeel if very alive and crisp at first sip . maybe a bit overpowering on the carbonation .

aroma is malty with breads and burnt sugars . i did n't care for it , but my roommates gf said its good for girls and she really likes it .  got a single of this the other day , and poured it into my mug and the appearance is beautiful . hazy straw color , best looking ive seen in a hefe .  m - a little watery for the style , but not objectionable .

aroma was pleasant . it smelled like a bitter root beer with star anise and ginger .  pours a beautiful clear golden orange with a plentiful fluffy head and excellent sticky lacing .  t - again , bicuit and nut . nice and malty , virtually no hop bite , but tasty none the less . d - i have had this a ton in the past , but i only just got around to getting another one for the purposes of reviewing .

overall i enjoyed it , the smell still does n't please me but the beer in general is quite good .  a : pours a wonderfully bright golden/orange color .  mouthfeel is smooth , crisp and almost watery , with medium carbonation and a medium body .

s : dried apple skins , a little banana and some bubble gum on the nose , although even as the beer warms it does not release much aroma . t : on the palate one finds freshly baked bread , some apple and pear , and a bit of spice . its flavor and aroma profile is on the milder side .  this beer was poured unhurriedly into a flute . lots of swirling carbonation and three solid finger s of thick creamy head .  mouthfeel too prickly and astringent but medium body is appropriate for style .

smell of some sweet malts , that 's about it .  this beer poured a very dark black color with very little light getting through it .  best as it warmed , when the malt flavors of chocolale and toffee become a bit more complex and the mouthfeel seems fuller .

s : the combination of hops and funk is a little weird . nothing about the smell is jumping out and telling me that i want to drink the beer , but it 's not off-putting , really . it 's quite sharp , and big kind of like a double ipa . it 'd be nice to slip in a saison dupont or hennepin between servings .  the body is as dark as night ; it is absolutely impervious to any light .  it 's viciously acidic , but tasty . i like acidic ... i 'll drink straight malt vinegar . this is fizzy alcoholic pomegranate juice with nothing to resemble beer to my palate . i would n't hold `` not tasting like beer '' against a legitimate ale beverage , which i 'm sure this is , except that i like beer , and i do n't like this .

s : dark roasted malts and coffee . kind of disappointing for the style and look .  that 's an outstanding looking brew - steady head , chunky like snowfall on fence posts from the beginning , but it melts down a bit to only ring the glass . like deep brown bricks , with hints of orange around the edges - strong looking beer .  the beer poured hard but the carbonation ended up being low and the mouthfeel medium .

s - roasted grain . bit of coffee , that 's about it .  poured from the bottle into a pint glass a - pours a brilliant off-white three finger head with great retention . leaves gorgeous lacing .  i almost gag every time i take a sip of this . tastes like day-old miller high life with some bread , chocolate , and coffee mixed in . it looks like cola , and at first it smells like oh , say , a bottle of old milwaukee . if only it tasted even half as good as old milwaukee . please , for your own sake , stay away .

laced well . maybe i have a sinus infection or something ( or had the beer too cold ) but i could hardly smell anything . the faint aromas i got were plesant , but i did n't really smell much . again ... what taste ? choice between this and `` lite '' or bud light , this wins , but i prolly wont buy it again unless i really do have no smell due to sinus .  a - pours a gorgeous bright and translucent dark copper color with some nice golden and slight amber hints . very good retention . almost perfect looking beer .  medium carbonation .

the smell is very boring , some mild piney hops and presumably cedar , and definitely did n't impress me as i tilted the glass back for the first time . unfortunately for all other ipas , the standard to me is pliny and it 's pretty damn hard to come close to pte in drinkability .  appearance : very dark brown with a thick , creamy , light tan head with excellent retention and fabulous rings of lacing . the cascade is a thing of beauty !  m - moderate carbonation-almost too much , dry finish , medium bodied due to the carbonation .

s : bouquet is faint , but notes of smoke , bananas , and butter make it through nicely . t : smokey upfront with a hefty dose of walnuts .  11.2 oz , 2007 bottle a : deep brown , not quite black under a nice sized tan head . excellent lace and retention .  mouf & gt ; sudsy .

a - pours an orange copper color with a layer of fine bubbles on the surface s - lots of piney and citurs hops , lemon , orange , just a totally amazing aroma t - grapefruit & orange upfront , sweet malt & a slightly bitter hop finish , a really flavorful hopbomb m/d - medium body with good carbonation , just a really drinkable beer , somehow its 10 % which you really have no way of knowing  lots of bubbles along wall of glass . leaves a huge & healthy white cap with bigger lacing along the outside of the body .  t : wood chips , obviously , tastes like a sauna smells , charcoal , molasses , savory like breakfast sausage , soy sauce , real sharp sweetness that 's broken down by hops lurking in the background and that 's absent at the finish m : medium body , very low carbonation , i 'm surprised this was n't the cask ( it was n't but they did have it ) , dry bitter charcoal finish . the mouthfeel was a big drawback for me , it was very flat , considering this was the draft veraion .

light tan head sits upon this almost purple/amber colored beer . not much in the way of aroma . this concerned me and i was not hopeful .  a- caramel amber beer , nice dark coloration , super huge head with sticky lacing .  very ashy , very charred , and it really lacks some body and sweetness to back up the astringency . feel is very light , a shame , because a thick , chewy , silky body is a necessity in the style .

the smell really impressed me with the strong clove scent like a cooling pie .  tall , nearly white head with good retention and great lacing .  great big head , perfectly tempting aroma , somewhat thin mouthfeel .

the smell is of strong apple juice , sugar , some spice , a bit of yeasty funk , faint straw , and some muddle earthy notes .  this amber ale pours with a clear amber body topped by a thick head with lots of lacing left on the glass .  mouthfeel/overall : the body is very light , and it has pretty high carbonation .

nice looking beer on the pour and nothing offensive in the nose . it is smooth and sweet and has a nice hop middle with a sweet end that manages to dry up , but just . a good basic beer..but not a true pilsner more like a incredibly good canadian molsen..  great streaks of lacing that never disappear .  it was pretty smooth for stout and for for the alcohol content . i tried it with a few other beers .

there is a lot going on here . smells kind of like red wine , also smells like a lambic . i 'm guessing the lambic aroma is really brett . the more i smell it , the more i like the smells .  black with a glorious creamy beige head with great retention and lacing .  m - fairly zesty and zingy carbonation that left me feeling a touch bloated after a third of a glass . medium-light body that also has a bit of grain character .

aroma was pretty limited , either it was me or something , but i could n't detect much .  a toasted head has great retention and lace .  m- a little thin , but not too bad . nicely carbonated , with a slight bitter hoppiness at the tail end .

the color was reddish-amber and the smell was fantastic ! floral , sweet hops - strong and complex . the taste is hops up front and hops on the end - not as complex as the smell .  the pour is beauty in the glass ( a snifter this time ) . a mysterious murky deep orange that still reveals the active carbonation rising up to the dense 3 fingers of sturdy , creamy off-white crown . once it was swirling in my snifter i got strong fresh hop tanginess , herbal esthers , big florals , and a kind of peanut brittle sweetness .  nice aroma of hops but i would hope for a bit more being a hops lover . the celebration ale , from the same company , seems to hit the spot more than this beer but still worthy of a place in the fridge and still better than many micro beer ipa ii . sierra nevada seems to me to be the only mass beer company that brews excellent beer for `` mass beer '' prices .

very pleasant and layered . t - very hoppy at first , but the finish balances that out with a mild and sweet maltiness .  appearance - really dark with a very nice looking mocha/tan head . looks incredible .  mouthfeel - very enjoyable borderline complex character .

lots of pine in a very unique nose with just a touch of citrus and caramel .  on initial pour this is one of the finest looking brews i 've ever laid eyes on .  500ml bottle served in a shaker glass.enjoyed on oct11.melon yellow in color.haze appearance.white close & dense crown.good retention leaving lasting lacing collars.citrics & hints of melon to the nose , some banana hues.sour upfront then a pleasant sweet malty flavor comes , subtle spicy hues too.slightly astringent notes.medium body.medium carbonation.rough but gentle finish.refreshing.well balanced flavors .

smell is heavy of malt , and a bit spicy .  its dark amber color and white head give way to perfect lacing as i drink down this wonderful libation .  the mouthfeel is sort of watery , but it 's alright . this drinks very well .

nose is spicy , vanilla , wintergreen , sweet malt , molasses , and a few other thinks , not bad mind you , certainly different , start is sweet with a sudden rush of bitterness , light grain profile , and top light in feel .  appearance : a dark tan head sits atop a black-brown body . long lasting and nice to look at .  mouthfeel : a bit thin in body but makes up with an even overall texture not much carbonation very wine like with each sip .

not too much aroma , but you can detect a sweet , double ipa smell through the cloudy yellow foam .  a careful pour produces a robust , sandy colored , three-finger head with excellent retention and lacing .  the mouthfeel seems a bit week and flat , but it 's not bad .

there was a faint earth and citrus aroma but nothing really pronounced .  frickin ' a beautiful . deep and black , medium head of nice and tight dark tan bubbles . no effort required to get it and even going vigorously on the pour it seems like there 's not a crazy amount of head . beautiful .  mouthfeel : this is the one downside of this beer ; it 's just a bit thin .

s : light on any nose , what i could smell was a bit malty , but otherwise the entire scent was nearly non-existent . t : fantastic ! powerful , full malt with slight yet perfectly blended hops . i was a bit turned off by the smell , but as soon as i had a swig , i was totally impressed .  a deep amber reddish beer with a mother of pearl head . the head on this brew is large fluffy , lasting and pungent .  m & d = carbonation stings a little more than i would like , has good medium body but mouthcoating , while medium , is a little less than i would have preferred .

smell is still rather clean . light hop backed by a light grain nose .  appearance : cloudy golden yellow with an amazing , big , billowy head that last all the way through the beer , incredible lacing too which sticks all over the glass . the best looking tripel i 've ever seen .  taste was pretty balanced with a bit of malt sweetness . overall i liked this one . this is the first beer i have tried from boulder . based on this one , i 'll have to try some of the others that we can get in ct . the website says that a secret spice is added , but i can not really taste any spice . maybe i 'll figure it out by the time i finish the six . good brew .

however , the nose is pretty muted overall .  the beer pours a bright , clear , pale straw yellow with a full inch of dense head . good lacing - by the time i finished i had delicate remnants of head all the way down the glass . carbonation is very energetic . this is exactly how a pilsner should look .  i was disappointed by this beer . it 's also obvious a lot of quality ingredients went into this brew . it was as if they intended to toast something , left it heating too long and then used it in the beer anyway . so my opinion may not apply to all bottles of this beer ever made . the finish was so bitter/burnt ( and someone else said aspirin-like , and i agree ) that drinking a whole one was difficult , and i found i did not want another when i was done . i do like brown ales , and i 've never tasted one that tasted like this . if the brewer is reading , this will be an abomination to him . the result is quite nice , with the bitterness now toned down to just one note in the chord and the revelation of some of that band-aid-like taste i associate with belgians . i 'm on the second mixed brew now , and i must say i 'm quite enjoying it this way .

smell : gentle hoppy smell .  poured a beautifully clear , clean amber golden color , with a huge 3 finger , frothy , white head . lacing was incredible on this one , totally covered from the top to the bottom of the glass when finished .  flavour is better than expected- a little woody and slightly spicy , with a thick strong maltiness . i 'd like the hearty body on this one , were it not for the turbocharged carbonation .

the aroma is very weak . actually , i ca n't get any aroma , even with a big swirl .  pours smooth and deep , with a nice creamy off-white head . great appearance , large dark oily brown head .  the carbonation is surprisingly strong for the style .

s - delicious blueberry scent which overpowers just about everything else .  a massive , three-inch head rose up to the top of the tulip glass . lacework aplenty . a real beauty .  like the aroma , there was a maple hint somewhere in there but it was incredibly hard to get the taste and keep it , it was very slippery . the cloying sweetness kept me from even finishing the beer and my girlfriend refused the rare chance to finish one of my drinks after trying it herself .

smell : nothing here .  great looking beer .  m : the feel is slightly creamy but on the lighter side of medium bodied . could be a bit thicker here ... d : if you like coffee beers i could see someone drinking good amount of these .

aroma was intensely hoppy yet smooth and balanced . piney and floral hops , citrus and fruity esters came through strong along with a touch of candy-like sweetness . cascade hops and hop oils soon became bitter and biting and left a noticeable film on my tongue . unquestionably , this was the most bitter and unbalanced ipa i have had to date .  2011 batch 1 - 750ml bottle poured into a cbs snifter a : black as night . gorgeous finger-and-a-half dark brown head that leaves a nice full cap throughout consumption .  thin to medium bodied with moderate carbonation .

aromas are faint , a bit of spice and floral smells . but not much on the nose .  a beautiful looking beer with at least a two-finger head that lasts for a while before fading to a nice cap that remains to the end .  dare i say it seems a bit on the thin side . the meatiness in the flavor is not backed up by the body . not bad , but just a little disappointing ... this is a fine stout .

aroma - a pretty grainy first whiff , light roasted malt and a bit of chocolate come out on setup . fades a lot and does well to maintain some faint roasty aroma . taste - sweet , fully roasted malt and milk chocolate malt .  poured a dark mahogany with a big light brown head that left some lacing .  a : pours a dark brown with a two finger head ; burnt orange around the edges of the glass when held to light ; lacing is excellent s : smells of caramel and coffee ; very earthy aroma t : tastes like a bitter coffee initially , but the sweetness of caramel and honey slowly creeps in m : i think its a bit too watery and the carbonation does not seem right d : two in a sitting is nice ; i 'm generally not a porter fan , but i enjoyed this beer

s : extremely rich and fragrant . tons of fudge brownie , boozy spirit barrel , cherry , dark fruit , and solvent alcohol . not too intrusive , but feels a little `` tacked on '' if you get my meaning .  12oz bottle into a tulip glass - from the latest release a : pitch black pour with 2 fingers of fairly dark brown head . beautiful beer .  m : light but slightly creamy body .

i had mixed feelings about the noble pils before it even came out , as i had always enjoyed the white ale that sam adams had previously marketed as its spring seasonal . basically , i feel like the white ale should have remained the spring beer offering , whilst this beer should have become a full time staple of the sam adams line-up . great taste , and easy as hell to drink !  the pour is absolutely beautiful on this one .  the palate is somewhat thin for the style but it 's still smooth .
aroma is malty , but weak . nice but on the weak side.worth a try for sure .  very sticky and lacing all the way down the glass . looks fantastic .  the mouthfeel is just a little light and watery .

nose : mulled apple cider . sweet and fruity .  chocolate head over a pitch black pit , some sweet lacing ... some mild anise and roasted malts tingle the nose , also a hint of acetone in there .  m : okay , mostly wet and satisfyingly quaffable , but with a noticeable alcohol presence in the finish .

nose is delicate like a bouquet of spring flowers , freesia and tea rose .  the head very slowly fades to a 1 cm cap atop this impenetrably black brew , leaving beautiful , copious lacing everywhere . perfection in appearance .  m : the body is medium and so is the carbonation .

the aroma is lacking . it is n't unpleasant , it 's just very weak . although the look and the smell were n't promising , bell 's lager proved to be a quality lager with a good bit of hops .  pours deep brown with a stiff egg custard-colored head that fades slowly .  it 's sort of smokey but in an artificial way . rubber and alcohol . the rubber turned into a slightly smokey malt flavor but still lingered in there . alcohol dominated any sort of flavors coming through . i just did n't enjoy this beer at all . if i ever cross paths again with this beer i 'll re-review it .

aroma is hoppy , with some sweet malt .  appearance : a hard pour gave me about three fingers of sturdy looking off-white foam . good lacing and head retention .  the rye is evident , as is a tangy almost sour note along with the bread . a little over-carbonated ... i found it slightly distracting and that it may have affected my enjoyment of the beer 's complexity . light-bodied and very refreshing . while i have little to no experience with beers of this style , i enjoyed this one and i believe that its a great refresher during the summer months .

the smell is hardly there , but i do get the twist of saaz hops and some nice wheaty bready and certainly grainy malts , a clean overall smell just not very strong .  black as the abyss with a dark sticky head .  m - average mouthfeel . carbonation on par , but a very thin feeling brew .

s ; has a mild roasted malt aroma with a good bit of sweetness mixed in .  pours a hazy amber colour with one of the most impressive head i have ever seen . a frothy rocky mountain large off white head .  the beer feels just a bit thin on the tongue .

the smell is average , its not bad or obtrusive , but there is very little of anything that i could smell , neutral to the most . its fairly simple , but sometimes excellence is in simplicity . very clean finish .  poured into a new belgium snifter a - a beautiful clear dusk sunset color , 2 finger head that lingered and lacing through and through and awesome tiny bubbles for days s - pine , citrus , malt , floral , cotton , sweet , grains and maybe a bit toasty t - very nice bitter sweet , pine , orange , melon , pineapple , very hoppy and yet super bitter sweet malty m - coats the mouth a bit with some super bitter sweet lingering .  drinkability - taste is pretty good , stays consistent throughout , isnt too thin , and has a reasonable abv so overall this would be a good beer to have a few of if you options are limited .

there 's not much of a smell to it . ( very ) faint hints of nutty biscuit and faint hops , but not much else .  beautiful clear deep red-mahogany color with a huge soapy white head . serious staying power and some awesome sheets of lace stick to the glass .  the mouthfeel is much like an american macro lager , but a bit wimpy .

very little aroma . some roasted/molasses type scents .  this was poured from the bottle into a consendonk tulip glass . a - clear light golden straw color with a thick foamy , ice cream-like head that is very well retained s - sweet malt and fruity yeast aroma with a slight hop spiciness t - like aroma , sweet malt up front with fruit-like notes and a very slight amount of hops on the finish m - medium body with high carbonation d - this is a decent , well-made beer .  drank in a chalice from a bottle in brussels at delirium cafe.. this is very good lambic . it smells great very sweet with cherries . the beer has a beautiful red/brown color with a white head , not a lot lacing . it tastes sweet with cherries dominating but has a nice sour kick too .

not much of a nose on this english ipa .  a : a modest pour generated a black body and a massive head of over two fingers . the head was dense and sticky .  the beer seems to thin a bit in the mouthfeel . very clean beer for a triple , slightly thin in the mouthfeel , but that helps give this beer a nice clean dry finish .

smell is mostly of malt and a bit of hops not much there .  330 ml bottle poured into a tulip glass . appearance - the beer pours a hazy golden orange with three fingers of pillowy off-white head .  a very special thanks to zeke at the speakeasy for sharing a bottle of this 1995 treat . it still had carbonation in it which was crazy . the beer was very dry at this point . the spiciness of this beer has been cut down from the aging .

edit & lt ; this is actually a review for `` guinness extra cold , '' ( that 's right - they were actually bragging about how cold a stout was ) which was damn near ubiquitous in otherwise decent pubs throughout the uk when i was there in the summer of 2001 . guinness extra cold is basically the same as what one often gets when having a guinness in an american bar . oddly enough , when i was in england two years ago this was the only kind of guinness i found in the pubs i ventured into .  but wow , this one looks amazing ! a gorgeous burgundy with beautiful creamy froth on top .  this cask had not dropped bright or was a few days past where it should have been , my guess is that they put it out too early or the servers that placed the keg out rolled it out from the back and mixed all of the yeast back into the brew . full of yeast yeast in the aroma and flavour , just down right crappy cask what a disappointment .

i am a big ipa fan and had never heard of this beer , but when i saw it on tap at a local restaurant decided to give it a try . nice traditional amber color , slight citrus nose , decent malt to hop balance , very drinkable , and went great with my pizza .  i thought i did n't like saisons until i tried this one . great head , fine bubbles that stuck to the glass the whole way down .  drinkability : mouthfeel is a little thin , but this is a very solidly crafted stout , up there with the tops in style .

yummy ... pours a heady white-over-bronze trophy , some modest lacing which arches around delightfully un-predictable shapes ... i think i see a war-elephent trumpeting hannibal 's decent from the alps ... smell was somewhat subdued , i did n't have any good glassware handy , i used a big wine glass . smell was suggestive of good things to come , but nothing terribly fancy . this is where the fun really starts .  score : 89 appearance : pours a dark red-brown color with plenty of opaque-ish ruby highlights with three fingers of cream-colored head . excellent lacing , and the head really stick around -- if not apparent by the photo ( proprietary ) .  body is light and a bit watery , not too syruppy at all .

smell is slightly hoppy with a bread-like background . first class beer .  the foam is perfect as is the amber clear color ; perfectly bright .  very simply -- -if this were n't a trader joe 's beer , it would have higher marks -- i 'd bet anything . at least here on the west coast , there are no examples of this style , at any price point , that compare to this beer . heater-allen , the only contender in oregon , way more expensive and neither as good , nor as consistent as this beer . while not in class with the best german hefeweizens , it 's damn close and an absolute steal for the price .

roasted coffee nose .  look : bright golden color , white head of creamy foam with 2 fingers thick , very good lacing , has a sticker that say it was the best beer in the world in 2002 , let see if it 's true ; smell : biscuity malts and fruit essences ; taste : pine and spicy hops , molasses , some biscuity malts , alcohol and sugars at the finish ; mouthfeel : dry and very bitter , bittersweet and spicy finish , the body is creamy and thick ; drinkability : the first time i try the `` tripel '' style , very spicy .  m. actually a bit thin , would have liked a bit more substantial body , but it went down well enough .

750ml bottle ( cork & cage always cool ) purchased at carmel mtn . fruit in the nose , sweet apricot perhaps . slightly musty , too .  pours a thin layer of dark tan head over a crystal clear gorgeous dark amber liquid .  the mouthfeel was its weakest point , i thought .

smell : not much here , smelled like your average porter . weak coffee scents were all i got . taste : like guinness draught with some balls .  i really do n't have anything too negative to say about this beer , it looks great and smells good .  the beer feels light but not watery . there is a little prickle on the tongue at the swallow .

s : sweet and dark ... rich .  pours very dark brown color with a 2.5 finger dense tan head with incredible retention , with some very nice lacing on the glass .  mouthfeel is soft and a little heavy .

aroma - a light roasty grain and smoked peat . pleasant but fragile levels .  pours opaque black with a thick brown head .  m - nothing special just went down really easy ... .it was n't bad tasting ... .i was surprised how quickly i finished it because it went down fast .

s - roasted malt and faint molasses and hot chocolate notes . t - roasted malts , bakers chocolate , coffee and a faint sour note that i ca n't place , but it 's not unpleasant .  poured into an ommegang chalice a reddish/purplish brown color with a solid half-inch of head.. perfect for the style .  the mouthfeel has a little bit more carbonation than i would like a brew of this calibre to have , thus the 3.0 .

s- faint smells of malty prunes . really not much here for the nose .  hazy blond in color with a steady stream of bubbles rising from the bottom of the glass to form a huge , thick , rocky white head that lasts for the entire glass .  high carbonation detracts slightly .

good aroma , lace , but sour and strong carbonation .  a one finger , mocha colored head has supreme retention and some amazing lacing to go along with it . very nice looking .  lowish carbonation and a slightly thin mouthfeel .

smell was deep with plenty of sweet chocolate aromas and bitter grains .  a : what a great looking stout . deep brown color with an extremly silkey 1/2 '' head that slowly disipates into lacing s : roasted malt t : grain sweet ness and roasted malts m & d : mouth feel was medium and dry .  rich , almost like chicken soup broth , and very low carbonation . in the world of bocks , this could be a new favorite of mine .
