smell : not much of a nose on this one , although what there is of it smells like a saison ought to - some clove and spiciness along with a bit of citrus . taste : wow . overall : $ 14 a bomber was a bit steep , but i as i sit here enjoying this beer i am very happy that i splurged on it and i ca n't wait to split the other bottle with my girlfriend . this is great work by the guys at flossmoor , i just wish it had a bit more of a nose . one of the better saisons i have had .  poured out of the bottle into my samuel smith 's pint glass a jet black in color with a nice 2 finger tannish-brown head that settled to about one finger after a few minutes .  mouthfeel lightly carbonated and a tad bigger than light-bodied .

( s ) - very aromatic . very dynamic & layered . again , a good taste that followed suit to the smell . great aroma . lends itself more to a better drinkability score due to a lower abv than alot of strong ales out there ; thicker than most too , but it fits it well . this might benefit from further aging , but its great now .  wow ... what a head !  taste : a bit thin for a porter , almost to the point of being slightly watery .

s : aroma is of roasted malt , coffee and a hint of bitterness . t : taste of roasted malt , coffee , a bit of sweetness and a nice bitterness through to the finish which is quite dry .  left tremendous lacing all throughout . simply the best looking stout period .  feel seems to be about medium in body , but slightly watery , with a lingering semi-bitter dark unsweetened chocolate/coffee bean aftertaste .

aroma is pretty strong dms , light pils malt , with maybe a little spicy hops way in the back . the smell is really bad , but the flavor is ok for what it 's supposed to be .  pours a deep brown with ruby highlights into a tulip . creamy off-white/light khaki head leaves excellent lacing and retention .  m- actually the mouthfeel is n't that bad but it was really hard to focus on that while i was drinking joan rivers perfume .

the aroma is surprisingly weak and consists of a vague smell of roasted coffee .  bottle : poured a golden color ale with a huge pure white foamy head with great retention and lacing .  mouth- thin ? it 's a little thin , it lacks depth , and too much raisin for my taste .

overall : 3.85 appearance : 4.5 | smell : 3 | taste : 4 | mouthfeel : 3.5 | drinkability : 4 740  this beer is absolutely stunning in appearance .  a bit watery at the start , but , it gradually gains weight as it rolls to the back of the palate .

smells delicious . ( t ) bold combination of mild coffee and chocolate , with a sweet , smoky flavor .  a deep , but crystal clear cherry wood red/brown with some creamy tan head . just perfect !  the mouthfeel is light , but hey , its a light beer ! for drinkability , again , one of the beers that could probably never offend me .

has a mashed ripe banana smell with sprucey / piney notes .  a : a straight pour winds up producing an ideal 2 '' of tan foam above a body that looks black , but proves to be the darkest of clear cherry reds when held up to light . strong retention and some truly admirable lacing . beautiful .  it seems to light and over carbonated for a stout .

it 's a very appealing smell . taste : part belgian wit and part apple cider blended together . the smell is really good , but the taste is a bit disappointing in comparison . the good aromas in the smell do n't show up in the taste .  poured a deep dark black with few brownish ruby highlights observable when held to the light . creamy tan head the lasted the whole glass ... superb retention .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied .

very simply , appearance-wise , this beer is not markedly impressive - with its stillness and particular redness it could easily be mistaken for a glass of pinot or cabernet . accordingly , the nose ( what little manages to announce itself ) is wholly dominated by obvious wine-like grape notes and supple/elegant tannins ; there might be a spicy undertone ( nutmeg ? however , once we have moved beyond these categories , this beer is radiant . the feel is gently carbonated , extremely dense and somewhat ideal .  a - quite a beautiful opaque orange body with finger hight white head . s - very malty ( strange for a hefe ) , average yeast aroma for the style and very spicy and sweet aromas .  m- a bit over carbonated for me , but other than the crisp nature of most kiwi beers , nice malty and dry .

do n't be turned off by the little green specks floating around as they are chucks of hops leftover from fermentation and help accentuate the huge hoppy aromas . pours a nice creamy golden color with slight greenish hue to foamy head . aromas of malts and hops give way to dried fruit .  this really is a beautiful beer with it 's deep amber hues and dense mousey head that clings to the side of the glass .  surprisingly light mouthfeel makes it a fairly easy drinker for a 9 % er

the smell was n't all it should be , but average . the taste above average , in fact , very good , but no top shelf kind of beer taste .  it pours a rust-colored brown with a roasted 2-3 finger head . this looks as good as any of the big ipas made by stone , smuttynose and company .  m : very carbonated .

a two finger , quite dense and lifeless head shows very good retention , leaving a decent amount of lacing s- quite weak aroma of sweet biscuit malts , with maybe a hint of roastiness . very nice but really too weak t- mild malts with a hint of roastiness and a good amount of sweetness ( is sugar in the mix ?  2006 appearance , great head and retention . easy to create head .  refreshing when ice cold , pleasantly balanced when it warms a bit .

s : not the best aspect of this beer -- smells a lot like balsamic vinegar without much of the underlying fruit coming through . t : quite tart with a bit of barnyard horse blanket .  22oz into nonic pint in the mid-forties . booming 4f of cream-colored head , over a clear but rich amber body - tons of carbonation present , and lots of sugary/sticky lacing .  but there are hints of dark fruits that seem to disintegrate on your tongue , slight astringent alcohol tate/smelll this is defiantly a very drinkable brew .

i first enjoyed yuengling traditional lager on a cold winter day after a snow storm passed i was helping my dad cut some firewood . this beer was very delightful with a mild flavor . and the price is great , yuengling has become my everyday drink .  a - incredible crimson-amber color with a lasting two-finger off-white head .  m : the body is not as thick as i was expecting . it on the thin side as far as stouts go , but drinks very smoothly . i would have liked a thicker body , but that 's just being picky .

the nose is surprisingly mild , with just a hint of mild flowery hops .  jet black in color with a large milk chocolate head .  mouthfeel is a little thin and alcoholic with low carbonation . overall this beer has a nice balance of flavours but i feel the barrel presence is a little bit too subtle and the mouthfeel a bit too thin to prevent a higher score .

superoir lacing & very good head retention s : nothing up front , but then earthy hoppyness & whisper of fruit . this was the only area this beer let me down t : huge grapefruitty hops & then a little fruittyness up front .  a solid five fingers tall , the head falls slowly , leaving behind a cragy , mountainous blanket over top of the glass with massive amounts of lacing . best looking head i 've ever seen .  a- blackness with a espresso colored head s- coffee beans ground soaked in licorice coffee and dark chocolate really bold t- straight up coffee and espresso with bitter chocolate and a slight tang finish m- medium carbonation and a bit watery for the style d- i drink 3 cup of coffee a day who am i to judge ?

n : lemon peel , citrus and some kiwi ( ? ) with some sweet malt smells . hops come and go in the aroma , knocked out a bit from the orange and coriander .  pours an opaque black with a creamy tan head that retains well and laces the glass .  mouthfeel is a bit light .

smell is a very subdued smoky chocolate , a bit earthy and a faint whiff of bbq sauce .  i fricking love the way this beer looks . huge foamy white head , brilliant dark golden color with a cascade of carbonation bubbling up the side .  it may not be for everyone but i think this is a beautiful product . flavor is far less sweet than the smell and look might hint , in fact this is gobs of sour black cherry . it 's an instant classic and one of only a handful of lambics i 've liked so far .

a- beautiful rich amber with a dense creamy head . s- a little faint , but my allergies are clogging my nose a bit so , it 's probably better than i can tell . some floral , some hoppy spiciness . first i get the fresh pine and resin notes , very bright and spicy , with floral overtones throughout . i do n't like bitterness and its the only fault i have with this beer , but since it is a tribute to hops its really not a fault at all .  poured into a duvel tulip , between the brilliant dark amber body and the tight , creamy head it fills the glass . simply beautiful - my wife heard me say something to that effect , took a look and said `` wow ! that 's pretty !  long , super bitter piney bitterness , aftertaste almost of pine-sol but i love the hop attack . problem is that it 's too sweet and slightly syrupy , especially evident in the middle . a little harsh and unbalanced overall , big beer and it shows .
smell is roasted grain , coffee , caramelized sugar .  bright yellow and unfiltered with a full white head that leaves nice lace .  m : still a bit watered down , but again , it 's better .

my poured stubby elicited little smell , but the initial flavour was a rounded coffee chocolate.the flavour fell away though , to a minimalist charcoal toast it felt smooth and soft , perhaps too soft in the mouth . this is a strongish brew at 6.8 % and the coffee chocolate predominance makes it an enjoyable stout but one for moderation  pours thick and black with a big fluffy head with excellent retention . looks rich and dessert-like .  quite watery for the big flavor this one tastes and smells different from the main stream craft ipas , which is a pretty new category i 'll give it that .

s - smell is terrific and pops way more than a lot of nitro beers i 've had .  this keller bier produces vast amounts of bright white head and has a hazy orangish and silver color .  m : the only thing that let me down was the thin and carbonated mouthfeel .

also present are dark chocolates , licorice , spice , robust yeasts , sweet malts and some caramel that all lead to a very complex and pleasing aroma . the taste is not as complex .  a : dark amber-orange color , good carbonation . very good sized white head with great head retention . maintained ateast 1/4 '' head throughout .  last weekend fellow ba das freak showed up with the dundee craft pack sampler . after tasting the pa , ipa , porter and pale bock lager i thought we had stumbled onto something above average , then came the honey brown lager . at first i thought it had a funky after taste but it does n't wait until after . when my dog broke wind i thought i was at a beer pairing in hell . sorry for the negativity but if i can save one ba from this fate it will have been worth it .

it do n't smell all that strong or sweet , even for the style this seems little tame . light nodes of dark roasted barley . that 's it . tastes a god sight better .  black with a nice brown head that leaves good lace rings .  very low carbonation , strong , hoppy with lingering after taste , a very typical english bitter but not my cup of tea .

the taste of this beer is exceptional given the style . yeast provides subtle fruity notes . the hops are there but very mellow . the most flavorful adjunct lager i have come accross . this is a very drinkable adjunct lager and if the price is right it is a pretty good session beer .  the beer looks great . there 's a great cascade look while the bubbles settle , and once they do the head is a solid milky white about 2 fingers deep .  some hop aroma and flavour , a little to light in the body for my liking .

nose : very slight nose .  towards the end of the night it settles down to a thin concentric ring but a nice swirl brings you back to viewing what i consider one of the most beautiful looking barleywines i 've ever seen .  take this beer for what it is ... a nice `` treat . '' it 's not something you will want to drink all night long . but for a nightcap , or change of pace this beer fits the bill . the vanilla taste is not overpowering , it 's there , but not so bold and overpowering that it seems fake .

omg , the hops . maybe that was the garlic potatoes . but i want to get back to my beer .  from a bottle this poured a pale golden color . very clear , well carbonated with fine bubbles of co2 and topped off with a very attractive creamy head of foam . this certainly looks like a premium beer on the highest order .  m-medium body and syrupy with a grainy tough texture . strong carbonation and a slightly messy carbonation in the finish .

subtle . t/m : great malt flavor .  thanks to mistakebythelake for this growl pour apperance- golden orange with a good amount of white head . a gorgeous beer !  the taste is very good , it could use a bit more body but the flavors are great . tons of chocolate and roastiness dominate the profile but there is also some caramel and hops . the bitterness is at a great level in comparison to the sweetness , especially for the style . the guy below me has it right : not quite edmund fitz or blake butte but this one is one of the supeb examples of the style .

pours a 2 '' tan head and looks a standard coffee brown in the glass . flavor itself was pretty mild but what is cool with this beer is it has the flavor and feel of drinking a mild mocha malt . i found it thoroughly satisfying like a kid at a malt shop slowly draining his glass .  a : dark brown and reds blend into an opaque liquid topped by 4 fingers of off white head that paints the glass all the way until the end . a beautiful beer .  for the mouthfeel , i found this stout almost watery in consistency .

s : honestly , not too much aroma . it definitely tastes better than it smells . pleasing bitterness that is n't ever overbearing , and it sticks on the palate well into the aftertaste . at first the appearance and especially smell were nothing special at all , but it makes up for it with the great taste .  frothy head retention and lacing is outstanding .  mouthfeel suffers a little bit as i feel a higher abv would 've left this coating the tongue a little better . it seemed a little too thin to match its flavor profile .

smell is a bit muted , whiff of malt .  appearance- beautiful honey-tan-golden creamy pour with a nice 3/4 inch fat solid head . lacing is a solid sheet of white down the entire glass .  t - tastes like a combination of pine-sol and a basic light lager m - who cares ?

when inhaling deeply i manage to smell a lavender soap aroma with some malt and spicy hop .  pours thick and pitch black , no light can penetrate this . has a nice sized brown head that fades to medium ring that leaves an awesome lace .  nothing special here .

odd for an ipa . for a big ipa it also has a fairly tame pine hop aroma with a hint of dirtyness . despite these discrepancies , torpedo is a very robust malty ipa .  $ 5.00 / 750ml bottle county market grocery store stevens point , wisconsin appearance - a haze of golden yellow to a pale orange with a lasting frothy white head . very much carbonated as a constant flow of tiny bubbles speed to the top if the beer from the side and bottom of the pint glass .  had this today on tap @ hibernia in boston . diacetyl ? in an ipa ? and what 's with the low hop profile and mega-sweetness of this beer ? my pint was quite cloudy too . beer drinkers of the world ... this is not an ipa , and it 's a pretty crappy beer to boot .

the aroma is of muted hops and barley . there is n't really much going on in the nose . after smelling this beer i thought it would be rather bland but the flavors pop off the tongue . i would n't call any 8.7 % alcohol beer extremely drinkable , but this is exceptional .  a freind brought this brew over ... a : perfect look for a belgian ale . deep dark ruby color like an iced tea .  mouthfeel is a bit thin .

the aroma is oddly sweet . the floral nature of the jasmine really comes out in the nose . i really do n't know if the sweetness comes from the jasmine or the malt .  a - what a beautiful looking beer .  mouthfeel : it 's a bit heavy for the style .

has a strong fruity citrus smell , i do n't really smell hops ... maybe slightly ... but not as much as other people say .  pours a very clear copper color with a fluffy white head . leaves lots of lacing on the glass as it slowly recedes .  m - a little on the thin side .

the aroma is pleasing with a dominant smell of overripe peaches backed by toasty malt and pecans .  pours a cloudy amber brown into a wine glass with two fingers worth of frothy , white head . the lacing clings to the inside of the glass for dear life , and is quite exquisite .  not too much that i can to the other reviews here . this beer was nothing but dissapointing . the label does say ipa right ? where are the hops ? i know that it does n't have to be a hop bomb but the flavor just is n't very good at all . i 've got 5 bottles left from this 6-pack . now i have to decide if i struggle though them or i just pour them out .

very straight up pale lager smell , it does supply some decent scents of fruit and bread . much more flavorful than expected !  there is something hypnotic about watching the beer cascade into a jet black liquid with a wonderful tan thick creamy head . to me , the head on this is the best of almost any beer , and has a unique look .  pretty weak mouthfeel , it 's a bit watery . i 'm enjoying the flavour and aroma quite a bit but the mouthfeel is a bit weak . but lacking in mouthfeel .

a lighter bodied golden ? ale . mild malts and hops . finish is clean and smooth . aftertaste is slightly bitter .  pours a golden straw , as clear as an unmuddied lake of deepest summer . dense white foam fills the glass , then gradually settles to a solid rocky head that forms big sticky patches of lace .  very dry with a bitter finish . a little sticky from all the sweetness .

smell - some nobles are faint but mostly a faint skunky smell taste - a pleasant combination of barnyard flavors ( straw , earthiness ) with nicely balanced noble hop flavoring and slight crisp in the finsih mouthfeel - full bodied for a pilsner . overall - this a very decent german pilsner in my book .  a gorgeous beer , this pours a rich , hazed , honey amber with a killer head of eggshell puff that forms stiff rocky peaks and deposits thick clumps of lace .  smell was sweet , with a citrus hint and strong english ale smell . initial taste was interesting , and i was n't sure about whether i would like it . by the end of the bottle , it had become one of the best beers i 've tasted . i would n't recommend it for any parties , but in small groups of like minded people i would say good call . very drinkable beer . looking forward to trying more from the brewery ( if i can find it )

loads of burp from a very clean , light golden fizz and a nice hopped edge on the aftertaste . certainly wo n't stand up to serious beer for beer competition but this is the type of refreshing hot summer beer that 's best served very cold for thirst quenching . like i say this is the best choice for a breakfast bar beer - nothing else .  came out a murky amber-gold with a good inch 's worth of head on it . great retention , and perfect lacing rings after each sip . beautiful .  average body and carbonation .

the head really has some large pillows in it and it just sits high the whole way down ... one of the more impressive looking pale ales ive experienced . the nose is very very subtle ; biscuity malt , pine and citrus , but very subdued , i had to stick my nose down in it for a minute to really draw everything out .  appearance - crystal clear gold body with a huge white head ( took three goblets to pour this ) . gorgeous .  the body is surprisingly light with moderate carbonation , helping to make this very drinkable .

almost black in color , charcoal/black licorice , hardly affected by light when held up . s- faint sweetness , molasses maybe . hard to fully describe the scent other than it definitely had some sweet tones to it .  enough of the stupid remark , bust out the old guardian glass and opener and get on to the beer : it 's magnificent looking ; a darker shade of gold , tiny bubbles that are clearly visible from a few feet away , a thick creamy top that seems to last forever .  appearance : pours a clear , healthy copper color , with moderate carbonation , yet quickly dissipating foam and nearly no lacing . smell : light scent of fresh hops is predominant , slightly dry with a piney undertone . taste : begins clean , progressing into a moderately dry hop taste ; as the scent indicates , there is a note of piney taste that is part of the dryness of the hops , finishes with a slight dryness that yields clean . drinkability : prime example of the style , well hopped , abv is adequate , and the fresh and clean taste only enhance its drinkability .

a- pours chocolate milk color into black with the creamiest of tan heads . s- aroma is soft and roasted , not much going on . perfect amount of malt .  a - extremely dark brown body with a dark brown head to go along with it . the thick and frothy head started out at about 4 inches and ever so slowly faded down leaving a thick humocky topography .  mf : a bit thin , light body , medium to high carbonation d : another winner from sierra nevada .

s : very heavy on the mint , with some alcohol and roasted malt . smells like a peppermint patty . t : initial punch of mint followed by chocolate malt .  a - translucent , super vibrant golden straw color that could illuminate a room . finger eggshell ( always wanted to work that color into a review ! ) head with a nice bubbly ring and a thin white film of bubbles remains on the surface .  i got this beer in the beers of the world gift box for christmas . immediate taste is a lil sharp and bready with a hint of citrus in the smell . it was not an out of this world experience , but it is a very light and enjoyable beer for everyday or get togethers .

hay and some sweetness give this beer a fairly simple aroma . grainy flavored beer with some faint pale malt sweetness .  pours black and thick . substantial tan head that forms of a billion tiny bubbles then morphs into a very slow fading creamy foam .  perhaps a bit thin for the style , which i suppose makes it a good pale ale for summertime quaffing .

not a lot of aroma up front . a few quick whiffs provides a subtle hint of ginger root .  appearance - 5.0 pours two fingers of moussy cream coloured head which settled at a dense centimetre over a brilliantly clear body of amber-orange . left spots of lace all the way down the glass , gorgeous !  m. thin to medium body with a somewhat biting carbonation . ends fairly dry .

smell : rather light on the nose despite the big head , just a hint of citrus and maybe a bit of fresh cut grass taste : very light malt that reminds me of cereal and almonds ( just a hint ) and a nice solid refreshing lemon zest hop finish . kick ass lawnmower beer . very good stuff , it 's superb drinkability and the genuinely good ( not superb ) flavor .  i love the look of this in the glass , nice pale yellow color , frothy white head . it looks like it was dry hopped to me .  s- coffee , malty caramel t- more coffee , chocolate , caramel and a little alcohol in there too m- medium bodied , a little watery really , decent carbonation d- a great example of a porter , just the wateriness that draws back from it

this hefe comes from a brewery whose name can be easily pronounced by an american speaker and as such , is approached with disdain and apprehension . if this were pfaffleschlutzelbraenhiemer brothers hefeweizen , i suspect this beer would be more favorably received . its all wheat and the faintest essence of fruitiness . some are hoppier , but the existence of superior beers dont make widmer hefeweizen a bad beer .  a : deep copper with a light tan head , excellent retention & lacing .  it 's a black colored beer with ruby edges . fairly nice nose , with a variety of dark fruits , as well as a bit of chocolate and coffee . really nice nose . flavor is fully packed , loaded with dark fruits ( blackberry , plum , cherry and currant ) , as well as some notes of dark chocolate , coffee and a light hint of alcohol . i like it .

s : hints of breadyness mf : medium bodied , slick & very well balanced great drinkability , such a well crafted dubbel ! although the lack of nose is a let down .  a : pours a beautiful hazy orange colour . huge fluffy , rocky white head . lots of retention and lace .  m : light body , watery touch , smooth with low carbonated in the mouth .

trying back to back kolsch beers today , poured into a standard pint glass a light clear golden with a large fluffy white head that never fully settles , another spritzy lookin klosch , this head a great head to hit as well.aromas are muted , only some light toasty grain , this is a crisp dry kolsch , spicy/herbal hop and toasted grain flavors mainly , i like the crispness of this beer.now this a perfect warm weather brew that again isnt a throw back beer , i like this alot .  this beer poured a beautiful gold with a rock-like head that persisted in all its glory for a few minutes before collapsing into a nice ring-around-the-rosie .  m : very carbonated .

smell : sweet malt , floral hop , light brown sugar , light bread , light whiff of dark fruits . the nose was a little light and the beer itself is more hop forward then what i would consider perfect for a esb , but on the whole a very simple but good brew .  the beer appears jet black , with a thick , creamy , beige head . the glass is completely coated with a heavy sheet of tan lacing .  mouthfeel lots of fizzy carbonation , lighter bodied , finishes dry . the high carbonation combined with a thinner than usual mouthfeel really did throw off the beer making the flavors less prominent than i feel they could have been had the aforementioned two things been toned down a bit .

smell is very moderate , a bit malty .  this beer pours with a thick and foamy head . wonderful active bubbles slowly float to the top to form a thick white head .  ordered this one in a taproom and was vary pleased . this beer is solid , as one might expect from north coast . it 's is as good as any pilsner i 've had . it drinks easy , has a hint of subtle fruit flavor , and smells very good . it also pours very nicely from the tap with a fluffy head . i 'd pick this one again on draft and might pick it up as a favor for a host when a house guest .

i just love this beer along with pulled pork and ribs . upon smelling it , one will notice a slight sweet , malty aroma , but again , nothing special . where this beer shines is in the taste category . plus , it 's relatively cheap and easy to find in almost any store that sells more than 2 different types of beers .  poured into my delirium tremens tulip . a : pours a slightly cloudy amber/copper color with 3 huge fingers of head that fade very slowly leaving tons of sticky lacing behind .  the body is rather thin though .

aroma is disappointingly mild . honestly smells like a watered down lot 6 with very minimal spirit presence .  the beer was poured into a champagne flute . appearance : this may be the singularly best looking beer i have ever seen in a glass . the head was very tall and proud with an off white coloration . the retention was perfect throughout the consumption of the beer . the carbonation was explosive rolling boiling bubbles .  m-medium carbonation . medium body , slick .

a bit light on the nose . pleasant and fresh , but not ultra complex .  poured into a fluted pilsner glass , this czech pils showed an exceptional ability to form a stiff , meringue-like , rocky head of foam . retention was great , lasting for the duration of the glass , leaving irregular clumps of foam on the way down .  mouthfeel is full and seems overcarbonated for the style , but overall has the typical heavy/slightly syrupy mouthfeel characteristic of wheat beers .
nothing outstanding .  perfect head retention & lacing s : slight hops aroma t : some fruittyness up front .  the palate is thinner than expected but not bad .

it just smells like beer .  hazy light golden with a nice , moussy white head ; excellent head retention , and great lacing . perfect looks . no contest here .  mouthfeel : i wish they would dial it up a notch , needs a better backbone . stopped after one because it needed more body .

this notes of grapefruit and pineapple . just thick hop notes here so ripe and fresh it was like heaven just smelling this . smooth and mellow delivery of the flavor , though not as strong as the aroma would have led me to believe . light alcohol notes as well and a really good medium feel to it . something i would love to try again as the aroma itself was worth the price . this was damn nice  thick , oily black pour unleashes a magnificent tan head that just stays and stays , eventually forming a thick collar that remains til the end . crusty lace coats my glass .  m : aftertaste is bitter and body as well as carbonation is medium .

smell : almost nothing to say here , the smell is very weak , it seems . from what i *can* detect , there is a gentle grassiness coupled with moderate sweetness . it 's unoffensive , and get more flavorful as the beer warms .  beautiful rich yellow color , with a decent , small head .  not too complicated , but a pleasant experience overall . goes down quite easily ( in part because of the low carbonation ) .

reviewed from notes : appearance : orange copper with a 1 finger head smell : bourbon , vanilla , fruity taste : sour fruit , something went wrong in this bottle mouthfeel : mild carbonation , medium body , overall : i think i 'm going to need to try it again .  this brew pours with a deep amber body topped by a medium thick head with lots of lacing .  if you closed your eyes and smelled this you would think your smelling a good octoberfest beer due to the scent of carmalized malt and faint hops . has a carmel toasted nut flavor on the tounge and finished dry . i like the fact that this irish red is a little more bitter than most red ales but still not overpowering . tongiht i will be reviewing 4 of hook and ladder beers as i bought a gift pack that came with 3 bottles of 4 different beers . the beers i got were backdraft brown golden ale pipe and drum irish red ember amber ( a type of black and tan made with their backdraft brown ale and golden ale ) . try these beers if u can find them they are good

despite my usual preference for ales , i really enjoy this lager . if the macros produced lagers like this one ( and i 'm sure they could do so ) , american beers would be looked at quite differently by the world of beer experts .  once the head settled with a good half inch left on top the beer was a dark solid black . it looked eerily similar to guinness .  light copper color with a large head s. malty with a slight resiny hop smell t. more bitter than sweet but well balanced with roasted malt m. a little to acidic and carbonated for my tastes d. a good lighter amber ale that i can heartily recommend

( s ) - a dry , yet floral-like citrus . a damp wood-like pine . ( t ) - a fresh & crisp floral citrus of lemon , pineapple , grapefruit , and lime . has everything you would expect from the style .  pours hazy light brown with some orange tints . great head and great lacing .  ( i actually do not care for this sweetness , but the beer still has great flavor ) m : nice carbonation , but the body is a little weak .

oddly adjunct lager aroma detected at arms length . aroma is weak and watery with more of that adjunct lager character . lame .  this beer had a beautiful pour into a tulip glass . very dark and rich , with a dark roasted tan head that was very thick and continually rebuilt itself every time i swirled the glass .  the mouthfeel was medium/light bodied with a fine , prickly carbonation .

nutty malt aroma with slightly metallic hops . mediocre .  appearance- one of the best looking belgian pale 's i have seen . a large 2 inch big bubbled head which 1/4 inch remains until the last drop is consumed . excellent lacing stuck to the entire rounded wall of my glass .  mouthfeel : i 've always thought this was a little off ... not quite enough spine to offset the sweetness .

aroma is as good as it gets ; fruits , flowers , grass and everything in the yard makes this smell like a spring day ; impressive . medium to light bodied , its taste is interestingly hoppy with a lot of fruits , but the bitterness is not prominent , and it is well balanced by an underlying sweet maltiness which increases its drinkability a lot . for the sake of comparison , this was on a small tasting with alpha king and arrogant bastard ; the taste is better on the other two ; but drinkability and aroma are better here .  amazing lacing & head retention , really pretty to look at s : hints of choclate & some roasted malt as it warms t : rich choclate up front , then a little grainyness & some bitter choclate .  this one is a bit light and watery but does have a decent taste .

murphy 's stout on tap is one of my favorite dry irish stouts . this style of beer does not have much of a smell , but the taste is wonderfully sharp and smooth at the same time . murphy 's is perhaps a bit less bitter than guinness , but they are close . the mouthfeel is very smooth , and i personally find this to be an extremely drinkable beer , and i am happy to drink it all night .  appearance : gorgeous beer with strong lacing throughout the entire glass . it looked sooo good , but there is almost no aroma .  ( m ) - this is where the beer starts to fail in my opinion .

nice lacing developed . the aroma was of some barely noticeable malt .  a - pretty , near black pour with quite a sold 1+ inch head that stays around for awhile .  it was watery with no carbonation , and had a bitter aftertaste . but it had good flavor and decent body , and was fairly clean and easy to drink .

reminds me of an long island iced tea . s - not overly strong . almost like plain carbonated water . t - very mellow and smooth .  excellent lacing . great looking ipa .  surprised didnt taste as much hops as anticipated since it is called `` hopfish '' lighter on palate than majority of ipas mouthfeel- slightly watery but pleasantly smooth .

had this one on tap at a bar just down the street from the brewery , smell of biscuity malts , color a classic amber , tastes of german malts little to no hop presence , abv quite high for the drinkability , and as such it makes a good session beer , if you do n't mind partying a little hard .  appearance this beer is absolutely gorgeous . the body is a dark , orangish-brown and murky with lots of carbonation and had a bountiful , brownish-white head that was full without exploding and pitted well on top of the liquid leaving some awesome , shaving cream foam around the edges of my pint glass .  i like a little heavier of a mouthfeel than this offers , but the lighter feel is not surprising considering the crystal appearance .

it it just kind of a sad looking beer- there is nothing exciting there . s- very chocolaty and earthy . oatmeal is definitely noticeable . very roasty .  pours into 't hofbrouwerijke chalice a deep dark chocolate brown with a huge , i mean huge , light brown head . this is a head that just wo n't quit . it 's stunning .  maybe a touch too much carbonation .

i live in north carolina and love to get my hands on beer from my area back home . the smell is just fairly subtile but hinted of almost friuty . overall a very decent beer .  reviewed 12/27/2008 ( bottle ) : pours a pretty clear darkish orange colored body , with a huge foamy off-white head , very lasting .  pretty thin mouthfeel i guess , but overall its a great balance of flavor and drinkability , something i would definitely buy again .

what i liked most was that it was well balanced and not a hop bomb in my opinion . i love sierra nevada pale ale and i think fans of that will like this too if not more . very drinkable and probably could go through quite a bit on a warm sunny day .  a : damn near perfect in my book . nicely hazy , radiant golden orange color . it 's got a big , soapy head that settles into a cap and leaves big sheets of lacing . so far so good .  the carbonation is interesting , but a little too fizzy for me , i feel like this beer has a watery quality to it which i do n't particularly like in a porter . it starts out watery , then the carbonation kicks in .

smell is really good . very sweet and carmelly with some spices in there .  gorgeous looking beer s- getting a bunch of citrus , but the aroma is really weak .  3.0 m : medium body . smooth , but not creamy .

smell is subtle and surprisingly fruity . overall an outstanding example of the style .  a - a beautiful pour . deep amber with an inch of off-white head . as the head slowly goes away it leaves great lace and ends up in a creamy , bumpy layer on top of the brew .  s : slightly citrus , faint banana t : citrus & yeast & candy sugar m : bit thin , but not uncommon for a triple o : i am sure age did this one well reading the prior reviews ... think i paid $ 3.50 for it , well worth the price and a good brown bagger at a tasting .

had on tap at the rockcats game a- dark dark brown with red overtones , thin white head that lasted only a few seconds s- some malts not to much nose here t- some nice malts with a nice clean refreshing finish m- thin but as expected for the style d- great drinkablity from this and any brown ale . while this is not the best brown ale i have a had it certainly is a good beer i would have again . i think brown ales are one of the most sessionable ales around .  poured to the expected golden orange with thick off-white head that stuck around for the whole glass , and left excellent lacing .  4/5 m : surprisingly thin side of medium , slightly tongue numbing , spritzy .

aroma was surprisingly weak , notes of smoky roasted malt and hints of coffee .  appearance : pours the color of a tripel ; that burnt golden orange appearance . head is gigantic and rocky which dissipates slowly into a thick rocky soapy lacing that clings to the glass tenaciously and refuses to let go . it even have yeast in the bottle which i found out on the last pour of my bomber . so really proper looking for an imperial ipa and the color of a tripel . i 'm giving this a 5 ! its a beautiful beer smell : this a very hoppy beer .  the body was medium to medium light .

aroma of coffee though initially strong fades to subtle . the taste is superior to the smell . good mouthfeel with pleasant carbonation .  bottle to a tulip pours a clear red body , and by red i mean excellent vibrant red . has a fizzy white head that doesnt stay for the party .  not too complex- makes for easy drinking , as does its texture . carbonation level seems low , though as an earlier commenter noted , it is actually just very fine .

the aroma is possibly the best feature of this brew . very sweet and flowery , almost of lemon , chamomile , and honey with very strong hop overtones . a nice light amber color , slightly darker than the 60 minute .  pours an absolutely gorgeous dark cola body that illuminates to a caramel-amber when held to the light . creamy , light tan bubbles form a sizable froth on top and slowly settle to a thick veil of foam , thanks in part to a vigorous carbonation level .  an e-mail from the brewery indicated that twins lager is not the same beer as hauenstein , just with a different label . schells tells me that the twins lager uses a different recipe and yeast than the hauenstein , but a side by side comparison leaves me wondering why they would go through the trouble . i have always liked `` cheap '' beers . the beer drinkers of olden days wanted it cold , crisp , and cheap . but for afternoon lazing back and swigging , there is certainly nothing wrong with a cold bottle of twins lager . twins lager might be `` twice as refreshing '' as the label purports , but , boy would it be a treat to drink an original recipe fitgers again !

based on tasting notes poured golden with 1/2 '' of white head , with good head retention & very good lacing s : some herbal & lemony hops t : lemony hops , & a little breadyness .  a- clear dark reddish copper hue with a billowy tan head that last forever and leaves tons of sticky lacing on the glass . edit : holy shit , this beer is so hoppy it turns your tongue yellow !  the carbonation is ok ; small fresh bubbles at a decent strength .

rich chocolate aroma with a decent bit of hops in the back ground .  browning 's bourbon barrel imperial stout pours a very nice , pitch black into a snifter with a small , light tan head that leaves lots of lacing behing .  m. a bit acidic d. overall a nice iipa .

good , solid , workaday porter . no off characteristics . clean and balanced . really good beer .  bottle : poured a bright golden yellow with a super huge pure white foamy head with great retention and super good lacing .  smell : uh oh , something is going wrong ... taste : blecchhh . my stomach is starting to turn . what happened to this beer ? simply put , the taste is sour and offensive . beef notes : horrible . what was the thought process when putting this beer out for sale ?

has a light hop aroma . moderate carbonation , with a silky mouth .  once cracked it pours a deep , impenetrable black with a thick , high , pillowy light tan head that leaves intricate webs of lacing .  i have had ipas that went down a bit smoother but this one is n't bad it still goes down good but with just a little more carbonation and bite .

so-so lacing and at least for me no real aroma detected . however this beer tasted great and i am at a loss on how to describe the taste .  a : poured with a large , white fluffy head that was very long lasting ... never got below 1-2 fingers size . body is a beautiful , dark orange color , with excellent clarity .  taste some roasted chocolate flavors . flavor lingers on the tongue after each sip . not quite what i would consider a savoring beer , but tasty none the less . i could drink this beer around the fire in the winter or after raking leaves in the fall .

s. herby ( marijuana/skunk ) essence on the nose . not much else .  50cl bottle poured into my paulaner weissbier glass a - hazy pale golden body , with the thickest ice-creamiest 4 finger head i have ever seen . super brussels lacing on the glass throughout .  the drawback on this beer is the carbonation - it 's too heavy . sparkly but with a nice dryness in the finish .

smell was very faint . malted grain was minimally evident .  this beer pours beautifully , glowing , hazed apricot amber in color with 3 fingers of fluffy froth topped by rocky peaks . retention is epic and lace coats my maredsous goblet .  little fruityness . light to medium body , oily , light carbonation . could be a little more carbonated .

foam didnt leave lace it left a coating of thick shaving cream , very nic ! s-dominated by sweet caramel malts with low floral/ citruy hops .  a : pitch black , slightly viscous . excellent head formation and nice lacing . this is how an ais should look in the glass .  mouthfeel was unremarkable .

t : this beer has a little malty but mostly hops , actually more hops than expected . m : reasonably full d : very good , i had a second pint  bottle : poured a deep opaque brown color ale with a huge dirty white color foamy head with good retention and some lacing .  do not know if this was an aberation , but this caused a lower score in mouthfeel .

a = pours a nice copper color with a 1/2 '' white head s = smells slightly hoppy with citrus undertones t = very much a citrus taste with slight clove undertones .  a-pours a slightly clear copper/amber color with lots of thick white head that leaves outstanding lacing .  mouthfeel : high carbonation gives the impression of a thinner mouthfeel , and the carbonic acid and alcohol bite knock this one down a little in the mouthfeel rating .

s : i was a unprepared for the smell , as the malts had a big impact . if i was pressed for details ( i suppose that 's the point here ) i could pinpoint some caramel . t : i think the flavor of this beer is gorgeous . do n't let that push you away though , because it is n't a kriek by any means . kudos to the widmer brothers .  the beer looks really good with a thick brown creamy head , tons of lacing , and a very nice head that lasts and lasts .  very nice m : medium bodied-a bit thicker than i expect from an ipa or a dipa , but it works well with the oaky sweetness of this beer .

s - kind of muted actually . maybe some slight dark fruits and touches of rum soaked bread .  poured black with a thick brown head . the retention was great . very creamy and capuccino like looking head .  mouthfeel is pretty average , as is the smell ... i ca n't think of anything distinctive about these characteristics .

the aroma on this beer is perfect . absolutely no off smells and wonderfully balanced . as one would expect in an imperial , it has the requisite dark and roasted malt smells , but delightful hints of chocolate and raisins add to the aromatic complexity .  a - brilliant copper color with a finger of thick solid off white head .  mouthfeel however seems a little thin for this complex brew .

the smell was not very distinctive , clear smell of hops with a hint of sweet vanilla and a very mild fruity smell to it .  appearance , beer pours a red golden with a huge pillowy off tan head that lingers and clings to the sides of the glass thickly . big bubbles and small bubbles intermingle making this beer look alive on the pour . the red gold color is more of a ruby when held to the light , this is one impressive looking barleywine .  a : dark reddish copper ; flat head ; strong carb ; not much lacing s : strong raspberry aroma , very inviting ; occludes other smells t : expected sweet -- it is n't ; the raspberry dominates , but it 's quite sour , draped over a wheat-beer-like base ; i must confess , this tasted terrible to me ; it tasted like nothing else i 've had , so i do n't think this is something against the genre m : good carbonation redeems the experience a bit overall , a terrible beer , for me .

i poured this beer into my tumbler at 45 degrees the beer was a amber color that had a big caramel smell .  on tap o'brien 's pub san diego , ca black with a lot of visible carbonation and a thin brown head . regular , lined lacing down the glass . very attractive and perfect for a black ipa . roasted malts and pine aromas combine , though i would suggest that the roast is fairly dominant .  mouthfeel : light bodied . i might even go as far as to describe it as watery . the carbonation was where i like it to be .

surprisingly underwhelming . wow !  a : thank god with the help of the cellarman and barman it pours a pint of heavenly nectar~~ white , tight frothy head on top of a pale amber hued nectar , very low carbonation just like a cask-conditioned ale should be . the beer head settles to a 1cm thick layer of creamy foam and stays forever ( i mean throughout the drink ) , leaving incredibly tight and creamy lacing ... this is a dream for a cask-conditioned ale , right in front of me , really .  the mouth is a little lighter than years past .

s- only could smell sweet and smoke . the only off area was the smell which is usually the area that lacks in most of my reviews . overall this was a great beer .  bottled on : ( should be on the bottom right hand side of the bottle but its just dots ) purchased through lakeview liquors , chicago , illinois price - $ 9.99/bomber appearance : pours pitch black with a creamy mocha colored head . with each swirl of the snifter another layer of froth reveals itself . looks tastey .  mouthfeel : a little slick , thinner on the palate than i expected drinkability : a fine porter , would definitely drink again .

smells of a typica quad , a bit spicey and harsh .  ale here in western ny so quickly.my second time trying this new black ipa style of beer my first being rogue black brutal wich i had mixed feelings about , this poured a deep dark brown but not black some ruby colored highlights thruought a thick 2 finger head atop that never completely settled just a fantastic creamy mass left with gobs of lace behind in my impy pint glass , just awesome.mix of piney and tropical fruit hops and black malt in the nose mainly i picked up some pineapple and molasses wich was nice and it strayed away from the one dimensional resiny hop profile and caramel malt base.the hops are big but so is the black malt element of this beer sure its big and piney and citrusy but the dark bread and molasses in there is large as well in finely balanced that black malt character really shows itself.the alcohol creeps a bit but this is a very interesting brew it has it all big hops and some malty sweetness , another top notch brew form one of the best .  mouthfeel : thin body and medium carbonation overall : a nice geuze , a bit too watery for my liking though .

i was actually pleasantly surprised by this beer . i acquired it in the winter variety case and finally got to it . very nice red hue to the beer . very carbonated , of course , and more than a hint of cranberry .  the duchesse pours with perfect presentation . moderate amounts of milky tan head , with a moderately hazy brown body , including hints of reddish hues .  a sticky medium body with good carbonation . a bit too sticky for me .

smell is extremely faint ; all i can detect are pale malts and maybe a bit of citrus .  visually stunning with a clear red-amber hue , plentiful off-white head and lace , and carbonation bubbles that seem to be in slow motion as they rise to the surface .  mouthfeel is okay , no carbonation to speak of .

happily , though , if you give it a minute or two , the stench fades away some , to reveal a nice malty aroma underneath .  a half inch of rich , russet-colored head temporarily lays upon a very dense cola brown body .  the taste was very light and highly carbonated . overall i 'm really surprised at all the negative reviews of this beer . maybe it 's just the fact i had it on tap , or that it was fresh .

s : smells like roast and acetone ... yup , that 's nail polish . ok , i 'm not very impressed with this beer so far . t : aaaahhh ! d : as long as you hold your nose , this has great drinkability .  this pours out the same deep orange color as the last one with the same solid fluffy head , lacing , etc . as appearance goes , there is nothing left to improve upon .  mouthfeel : the carbonation is light , as is the body .

smells ok ... ca n't exactly put my finger on what is wrong ... but it may have something to do with the `` party pig '' it came from .  thanks for the opportunity ... poured into an imperial pint glass , formed a 1/4 '' dark brown ( almost purply black ) head above the opaque black brew . head hangs on , with average lace , which actually is pretty good for the style .  the mouthfeel is just a touch too syrupy , though it does n't detract much at all from the enjoyment of the beer .
s : faintly nutty , with no alcohol detectable . overall very mild , not really noteworthy .  a pretty good looking beer .  good carb , but feels a bit thin and watered down in general .

s - caramel and a slight coffee aroma . t - there 's a chocolate flavor accompanied by a caramel taste .  the carbonation gives rise to an absolutely stunning off white , creamy head with excellent retention .  i 'm rather late with this review but i had this on tap at nicholson 's downtown and it reminded me of sierra nevada celebration . in fact at the time the original name was celebration ale . i 've since had a few growlers from jungle jim 's and though it 's a quailty brew i 've experienced some diacetyl like off-flavors when served from the growler . still it 's quite enjoyable and recommended . i wish the best to mike and his future brews !

s - nice smelling , friendly , but not a whole lot there , pretty weak .  a- body is a moderately pale amber hue that pours with a nice 2-3 finger foamy white head . body is uniformly translucent and has the head has great retention with lots of lacing left all the way down the glass .  m : it feels light- to medium-bodied , smooth and a bit watery on the palate with a moderate amount of carbonation . o : the beer goes down rather easily and is quite flavorful despite its thin body .

drinkability : the strong alcohol , of my opinion , does n't go well with the refreshing smell and taste .  simply beautiful cascading action that lasts for over a minute ! superb tan head retention that is not going away at all !  light to medium in body .

very interesting . the flavor was crisp but muted and started slightly sweet then the hops kicked in a little bitterness .  have had this a couple times at churchkey and paradiso in dc & gt ; a : a very sudsy pub cask like look to this one with sticky lacing , a beautiful finger of fluffy head and a darker orange body . great start .  remarkably good . but pay attention : almost 10 % alcohol , but you hardly remark it . it does not have that much body , but it surely has a delicate taste . i 'm a bit more inclined for brown beers , but this one is really good , and not brown at all .

s : smells of pumpkin , nutmeg , also something sour i ca n't put my finger on . t : taste is much more impressive than the smell ; tastes like a boozy pumpkin pie but the sweetness is held in check nicely .  it is as black as pitch . a nice , pillowy thick 2 finger head formed and stayed for the whole beer .  mouthfeel is a bit thin and the carbonation is too light in my opinion .

bland/plain smelling . some cereal grains and buttered toast . t : just great . sweetness throughout with some alcohol .  there is lots retention and great lacing . it might be best lacing i 've vere seen .  the mouth is a tiny bit like flat soda which was the only off-putting part of this beer .

really though , the harshness is what you get from the start , which is obviously off-putting . better as it warms . however , the nose dings the score a bit .  ruby and brown shades with decent clarity , a beautiful 1/2 inch head of white foam sits atop with solid retention .  m : slick mouthfeel with a medium amount of carbonation that can be prickly at times . body is medium and has a bit of resiny stickiness to it .

s : very mild malty , grainy scents . some background hop aroma present .  the imperial stout was very black in color with a dark brown head . very pretty .  a completely black beer with a thin mocha head . boris is a thick , almost to the point of sludgy beer with a roasted malt taste with a noticeable but background hop presences . the oatmeal comes into play as a slight cookie taste . overall it 's a great beer that worthy of a try .

s : apple skin , musty dried fruit , creamed corn , slightly metallic . t : sweet and fruity up front - apples , a bit of raisons , prunes , figs .  a : moderate pour yields 1.25 fingers dense tan head with superb retention . a beauty .  the mouthfeel could use some more body to combat the higher level of carbonation .

a : transparent light amber colored beer , that has a good head to start off with , but it dissipates fast . s : hoopy but nothing special , not that potent . t : overall good . mild hops taste with hints of citrus , and a bit of a bitter aftertaste , but nothing overwhelming . very much so torn between 3.5 and 4 .  first of all this is an amazing looking beer . a nice pale orange , hazy , with a huge rocky white head . great retention and that belgian lace that i love .  has an awful , mouth-burning sweetness , a very artificial flavor , and a sticky-sweet mouthfeel .

nose is extremely mild - had to stick my nose in it for a solid thirty seconds to get anything . dirty malt , i guess , but it 's hard to tell .  this beer poured a black body with a thick dark tan/black head . a beautiful sight to see .  m - a little thin-bodied and watery and a little low on the carbonation .

smells of apples , seriously . yep , apples . if i was drinking this blindfolded i would n't guess that it 's as dark as it is ... then i would probably accidentaly knock it over , spilling it and making myself smell like apples for the rest of the night , but i suppose that 's not important . overall : apples ; perhaps this keg is infected , or something .  a- a golden orange color with a strong 2-3 finger head . very thick white head holds up like sea foam . superb lacing . sticks beautifully to the glass and just stays there .  m & # 8211 ; thin , refreshing , light , plentiful , smooth carbonation .

foam looks like insulation foam.. smells okay , not a whole lot going on , mostly dark malts .  appearance : pours a clear orange color with a big 3 '' head that lasts quite a while .  m- medium body with medium carbonation . a bit to high carbonation for this brew but still has a light creaminess to it . nice blend of flavors just mouthfeel is lacking a bit imo . also the head could of been a lot better especially due to how much carbonation .
no strong smells here , picked up on roasted barley a little bit .  poured an opaque ink jet black with a nice khaki head with good lacing .  smooth , mellow finish , and a thin watery mouthfeel .

perfect fruit scent . clean , pleasant , and wonderful . almost erotic , even - i want this beer to have my abortion .  excellent lacing . a great looking beer .  the mouthfeel is a bit thin and the carbonation is quite sharp ; a bit fizzier than i 'd like .

a pleasant aroma for sure .  appearance- 3/4 inch full dirty brown head . dark brown , maybe and off black colored pour . full length lacing sheets plaster the glass . lovely sight .  the mouthfeel was lowly carbonated .

the smell is rather clean with grain upfront , other than traces of floral it is very clean to the nose . the taste is excellent , light bodied , refreshing and crisp .  pours a deep burnished copper with a nice , creamy light tan head with awesome stickiness and retention , leaving plenty of lacing . aesthetically an unusually pleasing brew .  mouthfeel is a little thin and aftertaste is a little too much ... like the brew has gone stale , although i know it has n't .

citric , fruity aroma . flavor is dominating by a surpsingly nice fresh , leafy hop flavor throughout the sip , undergirded by amaltiness which starts off sweet and develops a toasty , biscuity character toward the finish .  had awesome retention and never showed signs of totally leaving .  mouthfeel is a bit thinner than i would have expected .

smell : it has the smell of wet low acidity hops , slight earthy/barnyard and almost a hint of malt . mouthfeel : balanced with a smooth medium body , medium carbonation and a nice nip on the tip of the tongue .  just an absolutely pitch black beer that poured like motor oil and had one of the darkest , longest lasting heads i have seen on an imperial stout .  parching on the tongue . almost no flavor : slight sweetness up front , trace of bitterness on finish . really .

the nose begins to drift toward me as i pour ... a nice roasted barley , chocolate and espresso with a hint of cinnamon . this smells more like a stout . the nose is deceiving .  pours black with off-white/brownish head in one finger thickness that lasts for very long time , generous lacing . perfect .  m - thin with medium low carbonation d - not a bad amber .

smell : boozey , toasty malts . uh oh.. `` dirty nickels '' .. but not that much.. lets hope we dont taste them .  looks like a cappuccino with a marshmallow melting into it . leaves amusing puddles of lace behind and seems murky and cloudy . exquisite - a marvel to behold .  easy drinking but it has a different mouthfeel , it almost leaves a film in my mouth .

the nose was surprisingly subtle ; could n't pick up much besides a distant chocolate and tartness .  pours a pitch black , with a solid 3/4 inch head that has serious staying power .  the mouthfeel is larger light with a very , very slight fizz .

special cask for crockett 's public house in puyallup . smell is slightly fruity , slight pine , honey , and earthiness .  pours a pitch black with dark brown edges . fine sticky mocha colored head about an inch thick with sticky , sticky lacing . i love stouts , and i love this one .  heavy in apricots and dates with some coriander and maybe some hidden hops late in the nose . the spice showed more as the beer warmed in the glass . the drink started with a heavy fruit taste , around the middle of the tongue the spice showed up . the finish was lingering hops with and oily attribute followed by a light alcohol heat . all and all a good beer to drink with friends and discuss the merits of beer drinking . but i do n't think it would go good with food and it 's not the most refreshing beer .

smell here is n't of really much . perhaps a bit of creaminess . it 's just kind of `` beery '' . an easy drinker ... at this low abv , you could drink these seemingly all day .  it was presented in a room-temperature glass with a thin , bone-white head with moderate retention . the color was spot on - a beautiful , deep-golden yellow with ne-quality clarity .  m : relatively light though not particularly carbonated .

the nose is n't prominent at all . all i can pick up is some muted honey cream and some pale malt sweetness with perhaps some clove . despite the short list of adjectives i used to describe the flavors , it 's actually very , very good for the style . this is a very good belgian strong pale and worth trying .  with a stiff pour , the brew produces a good two finger thick tan head , with a body that is dark ruby red and copper in color , and is well filtered . head retains decently , and lacing lasts pretty well for the style .  this beer poured nicely with a creamy white head , giving off nice citrus aromas . the flavor was shocking , however , reminding me of kool-aid orange flavor , and with almost as much sweetness . i could n't distinguish any hop bitterness , though it could have used some to balance out the excessive sweetness . this beer tastes as though all the yeast were filtered out , and then orange kool-aid added post-fermentation
mild hoppy smell , and malt .  pours near black with tan head .  surprisingly carbonated , almost like a lager .

lacking a little bit on the smell but the taste has all the usual fall spices in these seasonals . very drinkable and balanced with a nice body to it . along with the lack of smell , there 's also a lack of carbonation i thought , which would have improved the score .  very attractive beer . massive sticky foamy eggshell colored head rises to 2 fingers and holds there forever .  perhaps a touch lacking in body , but dextrinous enough to help facilitate excellent drinkability . although stoudts fest falls a touch short in malt character and body , but is nonetheless a well crafted , tasty and highly quaffable brew .
the nose is subtle , but has a little bit of winter spice .  appearance : golden with a nice amount of head that stays with it until the last drink .  mouthfeel : medium bodied .

smell was at first scent , that of a macro lager . not a whole lot in the smell department.. taste was pretty complex , yet smooth .  pours a brilliant colour , reddish , orange , very clear , just amazing , thick white head , lots of lace , great retention , head never leaves , i have to give this a 5 for appearance , simply one of the best looking beers i 've ever seen .  body is fairly thin , but that is expected for the modest abv .

after enjoying the living heck out of noble pils last week and seeing that my local bottle shop , bar was out of it today , i decided to give this one a whirl . what got to me was that it tasted incredibly sour . the hops and lemon seemed to be battling it out in my mouth and neither ingredient won . afterward , it tasted remarkably like a corona , the way it 's served in a mexican restaurant . major disappointment from what 's usually a fantastic brewer .  this beer is a very dark brown with a dense , light tan head that provides excellent lacing .  the mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with no carbonation .

sexy stuff . smells of roast malt and cocoa . very faint , should be stronger .  appearance- beer pours clear and golden with a half finger of creamy white head with ample lacing on the sides of the glass . carbonation rises from the bottom of the glass as if this were a pilsner . very nice on looks at least .  the mouthfeel is slightly buttery but leans more towars a syrup-like feel . carbonation would be greatly appreciated and add a very unique feel for this beer .

s : faint smells of oranges and honey and quite a bit of booze . smell reminds me a bit of apple cider vinegar and copper . not a real great combo . t : tastes are of orange peel , honey , and a fair amount of booze .  a sexy , blurred mahagony colour with patches of head . would leave small remnants of lacing .  mf : the carbonation is n't quite as spritzy as i would hope to go along with the huge sourness , the body is light d : this is a great lambic .

it has little aroma , but i drank it from the bottle , so perhaps i did n't give that aspect a full shot . overall , a fair , crisp beer .  not sure if i need a spoon for this one . pours thick as anything i have ever seen .  does smell a little like `` beer , '' as my wife would say . so sweet on the tongue . slight raspberry tartness but it is like drinking raspberry sorbet after it melts . it is still trying to recover from the sweetness . a good once in a while beer . sorbet beer , i tell ya .

i definitely smell some sweet notes . t- tons of stuff in this one .  poured a beautiful amber color . wonderful lacing . just a beautiful beer .  this was my first encounter with pumpkin ale . i must confess that i could not finish the bottle . i had the distinct impression that the beer was trying to taste like something and not quite getting there . fearing the latter , i tossed the bottle after about five sips .

as others may have observed , this is more like `` pumpkin pie ale '' than `` pumpkin ale '' . picture a nut brown ale , with a pumpkin flavor , and the nose of cinnamon & nutmeg and you have this one .  it almost overflowed out of the glass but soon settled into a craggy , dense mountain of a cap . massive cordillera of lace are plastered to the glass .  my only complaint is that i wish the mouthfeel was thicker . it was smooth , but a bit watery to me .

smell : hops across the board , floral with fruits all paired with citrus . great , strong hop scent , but not aggravating in the least , floral .  incredible retention , eventually falling to a quarter-inch layer of froth . impressive start .  a tad thin .

smell isvery light hops , light malt and bugger-all else , zip , nada , zilch .  notes from 6/16/10 pours jet black with a lovely tan brown head crowning the top . the head lingers and sticks to the glass creating lacing art on the sides of the glass . this is one of the better dark beers i 've seen come out of a bottle .  mouthfeel : bubbly and light body . the mouthfeel is a little peculiar and affects my experience .

smell : some bready caramel malt sweetness . not a ton going on here . overall : a solid irish red .  poured into a glass stein and had an above average white head . it looked great in the stein .  mouthfeel seemed a bit to lean to me .

aroma - not much of aroma . taste - cola and lightly fruity flavors . nothing amazing , but nothing to be shy about .  a : solid black body topped with three full fingers of rich , dense , medium-brown head that just barely poke above the rim of the glass ; incredibly persistent retention and a practically solid sheet of lacing .  m : the feel is creamy and medium bodied . rather light for a ris and that really detracts from the beer in my opinion . the mouthfeel is lighter than what i come to think of when i thik of a ris .

it has a nice colour and can easily be consumed on mass while watching either the maple leafs of the blue jays . i find that creemore does not have the best aroma and infact it greatly detracts from the flavour .  looks great . almost pitch black body with a massive tan head that is both dense and puffy . head retention is excellent and lacing is substantial .  t - great pilsner , very slight hops , clean finish m - light body d - very smooth and very drinkable .

aroma is surprisingly mild with light roasted malt and espresso scents a hit of grassy hops mixed in too .  appearance- beer pours a clear golden with a substantial two and a half finger head of eggshell foam over the top and lacing clinging to the sides of the glass .  t- the taste is dry , and more of the wood flavors seem to be more present . it seemed a bit much for the style of the brew . d- it was n't bad , did n't go down as smooth as most ris do , but it was still easy to drink .

s - light citrus hop aroma . not much else .  a- looks awesome . pours a crytal clear light brassy orange , with a massive white oamy , fluffy head that slowly shrinks down leaving behind all kinds of webbing lace .  smell is cocoa , touch of coffee , licorice , slight vanilla , a whiff of smoke . taste is thick creamy , dark and bakers chocolate , touch of espresso , end is dry and slightly bitter , a woody aftertaste .

the smell dropped off a bit , being dominated by a biscuit smell with bit of roastiness under it . nice , but nothing special .  a nice amber color with a thick tan head . lace was thick and copious .  a bit thin , for i think i like them a bit more bodiful , but smooth and flavorful i do think this one , yes .

s - not bad , vinous with a touch of vinegar . some fruitiness there as well . t - fruit vinegar and a touch of funk there .  very pretty in the glass , big foam head that would n't quit through the whole bottle . heavy orange color .  s- smoky wood and scotch , one of the more interesting noses on this beer t- malts , with some nice roasted flavors that come through and then a hit of alcohol m- lighter bodied than expected d- a very interesting and drinkable beer , but one i need to be in the mood for

smells good too , obvious floral hops and substantial bready slightly sweet malt , both of which hit at the same time . this review is probably going to come out higher than it should due to the deceptively good appearance and smell .  perfect looking .  m - the reason i dinged it on mouthfeel is because it actually left some of that nasty coffee-mouth feeling in my gullet .

smell is actually quite strong , a blast of medicinal malts , along with hops .  appearance : pours an incredibly rich , thick molasses/mahogany . you 'll be hard pressed to find a better looking beer than this .  mouthfeel- light-medium bodied , high ! carbonation , and leaves a bit of hop on the palate but nothing else ... pretty boring here . refreshing and highly carbonated , this one grabs your attention for the beginning of the drink but then finishes weak .

there was almost no smell initially after some warming i started to notice some malty essences , some molasses . pretty light taste wise .  poured with some mild carbonation that settled into a thick yellowish head . absolute best porter i have ever seen .  m : very carbonated - almost too much .

s : typical grain and bready aroma . t : surprisingly less bitter than i expected .  a nice cloud of white head that really sticks around and leaves nice lacing . beautiful in the glass and that nice tart , musty funky taste .  medium bodied and a bit sticky in the mouth .

aromas of hops , yeast , and mellons . smooth and mellow with plenty of depth ; i really liked this beer , but it did n't present itself in both appearance and smell as well as it tasted .  huge head , very lasting w/big bubbles & good lacing .  perhaps a little watery , fuzzy . quite drinkable but somewhat sweet .

smell is nearly non-existent with some dark maltiness . easily the best dunkel i 've ever had .  looks very impressive ... just like i expect beer to .  in the mouth , it 's rather average , with light carbonation .

smell is light with a hint of corny sweetness .  i enjoyed this stout as it warmed up to room temperature . this is as black as you can get which is expected for a stout .  m : fine , nothing special d : probably too sweet for a lot of people , but i 'm a fan .

smell is faint , like cupcakes baking in the oven as you approach the house ( no , that does n't actually happen in my household ) . not as hoppy as i expected , but the hops are delicious and balance the beer nicely . but it 's still a terrific beer .  the most delicate looking head i 've ever seen , pillowy and white , thick and longlasting . beautiful .  m : upper light body with high carbonation .

the smell is not good at all . almost rotten . without a lime , this beer is best on the shelf . it tastes like it smells .  this brew pours a small head of dark brown colored bubbles and an opaque black brown colored body .  mouf & gt ; meh . okay . average .

i could not get much out of the aroma with this one .  damm , skippy , now thats what a stout should look like ! deep , cream black pour . an absolutely beautiful , thick and fluffy brown head , clings to the side of the glass endlessly .  a - black on the pour with no head whatsoever s - big burnt malt and bittersweet chocolate aroma along with some bourbon , some oak and vanilla in there as well , slight alcohol , as the beer warms up , smells almost like straight bourbon , maybe more like a bourbon and cola t - big bourbon flavor right up front , lots of oak as well , some bittersweet chocolate in the body , finish is more bourbon and oak along with some vanilla , alcohol notes , long finish m - a bit too flat for my taste , full-bodied but totally devoid of any carbonation action in the mouth d - i 'm glad port put this in a 375ml bottle , because this is a sipper , treated this almost like fine bourbon sipping for quite awhile , but i could sip on this all night very interesting beer .

the head was huge and creamy which gave off some strange aromas . something like peanuts and sour yeast .  pours a deep black color with a half inch frothy head .  the only thing i felt was it could use a little more carbonation to balance the tart flavor and make it more perky .

s : roasted malts and cocoa dominate the faint air . there is a little old leather chair smell and it 's comforting . dark nuts , coffee , and some sweet hershey 's round it out .  a : a stunning deep brown near black with cranberry highlights . a inch of toasted head comes after a medium pour . the head slowly fades to an impressive 1/3 inch . lacing on a dark beer ?  i found the body to be a bit thin carbonation medium to low .

tried to hold it up to some light , and managed to spill ( experimental error , or general incompetance ) i 'm finding it a little weak in the nose , generally unexpressive . solid dark roast , a little espresso , perhaps a little sarsaparilla . tastes deep , heavy , and satisfying .  bottle into an english pint glass appearance - dark brown/red hue reminds me of high grade saddle leather . a very handsome brew , sir .  good , but the mouthfeel is distracting . 3.0 m : light body , mainly due to low carbonation . need to get some better carbonated beer .

s- light sweet malt and some mild chocolate . pretty mild overall .  first off , this is easily the coolest looking beer can ever . awesome retention and lacing .  i wont go through the details but if you are looking for an ipa do not drink this beer . it may sound novel , but black ipa is a retarded name for this , its not an ipa whatsoever . no hop flavor in the taste , not even close . im pissed i paid 4.30 for this . ridiculous .

aroma consisted of malt and a hint of caramel . nothing else really stood out .  lovely looking beer , and very similar in appearance to the classic guinness look , with a large creamy tan head on top of a dark body .  m- a little too carbonated for my liking , that makes this beer have a little `` sting '' to it ( especially if it is served too cold ) .

very dark with a light tan head . smell is not too impressive and kind of fruity .  beautiful box package , dated 2004 , opens to reveal a classy looking bottle , numbered 85352 . this pours into a tukip a dark amber/light brown , with a thin head .  this is a very good pumpkin beer . picked a 6 pack up at the local market , came home on a chilly night here in rural mi , and my girlfriend and i finished the whole six pack . lots of pumpkin taste , beautiful color , and an overall great seasonal choice . i would n't drink it in warm weather , but on this cool fall night , it hit the spot . i could see picking this up in the future to bring to a bon fire , or to enjoy while i hand out candy on halloween . cheers !

smell : has a bit of a roasted malt smell , similar to a coffee smell , but it 's a little bland . almost watered down in smell .  the head is one inch of bright white foam that recedes very slowly into a firm cap of lacing that lasts until the beer is gone , and leaves rings of lacing all down the sides of the glass .  slight astringent twinge . d- very good `` sessionable '' strong ale .

s- light malt and a much more dominate hop aroma . pretty tame overall though .  a : orangey amber cloudy beer with a huge 3 finger cappucino head that settles to peaks and valleys veery slowly , great lace throughout .  m - kind of watery , but good carbonation .

the appearance is a pumpkin copper-amber suited for late autumn days . the aroma is a bit week for this particular style of beer . i expect a stronger presence in some area but it is n't there . it is a very drinkable ale .  pours garnet with 4 fingers of off white/sand colored head . insane lacing & healthy head retention s : sour , vinergary notes up front that dissipates to not much of anything & then comes back t : sweetness & sourness do battle up front , along with serious dryness .  the carbonation is around medium . there is a watery texture to the beer which is not pleasant .

looks great , clear burnt orange/ harvest orange color that has hints of brown . smells has some vague fruity esters , lemons , a hint of pepper , almost a hint of tea leaves . upon re-drinking i can gladly up the score a bit but still feel there are better saisons out there .  a- looks perfect . ruby amber with a one inch head that only fades after drinking and leaves some nice lacing .  the mouthfeel however is slightly taut . body is clear red copper with sustained carbonation .

the nose had some malt , and a light note of candy .  ( bottle into pint glass - sampled 4/5/10 ) picture perfect pour with a dark brown color and creamy off white head .  medium bodied fairly low carbonation .
