it smells distinctly like pineapple cake . i mean you get the sweet pineapple and a really bready smell underneath . probably my favorite smell in a beer ever , different than the norm for an apa . definitely does n't live up to the smell but i enjoy it . the carbonation level is good and there is n't really a harsh aftertaste . there certainly is n't anything off-putting , and i would recommend it to anyone , at least for the sake of smelling it .  ( this review from notes taken like the others ) appearance-pours well with a decent head , ok clarity , fine color smell-pleasent , with hops and grain coming through as well as malt and fruit .  amazing mouthfeel . creamy and finely carbonated .

smell : very little aroma . cooked and lightly toasted grains .  appearance : nice orange amber , slight chill haze , no luck on a head , or lacing . nice color though .  velvety mouthfeel and smoother than sinatra .

viscous notes , along with minimal head retention & lacing s : orchard fruit , grainyness , & pineapple t : peaches , pineapple , honey , boozey grain & a kiss of estery yeast & mushroom like funk .  ayinger bru weisse pours a light golden color into my glass ; it has a perfect hefe haziness to it . moderate carbonation , no lacing . i was slightly disappointed by its initial appearance , but the taste is fantastic .  the mouthfeel is dead-on creamy .

when i went to smell the aromas , i was very impressed with the assumed banana and clove . they were very prominent and defined ... i couldnt wait to taste ( damn it has a strong aroma that belies its appearance .  pours a caramel with a light tan froth , good retention , & average lacing .  mouthfeel is a heavy but perfect . heavy with lots of lactose , light but fizzi carbonation .

the bottle says red beer , but it certainly is n't a irish red . pours with very little head , but a bright red color not unlike wine , it almost looks artificially colored . drinkable , but nothing spectacular . recommended for uniqueness if nothing else .  has an okay color , but is not cloudy enough . i was hoping for something close to opaque , but it is just mildly cloudy . i 'd buy a sixer of this over a lot of sa 's beers , and it 's easily the best thing in the harvest pack ( even if the mediocre appearance is going to knock the score down a bit ) .  m- very , very thick and chewy . also quite heavy .

the smell is real nice , smokey coffee that makes me dive right in .  it came with a pale orange hue and a small off-white head .  everything blends nicely in ot 's thick , chewy , oily body . minimal carbonation here , and it works nicely .

s - corn , sugar , sweet malt , slightly floral . t - slightly better with less corn .  i was dissapointed with the appearance . when poured it did'nt reveal any type of head or lacing .  m/d : full creamy body with light carbonation , pretty drinkable for 9 % .

aroma is fabulous , even at this temperature . delicious . well worth the $ 6 canadian that i paid for it .  2010 vintage : appearance : brownish amber color , crystal clear , small 1 finger head with no lacing and little retention .  m - absolutely creamy and delectable ! the amazing , tiny bubbled froth envelopes and contains any alcohol sharpness that would otherwise make this 8.0 % beer a bit fiery in the swallow . superb . d - the mouthfeel makes this otherwise straight-up scotch ale an incredibly drinkable beverage . but be careful ! at 8 % , this beer is like getting a two-for-one special in each pint !

smell - smells absolutely delicious ! ! lots of fruit/wheat and some toasty nuts ... yumm , 5 for sure .  pours a clear , medium copper , very much like apple juice .  mouthfeel is where this one shines , smooth as can be and perfectly carbonated , a light yet creamy quality .
s : a little sweet citrus at the start followed closely by some pine . the best aspect of this beer for me .  good lacing , poor head retention .  m- full body in the mouth and sticky on the lips .

aroma is big sweet , multitudes of dark fruit , caramel and quiet peat moss . quadish exceptional highly complex flavor , something for everyone . sweetness not equal to the expectation from the nose . the evolution of the taste is significant .  poured with a little head , but after the initial head was gone , could n't get it back . no lacing at all .  m - perfect . excellent balance of thick and creamy yet smooth and light enough to drink without too much concentration .

clear yellow in apperance , plenty of carbonation bubbling to the surface . smell is like molded bread and wet grass.. or something like that . to me this is better than some of the more popular macro swill out there , even the self-proclaimed `` king '' .  nice oily sheen to this , along with some head retention & lacing s : chocolate , dark fruit , & some oakyness t : dark chocolate , oaky , a bit of iron & much dark fruit up front .  m- creamy smooth with just the right amount of carbonation and a nice , dry finish .

d : nice big i.p.a. , best smelling i have had yet , very flavorful and the malt has been kept in check and the hops can come right through .  the beer pours a translucent dark red color with no head at all .  wow . the thick and creamy mouthfeel is perfect for the winter months and so warm .

the nose on this thing is awesome . complex sweet fruits , sultanas and figs , some ginger , brown sugar , earth and alcohol .  slightly hazy light amber with a touch of off-white head . some rising bubbles and a touch of lace .  the mouthfeel is a true hallmark of this beer .

very unique . i could tell from smelling it that it was going to be sour , but had no idea the extent of sourness .  2011 vintage - 375ml bottle oh man , what a gusher . not a really great looking beer in the glass . mostly opaque brown , small ring and a thin island of foam once it settles .  mouth : velvety good . nice water . sweet , full , but not thick . medium to full bodied .

smell is super fruity sweetness , excellent complexities including wood , vanilla and a bit of alcohol . taste is an explosion of goodness . i love that barleywines come in 12oz bottles** , as that 's the size that i 'd prefer to have this style of beer in .  served in a hill farmstead tulip glass . a - minimal carbonation . thin-late rising wisp of bubbles that linger on top . not much of a looker here .  a bit astringent . fantastic , full body with a very creamy feel -- pretty impressive .

s : smell is the best part of this beer in my opinion . strong scent of hops . reminds me of some other good intoxicating herbs . i really love this hoppy goodness !  pours a hazy straw color with a one finger head that disappears into a ring around the glass smells of belgian yeast , wheat , and spicy esters .  the mouthfeel is chewy , thick and amazing and the light carbonation is just right .

just flat out wonderful , this is just an exceptional nose here . the nose on this is just flat out fantastic .  500ml bottle bought from the vineyard , belfast ... poured a nice rich coppery orange colour . creamy head with some rusty hints poured quite small and then faded to light wispy layer ... no lacing and no carbonation to talk about ... aroma - nice strong , lightly toasted , biscuity malts , toasty bread , juicy fruits ( figs , raisins , oranges ) , strong nutty notes , caramel / toffee sweetness , some sea saltiness , the faintest of dusty / smokey notes , peppery hops , grassy traces ... taste nice strong spicy / peppery hop bitterness , juicy and vinous fruits ( raisins , prunes , bitter oranges , apples ) , strong toasted bread notes , caramel maltiness , burnt sugar sweetness , nutmeg hints , malt loaf notes , woody / earthy hints , some grassiness ... feel - initial sharp bite then mellows out ... light / medium bodied ... very very refreshing and drinkable - excellent session brew at 4.3 % ... overall - an excellent bitter ... i wish i had bought a few more of these.. definitely recommended..  wonderful carbonation .

hops . a touch of skunk . excellent aroma . t- hops ( pine forward ) .  pours a very hazy , dark golden apricot/brown color with a half finger white head that quickly fades into a thin lasting ring . minimal spots of lacing left behind .  full creamy mouthfeel with a low carbonation . thick , thick mouthfeel .

the grapes come through again from the aroma but the flavour depth is n't as good as the nose . a decent ipa with lots of great aroma but lacking a bit of flavour . a really nice showcase of the nelson sauvin hop and a great idea from mikkeller .  pours a not-quite-clear straw color with a small head that rapidly diminishes .  mouthfeel : fully body , lower carbonation , love it .

hops are juicy smelling . very complex and citrus-fruity aroma . t : mmmm ! d : this is a tasty beer on the verge of being terrific . a solid offering , i would have a few of these .  the body pours quite a pale yellow , with a moderate haze and thinnish bone-white head .  taste again where do i start ... sweet , spicy dark fruits soaked in alcohol ( raisins , currents , dates ) , toasted caramel notes , bready , some brandy / rum traces , biscuity , warming alcohol , spicy hop bitterness forces itself through the sweet maltiness , light madeira wine hints ... feel - so silky smooth ... rich and creamy ... light viscousness.. low drinkablilty for this one - a beer for savouring and sipping slowly ... overall - a phenomenal beer ... highly recommended .

amazing smell -- coffee and chocolate dominate the aromas with some caramel in the background .  pours a clear , dark copper with one and a half fingers of a fizzy head that quickly peters out .  m- extremely smooth with the right amount of carbonation d- this one goes down too easily .

top of the line nose on this one , just fantastic . my first impression was damn ! the consensus was this was an excellent beer , & there was a marked difference once it warmed - a collection of `` yeah , it 's ok '' changed to `` damn , this is good '' after 10-15 minutes . really glad i got to try this one , thanks again tucker !  pours a two finger white head that fades slowly leaving traces of lace . cloudy almost pale amber color .  smooth grit with comfort .

the aroma seems to be pretty good , nice strong malt scent that gives off the idea of caramel also giving a sweet smell .  a : pours a nebulous reddish brown with a fast fading small head .  the mouthfeel of this beer might be its most remarkable consistency ; velvety , silken slickness .

very very unique beer , the nose right off the bat informs you of it . rich aroma of the carmel malts used , very heavy scent , but goes along nicely with the character of the porter . really good on a cold day in warm house kind of beer .  i heard such great things about this beer that i figured i should enjoy my first from the can . smooth ; very good for the summer . best canned beer i have ever had ( the rumors were true ) . recommended if you want a stronger pale ale for a backyard cook out , or a few beers doing house work .  in my mind , this is the perfect feel for an imperial stout .

s : extreme vanilla , boozy bourbon notes . otherwise this is solid . d : weighing in at 13 % abv , one gibcs could do you in ... yet , i think i could handle two ... and that 's saying a lot , especially after starting this session w/ one tripel karmeliet and one piraat ( both 33cl ) . an excellent extreme imperial stout .  a few nights later i got a bit drunk , and it was the last beer in the house and i still could n't stomach it . it tastes nothing like a saison should ( easy , grassy , and light ) , and aside from the category it is really undrinkable . my tasting notes were strong alcohol , rotten bananas , and wintergreen mouthwash .  the mouth feel is awesome . i let a full gulp roll around from cheek to cheek just to let my tongue play in the surf .

the aroma of this beer was the highlight for me : banana , apple , belgian yeastiness , other fruits ... really great . golden yellow in color with a small ring of head at the top after it settles . alcohol comes through very nicely . sweet aftertaste is enjoyable .  pour was decent with minimal head and very little lacing .  very thick with just enough carbonation that completely fills the mouth and leaves a bittersweet flavor lingering on the palate , and a bit of a syrupy feel on the back of the throat with just a bit of alcohol heat that is perfect for the style .

excellent . t- sharp hop bitterness with a floral blanket overall . slightly sticky d- smooth , smells great and tasts great .  pours a clear orange with a two fingers worth of fluffy head that subsided quickly . a good bit of lacing down the glass . this is a highly drinkable beer that masks the alcohol well .  m : wow ! just so damn smooth .

smell has a great malty dark fig aroma . very warm smell . taste is also very malty .  not much to look at . amber , a bit hazy , with a small white head , with some lacing . nothing to get excited over .  very palatable and no alcohol taste at all m - silky smooth , great carbonation .

it 's sitting across the table but throwing great scents my way hazy amber orange with some sudsy head juicyfruit aromas : immense , zesty citrus , mint . not much pine , which is a nice change from the norm . good , robust , woody bitterness ( it really hangs on the tongue ) with excellent hop depth . mint .  bottle w/ some bad ass artwork on the label ( i love flying dog 's illustrations ) cloudy golden color w/ a very thin head that quickly dissappeared to nothing , no lacing to speak of .  unbelievably smooth . feel is so outstanding for a heavy dark lager .

strong hoppy aroma with a floral hint .  appearance : the colour lays somewhere between burgundy and brick red , cloudy to the point of being murky in a way . thin bubbly lace has a pinch of pink colour to it , some champagne like bubbles force their way to the top .  the mouthfeel was very very thick and creamy and not as thin as say a sierra nevada .
overall a fantastic beer .  pours murky muddy brown with large bubbled brown head .  m - huge , thick , syrupy , creamy , perfect carbonation .

s- strong aroma of banana , clove , yeast , pear , bubblegum , wheat , nuttiness , and spice . complex and aromatic . t- banana , clove , pear , lots of spice , and the alcohol was surprisingly prominent , some warming . m- pretty high carbonation , crisp , finishes dry , drinks smooth o- first weizenbock i have ever had .  this is a great beer , an english friend gave me one to try , it was quite different from what im normally used to drinking but it was very good . not much more to say then whats already been said .  m : the best feature of this beer . rich , creamy , and silky as it goes down .

the aroma is crisp and clean with a light toasted grain aroma with only faint hints of grassy hops and a little bit of light fruit .  pours a hazy orangish-yellow color with a good head that dissipates quickly and leaves very little lacing ( poured from a bottle into a mug ) .  m- incredibly smooth with a nice carbonation .

it has a mild floral-yeast aroma with a smooth slightly fizzy foretaste and a clean finish .  the beer poured a hazy burnished amber with next to nothing of a head .  the taste is initially of a very light porter and with a clean aftertaste that becomes a fruit sensation on the palate . the hop/malt balance is the real achievement here and it really contributes to the supreme drinkability . the smell upon opening the bottle is not an effective contrival of the taste that this beer is hiding as it only gives you an idea of the rooted flavor that is to be unleashed , the supreme balance and sublime flavor . great bier .

it pours a cloudy golden orange color and smells delicious . the nose had hints of orange peel , coriander , hops and light caramel . drinkability was a little low though due to the over carbonation and the sweetness of the beer overall , but very good . will buy again  pours very dark brown , almost black with slightly effervescent light tan head , very small patchy downsliding lacing .  the mouthfeel is dry with a long and deep finish which is full of blackened malt and char . very very nice .

smell is thick hop resin , extremely floral and sticky . nicely complex , with a strong bitterness and sweet underlying malt character . taste is bitter , earthy , and vegetabley . the flavors are deep , dirty , and almost unpleasant .  batch 1 bottle 198 of 228 pours a cloudy peach color with a decently sized white head that slowly reduces to a ring of foam .  a - bright golden orange color with some chill haze present , two fingers of white frothy head that leaves thick froth-lace s - not too much rye here , just hints ... hops and bready malt t - hop bitterness up front , sweet bready malts in the back , only a hint of rye in the middle ... the malt backing is about as significant as it gets ... taste 's more like a straight up ipa than most rye beers i 've had m - hops tingle the tongue and give way to very thick , chewy malts that slide down nicely ... full-bodied and very enjoyable d - this is a reeeally well-balanced beer , i just wanted more rye flavor .

aquired through a trade with xpimptasticx , thanks wanted to try for a while a- well , it looks harmless , it looks like a regular dipa except it had hardly any head and no lacing but ... that 's where the similarities stopped s- incredible smell : blood orange , booze , hops on performance enhancing drugs and a faint mango in there t- sweet booze , like a orange hop liqueur or triple sec .  this brew arrived at my table essentially headless . lacing was very sparse .  m : one of the most enjoyable mouthfeels i 've ever had in a beer ; medium-bodied and moderately carbonated , immensely smooth and surprisingly creamy . d : i thought that the taste here was good , not great ... but the amazing mouthfeel and complex flavor keep drawing me back in , and at much faster rate than that of many beers whose tastes i prefer .

deliciously hoppy nose - massive sweet fruit backed with gritty , resinous hops . extremely fragrant , and powerful . palate is less robust , with a subtle , but pleasant hop character riding over the top of a smooth , buttery sweetness . this leaves it extremely drinkable - very smooth and refreshing . an excellent and tasty little ipa .  appearance : poured with a large light tan foamy bubbly head , that dissipated quickly to a thin layer leaving just about no lacing . the beer is a cloudy orange brown color .  s - sweet malt , molasses , licorice and red grapes t - sweet dark malt and licorice with a pleasant spice finish m - strong carbonation with a chalky finish that subdues the strong alcohol taste nicely d - very strong licorice and spice flavors combined with a great mouthfeel that balances the alcohol

smell reaked on alcohol/bourbon . however , surprisingly , it did n't taste like alcohol . extremely drinkable .  dark brown with light tan head - no real retention , and the head quickly faded away .  m/d - the mouthfeel and drinkability are exceptional . this is a simple brown ale that i could knock back one after the other .

smell is very spicy , orange , ginger and cinnamon as mentioned on the label , and a bit sweet . taste is plenty spicy and not sweet at all , more roasty , some toffee and a bit acrid .  it pours a nice light amber , maybe more of a copper in color . a tad disappointing with a slight head the did fade a bit , there is some slight lacing on the sides of my glass .  m : thick and creamy , the mouthfeel holds up to the indulgent theme set by the flavor .
fantastic stuff t- it 's ... really bitter ?  pours like black water .  m : very viscous and full . smooth carbonation and a nice stickyness make the mouthfeel very complimenting to the taste .

the smell is lovely grapefruit essence from the hops , and a small malt offset ; what an anticipatory aroma ! the malt influence is quite mild ; this is all about the hops , which i 've come to learn is n't always a grand thing .  appearance is dead jet coffee black with a tinge of orange/redness along the edges and little head or lacing . not much to look at .  t- pretty solid all around . very smooth , robust , and thick .

smell : very sweet with caramel and molasses . also , it is very floral with a nice hop aroma .  pours out pale yellow and sits a gloriously bright orange in the glass . a small , a forcefully poured white head sits on top , but is soon gone .  the mouthfeel is what really sets this apart . having had very few english cask ales , i do n't know if this is gold standard , but it is the best mouthfeel i 've had on this style beer .
very inviting , to say the least .  orange in color and cloudy . a pretty color to be sure but otherwise not outstanding . lots of sediment in the bottle , so pour carefully .  creamy but thin body .

smell : ridiculously aromatic , spicy/floral hops , as well a very fruity malt profile ( plums , berries , peaches ) .  picked this up at the biergarten in jenks : pours an effervescent apricot/caramel with 2 fingers of cream colored head . average head retention & lacing s : orchard fruit in abundance , burnt candi-sugar , peaches , green apple peels & honey , almost pulled a 4.5 t : persimmons , pears , white grapes , candi-sugar , a touch of brown sugar & dryness up front , some lemons & grassyness there as well .  mouthfeel is full but not too heavy .

a strong blonde ale . there may be hops , but very subdued .  appearance : hazy/cloudy amber orange with virtually no head .  great relaxed flavor , it has a nice sweetness to it , a good malt body ; it would be a great beer to drink while out on the river all day , as it has a wonderful flavor without having too much ( it was made with this in mind , according to one of the brewers ) . goes down extremely smooth with a great crisp , sweet aftertaste . ( had on-tap at the star city vfd brew fest fund raiser .

the aroma continues to provoke the senses with a luscious , mouthwatering perfume . its flavor had a tough time catching up to its exceptional aroma , but still came through with a graceful sequence of sweet malts modestly checked with a light hop scheme .  pours a cloudy amber-orange with a thin beige head , and some lacing .  t : the taste was about average for a stout , almost identical in flavor to guinness m : amazing mouthfeel , so creamy and so smooth .

the aroma is sweet fruits and some spice including coriander , orange peel is present as well .  it 's like an american dos xx = no slime ! it 's very drinkable and should be consumed with lime . just a great all around , drinkable beer .  mouth is extremely crisp , clean with tremendous carbonation and a nice light body .

the aroma on this beer was exceptional . cinnamon and plum came across strongly , along with hints of ethanol and orange rind . it had a nice bitter finish , but i struggled for awhile to get a handle on the sweet , fruit flavors that seemed to stay with the beer for the duration . i was thinking cherry with a few orange notes , it seemed very familiar , and then i finally put my finger on what it was reminding me of : cough syrup .  extremely dark with no head at all and no visible carbonation .  the mouthfeel on this ale was great , and i think the mouthfeel of just about any beer is enhanced by cask conditioning . it had a nice thick feel on the tongue .

a- straw pale yellow s- strange and unpleasant smell that i ca n't quite describe , although there were times i drank it and it smelled a little like vomit .  however , deep copper color with golden highlights . no foam .  smooth as hell , perfect weight and carbonation .

smell is of bourbon barrels , alcohol and some deep plum and cherry/chocolate on the nose . taste follows with notes of the barrel and a very lingering close ... nice.. good feel and the drinkability is extravagant given the potency , as the alcohol is present on the nose but not on the tongue .  pours a burgandy color with no head or lace .  mouthfeel is very full and round .

really delicious . 5 t : malty chocolate with some tangy fruit character from the blueberry .  a : pours a rather hazy , blonde yellowish colour . disturbing the settled yeast added a good amount of sediment to the pour .  the evil spirits pass by , leaving behind a faint citrus peel flavor as a reminder that they now own your mouth . it 's insanely smooth and creamy ... absolutely perfect in that aspect .

aroma is excellent . it 's full of fresh hops , citrus and pine .  a- hazy orange with hardly any head that dissapates quickly . i expect a huge head with a hefe but no matter how aggressive i pour , results are the same .  mouthfeel is very delicious with some creamy notes but some nice crisps and sharp grassy hop notes .

fantastic . i 'm a big fan of floral ipas , and not so into the bitterness . delicious . reminds me a lot of abrasive in this respect ( the floral/citrus vs. bitter balance ) , though not quite on that level .  what a quality ipa ! clear dark orange pour fresh from my sly fox growler into my sly fox pint ( now al i need are sly fox underoos and i 'm all set ! ) this growler was filled up two days ago . finally , this pour is topped off by a beige head that fades to a scant slick as i progress thru this one .  the mouth feel is perfect , medium-thin , medium-low carbonation .

aroma is big citrus , sweet fruit , tropical and juicy .  the color is very very dark brown , and a bit murky .  mouthfeel is really impressive . very gradual on the tongue and extraordinarily balanced .

the smell is close to overwhelming , but exceptionally pleasant nonetheless . oak , vanilla , toffee , caramel , dark chocolate , raisins , bourbon/brandy , and maybe a touch of cinnamon all alternately ( yet congruently ) jump out at you . quite a complex and interesting beer , the drinkablility is hard to judge due to the faux-thin nature of the body .  i was glad to see brew kettle still serving a pumpkin beer during my visit in late december ... seems like a lot of brewers plan to sell out of pumpkin beer by thanksgiving , and to me the flavor is appropriate through the new year . appearance-wise , it looked a great deal like the chief 's rye - not quite colorful enough in the amber body , and with a medium amount of head .  the mouthfeel is outstanding , substantial and even sticky .

raw in your face noble hop aroma . just amazing . poured a tiny bright white head that disappeared when i looked away . the hop flavor does n't approach the strength of the aroma , but that could be a good thing .  a - poured a caramely copper-colored body with modest carbonation and very little head that quickly disappeared and left no lacing .  mouthfeel : delightfully creamy and full-bodied . very pleasant .

i can also catch a slight nose of peaty scotch if i catch it the right way . fantastic aroma here .  got this beer on tap at the flying saucer . pours a yellowish amber body with finger width white head .  silky silky smooth on the mouth , it makes it feel as light bodied but if you take the time to get a feel it 's almost medium . just fantastic . o- this is deffinitely a good saison , the mouthfeel is the highlight .

the smell is phenomenal , with loads of tropical fruits , pineapple , passion fruits , grape , mango and green apples . this boquet is really amarillo , and everything amarillo can be . any possible malt-notes in the nose is totally subdued by this awesome onslaught of amarillo !  pours a dark brown root beer color with but sits opaque black in my glass . thin beige georgia clay colored head is quick to collar but leaves consistent tiny speckles of retention .  mouthfeel is incredibly smooth and creamy - almost reminded me of a nearly flat ginger ale , with more depth/body .

smell is strongly vanilla , delicious bourbon vanilla .  a - pours a deep brown with very distinct ruby highlights . thin off-white head and very little lacing .  just a hint of carbonation on the palate - utterly smooth .

the nose on this one is very strong . some pineapple , orange zest , and grapefruit along with some floral and piney notes . if this tastes as good as it smells , i 'm in for a sweet , citrusy treat . the taste is , unfortunately , not as juicy as the nose might suggest .  a : copper tangerine with just a touch of haze . poured vigorously but still could n't conjure a decent head . only a frail ring surrounds the glass .  a very heavy body that is infinitely swishable in your mouth and extremely creamy . this beer is truly fascinating .

forgot to mention , i hate the bottle a - sweet grassy aroma , grainy biscuts , the subtle sweet is throwing me off , not much of a hop aroma .  a - reddish brown brew with a big head and a little bit of scattered lacing .  all the great flavor of the bottled lhms here , but perfectly creamy and full in texture . this only further reinforces my belief that nearly every big beer should be served nitro .

that settles into a nice thick lace covering most of the glass yes it 's a chocolate stout and the aromas defiantly back it up lots of sweet chocolate aromas some earthiness to it along with some hint of roasted malts flavor 's of dark chocolate are dominate not overly sweet with a coffee backbone it 's got this mocha thing going on the mouthfeel is medium to thin would have liked it a little thicker this is really one of the great chocolate stout 's especially for under $ 5 a bomber well worth the experience  pours hazy reddish orange with a thin head that soon becomes patchy .  you can feel how well-crafted this beer is : perfect body ... thin , but not too thin ; carbonated , but not overdone ; hoppy aftertaste , but not a tastebud destroyer .

very very nice . very complex .  pours a light bronze with notable carbonation .  mouthfeel is thick as hell and creamy , perfect for a big ris this is smooth as hell , much smoother than beers with this much ash flavor usually are .

stoudt 's double ipa 12 oz bottle medium pour in a mug recent brewing , ingested 12/06 poured a hazy orange amber with a rocky off white fully lasting head with excellent lacing that left layered ring of lacing upon every sip , like reading the rings of on a tree and tracing it 's age . smelt of strong sweet grapefruit and orange , tropical pineapple banana bubble gum or starbust mystery flavor , parsnip , with light barnyard and earthy yeasty flavors . overall , a great dipa that balances a malt sweetness backbone and strong hops nicely .  opaque orangish gold color with a little one finger head which makes its exit quickly .  thin in the mouth but heavy on the tongue . perfect for the style and the season .

that bright yellow can is like a delicious beacon calling to me at the supermarket . the taste i 'll admit is n't hoppy , or even very stong but rather subtle and beautifully simple , zen if you will . a real guzzler that 'll quench your thirst without fucking you up too bad .  appearance : black liquid , more brown than red , with an adequate head and good lacing . could use a bit more head , and head colour is too pale .  the lush velvety texture takes control of your mouth .

smell : smells like a nice rich coffee from sbux with tons of caramel added .  bottle to sniffer appearance : pours with a small brown head that quickly dissipates , looks of black coffee the carbonation barley able to keep the head alive .  m - very smooth for such an alcoholic beer . disguises the bite very well .

aroma is grainy , husky malt with some caramel and not much else , rather mild on the nose . very clean finish and easy to drink . i wish the fruity flavors were just a little more robust and the aroma was more pronounced .  a - pours a slightly hazy straw color with one finger of quickly dissipating white head . very little lacing .  m - smooth , silky , full body with the perfect amount of carbonation o - great brew !

smells creamy/milky with rich , almost sweet coffee , chocolate , kaluha , cocoa , and a touch of green hops . absolutely divine . the flavor is roasty with burnt/charred malts , coffee , chocolate , and a medium bitterness .  but i was in a pils-y mood today and picked up some budweiser ( the real budweiser ) today and drank it before this guy , so i was worried about how it would hold up to that greatness . but it really is like comparing apples to oranges . troegs is a very faint , almost macro-lager yellow , almost definately not decoction mashed . like biting into an apple on a summer 's day . it does n't taste like an apple at all , but that is what it makes me think of . the mouthfeel is good for a pils . it 's a well made pils man .  the mouthfeel is the standout . it 's thinner but soo creamy and velvety . the oatmeal gave it the feel i had hoped .

very nice . smells light , not expecting much malt in the flavor . where are all those delicious hops i smelled ? as with many ipas , i find that it smells better than it tastes .  what foam there is settles quickly and after while this looks like espresso in my snifter .  mouthfeel - big , bold and smooth with lots of carbonation .

the aroma was very fresh , like a breeze on a river , ( stunning ! ) floral hops and hints of citrus along with caramel malt ; a sweet and inviting blend . muted orange rind , grapefruit notes and a doughy malt/yeast blend were present but the bitterness that sat atop them i found unpleasant .  kerberos is a tangerine orange , pretty cloudy . the head was small after a pretty vigorous pour , and did n't last too long . a small web of lace stuck to the snifter .  the mouth feel is amazing on this beer .

yes the smell in particular is very banana bread , the flavor less so , plus there 's a nutty bitterness which a bit overwhelms the banana .  a thin white head disappears before you can say royersford pennsylvania . lacing was good for the style .  mouthfeel : great thickness ; fully coating the mouth with great flavors . the mouth is great and just thick enough .

smells interesting and fun . the taste is floral and spicey .  rather short head with no retention or lacing and the faintest of foamy rings on the cap .  the mouthfeel was awesome with silky smooth liquid and superb carbonation .

i look at these two next to each other and woder if i have not walked into a paint shop and someone mixed my color swatch perfectly ... the aroma is fantastic . it has all the elments of a wonderful malt bomb , and just enough hop remnants to keep it interesting .  a- vigorous pour yields a thin layer of tan head sitting atop an opaque beer . no lacing is apparent as what little head there was dissipated rather quickly . nice job shorts !  the mouthfeel , though , was the best part . it fills your mouth with mousse like consistency with very round edges .

smell & gt ; sweet and resiny . a perfect balance of the two scents without much alcohol heat .  it poured a dark brown color and left just a 1 finger creamy tan head that soon disappeared to just a tan ring on top producing just a minimal of lacing . nothing exceptional about the pour or appearance .  m : medium in body with a really smooth and creamy feel on the tongue .

s - great smelling ! lots of nice fruit and hoppy deliciousness . overall , a fantastic beer . it 's odd that it 's an amber , as it tastes a lot like an ipa .  dense two finger head shows good retention but weak lacing .  the carbonation is perfect . i love this .
smell is pretty dang good . smells like cherries and more cherries .  pours a pale , clear , gold/yellow with almost zero head .  mouthfeel . amazing , thick rich and seems sweet but comes together .

apricot golden body , tiny hop flecks visible and a classic ivory creamy , spritzy cap . the nose is very aromatic like a freshly prepped bowl of ambrosia . lots of ripe citrus in the nose , specifically tangerine and ruby red grapefruit . the taste is crisp , hoppy and i could tell upon first drink the mouthfeel is superb . i 'll say it , it 's overrated a little .  bottle poured into a snifter a- yellow with a white two finger head . looks like a light beer not a double ipa .  m : the feel is excellent with fine carbonation lending a creaminess that is top-tier and a clean scrubbing finish with the right balance of crispness and aftertaste . d : an fine tripel with classic light fruit flavors mixed artfully with pepper and spice and a top-notch mouthfeel compose a very good brew .

nose reveals a unique combo coffee beans , dark fruits , brown sugar and roasting malts .  appearance : bronze with a coarse , thinning beige head .  mouthfeel : low carbonation leads to thirsty gulps .

instead , the color of this beer is peach . you can smell the raspberries . maybe it might my description of the color that 's playing the jedi mind trick with me , but i swear i smell peaches as well . there 's also a bit of biscuit behind it all . this does n't taste as nearly good as it smells . the fruit flavors you get on the nose are seriously muted on the tongue .  appearance - three fingers of quick rising head are noticeable immediately . a very transparent lager-looking beer . caramelly yellow that looks sweet and inviting .  the first thing i noticed actually was the incredible mouthfeel .

aroma is nice . light caramel .  good initial head , but it dissipates to a single layer . the lace is spotty and light .  m : the best part of the beer . very creamy while still having a touch of that hop thickness you want .

wonderful aromas of fresh pumpkin pie ! i could really smell the spices of nutmeg and cinnamon , plus the fresh smell of carved pumpkin to round out the spice . t- pretty much tasted like it smelled but not as pronounced . it 's easy drinking , great autumn flavors and smells ... .a real pleasure to drink !  pitch black with a thin mocha head that disappears instantly . no lacing , pretty standard stout appearance .  incredible mouthfeel .

this is one of the five winter beers offered at cambridge brewing , an irish dry stout . it 's drinkable like all the other dry stout , and quite tasty to boot .  a : deep orange-brown , murky to the point of opacity in some spots , with a minuscule head of fizzy light tan that becomes a thin ring within seconds .  mouthfeel is probably the best part of this beer .

aroma is powerfully sour and very champagney . this is a very good beer , and quite a unique one .  a - poured a dark copper with a one finger khaki head and no visible carbonation . no retention and slight lacing .  still i thought the aroma was alittle weak , but once it hits your mouth it is amazing .
aroma : very sweet smelling . hard for me to pick up on the spices they used . slight phenol notes .  pours a nice rich brown , not much head .  super easy going down with a perfect dry finish .

s : grainy malt , not too exciting . t : creamy smooth malt with bitter hops . o : well , you 'll get what you pay for , and this one came cheap .  this one pours a dark and murky , dirty gold in color .  medium bodied beer combined with very active and tight carbonation combines to create an exceptionally creamy beer .

nose is simply stunning . soaring sour limeade with an intense barnyard element , a good smack of leather , and just a hint of very sweet malt .  a hint of wheat in the flavor and the wheat bitterness that i guess is part of the beer . this beer makes me want to go back and try another sweet water blue ( a beer i didnt like much on the first go ) a beer i could drink some of i think , would pick it up for a pick-me-up .  hard to imagine this almost perfect mouthfeel sticking around too long .

as it warmed , it ran the gamut of aromas from root beer , estery banana , and authentic wet vanilla sticks . it starts off offering complex flavours and aromas , but the alcohol comes through more as it warms up , and the nuances become more muted .  cloudy caramel colour with little to no head .  perfect silky creamy carbonation .

smell is a wonderful grapefruit burst .  this poured a nice cloudy slightly yellow with little head ( where 's the head ?  the finish lingers for a while , almost spicy with a slight alcohol burn m - pretty ideal for this style i thought .

s - the aroma is pretty impressive , and accurately captures the smells and intricacies of apple pie .  comes to a light orange with a head that quickly dissipates . not quite opaque with carbonation coming through .  a thick , milky mouthfeel , with tiny , spritzy carbonation carrying the rich flavor through your mouth .

a - black with a huge coffee colored head s - smells delicious - very sweet , chocolate malts . the most balanced smell to a stout i have had the pleasure of knowing .  dark , almost black with no head yet nice lacing .  outstanding mouthfeel ! very drinkable .

how many citrus fruits are there ? this one has aromas of all of them -- i 'm picking up kumquat , grapefruit , lime and tangerine ( piney rind ) at the very least . all those citrusy hops i smelled are seriously restrained in the taste . from classic to extreme , from belgian to beefy american , from populist to just plain weird , dogfish head 's got it all . i 'd be their bitch in a heartbeat .  black in color with virtually no head , the look is n't doing it for me . perhaps the lack of head is a result of the mallow garnish ?  nice touch of bitterness lingers as i contemplate the rich , full mouth feel . nice beer , much more approachable than the expedition .

s- probably the most disappointing part of this beer , the smell is so faint that i ca n't pick out any specific notes .  pours a light copper with a soapy light tan head . poor retention and scant lacing .  the best part of the rwanda gatsinga coffee stout is in my opinion the mouthfeel which is extremely smooth and leaves a pleasant malty coffee-dominated aftertaste and a smile on your face .

s - roasted grains , caramelized sugar , wood smoke , charcoal , fireplace and campfire aromas abound ! wonderfully smoky , earthy , outdoorsy , and roasty ! i also smell some nice cheese notes hidden behind the smoke , and some solid hops are there too .  very small , quickly evaporating head and absolutely no lacing .  smooth and rich on the tongue .

s - sweet , malty nose with strong notes of molasses . smelling this blind i would not have guessed ipa .  the beer pours deep amber brown with a thin white head that dissipates quickly leaving no lace .  entering the mouth , i immediately take notice of the huge mouthfeel on this . this is fluffy , powdery , quaffable , and has this charming soft carbonation that is typical of great beers . palate displays a superb spicy bitterness executed in incredible balance and harmony ( this and the mouthfeel are the 2 attractions imo ) , gentle woodiness .

this had a wonderful nose of tropical fruits , sugars , and malts , with a little herbal hop bitterness thrown into the mix as well . the taste was more of the same , fruity , sweet and delicious . this did have a medicinal , somewhat metallic , after taste though that kind of reminded me of orval .  12oz bottled poured into a dfh pint glass a : orange/amber hue that surprisingly leaves little to no head .  m - exceptionally impressive mouthfeel , it 's extremely smooth and rich tasting .

smell : oddly this beer has no aroma , nothing . it 's rather scary , but i had my nose way down into this beer and i could n't smell anything .  poured a hazy orange/dark peach color , providing not much of a head and leaving behind hardly any lacing to speak of .  perfect carbonation to it .

the smell is amazing ! ! very nice indeed . mouthfeel is medium light with a healthy amount of carbonation and a dry finish .  pours a really fizzy white head over a cloudy peach-colored liquid .  great mouthfeel - full yet fluffy , almost leaving my tongue numb .

s - roasted malt , chocolate , coffee and cream . t - yes !  pours a light gold with little head and just a bit of bubbles floating to the top . decent lacing on the way down .  m- full , smooth mouthfeel .

the smell- incredible . at first , very sweet smelling- hints of pineapple . for such a strong beer , it finishes very abruptly , leaving you with just a tad of malt . overall , incredible .  this beer tastes like bacon if bacon = good and beer = good and this beer = bacon then for you , the beer = good if you do n't like bacon , do not get this beer .  ideal texture for an ipa .

smell is amazing ! nice and sweet and very hoppy . very appealing and aromatic . a very good blonde .  a : dark brown beer with a very small layer of tan head that rapidly dissipates . small flecks of floaties are evident in the beer ... not a pretty sight .  mouth-feel was velvety smooth and creamy .

sweet and very appealing like a hopslam . t - taste is a bit different than the smell and reminds me of pliny the younger . very good . o - i think this is a very fine dipa .  my first ballast point . a- hazy dark gold topped with dog slobber .  the mouthfeel is excellent . it has a medium body and good carbonation .

exquisite critrusy , lemony aroma ; actually smells 'juicy ' . just amazing . flavour consists of traditional hefeweizen attributes with the addition of citrusy , american style hops .  pours a bright , clear straw sunshine yellow . very quick , spongey head and one string of bubbles .  mouthfeel- medium bodied ale for sure and had small amount of carbonation . very creamy , and left a easy feel on the tongue .

smells of yeast and light hops .  had this out of a bottle poured into a weizen glass ... a : hazy darker yellow color with a small , quickly fading head ... nice lacing .  this has an excellent mouthfeel .

this smelled like the kitchen while my mom bakes banana bread .  gold color capped by a thin head . it does n't look as bright as i expected so i take a closer glance . i see a fine haze of tiny particles in the glass , though i only poured in half the bottle .  m : very smooth and full bodied with a low carbonation .

s : best nose on a dipa i 've ever experienced . the alcohol is actually a complement to the hop aroma , however . this is one of those `` i wish this was an air freshener '' aromas . t & m : flavor is interesting -- some herbal and grassy hops , some notes of citrus , and a good smattering of pine . it does n't seem to be as balanced as stone ipa , but it 's still pretty tasty . the mouthfeel is very nice -- a sticky , full , and lasting feel with a long finish .  poured into a tulip glass . dark opaque effervescing with a slight reddish hue .  mouthfeel is absurdly rich and creamy , silky smooth and slurpalicious . ) it 's the best feature of this brew . i mean , i like the taste , love the mouthfeel , and would enjoy having two or three of these , but that abv is on the high end .

not much aroma , but what is there is a little wheat and breadiness , and a dash of grassy hop aroma . taste is bready , with a nice grassy , floral hop bite and bitterness . miles better than the aroma . feel is light and crisp , clean and has a nice refreshing quality about it . drink ability is high , though it 's nothing particularly stellar .  this -bal barleywine pours with almost zero head .  mouthfeel : perfection . the bead is neither too large nor too small .

smell is on the sweet side but hoppy as well , sweet bubblegum scent , weed , juicy citrus and a malt punch , great scent . taste is enjoyable , alot of different things balancing sweet and hoppy in that order with the above mentioned scents going into the taste without the weed .  a- slightly hazy and yellow with some floaters in there .  some of the best damn mouthfeel you will ever get in a beer too .
aromas are slightly amber malt , chocolate and coffee .  hazy lemon yellow color . white head which recedes fairly quickly leaving some lacing .  m - perfect for a porter .

the aroma is full on citrus hops . love it . the flavor is much more balanced than the nose . the citrus blast is there but the malt `` grinds '' away at it . overall another great beer from surly .  the beer 's appearance was a little bit of a letdown , there was almost no head at all even with an aggressive pour . below the beltline everything was all right , the beer was pale yellow and hazy , almost looked like a wit .  added points for excellent mouthfeel and drinkability .

great chocolate smell as soon as the cap came off , smelled just like a candy bar .  the beer pours an opaque light copper capped by a minimal off white head . there 's very little retention , despite a robust pour into the glass .  ( m ) mouthfeel is perfect for this beer .

aroma is great . i really get a spicy sage aroma on this one . a sweetness from the herbal notes really plays perfect with this one . really a perfect nose . taste is spot on too .  poured chilled in tall pilsner glass a : little carbonation ; minimal head ; clear , solid yellow s : clove , yeast ; inviting aroma t : dry , spiced , medium hops ; light on the belgian side of things ( e.g. , bottle conditioning ) ; not very intense flavor overall , a good solid beer , drawing sound inspiration from the belgians .  excellent mouthfeel and not too heavy .

nose : oaky vanilla , caramel/toffee and apple skins dominate this so-called imperial ipa . insanely sweet and syrupy like most of dfh 's `` super beers '' ( ww stout , raison d'extra ) .  by the looks of this bottle , this thing has some age to it . poured slightly thick , reddish-brown in color with no head .  i really this the mouthfeel is perfect on this beer .

very resilient aromatics , wonderful . taste - a brief sweet malt start goes nowhere before some serious hops kick in .  pours a beautiful deep brown , very little head quickly recedes- no lacing .  m- feel is exceptionally clean and smooth .

syrupy but not in an over the top fashion . s. phenomenal , tons of coffee , vanilla caramel and sweet chocolate , with a sense of dryness . there is a lot of complexity in the nose , i like it . t. sweet bourbon , oak dryness , all smells mentioned above , bitter coffee all the way through al little rough on the mix of flavors but still great . creamy and crunchy . i would categorize this along with bell 's expedition stout as being a bad boy of the style . its not a smooth and user friendly drink .  a : golden-yellow , fizzy white head , no retention , very little lace .  regular boris has the most incredible smooth palate and this follows suit . so silky smooth from the oatmeal . definitely an interest beer for this alone .

the nose on this evoked some memories of the amazing speedway stouts i had during sdbw with their vanilla and their toasted coconut variations .  a : pours a dark chestnut hue with just no head . no noticeable carbonation or lace .  m : awesomely smooth .

lively grapefruit , bright citrus notes abound . what a lovely burst of pineapple and fruit aromas . so very inviting . taste - resin and oily entry , coating the tongue with the expected presence of hops to the max .  not too much retention of the white head , but did pour a nice light amber color that was very clear . not much lacing to be seen .  it has a wonderfully creamy mouthfeel that makes each sip a pleasure .

s : the best component of this beer , gratifying spices on top of a light roasted malt . d : good smell and its light make for easy drinking , but i would prefer more commanding flavors and spices .  i was not able to get much of a head , even with a fairly aggressive pour , and really not much lacing .  mouthfeel is lucious : creamy and oily , rich in the mouth , but smooth enough to want more and more .
smell : very , very fruity ! it smells almost as good as a lady .  pours a pissy macro-ish yellow .  excellent body d - pretty solid imperial amber / ipa ( ? ) .

smell : strong spice and citrus , bubble gum taste/mouthfeel : thin but refreshing , banana , spicy hops this witbier was very good . i think the appearance of the beer itself lacks a little but the smell and taste makes up for it .  pours a murky brown-fuschia with an odd colored pink/brown head . not exactly a looker .  the mouthfeel was buttery smooth as silk with full body and low carbonation .

s : off grains , slightly metalic .  appearance : poured with some off white foamy head that dissipated quickly after leaving almost no lacing at the top of the glass .  the carbonation is spot on and that 's what makes the mouthfeel .

overall , the aroma is wonderful , the flavor is almost there , but the harsh bitter finish leaves you afraid to take another sip .  the appearance wasnt much , it looked quite like a lager .  mouthfeel is perfect . not too thick and good carbonation .

sour cherries , fresh-pressed apple cider , mild marble rye , yeasty esters and a faint touch of alcohol . complex and rewarding . effervecent and envigorating without overwhelming the tongue . much lighter than the appearance would lead you to believe and it resembles many other belgian-style ales in this regard . maybe not everyone 's cup of tea but i find it to be immensely drinkable and the alcohol is hardly noticable . quite good .  pours cloudy gold with almost no head . the color is decent , but when compared to the billowing , fluffy heads of grand hefes , it 's not really that great .  where this brew really stands out is the creamy mouthfeel . that smoothness works to perfection with sweetness , but does n't work quite as well with bitterness .

aroma : lush and full of fruit , beautiful and deliriously deep , slightly spicy , with further fruity develops , cherries and berries , but burnt . juicy hops and rich malt jump out through the nose , a perfect barleywine bouquet .  got a decent head however is was pretty weak and died quickly . coloring is light yellow that i did n't expect at first but now i see this is a pilsner thinking it was a pale ale . i guess corn ? this beer is solid !  very excellent mouthfeel and drinkability .

before i can even look more i smell fresh roasted coffee . incredibly nose on this beer .  pours a clear yet deep amber with a fast two finger , receding head . very little bubbling and no lacing , but good color though .  it 's definitely thick , but it does n't feel anywhere near as syrupy as it looks . o : this beer has a great appearance and mouthfeel .

the smell is aggressive , and with high standard , quite classic . a vanilla character from the oak treatment adds nicely to the vibrant sweet malty caramel butterscotch toffee brown sugar molasses notes . really nice ! ! the flavor is quite nice as it reflects the nose yet has a surprisingly black licorice thing going on , especially in the really enjoyable aftertaste .  a- slightly hazy light amber with floaties , and a half finger head .  it is a full bodied beer with perfect carbonation .

delicious citrus fruits with resin-y sweetness in the background -heavenly . d : a little too off-balance to be gulp-able , but certainly a yummy beer .  pours a cloudy gold color with a minimal head that dissipates quickly .  full bodied and silky .

quite awful , stale hops and malt .  appearance is average , but with sticky lace all around . for a beer that has this distribution , and sheer volume , this one has an awesome aroma .  the mouthfeel was amazing . nearly full-bodied .

amazing . t : sweet malt that has plenty of peat flavors that i love so much in scottish ales .  review based on notes batch 002x1 pours a hugely effervescent brown/chestnut with a rapidly falling tan head ; a great beer to listen to ... nice viscosity to this , a touch of lacing & zero head retention s : much sourness , , leather , figs & candied cherries t : tartness , cherries , dryness ; leather , raisins & figs up front , plus a touch of leafy hops .  feel is really nice as well , lightly creamy and buttery with super calming smoothness and a bit of chewyness with a slightly bread dough drying in the finish .

very interesting . concrete and ginger . refreshing and smooth but a bit more bland than i expected based on the wonderful aroma . nicely mellow and subtle .  pours black with virtually no head , just a light tan froth that leaves minute dots of lacing .  m - creamy and rich . the carbonation is very laidback ... almost feels as if it floats on the tongue . very soft ... puffy , in a way .

pours a hazy amber/orange color with a small white to light yellow head , very bubbly . nose is amazing , fresh and fruity , mango , grapefruit , pine and sweet fruit juice . taste is much less fruity than the nose , but it 's still top notch , for a regular ipa it sure packs a hop punch , very bitter and palate tingling . a really nice addition to lawson 's hoppy line up !  the beer pours a dark brown color with a frothy beige head foaming up and fading quickly to an edge layer .  m - creamy and full in the mouth , so good , this is just what i want in a marzen .

s : chocolate covered cherries , vanilla , mocha , amazing ! t : huge vanilla ( a little much for me ) , oak , bakers chocolate , mocha .  the color is a pale straw yellow with a nice white head .  mouthfeel is incredibly thick and heavy , like drinking warm honey .

2008 vintage a- almost stout-like in appearance , no head , fizzy swirl of carb in the middle of a color-devoid structure ... s-vanilla , cherry , oak , intense , strong , amazing smells ... .omg ... .there is n't a single hint of sour beer behind this nose . simply smooth vanilla and cherry ... awesome ... .ca n't remember a better nose on a sour ... . t- starts off smooth , nothing much going on *served at 39 degrees f.* then spice , phenols , tartness , tanginess , oh man ... this is great ... . m- solid brick of a mouthfeel , with a few glimmers of carbonation ... nothing exceptionally nasty about the 'brick ' that i speak of , but it is different ... .all together a different beer but for mouthfeel , i 'd expect something flat to taste like this , but in all it provides the right amount of carbonation ! duchesse on crack ...  when poured with vigour , it ends up a pale and bright golden colour , with minimal head , although what 's there leaves some very dense and intricate lacing .  fantastic mouthfeel .

s : wow , this beer smells amazing . whiskey and bourbon dominate the nose . i could literally sit here and smell this beer for the 15 minutes and be perfectly happy .  pours a dark brown-ruby colour .. stable head , covers the top like a blanket .. dark semi-sweet malt and lots of peach , fresh and burnt , nice !  m : medium body with a fantastic carbonation balance ! amazing here !

a : pale straw and crystal clear . s : not much of anything . a hint of corn and cereal grain .  had this on-tap at ccb 's tasting room during the hunahpu release even on september 24 , 2011 . a : very dark brown , almost black body with a superficial tanned coffee head that dissipated quick . no lacing present . o : it was a good way to start the evening with this beer , which definitely starts shining after it warms up a bit .  the taste starts with a slight carbonation . the carbonation builds to reveal a sweet velvet feel . a milk chocolate flavor with a roasted finisht showcases a great mouth on this beer .

smell : the wonderful aroma starts with the smell of concord grapes . holy hell , this liquid smells amazing . its like a huge fruit salad mixed with brandy and raisins ! taste : so does it taste as good as it smells ? well , the taste is of plums , raisins , and maybe prunes .  it pours a very dark brown with some reddish hues . th head is about 1 fingerand is more white than tan .  m : perfect . it 's thick without being cloying .

s ) pumpkin pie ... this really has it covered . this is spiced , but not over the top , which made me very happy . a very nice balance of pumpkin and beer . this is quite smooth . nice finish and aftertaste . o ) i have n't really had many pumpkin beers , but i 've heard good things about this one , so i finally gave it a shot . i 'm really glad i did .  it poured a very dark brown , and is black in the glass , with no highlights . the head is disappointing . very thin , tan , and does n't last at all .  taste & mouthfeel : smoothness is impeccable within the moderate body , big doughy biscuity malt flavour is the showcase of this brew .

aroma is exceptional , with a great sweet citrus smell that bursts from the bottle and makes you want to take a huge gulp . this is n't a horrible beer , and if you love bitterness , you should love it .  there is a decent amount of head but it dies down quickly .  full bodied , super creamy and smooth . very nice .

huge sweet and bready malts rise to the nose upon an initial whiff .  on tap at o'briens pub 09/15/11 a : my pint arrived looking black as night upon first glance . a closer study reveals a thinning root-beer brown rim to it . you ugly !  the silky smooth mouthfeel was fantastic and carbonation was spot on .

smell : strong coffee , roasted malt , sweet molasses , and some sweet dark berry aroma at the end . very small amount of alcohol towards the end .  pours a slightly hazey dark yellow with a fast head and good bubbling .  ( m ) - this is ridiculously smooth despite its hop dryness and woody bite . great carbonation level and balance .

smell : this beer has an exceptional aroma of toffee leather tobacco cocoa , burnt caramel and coffee .  not very much head on this one , but a little lacing .  the mouth feel was excellent and one could tell the cask was being maintained properly .

i have to say that the smell of this is fantastic . t : wow , the taste is a bit of surprise .  a- pours a nice shade of a light amber/orange with a paper thin white head that immediately fades . looks good , but the head situation is greatly disappointing .  mouthfeel : excellent light and crisp mouthfeel which is perfect for this style .

the aroma is slight but hoppy , with some pine to it . the flavor is surprisingly light , with piny hops and a tinge of bready malt .  a : this beer poured a nice , brown-red colour . i was glad that the colour was nice to look at because the head barely bothered to make an appearance .  mouthfeel is quite exceptional .

great smell good apperance .  a - holy crap a lot of foam . point deduction for gushing . pours a very dark brown with a thick tan head .  m - medium body and low carbonation , so incredibly smooth . perfect mouthfeel .

probably the sweetest ipa i 've run across . aroma of candy and berries . nicely hopped with clear strawberry and other berry notes .  pours a rich gold color with just a hint of haze . creamy stark white head is minimally resilient . not much lace on this one .  m : great carbonation feel with a nice medium body . amazing here . perfect !

the smell is intense and wonderful , very unique and really lends to the overall quality of this beer .  pours with about a quarter inch of medium colored head which recedes very quickly to a film .  good and special beer , cloudy , double fermentation , yeast , hops , malt and wheat are present in smell ; taste fruity , and floral like grassy and herbs ; good for mexican haute cuisine , try with pasta and salads ; mouthfeel exceptional , well balanced and litlle strong for the palate ; 96 % recommended .

nose is very full and really inviting . aromas jump out of the glass a buttery toffee . a big abv sipper with a great nose . sorry jay-bone , just did n't cut it for me .  appearance : hazy and somewhat cloudy yellow ... a decent head .  mouthfeel is very crisp and smooth with some thickness from the yeast and bite from the hops .

pours a deep amber ruby body with a nice modest off white head . smells of a massive combination of strong barley wine and oak . there 's flavors of raisons , plums and caramel on the nose with lots of vanilla and toasted notes from the oak . bourbon and dark fruit play out initially .  appearance : a hazy yellow , head fades fairly quickly , and there 's not much lacing . aside from the color it 's nothing fantastic .  mouthfeel is full bodied and super smooth . very enjoyable .

floral pine caramel . t : at 99 ibu and 6 % i was expecting a hop bomb that was crazy unbalanced but the scottish golden grain holds up against the hops . real bitter and dry mouth with a little astringent flavor d : besides my mouth being super dry and bitter its a great session beer . one of the best ipas ive had considering the flavor of the beer .  poured from 12oz bottle into 20oz brooklyn brewery branded tulip pint glass . appearance : dark cola color with a small tan head that dissipates quickly and leaves a ring of lace .  mouthfeel is exceptional ! this beer is smooth , silky , creamy .

i 'm usually a light beer drinker ( meaning color -- i would n't touch `` light '' beer ) but on a whim i got this brew because it is local . it 's an amber beer and it puts all light beers to shame . it has great body and what i like most is there is no bitter aftertaste . gerst brew has an incredibly clean finish and it is highly drinkable !  poured from a 12oz bottled in 2009 a : pours a deep red orange color with a small white head that dissipates quickly .  m. just perfect for what it is . very smooth and thick .

the yeast notes are exquisite . not very earthy , mostly ripe fruit with a bit of funky complexity .  i poured this one from a 12oz brown bottle into a shaker pint glass . a= this ale poured a very clear golden color ( filtered i would say ) with a fairly low carbonation release and a 1/2 '' white head . the head dropped to zero very quickly and did not leave any lacing behind .  each sip of this full bodied beer is smooth and creamy with light carbonation . this beer is so smooth it goes right down .

the smell had plenty of hops notes , primarily pine and fresh cut grass but there was a very unpleasant acrid note as well .  pours out to a clear dark brown , forming a modest light khaki head with average to poor retention and minimal lacing .  mf - perfect ! soft carb .

it has the wonderful spicy aroma that the style should always have . slight phenols , cloves , a sweet bready malt and a beautiful underlying fruitiness are all there . it finishes very very clean and does n't linger at all .  hope i gave you something good.. a - pours a very hazy brown with small white head that latched onto the side of the glass .  the mouthfeel is silky smooth and really rounds the beer out nicely .

c : thick and dark h : jet black n : hellllooo cognac ! hints of coffee and roasted malt huge thanks to hopscotch for sharing this barrel aged treat that is good till 2020 ? really ? will the world still be in existence in 2020 ? did you order an imperial stout with your cognac ? this approach is often reversed by brewers , as people like to have the abv hidden in big beers .  pours an amber brownish tint that holds an inch thick white cap .  mouthfeel : the mouthfeel is outstanding . it sparkles just enough to give the palate a good tickle , but not so much that it scrapes away all of its flavor .

the aroma is of peat , caramel , nuts , and chocolate . i really like the uniqueness of this aroma . the taste has more caramel than the aroma . overall , this is a really , really good scotch ale .  copper-orange pour with a small off-white head .  very light carbonation and a perfect body for a porter , combined with what i have already mentioned , makes this a very drinkable proposition .

the smell is of overwhelming vanilla and roasted malt , there is a sweet malt smell as well .  i got a growler to go to assess . pour is a slightly hazy darker golden color . nice carbonation nose is alot of spice with a hint of citrus . i 'm a big dopplebock fan , but i liked this more than their dopplebock , it 's that good .  mouthfeel : perfect , just like champagne .

s. smells like christmas . hints of cloves , allspice , and roasted nuts .  on tap @ the office in cranford 01-16-09 a- bright golden color , a lot of carbonation , when i 'm at a regular bar drinking this i almost feel like i 'm one of the bmc crew but if they only knew ... s : yeast hops and some sweetness from the malt .  m : glorious . so creamy and good . reminds me of a cask pour .
smell : sweet in it caramel and rum raisin like scent .  absolutely no head on the pour .  perfect in this sense .

it smelled of the mediterranean sea and beautiful , long-legged , not to be fucked with , italian women with sensuous lips . a very sweet , lemony ipa that is excellent for what it is , and enjoyable , for a time .  appearance was n't much . dark gold , big bubbles in the head , retained some , but not great lace .  the mouthfeel is full and warming , in fact , this beer is a huge belly warmer .

just unbelievable . on the palate the beer is very good , but does n't blow my socks off . very nice beer from stone brewing .  pours murky burnished copper , bit of brown seeping in , with a thin , soapy tan head on top , that at least lasts for quite awhile on its own .  m - this is one of my favorite parts so far about this brew . moderate amounts of carbonation that whirls around your tounge and warms it in the process .
aroma : incredibly aromatic , rich bitter chocolate , fresh roasted coffee beans , smoked oak chips , burnt caramel , woody .  demon fish , 750 ml bottle .  mouthfeel is fantastic .

spices that remind me of christmas with fruit tones . not much in the way of malts .  it pours a lovely clear caramel brown with red highlights . very little head sits on top , and what little there is disappears almost immediately .  a nice chewy , creamy malt backbone makes each sip a pleasure .

just excellent .  tasting notes from 12/11/10- ( cask ale ) pours hazy yellow in color with a small off white head that faded quickly ; basically zero lacing , as it all slid down very fast .  m- creamy and full-bodied . what else would you expect from the style ?

this smells amazing . like perfumed hop elephants . but damn ... this smells amazing . i could inhale this all day . which sounds odd .  a - raspberry/brown color , not head nor lace .  excellent medium mouthfeel , that is slick yet dry - i could drink many of these but i am confident that time will lend complexity -- - please !

s : pumpkin pie baby ! very nice . t : pumpkin spice , clove , nutmeg and caramel from the malts .  pours dark brown with very little head .  mouth : full mouth on this one , just right for this style of beer .

lots of aromas , raisins , plums , maple sugar candy .  since i have said it for all of the other beers i 've reviewed in this category , i will say it for this one as well : pours a clear , piss-yellow color with a small white head . head disappears quickly and leaves no lacing whatsoever . it 's my first asian beer , but when comparing with any of the american and mexican macros and even a lot of the europeans , this is top class .  the texture is amazing . thick and silky , but because of the low abv , drinking this is just too easy .

it has a pleasantly pungent , complex smell . all sorts of flower and herbal along with some mint .  somewhat murky brown color-good orange to amber highlights .  sweetness with great balance . great example of what a tripel is supposed to be . drinkability : extremely smooth and creamy , incredibly so , on par with a westy blonde . extraordinary tripel !

smell is where it breaks down . took forever to find any smell at all and then only some malt and light hops .  my first brew from four friends , on-tap at flying saucer charlotte served in a standard pint glass a dark amber with a thin quickly diminishing head .  great full and luxurious mouthfeel , witha soft , albeit intense carbonation that really lifts the brew .

; ( the aroma was almost non existent - a major flaw in any ipa and what i could smell was mild butterscotch and a spritz of earthy hop . i swirled and stuck my face in - i got nuthin . a very mediocre beer , with bland and generic sort of flavor .  cloudy , dirty orange color .  what i really loved was the mouthfeel . very good for a lager style beer .

nose is quite complex with some really nice notes of oak , vanilla , chocolate , roasted malt , and some light coffee . the taste does n't mix these together quite as well , but is still tasty . great feel coming from all different directions and quite drinkable for the big beer that it is .  above average head retention & below average lacing s : huge fruittyness : apricot , grapes , & candy sugar t : candy sugar , honey , apricots , with leafy & lemony hops up front .  first sip reveals a smooth and slightly creamy texture , carbonation is almost non-existent as cask ale should be .

very nice and original beer - more body would have been better but still a great treat from a great brewery .  i had this beer with lunch at whole foods today and it really was good down to the yeasty sediment at the end . the beer came out a light golden color with a million little bubbles like good champagne .  m- wonderfully creamy . the carbonation is spot on . one of the creamiest belgian beers i can think of .

well i did a polish spread today with some locally made sausage and perogies and beer braised cabbage i decided to pick up a polish lager beer to go with it.poured into a .5 liter stein a glowing light golden with a nice fluffy one finger head that dissapated quite quickly leaving a trace amopunt of lace , i really didnt care for the aromas somewhat skunked in character although it wasnt some toasted grain and as some others of noticed like adjunct corn.the flavors are better somewhat sweet and grainy with a little alcohol sharpness in the finish although i dont know the alc % it creeps up at lets itself known , a little biscuity and raw in the finish.poland is vastly underrated in its lager production thats the conclsion i have come to they make damn good baltic porters and strong lagers this is better than average and quite food friendly , people try some polish brews i think you 'll like them .  bomber , a : pours mahogany with a small off-white head , fair retention , light lace .  mouthfeel : perfect mouthfeel . very smooth , lightly carbonated .

absolutely fantastic aroma . t & m : sweet chocolate , citrus hops , and toasted black malt all make their appearance .  bought a michelob mixed sampler 12 pack for $ 9.99 wow , big surprise here ! i may be a spring chicken when it comes to beer drinking but this was one of the better hefe 's i 've had and to think it comes from ab .  the texture is likewise decadent , being somehow both silky and creamy .

the beer is certainly lighter than i expected with an almost straw color . the nose on this brew is phenomenal ! i 'm immediately transported to magical grapefruit land as the beer screams citrus into my nostrils . there is a piney base note to this smell to that compliments the soaring citrus very well . not on hops of course , as the grapefruity citrus notes yielded to a piney bite on the finish , but rather the malt character . while still a world class ipa , i felt that the backbone of this brew just was n't quite as strong as i would have liked and the huge hop profile was almost overwhelming .  after gearing myself up , i cracked my 60 minute ipa with great expectations . this beer has a slight hint of a head that disappears immediately and leaves a lousy lacing .  mouthfeel - smooth , evenly carbonated , and a perfectly solid body .

bubblegum , banana and cloves . smells just like i 'd like a hefeweizen to smell . the taste does n't live up to the nose , however .  honey amber color , light thin head .  very nice full bodied mouthfeel . easily drinkable .

it smells fantastic . sweet floral hops , with citrus present . t - very good , but its a little more bitter and less citrusy than the aroma led me to expect .  1999 vintage , sampled nov , 2003 - no head whatsoever . solid black in color with slight garnet highlights around the edges .  the mouthfeel is luxurious , thick , and chewy . amazing . i am impressed with this brew . flavors are great and the mouthfeel is unearthly .

nose speaks of a wonderful sweetness , malty , yeasty , and fruity , but most of all carries a unique candy-like scent . excellent . taste is malty and semi-sweet initially , with some spicy hints lingering and a bit of hop dryness .  appearance- i got absolutely no head out of this pour , may be user error . absolutely no filtering , the beer has a cloudy appearance with a remarkable amber glow to it . it looks like syrup .  mouthfeel : wonderful balance all over the pallets and each taste-bud . the slightly raised abv can give cause to the minor warmth in mouthfeel .

the smell was good .  first off , i thought this beer was very delicious ... and i will certainly buy another ! i do n't know if i poured mine incorrectly , but it was very cloudy ... which i thought oktoberfests are supposed to be clear ( i 'm thinking about spaten , sam adams , and the like ) . in fact , i loved it !  exactly how i like my stouts to feel -- heavy and chewy .

the nose is heavy on the rye malt- showing a more pure breadiness with fruity tones of buttery apples , white raisin , faint cinnamon , light brown sugar , plum . the parallels to rye whiskey are awesome in this . the medium bodied palate is caramelly sweet up front with a mild bitterness that ushers in the rye maltiness- drying and spicy with lots of fruity tones .  a - clear , deep honey color . the head is thin and leaves scattered lacing .  smooth , airy , luscious , divine mouthfeel . tremendous ! a wonderful bsda .

s : great smelling beer . c-hops and american malts . potent nose . d : great beer , absolutely delicious , with the delicate touch of a masterful brewer .  bottled 08 04 2008 a- nice amber bronze with decent but short lived head that laces .  this beer 's greatest attrubite is , in fact , its spectacualrly creamy mouthfeel .

probably the best aroma of any ale i 've tasted all year . amazing ester profile .  appearance : crystal clear pale straw color with thin bone-white head .  mouthfeel is wonderful for the style ... crisp , wet and fresh with a punchy finish . this does n't look or smell like a euro-pils ( much closer to a craft brewed american pils ) , but the mouthfeel is nailed and compares to the fresh pils i had on tap in europe .

smell : like every other macro lager .  a - hazy , pale straw yellow color with less than a one finger white head . leaves little to no lacing . color is right on for a pilsener but the head/lacing is disappointing .  mouthfeel is thick with smooth and creamy carbonation .

the aroma is nothing more than adjunct and water , all the way . corn ? no particular good qualities , nothing terrible , a little grainy but beyond that beer water .  lots of sediment just waiting to get moved around in the bottom of this beer . not enough foam or head , or lacing for an ipa imho .  the mouthfeel is , in a word , glorious . smooth on the tip of the tongue , then seeming to evaporate off your tongue leaving a crisp , somewhat spicy finish .

smell is hops - straight , beautiful hop smell . seriously , smells awesome . okay , taste is lagging behind a ways .  appearance : pours a crystal clear golden color . i notice lots of suspeneded sediment in my glass .  mouthfeel is just about right , not too thin .

smell is delicious ; porter , plus chocolate , plus raspberry . highly encouraging . so wonderful up front , so nasty in the back .  pours with zero carbonation , and not as thick as expected . no head retention and has a dark brown body .  mouthfeel : fantastic . rich without being syrupy . carbonation is just right .
