good head s : roasty , fruity , over all not bad t : garbage .  2004 vintage pours cloudy light brown with a few bubbles , but no head retention to speak of .  initially the softness of the carbonation and the sweetness of the fruity flavors makes it like a sweet soda ( can anyone remember tahitian treat ? again with the yeast character and the near rancid presence ( the brett i presume ) , yet the overall soft flavors and soft feel are greatly appealing and enjoyable . the light , fine and bubbly carbonation brings an element of childhood fun to the drink ( how about fizzies , anyone remember that ) as it brings a tickle to the nose and tongue . light overall feel and great softness . soft and light and tasty ( again in a soda pop manner ) .

smell : super strong pine , grapefruit , and bitterness warns the tastebuds through the nose what is to come . taste : hearty caramel sweetness with a very strong and biting bitterenss .  pours like a pale ale , orange/amber with just a bit if white head . no lace . it 's a chili beer , who gives a damn .  perfect mouthfeel .

smell is extremely fruity , primarily peaches with some apples , oranges , and lemons coming through as well . this is a pretty interesting and unique beer for the style . a pleasant surprise .  this score might be a bit lower than appropriate , as i drank the beer in an opaque vessel , and in a dark room -- did n't get much of a look , so i just gave it a middle of the road score on appearance .  extremely smooth tasting beer . bodied is so full its nearly chewable . mouthfeel is full and round . finish is clean and very smooth .

flavour is bit more restrained , still very nice with all the traditional hefe characteristics , wheaty and yeasty with cloves but also some caramel and brown bread . aftertaste is , like with most wheat beers , very moderate but nice . can you expect a hefeweizen to be much better than this ?  poured into a pint glass appearance - pours a hazy orange brown color , inch head that quickly dissipates to a thin layer of foam .  m : one of the fullest and creamiest dipas i 've ever had .

s - great smell . dark fruits such as raisins and plums maybe . o - good over all .  a-pours a mostly clear yellow-gold w/just a touch of haze . white head with average retention .  m- full bodied and creamy . very smooth and silky in the mouth . full bodied but not heavy .

s - pretty much just rich caramel malts with a touch of earthy hops . not really what i expect from an apa . o - very drinkable apa , was just expecting more hops in the nose .  minimal head , that quickly dissipates . decent lacing .  mouthfeel is creamy smooth , thick body , low carbonation .

smell - a wonderful yeast or dough or wheat smell dominates , with orange or another citrus fruit tagging along . irresistibly smooth finish , tastes much the way it smells although the wheat is less noticeable .  been aging this one for about six months ... poured from a 750ml into an old raspy pint glass ... a - this one pours pitch black with next to no head . no head retention , as next to none was produced .  the feel is big and thick .

s- smell is awesome . tons of tropical fruits pineapple , apricot , and grapefruit a bit of sweetness coming through from the malts . t- follows the nose really well . a very nice hop forward beer .  a : a murky , iced tea colour ... not much head at all , and whatever was there did n't stick around long .  the mouthfeel is great , for the bittersweetness from the roasted malts provide the ideal amount of oomph to an otherwise creamy body .

three floyds beers have a unique aroma . the hops come across , thick and flowery . ive heard they use amarillo and columbus hops for aroma . many brewers could learn from these folks . milk chocolate , coffee , a little toasted malt with just a mild flowery hop flavor on the finish . slick , smooth and rich mouth feel , very nice , very drinkable .  nice deep amber/copper color was topped by a thin head that left zero lacing .  thick with just a little bit of slickness and just enough carbonation . sly fox oatmeal stout is a solid beer with a fantastic mouthfeel ; probably something i would order again .

s : abundant floral hops , definately some cascade . the perfect combination of floral , bittering , aroma , in a showcasing of hops that is presented beautifully , well balanced and tame but not lame .  poured from 750ml bottle into tulip glass . a : dark copper , head is generous and frothing but does n't live very long and leaves almost no lacing .  mouthfeel is damn near perfect for an o'fest , i think . impeccable balance .

the smell dances on the nose , full of floral and hops .  a - a quick-dissolving tan foam settles to ... nothing . lightly hazed dark ruby-brown body .  smooth and thick ( of medium thickness ) , with small abrasive bubbles ( in the best possible way ) . wish i had let it chill a little longer to see a greater range of flavors as it warmed , but still a nice experience .

unbelievable . taste , too has a very pronounced graham cracker taste in it , along with pumpkin , of course .  poured a dark orange . the head was nice at first . then it turned minute and the lace ( everything ) was eliminated .  body is n't the first thing you notice , but once the distraction of the sour wears off , you realize this brew is very smooth , neither tacky nor sticky , nor drying . carbonation can be swirled up , and compliments the feel of the sour in your cheeks quite well . all in all , a crazy departure from the normal dfh offerings and dang fine weissen .

smell is pretty average - sweet maltiness and slight citrusy hop aroma .  slightly hazy , deep reddish brown colour with a thin cap of light beige bubbles . a little spotty lace clung to the glass .  m : one of the most silky smooth beers i have had in quite a while . i would love it on cask , although the low carbonation is nearly perfect .

s - sweet hop delight . much stronger hop aroma than doppelbocks i have had before . earthy hop aroma with a very sweet scent as well .  it pours a typical , but still attractive , clear amber with an ok white head that leaves a little lacing . fortunately , appearance is this beers weakest point .  the feel of the beer was smooth as silk .

s- great nose ! pine , citrus , grapefruit , orange , malt , lots of hops yum . start is week middle is weak end is great . m- medium body , nice carbonation , o- this beer has a killer nose , one of the best but its color and flavor are a bit off for me , i would enjoy this fresh as opposed to part of their gabf temporary distribution in denver . good beer , but not world class by any means .  the body is a light yellow straw color , with a lot of little bits of yeast everywhere . the head is a nice bright white and has good retention and lacing .  the mouthfeel was silky smooth , and i think it was the best feeling oatmeal stout i have ever had . the low carbonation perfectly complemented the medium body , and the smoothness from the oatmeal made it a joy to drink .

s : as soon as i popped this one , i loved the smell of it . i was hoping after the great smell , it would have a taste i loved , but unfortunately not a taste that suits me .  pours a clear orange-y amber with an initially large white head , which reduces to a thin haze .  m : the mouthfeel is perfect . full and creamy with a little grittiness in the texture .

smells great ( but nothing like a gumball imo ) . incredible . very bitter for a pale ale , or pale wheat ale , whatever . it certainly smelled good , but nothing more than the typical tropical fruit-heavy pale/ipa .  poured from the bottle into a pint glass a - pours a dark copper with virtually no head . perhaps that explains the lackluster head ...  the mouth feel on this one is perfect . the head retention is outstanding and just adds to that smooth , creamy , malty , citrus finish .

s - immediate lemon smell . solid strength to the smell . t - the can on this says all malt .  a : pours a murky orange/brown color . a small , bubbly white head forms with little lace . very solid , and something to look for .  mouthfeel is as silky as they come , the sensation over the tongue is as pleasurable as quaffing god 's nipple lactations . taste is , however , the killer here because it 's just not as explosive as the complex nose and full body could easily have supported .

smell- figs ! drinkability- deciptively drinkable , i could finish up this bottle in a hurry and then find out that it 's 10 % abv afterward . nice .  pours a deep orange amber with a light tan head that lingers for a while .  t/m : mouthfeel is perfect on this beer .

the smell was bourbon and caramel . sometimes these things can taste like beer with a shot of liquor - not so with this one . all in all , quite excellent .  pours reddish gold with thing head .  exceptionally velvety mouthfeel on this one -- noticed that right away .

little smell to speak of , but what is there smells of malt and a general toastiness . quite drinkable and a overal pleasant brew .  a- cloudy golden/orange with 2 inch off white head that fades at a moderate pace to a lasting lace .  mouthfeel is very smooth , perhaps my favourite part of this beer . full bodied with subtle carbonation , it feels just right .

smells of dry , sour grain , ash and feet ? there 's also a sweet and easy doughy malt followed by a crisp woody hop .  but it was a good spiritual experience anyway . the color was a bit darker than i expected , but i am not a bjcp judge , so screw it .  m : as expected it has a wonderful feel to it that only a belgian can give . thick and creamy with a medium weight that gives way to an extremely crisp finish .

boozy aroma with vanilla and oak apparent , notes of toffee and coconut , roast and chocolate , faint licorice and figs . great texture , full without being heavy , moderate carbonation that provided an airy mouthfeel , a bit of astringency from the kilned grains and wood , slightly sticky .  a - let 's face it , almost all strong belgian ales appear cloudy , murky or muddy . the head is coffee with milk brown and dissipates in less than three minutes . what a shame ! m - not as heavy as the appearance would suggest , but it is substantial d - at 10.5 % abv you wo n't be having too many in an evening .  mouthfeel : fantastic . great carbonation , no real aftertaste and washes easily over the palate .

aroma is amazing ; quite flowery , tangy , fruity , with some yeast and a perfume presence .  deep gold/pale amber in colour . thin , foamy tan head fades to a respectable layer of foam . chill haze is very evident .  m - thick , very smooth and very viscous with little carbonation .

smells very sweet , of caramel and spice and a definite alcohol presence on the nose . i love it . one of the best smelling beers i 've put my nose to .  this is the 2008 version pours a pitch black heavy ooze . head is 1 finger , chocolate and rather weak . head retention and lacing are mediocre at best smell is mostly of dark fruit , raisins and figs .  mouthfeel - exceptionally smooth , with an awesome eveness that carries the taste for a while .

sn consistantly produces beers w/ amazing hop boutique aromas . t - flavor profile pretty much mimics the nose w/ the malts and biscuit holding the fort down so the trademark sn cascades can do what they do best . mf - creamy , medium body and goes down w/ a slick and oily feel d - balance , balance , balance . highly sessionable .  first observations : whoa , what a smell ! the appearance is dark , of course ... .well more of a dark red . not much head or retention , but i did n't expect much .  the palate is delightfully smooth and creamy . overall , this is an outstanding dipa that is sure to fill anyones hop fix for the evening .

although i served this around 40 degrees , i still thought it had surprisingly little aroma . what little roasted nutty malt smell i could discern was pretty much what it tasted like .  slight film persists , but no real head retention or lacing s : sour & oaky notes t : sweet cherry , then sourness , oaky dryness & small hint of vanilla up front .  mouthfeel is so big thick and creamy .

light citrus hop aroma . not a lot going on .  a - poured out a clear , orange color with golden highlights . it had a very small , white head of bubbly foam .  this beer has an amazing mouthfeel , very full and luscious , super smooth .
great aroma , flavor and bitterness .  a- clear yellow gold color with a small head that stick and laces .  the mouthfeel is absolutely perfect for a porter , so smooth and silky .

s - fruity and sweet and alcoholic . very different than a raspberry lambic .  i 've had several beers from troegs , and i 've liked them all . hopback was refreshing , easy to drink and delicious . i 'm looking forward to trying it poured into a pint glass so i can ge more aroma from it , but i would recommend it to anyone .  great , creamy mouthfeel .
woody roast malt aroma with wet earth , chocolate and other goodies .  2006 vintage . no head on the pour .  really great mouthfeel of this one has won me over .

s : this is an obvious german pilsener - pure malt together with nice bitter hops in balance with the slight fainter floral hops .  pours a pale copper color with an off white head from a brown twist off bottle .  slick mouthfeel with perfect level of carbonation .

the aroma is the best part , but it goes down smooth and tastes nice .  black in color , but lacks head retention and lacing which brings this down quite a bit .  m- great mouth feel . very smooth and not over-carbonated .

s- smells horribles , extremely generic in smell , can sense a little hops and maybe a little wheat .  shared a 6 pack with some friends ( peacebone116 and his wife and my wife ) , sadly didnt have the option to get an appearance since we drank them from the bottles on a picnic . a n/a since it wasnt poured into a glass , so ill go middle of the road with a 3 .  caramel , mocha , strong booze , brown sugar , raisins , figs , chocalate t-malt , mocha , booze , brown sugar , caramel , raisins figs , chocalate m-spicy , creamy , thick , barely carbonated d- pretty thick & filling .

the aroma is fantastic , sweet , sour , chocolate malt all blending to a wonderful bouquet . taste is a bit too spicy , but otherwise very pleasantly complex . mouthfeel is dry and acrid , not as smooth as some others .  pours a dark red color , very murky , small head , low retention , some lacing .  huge bodied and full ( again , suggesting iipa classification ) . this is a beauty on cask .

n : cherry , honey , fig , banana , candy sugar , light funk , hints of cinnamon and perhaps some clove . o : nicely balanced and easy drinking . this makes a wonderful winter treat !  ok retention with little fingers of lace .  m : full-bodied , a very firm and brilliantly sructured beer .

s : tropical fruit city - tangerine , pineapple , mango with noticable pine . put me on the beach in cancun . d : a quality double ipa from avery in colorado , the price in bottles prohibits me from buying this except for every so often , but it 's a quite good beer for hop fans .  frizzy white head . head doesnt hang around too long , just specks of lacing . dark straw colored beer . t & m : pretty fruity ( oranges and grapefruits ) .  the mouthfeel is great ... medium on the palate , but slick and well carbonated ... compliments the black pepper flavor perfectly .

pours a murky borwn with some red hue with absolutely no head to speak of here but was expected , great aromas of cocoa some sugar cookie dough and orange with some noticable nuttieness.a real sipping brew here and fruity to the hilt big orange flavors along with some sour cherry and i have to say it does have this vodka and cranberry flavor to it the first i have ever experienced that in a beer , as the beer warms a real nutty presence come out as well.a nice before bed beer very enjoyable and exremely complex .  no head to speak of .  mouthfeel - per style it is dead on ... fairly dry and actually not sticky compared to other barleywines .

quite a nice and pleasant aroma with qualities of banana , slight clove , a little phenol and a general light ( and sweet ) fruitiness with a backing of wheat . overall , a great aroma and appearance otherwise average , at best .  love the bottle , too bad the price is so high . a : pours a dark ruby/brown color with a small off-white head forms , comprised of rather large bubbles , and dissipates rather quickly . very thin lacing forms , but does not last .  the mouthfeel is very smooth , with minimal aftertaste .

beautiful hop smell : floral , grass , the smell of spring basically . a little bit of bread & cracker smell . very aromatic , but not overwhelming , a smooth & even hop character . the lovely hop character is forward in the taste , but again not overwhelming or destructive to the tastebuds .  pours a light orange color ( lighter than most pumpkin ales ) with just a bit of lacing and some nice initial head .  creamy , silky mouthfeel .
cloudy red beer has a hoppy smell , but not overwhelming . taste ; bitter .  there was very little head to speak of even with a vigorous pour .  a great feel that has a body that replenishes itself .

certainly has that belgain yeatiness to it as well as the smell of good old alcohol .  it came as a cloudy amber beer with only a thin head .  m : full-bodied , silky smooth , velvety rich and downright luxurious in the mouth . these guys have this whole mouthfeel down to a t. notes : malty rich , fruity sweet , and explosively spicy , this bspa is quite enjoyable !

the aroma of this beer is really something -- it 's powerfully strawberry , like sticking your nose into a jar of jam . very appealing , assuming you 're really into the idea of strawberry beer . but i was disappointed with the taste -- it 's less strawberry lambic than just strawberry juice , a powerfully sweet , syrupy brew with no real malt or hop presence .  the aroma is mostly floral malty with some grassy hops and barely distinguishable yeast . taste is quite similar - soft and sweet maltiness in the beginning , maybe some caramel additionaly and nice bitter finish . pretty good beer , i will definitely buy some more of them  mouthfeel is very thick and chewy , silky and long lasting on the palate , near perfect .

aroma has pleasant vinous overtones , port . superb taste is exactly as expected from the nose . the figs are turning .  pours murky amber with a respectable thin , fuzzy head .  the mouthfeel is outstanding , like an expensive champagne and it finishes very dry .

s : smell on this beer is amazing . i gave this beer a 5 . the beer smells like a cream stuffed pumpkin . d : drinkable for the style but still 1 bomb is good for me .  preface - i always rate brews to style ... a - very average . no head . or lacing .  amazingly full mouthfeel .

s : big yeast smell right up front . the yeast and hops work really well together . excellent nose . t : wow . d : very nice beer . still excellent beer all around .  pours a very hazy brownish red with a one finger head of beige colored foam . head falls to islands and a ring , with minimal lacing .  m : lovely . sort of creamy , without being too heavy .

not a terribly complex smell , but its really appealing nonetheless .  a : crystal clear golden color with an appropriate sized head . i was expecting something a little more cloudy .  appearance : amber , clear carbonated , medium head smell : alcohol , grapefruit , and citrus taste : alcohol , grapefruit , malts , hops , and slight caramel mouthfeel : smooth , slightly hard finish , can feel the carbonation ... it is amazing how smooth and unbitter this beer is for a beer with its abv drinkability : i will have this again , but may be one of the few that prefer the 60 minute ipa .

hardly any smell , a little bit of malt maybe .  the head was bubbly but weak . the carbonation was above average , though with just an average lacing .  m : full body , and shockingly creamy . this brew is extremely smooth of the mouth .

gives a snootful of dark chocolate and sweet dark molasses from 6 inches away , truly intense aroma . flavor is gently dominated by the chocolate , leans a little toward chocolate flavor extract , but nothing definitive .  it looks much like a standard macro-brewers lager but the similarity ends there .  starts with roasted coffee flavor , mouthfeel is incredible smooth .

nose is roasty coffee , caramel , roast chocolate , herbal hop , and fruity , spicy and nutty yeast products . crazy . the first thing that hits me is fruit bouquet , then herbal hop ushers in phenols . good if you do n't think of it as stout .  pours a golden color with very little head and no lacing observed .  m - perfect ? perfect .

a - black as can be with what started as a monster tan head that has died down a bit but still lingers s - big roasted aroma 's mingle with notes of vanilla . this is just what i look for .  pours a hazy , reddish-brown color with almost no head .  beautiful .

great nose on this altbier . very mild fragrance , overall , but perfectly to style . perfect for the cool austin weather this time of year .  pours a hazy mud brown with little to no head .  perfect ris mouthfeel .

s- as only a good british beer can smell , luscious . very complex . t/m- ok , the taste lets down a bit after the luscious aroma . a good beer but disappointed that it is n't a great beer .  the color and clarity are oustanding , but a lack of retention or lacing is concerning .  mouthfeel is a great aspect of this beer . a big , creamy , velvety beer . soft and velvet from the oatmeal , low carbonation .

nice . d - i 'm coming to the conclusion that i 'm not a huge fan of hoppy beers . but this is nice . while i ca n't say i 'd like this all the time , i 'd definitely like to revisit it .  `` pasteurized in cans , bottles and kegs , with nitrogen.contract brewed by interbrew at magor for heineken the license holders.ingredients : pale and chocolate malts ; roasted barley ; target hops . '' in view of the above , this is a welsh sweet stout based on the irish style ! it is , in my opinion , a very nice and decent drinkable stout that edges out the equivalent guinness product ( which i also happen to like !  mouthfeel is silky smooth , really nice . body fairly full and the beer leaves an impression all the way over the tongue .

nose is big sweet plums , ripe pears and sweet cooked peaches with light spice - big , full , rich and assertive with big candi sugar tones . flavors are very complex and layered . front palate is sweet spiced cola and compote cooked fruit that goes to a dull bitter mid palate and finish .  a - med-dark gold . t - the first thing you taste is whisky , but it fits nicely . beautiful rogue malt profile . very tasty . d - highly drinkable .  finishes fruitty & spicy mf : huge & well balanced this was bit ponderous , but tasty .

does n't look like a stout very unpleasant smell . rotten fruits and medicinal booziness . the smell is offputting , makes me scared to drink this .  1/5 inch head of a tan color . decent retention and good lacing .  mouthfeel is velvety and smooth . great length on the taste .

wow . thick bourbon and aforementioned flavors , mostly caramel . lovely beer , quite exceptional .  based on notes , picked this up in las cruces , nm poured an effervescent amber with a very modest white head . average head retention & lacing s : fruitty with some musty notes t : apricots & peach , plus some honey up front .  m- the first thing i notice with this is how smooth and creamy it is . d- a very enjoyable english barleywine . tasty .

smell : wow , mazing ! roasty , dark chocolate , very coffee forward , sweetness . taste : very good , nice and roasty . overall : very good beer , i would certainly want to have this again .  slight amounts of sediment adds to the mild haziness . no lacing , and just about no head , but there is a slight cloud of head floating around . m- full and very smooth .  this is so creamy and not too carbonated , its just enough to get both senses of substantial and refreshing . quite thick , not so much as syrup but a few steps under . one please , fills the stomach nicely , not too harsh on the throat or stomach . it has a nice balance between warmth and coolness in the stomach .

very nice start of a semi-grainy and fully malted pilsner barley . delicious .  pours hazy copper with a creamy 1 finger tan head that faded about average time ; good lacing that clings to the glass and leaves rings .  m - smooth as silk .

aroma is like tap water that is passed over some grain . no hops anywhere in the nose at all .  a - some gushing led to a lot of sediment ending up in the glass . a dark brown color with about a finger of khaki head .  m : full-bodied and lightly carbonated with a soft and creamy texture . alcohol noticable in a nice warming effect .

head stays for a good while s- smells identical to apple pie .  i 've had the bottle , and there is some weird floaters in there , but they did n't bother me . there is little head and is a nice amber in color .  the mouthfeel is great and smooth as can be .

aroma of spruce and tiger lillies . supremely floral . this is not the aroma of your average triple . this beer could be marketed as liquid potpourri , and i 'd be proud to buy a lame plug-in air freshener that smelled like this . certainly , all the qualities are there .  the beer pours a medium brown color with a cream-colored head .  my favorite thing about this obviously the sweet rich malt character which adds to a very nice body for a beer of this alcohol content .

the smell had a distinct piney hops character - lots of spruce needles . also present in abundance were the usual line-up of spices anchor employs ; clove , nutmeg , cinnamon , and molasses .  cloudy , deep amber-straw . almost half a finger of bubbly white head that does n't last long .  mouthfeel is just perfect . the way this thing finishes it has a slight peppery aspect but it is dry and clean .

the smell is sweet , spicy , almost vinous , and very complex . each time i think i have an aroma captured it changes into something else .  pours an incredibly viscous murky brown with very little to no head or lacing .  the mouthfeel is amazing . the belgian in this beer seems to come from the relatively light body but firm and billowy head that rollicks around my mouth .

brewery states they did pick up some brett recently , popped the cork off ... corked talked about brett to me , more fruit than funk . hops stay modest . mild tartness , infancy of the brett ? it does have a ghost-like funk within . sweet roasted finish , pretty much burnt sugar . not a hair short of being great , the brewery admits to some funk ... wish i had another bottle to see where it goes .  pour is disappointing , honestly . a tiny fizz of head gives way to nothing in less than a minute . the good thing is , and this is what keeps it at an average score , is that the color is a beautiful golden-orange . the light really plays around , and i see a few carb trails so , strange that it has no head .  mouthfeel is superb . almost perfect , well rounded , full , with a snappy finish .

s : distinct and delicious aroma of butter rum leads off . honestly , this smells like angel 's share should have smelled .  i have experienced a bad batch of this brew , which was cloudy , and `` off '' in flavor . not quite translucent , which is not a negative , imho . nice white head .  m : a great , great medium body , that grazes you at the tail with sharp carbonation .

quite impressive - i just could n't stop bringing this one to my nose .  pours a murky orange with a thin , clingy head . nothing special in this regard .  mouthfeel/overall : this beer is every bit of full bodied ; thick , chewy and creamy . everything an imperial stout should be . overall , a very good imperial stout that i 'd love to have full time access to .

stunning rich and assertive peach and banana nose . unfortunately , flavor , character and body do not follow . however , nothing in body , flavors or character could lead one to conclude that aging will help this dull , simple and short flavored beer with a fantastic nose . smell it ; do n't drink it .  i would prefer the appearance to be a little more hazy & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; but this stuff comes from germany so i guess these guys know good beer & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; the smell is reminiscent of banana i do n't get too much clove to it & gt ; & gt ; i also ge an earthy smell too & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; it tastes just like it smells & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; very easy to drink & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; watery mouthfeel not my favorite beer style but excellently true to style !  mouthfeel - very smooth with a rich body and muted carbonation .

this might come as a shock , but this beer actually smells like real chocolate !  a : muddy brown with limited tan head that quickly fades but leaves lace on he edge .  mouthfeel is thick and chewy , as it should be fir a beer of this strength .

cappuccino , freshly whipped cream , vanilla extract , milk chocolate powder give the nose a soft , enveloping appeal , cherry syrup , brown sugar , this noted it does have an unprocessed graininess to it which approximates hop bite , fills your nostrils and stays there for some time . in the mouth it 's medium-bodied with an acidic punch which jolts you and momentarily forestalls the arrival of the cappuccino , vanilla pudding , whipped cream , graham cracker pie crust , cinnamon powder , licorice and baker 's chocolate . there 's also more of a perfumed lift than downwards pressure on the palate . tart cherry pie wafts through the finish .  long trail- double bag appearance- orange/ cooper/ red with a small but respectable head that did a slight lacing along my glass .  mouthfeel is thick and creamy , very nice .

big hop aroma -- a bit sugary , citric and piney . lots and lots going on just in the scent , and i can feel the back of my tongue tingling already .  pours a clear golden , big white head forms , billowy , goes fast , no lace to speak of .  mouthfeel is perfect ! not thick like a stout , but with enough meat to be very smooth and coating .

smells like apples , tastes like hops . very tasty . the fragrance certainly did not match the taste , which is a good thing .  somewhat muddy at first pour . very , very dark-ok i will call it black . low caronation head wise but seems lively enough .  full bodied with creamy carbonation and a lingering sweet licorice finish .

smell is just plain wonderful . it 's like an entire garden of raspberries up your nose .  poured a dark ruby-brown with a thin off-white head .  it 's as smooth as silk - perfectly suited as a dinner and desert sipper and easily the best porter i 've had the pleasure of tasting .

s : watery , yeast , soapy . t : esters up front , hints of banana and caramel , checked by herbal hops , all ending with nuttiness . d : yes , it 's drinkable .  appearance & gt ; not too dissimilar to the color of the bottle . dark brown , creamy head , no lacing .  full , thick , rich mouth feel .

two brothers heavy handed ipa : terrific aroma , very full and noticeable from several feet away . some heavy malt syrup aromas coupled with flowery hops make the aroma very appetizing . slick mouth feel .  12 oz bottle a : dark brown under a very small off white head . no retention and no lace .  mouthfeel is great . just the right level of thickness here .

caramel , i can smell the lager yeast . earthy .  the taupe head quickly falls to just a cloudy covering . dark ruby/brown with some chunk that look like pieces of mulch sitting on the bottom of the glass .  the way this tastes is absolutely nothing like the way it smells ... m - full , pleasing mouthfeel . the best part of this beer .

t - not as complex as i had hoped for , but still good . starts off with bourbon vanilla flavors with some caramel malt sweetness mid palate , then big oak flavors with a bit of spice through the long finish .  the appearance is nothing special -dark purple-black -- some ruby elements at the top part of the glass .  very full body that stretches the cheeks . just such chewy hops .

super sweet citrus tingle with a fresh evergreen aroma . a fitting caramel malt finds its way in the nose as well . wonderful exotic hop scents all the way through with this one . scary good drinkability for the style .  my pint was a stark black beer with a little ring of dark brown head . not very impressive looking at all . just a run of the mill look to it .  the texture is rich and creamy and coasts your mouth in deliciousness .

pours hazy copper brown in color with a foamy/creamy tan head that stays around for quite some time ; smells of sweet malt , dark fruit , spices and caramel . decent lacing sticks to the glass .  a very cloudy orange color .  excellent in the mouth .

it looks like watered-down , carbonated honey , but tastes nothing like that . it 's nothing to get excited about , unless you 're looking to get out of hand .  color is a nice golden orange , much like an iced tea .  mouthfeel is full and round .

however , for a cheap beer the can i quenched my thirst with was very refreshing . it will beat bud light always . miller lite has good taste compared to it 's peers in the cheapo light beer section . and if consuming large amounts of beer is your game this is your beer . it is best consumed very chilled and on draft .  a : a new penny copper , with about a finger high head of white ... retention is poor , receding quickly to a little lip of lace ringing around the glass .  m= smooth and crisp . feels resinous as well which is great for an ipa . d= super drinkable .

s - oh my , one of the most delicious aromas i 've ever experienced . d - fantastic stout .  poured into a snifter on 7/5/10 many thanks to pdxhops dark brown in color , settling black in the glass . in fact all foam disappears save a ring . no lace .  the alcohol is kept well in check allowing the finish to cascade over the palate with a ton of character and wonderful texture . strong , long finish .

while really good , not as good as aroma . overall : really good . would have liked the flavor to measure up to the aroma but you still ca n't go wrong with this one .  pours a dark black . no head or signs of carb . hopefully it 's not flat .  sour , some cherries , but most of all very tart and bone dry ; element of french cheese in it ( brie ) , some cream ; m : lovely alcohol , nice tartness , very drinkable ; o : not too complex but but very good kriek , which i will buy whenever i see it .

this fella was simply awesome . it smelled a lot sweeter than the normal ab , with the oak scent peaking through at the tail end of the nose .  on-tap at beachwood bbq , a : pours brown with a mild white head , no real lace , average head retention .  easy to drink due to it 's creamy mouthfeel and pleasant flavor .
smelled like coconut sugar pie , the nose is great . dark .  a- cloudy yellow with a small white head .  m - perfect body .

the aroma of it is amazing , almost a pumpkin cider type smell .  a ) 1/4 a head . quickly disappeared . looks like medium carbonation .  the mouthfeel is absolutely perfect . it goes down full-bodied yet absurdly delicately and dries the mouth a perfect amount for the hop zing this one has .

the aroma is like a fresh hop cone very nice . from what you expect with the aroma is a slight let down but that said it is nice . the taste malty to start the taste turns to a earthy hop flavor .  oops ... i was expecting a wee heavy . as an amber ale , it 's a little hoppier than usual , and pretty good use of malts .  it 's thick , creamy , rich , and robust .

smell is awesome -- the smoked pork hits you first , followed by hints of raw sugar , honey , apples or pears , and black licorice . first few sips have an element of 'burnt'-ness to them , but once you get used to it , it 's quite pleasant . there 's almost a saltiness to it , with some background flavours of coffee , chocolate , and strong malts .  poured into a 12-oz mug , this beer is a murky orange-tinted brown color with almost no head retention , and in fact barely a hint of foam at all on top .  m : the mouthfeel is dense and creamy and frothy ... and almost stout-like . excellent .

smell is heavier on bready malts than anything else . i really do n't pick up much hops in the nose at all - in fact , i have to work to find them . but regardless , it 's rather dull , with low hop presence and nothing really remarkable .  appearance : light amber color , lighter than paulaner 's version with decent amount of carbonation smell : slightly fruity notes and a little bit of hops come out as i swirled the brew in my glass .  overall a really complex , fantastic stout , one i 'd be happy coming back to over and over .

extremely fruit-fillled aromatics - pungent apple sauce notes lead the way into a more diverse array of stone-fruit esters . lush oaky notes with a touch of bergamot in the finish - complexity grows as the beer warms . i 'm still impressed that the base beer can be improved upon by soaking up the best characteristics of the barrels it is aged in , but these special editions of harvest ale have certainly `` matured '' more than simply `` aged .  this poured a clear medium golden , white foam head , that left broken lace all the way through , taste was nice , rather bold hops , up front , then mellows , to a bit of a sweet aftertaste , citrusy notes , fruit and hop nose , bit of apple , and lemon . mouthfeel was a little chewy , but fairly rich and full , drinkability is very good , nice summer brew !  visibly effervescent , the mouth feel is perfect ... classic rich micro bubbles lend a smooth creamy texture .

n : this is a beautiful , mouthwatering nose . smells very close to liquid pumpkin pie .  pours muddy brown with a tan head than disappears . almost opaque and ... yeah brown is the only color it can be called .  in the mouth , the tiny bubbles announce and incredibly smooth and balanced beer , with a roasted , slightly sweet flavor .

huge hop aroma , a nice scottish style malt presnece behind the agresive hop bitterenes .  pours a cloudy orange-ish straw with a small white head that quickly sinks to a very thin ring .  smells like a smoke beer ... .i get a little chocolate in the nose ... but the roasted smell is overpowering ... taste is sweet on the front end ... and an overall smooth taste ... .with a little bitterness on the back end ... very nice feel ... .creamy and smooth perfect for the style ... .velvet like smoothness ... drinkability is not bad ... although it is a stout and it weighs you down ...

aroma is mostly complex stages of hops , it 's easy to believe there are 10 varieties , there 's the big american c hops character combined with the refined english ones . very relaxing to sniff on and ultra-complex , like a touch of vanilla on fresh citrus ( grapefruit ) . in mouth this dances on the tongue , nice effervescence , creamy , full-bodied , complex malt sweetness and an obvious balancing yeastiness . this is a delicious big generous beer . tasting this with my buddy martint , we came to the conclusion that given the choice to pick only 2 beers from a same brewery to have an infinite supply of , hotd with fred and adam would probably win over quite anyone .  pours a hazy gold with a small off-white head .  m- great mouthfeel .

this is very easily the best smelling beer i 've ever whiffed . taste is very disappointing . the smell is this brews strongest point , but it is also the source of the beer 's greatest flaw .  hazy yellow in color and an initally large white head , but it diminishes down to a thin layer of bubbles .  mouthfeel is rich and creamy .

smell : i always find it to be a little skunk .  pours cloudy pale yellow with minimal white head .  pours a rich copper with a creamy one finger head that that settles nicely leaving some light lace , deep intese fruity aromas with some underlying but very noticeable pine.wow a big flavorful barleywine very pacific coast piney and resiny upfront with a big fruity alcolholic finish the alcohol really hits.just a sublime creamy mouthfeel and pretty slick going down the hatch and it warms the insides.wow truley and awesome big brew a night cap that cant be beat .

aroma : cloves and sweet spice notes .  poured a hazy blonde very similar to a witbier or hefe , with notable carbonation . very small head , but with some lace making it all the way down to the bottom of the glass . very drinkable , especially during the summer .  this brew is a tremendously creamy medium-body with a tantalizing , light bite about the tongue what can i say !

ca n't find one , really . t : roasted , hints of smoke and coffee . a bit too dry , too odorless and with too little after taste .  ) it poured a nice pale gold with a decent head that left quickly .  medium body and a wonderfully sprtizy carbonation keeps it light and makes the tartness manageable .

s : this is seriously the best part of the beer . the smell is a pronounced chorus of woodiness , vanilla , chocolate , and booze . is this nirvana ? t : starts out with a creamy chocolate taste which is followed by a sharp stab of flavor and alcohol burn on the tongue . d : overall a very impressive beer .  this beer pours a mirky brown with a sizeable light tan head .  altogether pleasing to the tongue and brain , it also had a beautifully full mouthfeel from the oustandingly appropriate delicate carbonation .

down to my last g'knight so i felt the need to review this beauty and hopefully it wo n't be long before i can get more . i 'll never forget the first time i popped one of these open , the smell was amazing , i could drink it straight from the can . pure sweetness in the nose , a bit of resiny hops , caramel , cake , so sweet you can taste it .  a - the low , poorly retained off-white head is disappointing as is the hazy golden yellow color .  mouthfeel was full and rich . this is a very good beer , and quite a unique one .

aroma is basic , clean and crisp .  12oz bottle poured into a pint glass pours a copper-straw with obvious carbonation bubbles rising to the surface . any head quickly fades to nothing .  m/d - medium to full bodied with an excelent feel .

when i first opened the bottle i could smell the cherrys right away . it was a very sweet smell which suprised me that the beer was not as sweet as the smell . very nice appearance .  very drinkable.it is refreshing to have a microbrewey beer , that is not that bitter , and very drinkable.gets you very drunk.be careful because the alcohol creeps up on you with this beer.tasted citrus.i also tasted a bit of nutmeg in the aftertaste.this beer is very easy to drink.exceptional drinkability . this is the quintessential summer ale.a light , very drinkable , however , complex enough to be a microbrewery beer.i highly recommend this beer . this is a good recommendation to the general public.inasmuch as this beer is drinkable and light , many people will enjoy this . moreover , what is cool about recommending this beer , is that many people are not aware of this beer and micro beer 's in general.this was a perfect find on a june saturday , great beer to have at a high school or college graduation party.this is a great party beer , and will generate conversation at a graduation party , because numerous people have not heard of brooklyn , even suprisingly , in new york .  feels wonderful on the tongue , perfect for a summer or spring day .

smell : yeasty wheat , dry and straightforward , expect for a slight strofoamish hint in the background .  poured into my guinness 20 oz glass , no idea when this was bottled ... there is no date listed on the bottle a-pale orange color with a small inch head s- sweet pale malt , flowery and fruity ( citrus ) hops t- very flowery , earthy , oily hops with a subtle citrus fruit taste .  thick creamy mouthfeel and mild carbonation . smooth silky mouthfeel is lucious .

the beer has a golden color with a hint of orange and features a wonderful malty aroma that is crisp and rich . the flavor is also crisp with some malt highlights and a pretty bitter aftertaste , and overall is heavier than i expected ( i was expecting something like a brewpub blond from this since they also offer a pale ale ) . my last swigs still get that great malt aroma wonderful ! !  this beer poured a dark brown with a minimal head , held up to the light , was n't quite crystal clear but a little hazy .  carbonation was nice and light , body was perfect .

the smell is outstanding , very malty and reminiscent of autumn .  a little head retention & no lacing s : slight earthy hops up front then a little fruittyness t : piney hops up front followed by fruittyness & a slight grainyness .  perfect carbonation .

half inch head and thick head retention s : straight dole pineapple orange juice or something like it ! phenomenally citrusy . t : more dole juice ! crisp bite at the front before smooth finish . o : delicious ! very unique . probably could n't have more than one but very enjoyable . the fruit juice character is pretty interesting , that 's for sure .  pours a deep dark black with hints of brown around the edges . the very thin half-finger brown head did n't last very long .  this beer feels absolutely perfect in the mouth .

this beer gives you a great looking glass ... smell- ... and a great smell ! incredible smell , might be the best smelling ipa i 've had so far . really nice batch . smells like a field of flowers and with its distinct flowery smell that might remind some of opening a pot of honey .  pours an opaque orange/brown , thin tan head forms , disappears to a thin ring really fast , some lace spots .  superb mouthfeel . excellent amount of carbonation .

the smell was horrible , resembled urine , and a uranal cake .  a moderate pour yields a 1/2-finger off-white head that deteriorates to a thin clumpy dusting and thin foam ring in just a couple minutes . the body is a beautifully clear golden amber with just a few small carbonation bubbles . some light lacing can be seen clinging to the glass throughout consumption .  m- the mouth feel is excellent for this beer .

s : a very sweet and complex nose here . lots of caramel , toffee , dates , figs , raisins , and wood . t : not quite as impressive as the nose , but still damn good . lots of caramel , bourbon , oak , and apple .  a : pours a light golden color with a big white head that does not quickly dissipate .  m- smooth and velvety , perfect carbonation o- great beer , bottle is on par with the draft .

huge amounts of fruitiness , candy , and grapefruit on the nose . sweet , light , and apricots also show up a bit . reminds me of some type of orange/apricot candy i 've had before but can not put my finger on it . very light , very fruity , yet tart but it is quite a curious taste . very easy to drink and although i do n't see myself buying a lot of lindeman 's myself i will highly recommend this to anyone trying a geuze !  despite a vigorous attempt at a pour , i got no head at all .  the mouthfeel is excellent .

a-pours a cloudy orange ... i 'm docking points because pilsner 's should have good clarity ... also excessive head ... s-outstanding aroma ... spicy , floral and somewhat fruity ... very inviting and the type of beer you could sit and smell all day long . but i found it an exciting , and tasting brew ... .one of the best smelling beers i have ever experienced .  pours a light amber with a cloud and a small head that dissipates quickly .  m - extremely smooth .

this beer was very jeckyll and hyde for me . the smell is also terrific : citrusy , apricot , peach ( as others have noted ) .  appearance this is a solid brown in color with a rather smallish head on a hard pour .  mouthfeel is smooth and rich , medium-full body , with wonderful carbonation .

the aroma was , well , heavenly . deep dark fruitiness leads the way with raisins and plums . a deep inhale yeilds only wisps of alcohol that contribute complexity . the flavor was just a step behind the aroma with dark fruits again in full force followed by caramel maltiness .  somewhat cloudy orange appearance.head that doesnt quit.wonderful aroma-oranges , spice , malt all reign supreme.dough boy-awesome flavor ! huge malt flavor-great spicy flavor.the orange highlights are really nice.coriander , peppery.huge full body-slightly oily.very well rounded overall.a killer beer-could enjoy this on a regular basis.really has to be the best unibroue product i have had .  the balance here is seriously excellent though , and the mouthfeel is probably the best i have encountered in an ipa , period . truly a creamy elixir , perfect carbonation .

excellent . sweet and sour fruits cominate the taste , but caramel malts creep slowly in , along with alcohol , honey , and even some wood . the feel ends up pleasantly sweet and smooth .  bottled on nov. 18 , 2003 drank on sept. 1 , 2009 pour : 12oz bottle to tulip glass . the head showed big at the beginning but dissipated quickly to a thin halo and smattering of lacing .  a big rubber sensation , great deal of that , with a fair amount of barnyard funk and a carrot flavour as well . beautifully textured feel - full-bodied but smooth with a great earthy feel .

s- nice nutty aromas , butterscotch , caramel , high end rum notes . this makes me smile . t- starts out a nice light dry chocolate , some nutty notes , light caramel , and some light dry hoppiness on the clean finish .  poured into a pint glass to give a nice clear golden ting witha 1/2 inch of white head thatlingered for a while but eventually dissipated to a thin film atop the beer .  its very smooth and velvety , very nice .

s : a faint smell of malt without much of anything else . not a strong smell by any means .  12oz bottle poured into a nb tulip glass . a : pours a dark black . no head .  extreme balance and smoothness in this beer , its quite good . big full body with a champaign like fizzyness . im impressed .

it smells like a a big pile of hops . there are also some alcohol esters and actually a decent aroma of biscuit-like malt . t : hops dominate .  continuous streams of bubbles , but i would like a better head retention .  m- mouthfeel on this is incredible . medium to full bodied , chewy and creamy , moist , and not a hint of alcoholic bite .

at first i was n't getting much out of the aroma . just some very lightly toasted malts . some generic ale yeast aromas show up as well . i 've never even brewed a batch of homebrew that smells as poorly crafted as this beer 's aroma suggests that it is . thankfully , this beer does not taste terribly .  pours a hazy brown with a small head that leaves a moderate lacing .  m - perfect feel to this medium bodied brew .

s : smells hoppy , nothing special going on really . some citrus .  pours a hazy brown with tints of red . topped by a brown head that thins to a film leaving some lacing .  in addition , there are hop oils , caramel , some sweetness and perhaps molasses along with a medium body that is oh so smooth and coats the mouth well . delicious and well balanced .

aroma is very fruit dominated , and not by any single one . peach , lemon , starfruit , lime , mango ... it 's an intoxicating tropical melange . some contrasting oak and fresh yogurt notes are there too , lending some harmonizing 'wild ' elements without getting too funky . flavor is moderately puckering , tart and verging on lemony sour . hop elements are present though indistinct in the mix , lending some possible leafy orange tea notes , and residual bitterness .  goes into my goblet a very dark red with a small tan head that hugs the rim .  m : soft , smooth carbonation , big and viscous body , excellent finish . there 's very little more that i want from a big ris d : i drank my bottle in an hour and was craving more notes : i did n't really expect much from this beer because nh have n't really impressed me with much of what they 've done but hot damn , this was impressive !

i 've had a few of these and this one plays up the humidor to 11 . incredible . t. the jai alai flavor is played down a bit to the predominate cedar flavor . the grassy and citrus hops are very nice with a good malt .  pours a hazy amber with a thin white head .  one of the best mouthfuls ever !

lovely , bright cherry red color ... head is large at first , simmers down quickly ... aroma : mmmmm ... .complex ! quite a rich and invigorating aroma , i postpone consumption to prolong my time drinking it deep into the nose ... really nice !  a : semi copper and clear . thin , tan head that dissipates quickly . two , despite the heavy graham and pumpkin , you never lose the fact that this is indeed a beer .  perhaps my favorite aspect is the full and very creamy mouthfeel .

the nose is deep , thick , prodigious coffee and some raisiny dark chocolate notes , and roasted dark sweet grains .  it looks like a simple pale ale . boring .  feel is thick and full , nice and creamy .

smells delicious . sweet raisin and toffee come through very clearly .  jet black with a very small off white head that disappears very quickly .  feel : low carbonation , medium body that is extremely smooth for so low abv , very nice drying finish .

smells of roasted hopps with mild hints of chocolate .  poured into a piraat tulip glass . has a 1cm golden head with but does n't linger with some mild lacing .  the feel is super dry , tannic and superb on the palate , rough , sticky , and full ... easy to drink as this crushed by the girlfriend and i in about 15 minutes .

smell is heavenly , with the almost overpowering aroma of peaches . there is a slight coating of sweet , sticky phlegm in the back of my throat , but it is sort of pleasing . over all this was a great journey and the buzz is just what i needed .  poured from a capped unlabeled bottle from my buddy adam . no head on pour , some carbonation .  full bodied , heavy on the palate and full of flavor . i love it .

the aroma is fantastic ; a huge hit of lemony citrus and grass with undertones of pale malt and yeast . excellent ; the best pilsner i 've tried .  a- golden straw color with a tiny little thin white head . nothing much to the appearance here .  really wonderful . the mouthfeel is the most impressive and outstanding attribute of this beer .

complex and strong aroma of wild flowers , banana , orange and coriander .  appearance is dark yellow with a few big bubbles which hung on the glass .  aroma is finely balanced between sweet buttery/caramel-like malt and big herbal hops . while the taste treads the high wire between hops attack and malt sweetness the same way the aroma does , the hops edge out the malt on the tongue . without feeling heavy , this has both a creaminess and stickiness that works well to match the aggressive hop profile and carry the candy-like malt sweetness that rides along . bitter and resiny in a way that inseparably welds flavor to texture , and really helps define the beer . feel-wise , it 's magnificent . while my description of the taste sounds like the description of a big-ass double ipa , it manages to pack in a lot of flavor without going imperial . the sensible abv helps with that , and this is basically an all-around excellent , clearly california-fied version of the style . another fine brew from the typically hop-heavy moylans .

smell ; perfect balance of rich , nutty and sweet malts and citrusy hops . beautiful aroma and the american hops work nice with the rich malts . taste ; starts with a sweet , sappy , resin flavor , mixed with white sugar .  pretty much the definitiion for an amber ale . poured at about the right temperature for a small to medium , light tan head that soon settled out .  the mouthfeel is great on this one too , effervescent and full at the same time .

smell was the only thing i enjoyed . rich espresso , chocolate undertones . nose was ok .  respectable cover of off white tiny bubbles that slowly collars and disappears leaving a few wisps of lace .  m- awesome thick mouthfeel on this seasonal .

s- have some citrus notes , but you could hardly smell anything . hops also in nose . t/m-medium bitterness , some wheat aroma , carbonation is present highly .  a - very , very dark brown , small tan head leaves to ring . not much lace .  m : really a standout porter . carbonation is perfectly dialed in and gives a very subtle tingle on the tongue .

s : citra hops up front . smells of pineapple and other tropical fruits . i 'm in love with the aroma . t : slightly sweet malts .  i got just a little head in my chalice , and what i got did n't stay long .  mouthfeel/drinkability- sublime mouthfeel , super-easy in the mouth .

the smell is a complete disappointment . it smells like a good ipa , just not a wet hopped ipa .  12oz brown bottle with a bottle code that i ca n't decipher . thin layer of tan head holds its own and leaves some lacing on the glass . opaque brown with amber hues when brought up to the light . coffee flavors comes in slow but becomes a dominant flavor middle to end .  and even so , it is still incredibly smooth , and the alcohol flavor can not be detected . the body is huge . one of the thickest beers i 've had the pleasure of eating . very good stuff .

the beer is a dark dirty orange , tons of bits of fruit float throughout the glass ... .the aroma is really nice , great notes of mango not at all overwhelming or too sweet , light pine resin on the back balances out ... the taste is a huge let down , most the sweetness is gone , light mango but a lot of medicinal/metallic/pine flavors are not great .  a - near clear , orange , lots of cling leaves to disk . m - medium body , good carb .  mouthfeel is perfection . perfectly carbonated and very refreshing .

really good . t : milder than the smell , with a taste of mostly apples and cider , creamy caramel , and a mild woody gin finish .  pours a dark brown with a small brown head that does not retain well , unlike several others of its class .  easy to drink , amazing body ; feels perfect to me . d - overall this is a very good doppelbock with an amazing mouthfeel ; felt like i could have had a few of these .

smell : vanilla is immediately evident , as is a woody character . bittersweet chocolate is evident , as is a tobacco richness underneath that may be coming from the tea added . this is one seriously complex aroma ... taste : surprisingly the tea flavor jumps out first , and it is very sweet , somewhat fruity , and not an altogether pleasant introduction to the tastebuds . very shocking first taste , but once you get used to it , things seem to get better . no hops to be found in this sugary bomb . '' this was a great workout for the nose and tastebuds , but unfortunately , the whole thing just did n't come together very well .  when i finally got down to pouring , the beer came out a very cloudy yellow . cloudy to the point that my hand was just an indistinct , fuzzy shadow when viewed through the glass .  it seemed to just coat my whole mouth on its way down .

aroma is overwhelming with citrusy peach essence of hop . so sweet and spicy , very cali . i usually sniff for 15-20 seconds but this beer merits much more nasal enjoyment .  pours to a thin off-white head and a solid clear brown color .  the rich , smooth , roasted chocolate flavor works well with the silky body . this is definitely highly recommended , as the beers tend to be from great lakes brewing company .

it pours like a big , english old ale . smell- fat and sweet , it 's a beautiful display of wood and chocolate covered cherries ... but more like the liquid that surrounds the cherries . notes of old leatherbound library books and rum soaked dark fruits abound .  directly from the fridge , after pouring there was almost no head .  m-medium carbonation with a great creamy finish d-hmm i actually like this a lot ... .i 'm very confused by the other peoples ' reviews ... the taste is n't too complex but its otherwise a great drink .

this is a lovely slow-sipping beer .  brown color with tons of yeast floaters . very thin tan head . nothing special to look at but not terribly out of character for the style .  m : medium to thick bodied . the carbonation works well for the brew , and there is a lovely creamy finish that really melts in your mouth .

i absolutely love the aroma of this beer , and with more restrained alcohol its drinkability would improve .  poured into a tulip . pours a hazy golden straw colow with a bit of an orange hue to it . no head here , just a little bit of white bubbles .  mouthfeel is superb . great level of spice , perfect carbonation , medium body .

strange aroma that i can not quite place , not very interesting , maybe malt , maybe hops hmm not sure . light and malty with a hint of roast in the finish but then disappears.not much happening here , it 's finish is ever so slightly bitter and somewhat soapy .  i 'm reviewing this one as i sit at the desk drinking it . i 'm weary of drinking something from a clear bottle , but i 'll get through it . the beer itself poured a rich mahogany or chestnut color . the head was fizzy and dissipated right after pouring . the initial flavor was a caramel nuttiness and molasses .  it is full bodied and creamy in the mouth .

big foamy head , a mix of burnt malt and thick coconut in the aroma & # 8230 ; very aromatic . nice clash of burnt malt that strays to slightly to the acidic side and the mild sweetness of the toasted coconut . very interesting and yet another beer i wish i had with dessert though this would have been better with the sweet potato pie .  nice bubbling and ok foam that recedes to nothing .  m - this is by far the smoothest ipa i 've ever had . the pour from a hand pump straight from the cask creates the perfect texture for this beer .

the smell of tangerine jumps right out at you the moment you free this beer from the bottle . tangerine just fills the room . this is a unique ipa . fruit fresh from the tropics start this beer off . mango maybe ? the flavor actually kind of mutes itself in the middle and the hops kick in during the finish and stay . the hops are very citrus in nature and somewhat floral . i do n't detect the piney nature of a lot of ipa 's .  granted i gave it a swift pour as i was n't expecting this much sediment .  mouthfeel is extremely smooth & this is a perfect beer to sip on on a lazy pm with no kids in sight !

almost no head at all even though i did n't pour it gently at all.smells sweet and very fruity .  the beer pours a delicious straw-gold with a tight head that quickly fades . nice clean malt presence with just the right amount of noble hops , a touch of dms ( just enough to give it a full lager body ) and a light carbonation that helps the goodness go down .  silky smooth on the tongue and exceptionally creamy .

the nose of this beer was amazing - grapefruit , orange , mango , and pineapple and pine . the taste is just about as good . wow . mouthfeel was medium and mildly carbonated .  there was no lace .  the mouthfeel is exceptionally smooth and creamy , terrific . thanks bif for the sample .
smells absolutely fantastic . chocolate , oats , sweet malt , cream .  a - nice dark caramel . not much head , not much lacing .  wonderful body .

pours bright orange , with a nice soapy head incredible hop aroma , tangerine , grapefruit , malt biscuit and some caramel sweet upfront with a bitter pine , citrus hop bite and a hint of booze very creamy , delicious and pretty well balanced for a double ipa overall it was a very enjoyable beer .  this beer is really quite good . it has a wonderful aroma to it , and though it looks just average when poured out , it has a splendid taste and a rich , flavorful mouthfeel .  mouthfeel : thick and smooth in every sense of the words -- a very pleasant experience indeed !

smell just after the pour is a nice blend of charred malt , cola , and peanuts , but after the head boils away , a dishwater/mineral aroma also shows up . not bad , just a little off .  nice light golden straw color with a slight haze appropriate for the style . head dissapears quickly to a light spotty blanket .  this beer has a smooth , creamy mouthfeel .

huge tropical fruit aromas on this one -- passion fruit , mango , pineapple and bubble gum . creamy , with a good warming alcohol finish .  appearance : golden amber with small cuspish of head . kinda average to say the least smell : fresh cut hops , what else ? taste : taste was a bitter up front hop assault giving way to a slowly building malt base .  typical stone excellent mouthfeel .
outstanding imo . a : normal , yellowish/orange .  pours clear golden with a thin white head . the appearance is not much to write about .  nice full bodied and well carbonated mouthfeel .

aroma is just perfect . a slice of pumpkin pie in a bottle is what this beer is . picture perfect . easy to drink with good mouthfeel .  this beer poured a light yellow-orange with only about a one-finger head , and not much lacing . the smooth carbonation level and the dry finish made this a very drinkable beer .  the creamy , delicious texture pairs well with the flavorful personality of the smoked porter . the dancing carbonation paired with the brews creamy-smooth feel and intense flavor essentially block dopamine receptors in your brain .

sweat , citrus aroma . almost caramel , but not as overpowering . mildly bitter , with a heavy feel on the palate .  i thought a wheatwine would be darker , similar to a barleywine , but apparently not . at any rate , it 's very light , sunny and clear . there is barely any foam - it takes some forceful swirling to get anything at all . s - heavy on the wheat , heavy on the alcohol .  mouthfeel is outstanding . super thick and syrupy , that flavor coats the palate forever .

intresting , very intens smell , very nice hop aroma , tons of hops , citrus flavour , very similar to pliny the elder , i want to taste this one t : similar to the nose but not that strong , wheat , tons of hops , citrus , sweet malts , nice slightly bitter finish , this could be the little brother of pliny the elder , but this is softer , not so strong , m : very smooth , very well balanced , d : very drinkable , alcohol is well hidden , i could drink this all day long , yammy , well done struise .  currant jam . appearance : very hazy orange-copper . minimal head with some lacing .  silky smooth thick bodied with a perfect amount of light carbonation and a ridiculously long lasting , balanced tart and sweet aftertaste .

nose was rich with fudgy chocolate , smoke and charcoal .  presentation : on tap . appearance : hazy amberish brown .  actively carbonated , yet still seems mellow and full . strikes a perfect balance between crispness and creaminess , just heavanly . strikingly balanced for the how big and malty this beer is .

not much there in the way of lace ... s - i could smell the hops when i was pouring this ... beautiful floral aroma with a little citrus ... like putting your nose in a bag of fresh hops t - good balance for how much hop aroma there is ... more on the sweet malty side rather than bitter ... definitely a sweet aftertaste .  it is cloudy , as wheat beers should be , with a golden color and nice head .  mouthfeel : crisp , clean , and exceedingly refreshing .

'' -- review from the growler ... .dark brown color with a small tan head ... .awesome aroma of fresh picked and mashed blueberries along with a sweet chocolate aroma ... the nose it top notch ... body is a bit light ... not horribly so but i wish it had a bit more meat to it ... taste is a bit acidic from the blueberries..the cocoa complements nicely but is definitely secondary ... .  pours an orangish-amber into a pint glass with very little foam .  mouthfeel : spot on in my opinion . medium to medium-lite body with perfect amount of carbonation .

smells amazing ! smells like raspberry muffins , with the sweet and tangy fruity smell and the bread-y , yeast-y almost sour smell of muffins . raspberry taste is very muted , almost would n't even know it was there . if only it tasted as good as it smelled .  red and clear , not very carbonated . not much of a head so kind of lacking in the looks department .  body is medium full with a great velvety smoothness .

nose has a surprising sweetness with tropical fruit esters of subtle pineapple and mango : both were of the dried and sweetened kind of fruit rather than fresh . citrus , earthy , grassy hops balanced with biscuit sweet and bitter malts .  glass with no head whatsoever .  mouthfeel is phenomenal , rich and creamy it 's quite thick and chewy without going over the top .

aroma was an incredible with scents of spicy dark bread .  it was bottled in april 2010 , so i think i 'm good ... duped by the standard brown longneck bottle , i poured this into a standard american pint glass , and it appears a cloudy dark iced-tea colour , with a bit of swirling sediment , and a half finger of soapy pale beige head , which disappears quickly , leaving some sparse spidery lace around the glass .  very smooth and rich taste though and perfectly balanced . wonderfull to drink though think it should be drank as i do n't think that more age makes this one any better .

s -- the deepest , richest coffee smell i 've gotten from any beer . lots of other coffee stouts have this `` stong '' of a smell , but none that i can remember have such a deep roasty smell , its hard to describe since i am not a coffee drinker .  somewhat cloudy yellow-orange with a small white head .  rich roasty chocalaty with a fabulous creamy mouthfeel . mouth again is just amazing . another great brew by troegs .

seems very complex , i love it . t : disappointed from the smell .  poured into my duvel tulip . appearance- cognac colored pour..i guess caramel , maybe ruby caramel . 1/2 inch head on pour which is gone before you can say doppelbock . no lacing at all .  the mouthfeel is thick and rich with a nice amount of bubbly to round it out . the taste is full , many-layered . . . wonderful . a little vineous though .

s - wow . full nose of citrusy hoppy goodness .  a - cloudy . yellow . not much head .  like other fine belgian beers the carbonation produces a surreal creamy consistency that serves to deliver maximum taste .

the aroma is awesome . right away it reminds me of kuhnhenn raspberry eisbock with huge notes of sweet raspberries and chocolate .  it is a dark brown color with a brown head .  great palate , though . even when it gets warm , great warmth and sliky smooth syrups .

aroma is sweet delicious malt bomb extravaganza . dark fruits , plenty of sweet caramel laced with burnt sugars , no heat at all , and a small amount of oaty malted milk ball aroma . a+ aroma for sure . this is one amazing beer , it woo'ed the hell out of me .  very little head and no lacing or retention .  extremely satisfying in this regard .

smell : this beer smells amazing . getting chocolate , coffee , and a little dark fruit . definitely follows the nose . chocolate and coffee , maybe a little raisin .  color is a deep garnet with amber highlights . gave me a thin cap of tan head and very little lacing .  mouthfeel is utterly smooth with just a hint of carbonation ... placidly perfect .

this smell is really on the money and superbly enjoyable . tasted honey sweet with dark malts and dark fruits that fades into a smoky birch bark and a really dirty lime or rhubarb sourness .  received one fat finger of head that quickly faded . brownish copper colored body was clear .  mouthfeel is the star here . it 's plush , velvety ... is nice .

the smell of th ebeer is of subtle hops , again , nothing to over-powering .  i love marin brewing co. beers and this is a well made ale . i just do n't think it 's my style . looked like a lager which was a bit surprising as i expected something darker .  bordering on chewy as you work toward swallowing . carbonation was excellent on tap , just enough to contribute to a dry and clean finish despite the initial sweetness of the beer .

a good looking beer that smells perfect , but ca n't hold up in the taste realm .  12oz can - & gt ; nondescript pint a ~ steady pour reveals very red body with pretty good sized head . appearance is not the highlight of this brew though .  m - full body , viscous and chewy with low , delicate carbonation , very smooth across the palate with some heat from the alcohol/bourbon content .

nose : this thing has everything : an early combination of chocolate , caramel , and nuts presents a whole pecan pie on a silver platter . all this is followed by some dark chocolate covered cherries and fruitcake aroma . it has a sweet plastic lasting flavor that warns off any hops . has a bit of a smoky swallow which is nice , but does n't mellow the bubble gum . this one is getting thrown behind bars for 3-5 - then we 'll see if it 's more under control .  a : pours a black body with a small , tan head with no real retention and minimal lacing .  the carbonation is fantastic -- beer feels creamy and smooth- almost velvety .

horribly skunky , so much so that it blocks out any discernible beer aroma . the taste follows the aroma -- horribly skunky .  a - poured a cloudy orange-colored body with a slim , bubbly off-white head that reduced to a wispy film and a thin ring of retention , yielding sparse lace that slid down the sides of the glass .  extremely smooth mouthfeel and very easy to drink .

the smell is exceptional . it smells like candy the mouthfeel is really smooth , and not very thick .  this is one of the most distinctive brews i 've ever had ; the 400 pounds of peaches they throw in really show through . beer had a very pale golden coloration that i didnt think fit it to well .  but the mouthfeel is absolutely incredible .

look : yellow pale color , bare amount of foam ; smell : vinegar with lot of carbonation ; taste : mineral water , at least do n't taste bad ; mouthfeel : watery and extremely fizzy , very light body ; drinkability : a light beer made with mineral water and nothing else .  a dark copper color with a thin dirty white head that quickly faded to the edge of the glass .  great creamy thick mouthfeel , light carbonation .

the color is the clear , pale yellow one would expect . the aroma 's very faint and all i can get is some grains , perhaps a little corn husk and a musky something .  bottleshare from darthkostrizer with bhobs and alucard4 pours a hazy reddish brown with a very quick dissipating bubbly head .  the feel is creamy , rich and smooth . just the right amount of carbonation keeps it full , but not overly thick .

the smell is sweet and malty . sugar cookie , icing , cotton candy , candy corn , it is predominantly sugar , but it is many different shades of sweet . it is a smell you seldom come across in beer , and it is great . the flavor is big and bold .  pours a crystal-clear straw-yellow body with a quickly dissipating off-white head .  mouthfeel : amazing . creamy and smooth , thick .

brett funkiness shows its face , but is n't as prominent as in others from similar varieties . like the smell , the brett funkiness is more subtle than others .  pint dated for march ( end of month ) appearance dark red body ; almost a soda-like head ; left the scene like a sodas head ; lace was barely in the house smell black coffee ; a bit of molasses , earth , grass , roast and chocolate taste a touch of smoke and caramel blends with roast ; malts dominate ; bitterness takes a back seat mouthfeel a relatively rich body is cut into by a muted but consistent crisp ride of carbonation ; end is a bit peculiar dry but also a bit layering on back of the tongue ; nevertheless , overall the feel is smooth enough drinkability the close detracts from the drinkability but overall it is satisfying this would be nice ale for the summer barbecue .  thick rich and creamy mouthfeel . for such a rich and big beer it is remarkably smooth .

this is one of my favorites , this is the alt which is available year around at the brewery on tap . the bottle pales in comparison to the tap version . love to spend a rainy afternoon enjoying an alt and the good company at the brewery . when at the berwery , i hope you get to meet nick , one of the last great bartenders - great way to spent a portland afternoon .  this beer is a dark gold color , with a small cream colored head .  thick lushious body and moderate carbonation .

smells sightly yeast , but there 's not much else there .  a - pours a translucent golden color with 1 '' white head which quickly dissipates . carbonation visible in the glass , a little bubbly lacing . certainly worth a try if you like light summer beers .  silky smooth , it has just the right touch of carbonation to keep it full but not too thick or syrupy . awesome ! overhyped ?

this beer smell awesome ! ! ! as i drink it , the problem is , what flavors match up with these aromas ? the beer has a great london/english fruity estery taste with christmas ale type flavors of nutmeg and cinimmon . i wish i had more than one of these to review beacuse its a really complex ale that i would like to clone . a very drinkable ale with a great nutty spicey fruity finish .  appearance = it poured from a twelve ounce bottle with a small head that quickly dissipated without leaving any lacing on the glass .  m - very rich and thick , has a nice little burn and pop at the end from a combo of carbonation , abv and hop bitterness .

s - a lot going on but still well balanced . smells of citrus ( maybe orange ) and pine , along with some winter `` spices .  they get me all strung out on what becomes my go-to session beer -- like they did with the long-lamented cinder cone red -- and then like lucy van pelt , they snatch it away at the last second , leaving me flat on my back and yelling , `` aauugh ! '' red chair nwpa is a copper-colored pour with a sturdy , vanilla-tinted head that throws a nose of nice fragrant hops ; floral and citrus notes add some complexity to the usual pine/grapefruit assault . at around 55 ibus , red chair was the more balanced sibling of the more flamboyant bond street sisters . personally , i do n't care what they call it , it is a much better seasonal replacement for cinder cone than the buzzsaw brown was , and if they get it in their heads to make it year around , well , so much the better .  m : exactly what i look for in a beer : full-bodied and creamy with abundant soft carbonation .

when you smell this beer , you know this is a big one . lots of power and lots of liquor , much like rum with some fruity notes to me . it felt like port or a fortified wine in my mouth and the taste was rather like a really , really nice rum .  pours an effervescent crimson/caramel with 2+ fingers of sand colored head . average lacing & head retention s : cherry juice by the ton , some tartness & woody notes t : cherry juice with some booze warmth & not much else up front , maybe a touch of tartness .  mouthfeel is medium bodied , very smooth and creamy . overall this is pretty damn good .
