i 'll tell you that the smell is freaking awesome . have n't tasted the beer yet , but smells of good things to come ... here we go . s - freaking awesome . especially since i considered this some bland , flavored light beer t - nice .  pours out a very dark color , black , with a bit of ruby/brown highlights on the edges . a cm thick brown head sits on top , looks fairly dense , but falls away kind of quickly , leaving only a little bit of lacing .  the aroma speaks strongly of roasted grains , as you would expect from a stout , while on the tongue the beer has tremendous body .

nose is medicinal , muted and not very appealing . the nose is ruining the taste for me do n't know if bad tap lines or what , but i this did not taste or smell like i expected it to .  poured pretty dark for an ipa , kind of an ice tea brown , but there are some other darker ipas out there where that fact is considered part of their novelty . 1 '' head gradually dissipated to lace .  mouthfeel is about perfect , and the body is about perfect for a bock style .

typical of the wheat and carapils . s - pineapple , mango , apricot , piney hops balance with the carapils aroma . all in all , good balance . m - smooth medium body with soft carbonation . d - well , i ca n't really detect any alcohol , it drinks really fast , and it 's delicious .  a - poured a dark copper with no visible carbonation , no head as it was poured all the way to the top , no lacing and no retention .  the mouthfeel is full and velvety .

s : love the nose on this one ! was expecting a typical citrus hoppy aroma , but instead it was a more roasted/toasted & earthy .  very nearly black in color with good clarity on the pour . the head is a nice crema color but settles almost instantly .  moderate body , excellent smoothness .

s : coffee ice cream cones ? like a joy ice cream cone , and a mild coffee . only beer yet to give me that . m : creamy , creamy and creamy . imperial anyone ? t : i 'll start with a heavy dark chocolate to start .  this beer is way too dark to be a blonde .  a very smooth , luxurious malt backbone enhances the mouthfeel , but a bitter smack of hops reminds me that i 'm drinking an ipa . quite enjoyable .

right after i removed the cap i got this instant burst of fruitiness on the nose . then when i began to pour it , the aroma segued into a toasted bready , creamy , yeasty , and neutral hopped balance . i was sold before i even tasted it . fortunately the taste was just as endearing with a bold body and a sharp bitterness nut-like quality concluding with a pleasant dry hop finale . this beer really hit all the pressure points in a good way and is highly recommended .  appearance : without the sediment , it pours a hazy , dark gold body with lots of foam . the only problem is the short shelf life of the head as well as the lacking of any real lacing .  first gulp of this was outstanding.. nice creamy , mouthfeel to it that just bombards your mouth with sweet , delicious beer flavor .

smell is pure oranges and very faint hops but the smell is amazing . taste did n't lead up to the smell kind of a big build up and then aahh .  looking forward to this evem after the disappointing eipa and apa a- very hazy , milky even , brown . white head looks like warm milk froth . lots of stuff floating about .  this beer is on the lighter side of medium-bodied beers and boasts an exceptionally pleasant mouthfeel . carbonation is perfectly balanced , i could n't imagine any improvement here .
fantastic stuff .  pours in ok but no geat head and a clowdyyellow colour .  the mouth feel is the richest and thickest i have ever tasted in a beer !

the aroma is sweet roasted grains and cola .  looks like apple juice , golden-orange and perfectly clear . lots of champagne bubbles rise to a white head that quickly turns to film , but no lacing .  m : creamy and delicious . everything is dead on here .
smell - a little bit of lemon , and not much else .  my pour created a finger of tawny head with decent retention . color was a slightly hazy orangish-amber .  mouthfeel : perfect mouthfeel .
seemed nice for the style .  dark brown and cloudy . no head really .  maybe i could not taste the `` rare '' but this really sucked compared to the 2008 classic gueuze which is a fantastic gueuze .

the smell was rediculously faint . smells of toffee and pine hops , but you got ta sniff hard to pick up on it . the taste was thankfully more present than the scnet , the toffee and pine tastes were there but also a nice smooth buttery taste , some wood notes , and light bread malts .  no head , not even a film . i 'm taking a bit off for the absence of head .  body is right- light , lively carbonation , not cloying or excessively dry .
smell : raisin and roasted malt .  appearance - decent looking burnt orange/peach color .  feels right in body , but the taste is just off .

smell : classic english barley wine aromas , if a little on the sweet side .  a- pours and looks more like a porter than an imperial stout . dark see-through brown with a quickly fading tan head .  yeast , stale hops , a little grass , so boring with a duvel quality ... the taste is equally as bad , bitter toffee , light stale hops , way too much yeast , sour finish . pass .
nice . the taste starts out pretty good .  it pours a clear amber color ? ? ?  the carbonation and mouthfeel were appropriate for this style .

aroma has a nice cereal malted barley smell with some citrus and earthy hop notes coming through to complement the malts .  on to the beer : there was no head on this beer when i received it in my tulip . the color is chocolate brown wih hues of caramel orange . very lightly carbonated , and no , this was n't from the infamous bottles of the 2008 vintage , but a keg ( sorry , do n't know what vintage ) .  there is a little tart cherry , but straight blonde base beer is like 75 % of the beer equation . i 'm not sure if there is wild yeast in the bottle , but it does n't seem like this beer has developed much over time . the sourness is only noticeable , and in the end there is a good deal of artificial sweetness in the finish of the beer that is very off-putting . truthfully , it 's better than a lot of back-sweetener fruit beers but if you think this is a lambic like cantillon , you are mistaken .

very good . taste : like the smell , there 's lots of clove and sweet malt .  22 oz bomber of the 2009 vintage pours a very lowly carbonated copper color with very little foam .  mouthfeel - some good body , oily smoothness per the style . carbonation is moderate .

sampled from a 12oz bottle at the falcon 's christmas in july tasting sharp citrusy aroma with a grapefruit rind approach with some dry toasty malt notes . it 's unfortunate , but i i 'm cerrtain this was a well travelled bottle of what feels like it should be an otherwise fine beer .  pristine clear copper with a thin head . head leaves a few lacey smatterings before collaring .  mouthfeel : light-bodied and crisp .

smells nice .  for pilsner drinkers , this beer has the smoothness and malt flavor one would expect , although oftentimes that leaves a beer without a distinct taste . very drinkable and when finished , would definitely look for another scrimshaw .  i 'm thinking of a breakfast bed . the beer was thick and the foam was velvety . the drinkitbility was okay for its thickness . however , the taste was terrible . a quick slam of semi-sweet citrus that is too heavy on the lemon . the beer ends with an unbalanced bitterness for more than half of the drink .

the scent is weak , some sweet grainy notes and not much else .  a : pitch black color , no head , no lacing s : raisins , figs , sweet woodiness t : sweet oak , raisins , figs , smoky chocolate ; finishes with a nice smoky wood bitterness m : medium-thick , lightly carbonated , velvety smooth o : this did n't quite live up to the enormous hype , but it 's still a world-class beer nonetheless .  was pretty decent mouthfeel : smooth and crisp , went down easy drinkability : good enough on a hot day and goes great w/ bbq .

smell : i smell almost nothing . wtf ? taste : very mellow flavor with equal amounts of both malt and bread notes , and the orange after taste works out quite well .  appearance : really cloudy , reminds me of a wit . pours yellow with an orange tint .  the mouthfeel is smooth and oily and the carbonation is alright .

i can barely smell anything , but i do smell a little something without malts and no hops , but a funny off flavor is in the smell .  pours a slighlty hazy amber with a pretty average head .  medium bodied ; good amount of carbonation .

the beer smells mostly of semi-sweet dark chocolate and is quite nice .  i was surprised when the beer poured a clear gold .  saccharine all the way . how can you add fake sweetener to bier ? the beer is best described as diet raspberry 7 up . i already go to the gym 4 times a week so that i can drink all the fabulous beer i desire . flavors were overwhelmingly sweet , and tart . complexion was shirley temple , and body was crisp .

smell is fairly muted , some lemon , some belgian yeast . wish the smell was more pronounced .  appearance : light golden brown , slightly cloudy with decent head retention on the white head aroma : definate piney notes , with some sharp citrusy grapefruit in the aroma .  i believe the bottle i got was 8.75 percent.. looked pretty good for a esl , smell and taste reminded me very much of great western extra gold.. very malty with a nice solventy sweet-like alcohol burn ... carbonated perfectly , making it halfway drinkable , still hangover juice as far as imports go.. cheers !

no lacing , but this beer is blacker than the ace of spades . a good strong burgundy wine . then when you raise the glass the fruitiness gives way to a sharp alcohholic smell , sherry , molases , and soy sauce ... somewhat remniscent of the polish porters i have had .  pours out semi-hazy , though it 's bottle-conditioned and there is a thick layer of yeast in the bottle , requiring a firm pour to achieve a modest creamy light-tan head with poor retention and sparse lacing , leaving a thin layer of sticky clumps .  mouthfeel - explodes in the mouth with carbonation , yet maintaining a noteworthy smoothness afterwards . the body is sturdy but not overly big .

s : malty with some hop on the nose .  the serving glass and size might have affected the appearance negatively . appearance 3/5 deep amber , slightly hazy , with a moderate off white head , poor head retention and some lacing .  m : probably the best thing this beer has to offer . very smooth , with just a little bit of unwanted bitterness and carbonation .

the taste though is a contradiction of the nose , as the brooding and seriously backward bitterness assault the mouth . this is a very weighted and saturated product that may be more of a showpiece of inventive beer making rather than a true beverage of pleasure .  a - pours with a thin tan foam that settles to a thick collar , but leaves minimal lace . not much of a looker here .  mouthfeel - good feel , not too thick , kind of creamy , decent carbonation .

pleasant citrus aroma , but also a pronounced herbal presence , which was a little bit jarring .  pours a small 1 finger chocolate head . dark brown in color with medium carbonation . head retention and lacing fade to being non existant first smell is of roasted coffee malts , some chocolate , and a faint smell of alcohol sweet malt is tasted , with some smoky coffee , and light hops .  this beer does have a nice smooth , dry mouthfeel .

the aroma was strong with amarillo hop presence .  appearance : pale orange golden with a slight chill haze . wispy white lace lays on top . notes : in true rogue fashion , this is a hoppy beer .  m - solid and full , with good carbonation .

i hate it when that happens- it looks good , smells good , and then does n't taste nearly as good .  clear brown beer , short live head . not much in the way of head retention or lacing .  the milk sugar cuts through and makes it a bit artificial and like one of those creme savers candies . creamy on the palate with sugary milkiness with some of the same strawberry flavor and other general fruitiness , a touch of tartness in the finish . weirdness in the finish ... not medicinal but has a certain harshness and fake tasting combining with the artificial fruity sweetness like many of the shorts beers , nice to try , but i did n't have any desire to finish the 12oz .

s : dominated by citrus , get a lot of tangerine , citrus , pineapple , and an earthy belgian yeast kick , light pepper .  minimal head and little carbonation movement , smell : sweet molasses , alcohol , roast malt .  feels very creamy but that does n't make the beer more drinkable to me .

fruity aroma of pinnaple , banana , carmelised candy sugars , some peppery spice , and a touch of warm alcahol fumes .  pours a light gold with a thin white head , some lacing .  however , the mouthfeel was very nice , which lent a overall smoothness and softness to it .

fantastic smell of sweet banana and a slight tart cloves .  visual : pale straw , gold in color . no head .  recommended by bert from bert 's better beers . smells like dark chocolate , burn caramel , and vanilla -- sort of like an chocolate chip oatmeal cookie . smooth roast malt , dare i say a tad burnt . there 's a mild pharmaceutical character in back that i 'm not a fan of . i drank half this bottle one night and the second half the following afternoon .

aromas of caramel and toffee malt , a bit grainy , low hop aroma , a bit earthy .  hazy light amber with a thin , off-white head that fades , becoming patchy . little bit of lacing .  mouthfeel is pretty good , goes well with the style of light and highly carbonated .
might have been skunked but the aroma was actually quite decent .  a : pure black body , wispy tan head that dissipated immediately .  there 's actually a nice amount of body to this one .

aroma is spot-on.. lite roased barley and dark roasted malts and chocolate overtones ... even smells creamy .  a clear light orange with a dense yet soft off-white head with good retention , there 's also not much lacing present . decent in appearance , this is also quite enjoyable on the nose .  mouthfeel was smooth and taste was of sweet malts at first but finished quite bitter with a sharp hit of hops , alot of hops .

good hops and sourdough bread on the nose , some citrus , nice complexity and pleasant tone .  a- hazy dark golden to orange color . three finger white head recedes leaving nice lacing .  the mouthfeel is very full and hearty almost meaty- sort of flat .

a very nice set of smells on this one .  12 oz bottle bought from the wine cask in cambridge , ma pours rich ruby brownish red with a nice tan head at first which disappears quickly and does not return with swirling . if it was an older old ale i would not let this effect its appearance score , but i dont think this is very old .  m - good carbonation and a nice balance .

the nose has raw grains like right out of a brewer 's kit . it looks and tastes thicker than it is .  appearance - like a pilsener , golden , small head , medium high carbonation . laces reasonably . mouthfeel - just right for pilsener .  the mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with smooth carbonation .

the nose comprises lemon zest , a light funk , cardamom , hay , and mandarin oranges .  golden , peachy orange with just a touch of haze ; not much of a head , but what 's there is fine and white . klsch-ish aroma but with a touch more fruitiness ; apricots and golden raisins , golden syrup and scones , hints of honey and malted milk with a honeysuckle floral overtone .  mouthfeel is nice and thick and well carbonated . the best part of the beer .

the nose is roasty and slightly smoky -- not overwhelming but very nice .  growler poured into a weizen glass . an aggressive pour at that , but the 3 fingers of foam reduces to a skim in short order . lazy streaks of lacing here and there .  good mouthfeel and texture for a tap beer .

raspberry attacks the tongue in a syrupy , soda-pop way . raspberry is over the top as an adjunct rather than brewing element . i got something like dr. pepper .  22 oz bottle poured into a tulip glass a-pours a deep reddish brown with a half finger white head that dissipates nearly as quickly as it forms . a few scant bubbles and a ring around the glass is all that remains after a half minute .  as hard as i tried , i couldnt find any `` beer '' flavor in it ... it was almost like it was one of those syrups you would see vendors putting on shaved ice and making a snow cone out of , it was that sweet . the mouthfeel was good , thick , syrup-y , heavy , and coating like an imperial/double stout should be .

s : scent quite good , grapefruit & melon , hops .  my second dark lager of the evening ... .a murky brown lager that pour with ample carbonation , but somehow the head falls flat ... .disappointing .  mouthfeel is good bordering on to thick .

the nose let 's you know this has a good bit of hops . the taste starts off smooth and malty , then the hops kick in and then more creamy goodness finishes this refreshing beer .  appearance : cloudy straw color with a thin white head smell : yeast , lemon citrus , sourdough bread taste : some tartness , yeast , citrus mouthfeel : moderate carbonation , smooth drinkability : very enjoyable .  glass : new belgium globe aging notes : one year at ~60f in the dark bang for the buck ( oz* % / $ ) : 22*6.2/10 = 13.64 a : orange , white lacey head , slightly cloudy from yeast s : horse-y farmhouse brett with hints of orange t : brett dominates ( horse-stable hay , a little dung almost ) , notes of orange m : silky , coating , lingering , pleasant o : worth drinking , a little one-dimensional with the brett .

s- grape soda , rasberry jam , sour , fruity lambic . t- hoppy burn but sour . hits back of tounge and washes/settles to the front .  had to try this while at dragonmead as you do n't see many pumpkins around in april . amber color , clean with minimal off white head that fades quickly .  mouthfeel - nice body , pretty crisp .

this beer had a lot of head , mainly because i 'd poured it so shittely the smell was quite good but the taste was a bit of a let down .  a shy color of inbetween orange and yellow . a nice foamy head that goes very fast , nice carbonisation as well .  a - opaque black color with a small head that disappears quickly s - rich chocolate-like aroma , mild yeast esters , some smokiness , no hop perceived t - roasted malt flavor dominates , some yeasty esters and mild hop flavors take a secondary role , very gentle mild hop finish with some lingering smokiness m - smooth creamy medium body with moderately low carbonation d - this is a decent enough oatmeal stout . the head and retention is disappointing , but the smell , taste and mouthfeel are acceptable .

aroma is cloves , bananas , grainy malt and a bit of bubblegum . mouthfeel/body is light/medium , it 's very spritzy and has way too much carbonation .  appearance : pours an opaque bronze with a thin bubbly head that quickly disappears smell : a strong burst of malt and a bit of hops on the finish taste : toasted malt dominates , but there is a subtle spicy finish not apparent in the aroma .  well , the bottle states this brew has a `` rich dark malt complexity '' among other things . unfortunately , i do n't care for that rich dark malt complexity at all in this red ale . i like my red ales `` red '' , but without an overpowering harsh chocolate/roasted character . i did like the hop character which is mingled in with the other flavors . i also liked the color and clarity of this brew . overall , this brew just did n't work for me . oh well , that 's why they make lots of different brews , right ?

smells very nice of a strong vanilla flavor . very strong coffee smell as well . taste is somewhat strange at first .  bottle ... dark brown body with oddly carbonated head ... head is white and thin and flattens quickly ... hops flourish early , bright and sprucey ... medium-to-full bodied and effervescent -- strong around the tongue and vibrant , almost demanding ... a crisp , malty presence -- no frills , full-on balance of the bitter and the sweet ... otto 's continues to deliver , after having my school twained by the jolly roger and my tongue singed by the double d ... a memorable and enjoyable way to welcome march -- like the month , lion and lamb in one ... rating would be higher if the opening and closing experiences matched  oily mouthfeel with next to no carbonation . quite thick and heavy , coating every area of the mouth .

it poured a very nice clear copper color , and while it did not have much head it looked good and it also had a nice aroma , however , it had one of the strangest tastes i have had in a beer .  it did not have much of a head , so i was a little dissapointed . but hey , what a beer .  mouthfeel was smooth , light , though i do n't know i 'd go as far as crisp .

the smell is that of sweet metal .  clear gold with a small bubbling white head . very balanced and enjoyable ... perfect for sessioning anytime .  mouthfeel was really good for a light beer . liked the carbonation , and felt richer than it tasted .

interesting . the taste is very smoky and has maybe a beer/bacon grease flavor to it .  a-light amber/reddish color with a small head nothing much else s- smells of spices coriander and pumpkin , smells just like fall in my humble opinion t- tastes just like it smells full of pumpkin with heavy spices .  mouthfeel was good and very drinkable ; however , it was slightly bitter ... something i was n't expecting this to have considering the malts .

s - burt sugar and alcohol with a faint baking chocolate .  a straw-colored pilsner that pours with an initial frothiness that falls quickly leaving a little bit of lace .  watery quality to the flavor . has a creamy quality and a smooth carbonation , but i ca n't recommend this beer other than for that .

very warm and quite appealing with a nice strength . warming , soothing , and well spiced . nothing jumps out at ya really , its a great medley of nutmeg , cinnamon , brown sugar , and pumpkin .  appearance : the beer is a slightly cloudy beer . with good head retention . the beer has a thick white head when pourd and reduces to a thin lacy head .  the mouthfeel is very smooth , with fine/sharp bubbles .

smells like tin foil .  it started a little harsh and sharp in its heat and hoppiness ... it softened up quite a bit with the chance to warm to room temp ... the beer pours dark but thin ... dark roasted brown color with crimson highlights under the lights . opaque at the deep points , but the thin edges reveal themselves , allowing plenty of visible light to shine through . it allows the milky carbonation to open up ... higher levels of carbonation here ... not surprising that rd finishes hot and dry . the thin character allows for increased drinkability ... a very solid beer .  mouthfeel : well-carbonated , as expected from the heady pour drinkability : low- i could n't get over the tire flavor , which is a shame because every other aspect of the beer was delightful

s - very goodly smell of malts and some faint raspberry juice in the background , biscut qualities too .  poured golden with a 1/2 '' white head . minimal head retention & lacing s : perfumy hops & straw t : straw , floral hops & akiss of malt up front .  m : fairly light , highly carbonated , and very soft . i like it .

nice aroma . chocolatey and roasty .  pours a thin a off white head that rapidly dissipates into the ethers . body is deep brown-black . the oakiness becomes a bit more pronounced ion the flavor along with some of the accompanying bourbon . new hollands crown jewel indeed . i drank this around cellar temperature which really seemed to bring out its full character .  m - good . a little sticky .

o : smells nice , but that 's about it .  pours a very dark , clear , brown . starts with small , fizzy , thin head that leaves quickly , but maintains a nice thin , creamy lace . a medium tan color .  dark brown/amber body . it is a very smooth and a sweet sipper . some hops , caramel , candy sugar and oak . not much bourbon . i was way excited to try this and actually find it to be rather average .

the smell is fresh , bitter and hoppy with some notes of apricots , pineapples and a hint of tobacco .  appearance : it poured a translucent amber color with a small white head with poor retention and no lace .  has a medium body which is needed to carry all the hops and alcohol . low carbonation lends a nice texture without letting the flavors being cloying .

water . water . but damn , it 's water that gets you drunk . natty light was my high school drink of choice , so i continue the tradition today . it really has no flavor to speak of , but perhaps that 's a good thing . unlike beast or hi-life , it doesnt make me want to vomit with one sip . in any case - it doesnt taste like beer , but it aint bad if you need to get a quick load .  pours nicely into beer mug forming a reddish purple body with a thin reddish white head that has some decent retention and a little lacing , and decent carbonation .  m : good mouthfeel , its crisp , refreshing , light bodied with moderately high carbonation .

pours a bit thin for a stout , and less opaque than a stout should be . great smell though , slightly bitter malty smell with a sweetness that comes from the lactose . bitterness is more alcohol than anything else .  pours a dark , clear brown with a very small head .  the body is somewhere between medium and full , with a creamy mouthfeel .

smell : floral with a strong banana smell . notes of lavender and spice come through as well .  label on the bottle says `` craft brewed brown ale . clear and a dark red-amber colour . even with it 's little head it still manages to leave some spots of lace .  mouthfeel is quite nice and full .

it appears average , smells bad , and needs a lime but it would be blasphemy for me to give it anything less than a c. i grew up with this beer , in fact this was the first beer i ever had . s : smells of strong yeast , and potent grain malts . also faint skunk smell .  pours with a black body topped by a thick , fizzy , quickly disappearing brown head with little lacing .  highly carbonated .

poured a nice golden color with a dense rocky head pronounced piney and citrusy aroma , along with an earthy spice to it . huge hop bouquet . this beer seemed a little thin and light bodied for an ipa .  some froth and lace .  everything about this beer was pretty light - light , crisp malt scent ; light fruity taste ; light body . feel - 4.0/5.0 - refreshing , which was really nice .

smell : strong citrus aroma boasting orange , pineapple and sappy resin . they really knocked it out of the park in the smell , what an inviting and pleasing scent . has west coast written all over it . overall : a pretty impressive brew from cisco brewers .  appearance almost resembles a cola . not as dark as other porters . little to no lacing .  m - very dry with hop resin in the finish . medium bodied , with a high carbonation .

exceptional aroma . very hoppy , and you get it at the first sip , then the sweetness , finishes bitter , with all the hops of an ipa but more subdued .  i poured it into a glass and it had a small white head that disappered quick . it poured a very light golden color . while the beer was sitting on the table i looked down at it , the bottom of the glass was almost clear as water . it was n't intense .  m. medium-high carbonation , zesty on the tongue .

a : pours amber color , small white head , slight lacing down the glass s : smell is very citrusy , slight malt background t : taste is also very citrusy .  effervesces through out the whole half liter . average lacing & head retention s : bananas , cloves t : bananas , lemons , pepper & cloves up front .  m - medium body and low carbonation .

a-black , thin light tan head s-surprisingly i 'm not picking up not much more than a light hint of sweet potato , and possibly some cream . very very unique for stout t-i 'm getting some coffee notes with a sweet potato after-taste but more than anything this beer is just watery . it is absolutely a terrible stout .  incredibly drinkable , leaves the drinker craving another ! typically , i prefer a beer that hits the total of the palette , but this beer is an excellent example of its style .  there 's also just a hint of citrus from the orange peel ( or orange oil extract ) the smooth mouthfeel and moderate body is not unlike that of a german hefeweizen .

the smell was good and true to form : clear , crisp , and clean , plenty of wheat and yeast , nice and spicey , and cirtusy-sweet too .  it pretty much looks like muddy pond water , but this look in a beer is actually sort of exciting , because it signals me that i am in for an interesting experience .  body is on the full side of medium . moderate carbonation .

when i poured this beer and smelled it i was both excited and worried . it had a very pleasant raspberry smell , but it smelled strong i worried that raspberry was going to be all i could taste .  golden-orange color , almost transparent and practically no head .  adequate carbonation .

fresh aroma , fruity , with notes of peach , nectarine , citrus . once a favorite , before i discovered what the revivalists among american craftbrewers have been doing with this style . apparently , the american version , bottled and draft , is weakened some for `` our '' taste , and i 'm profoundly disappointed .  once you crack this bottle open , the room is instantly filled with that fresh hop aroma ( someone should make candles out of citra hops ) , and the pour just brings out more fruity hop notes . while the appearance is a little less than to be desired from a pale ale ( looks more like a dipa , honestly ) , the taste is so clean and crisp that you drink it so fast you can barely look at it .  very smooth without being too full bodied .

s - bready , yeasty , fruity .  not much of a head , a ring of bubbles lines the inside of the glass . deep orange/amber in color , and a very clear liquid .  goes down smooth , no bite , and finishes with an appropriate amount of stickiness . carbonation is on the lower end of the spectrum . nice feel .

peachy wine smell , a little apple cider like .  kind of goofy throw back ( 50 's ) look bottle ( works well with the duke ellington i am listening to at the moment ... ) eyeballs ... straw with a brownish tinge , nice head , withstanding well , solid carbonation , nothing fancy nothing rancid nose ... bready , almost belgian esque but a bit breifer.. malt and subdued hops like honeysuckle rather than a full on bouquet.. pleasant enough mouth action ... a nice fullness without being heavy in the least , fills the mouth amply without over carbonation , the feel is excellent across the whole pallette , this reminds me of what a `` mild '' fullers esb would tast like , quite enjoyable , nothing overwhelming , just a nice malt ( not too sweet ) start and bare bones hops that finishes dry enough to not drown out the wonderfull mouthfell verdict : an excellent session beer , not as agressive as say long trail ale in america but similar in its ease of sip and nice full feel across the whole mouth .  this is a medium bodied , well carbonated beer .

i smell orange , tangerine , kind buds , papaya , pine , and hints of rock candy . the aroma is lovely ! it smells like someone is peeling an orange next to me . good , but not as amazing as the nose .  it comes with about a fingers worth of off white head . little to no retention , no lacing left on the glass .  m : it has a nice smooth body .

does n't look like much , more like a cheap domestic pilsner , but smells pretty inviting .  who needs a lemon in a wheat beer when you can have some apricot instead ? on to the beer : yellow to orange in color that 's cloudy .  good carbonation .

s : surprisingly mild . either my bottle is a bit stale or i 've been smelling too many good ipas lately .  here goes ... i bought the beer , a single bottle , in a grocery store in oristano , sardinia ( italy ) . does n't match the bottle at the top of the page , but it does say `` stout '' and it 's strong @ 7,7 % , so we 'll call it the ceres extra strong stout . enough background .  m - nice . thick .

smell is great , very complex . ripe fruits , some yeast , a tiny bit of roasty malt and a bit of alcohol .  i can tell just by looking at how the head fizzled out and the bubbles i can see rise to the surface that this has robust carbonation .  carbonation is right on par .

a - typical brown color that comes with this type of beer ; little to no head retention s - wonderful aroma ; slight caramel and hops ; this is what a brown ale should smell like !  this golden colored brew with a quickly disappearing head is not for the feint hat heart .  taste is a very light malt sweetness upfront with a moderately bitter finish of good length and crispness . a pretty uncomplicated beer , good for the style , a good lawnmower beer .

smells great though .  pours a cloudy brown with murky red highlights when held to light . smallish off white head dissipates quickly .  the body of this beer suits the style with the usual level of north coast drinkability and feel to it . definitely the best feature .

an aroma of banana , cloves , spices and hops .  there was pretty much no head , but a bit of lacing around the sides .  being of fan of bocks , i was fully prepared to love this ubiquitous doppelbock . it was kind of sweet and malty , smelled great , felt nice going down -- quite satisfying . there was a slightly funky smell to it , and an even funkier taste . i thought that was more common in highly hopped beers . at $ 10 for the four pack , i hate to try it again for fear of wasting my hard-earned beer money .

our group thought this was not bad for a blueberry ale , and in fact some thought it was the best they 'd had . its main advantage is a drier taste than the sweet nose suggests .  faded whitish lemon yellow with a waffer thin cap of white foam slipping right off to a skinny collar .  this beer has noticeable viscosity and a big thick feel . minimal carbonation .

very pleasing . taste is really subdued .  big white head and a lightly on the yellow side amber color . not many bubbles in there .  hints of chocolate up front , but quickly overrun by the massive spices . reminds me of chewing on a mixture of green baking herbs , and about as pleasing on my palate . an interesting brew to say the least , but not one i 'd purchase again .

the smell is a turn off , musty , raw , wet-grains perhaps , but noticable almost two-feet away .  pours a super black with no head and no lacing . another flat looking beer .  after smelling , i picked up on a semi-complex mix of belgium candy , malts , cherries and alcohol . it sat heavy on me and did not taste refreshing to me . i enjoyed this beer and can tell there was definitely quality & craftsmanship involved in it 's making ; but it 's not the best tripel i have ever had .

smells surprisingly good . the berry aroma really stands out here and is not what i would call subtle like the label implies . i was really pleased with the aroma , but this is just way too much .  nice head and golden beercolor with big particles in the beer . nose is strange for a white ; bretty , hoppy and sourness giving this brew a unfamiliar witbier nose .  mouthfeel is crisp and drying , as it should be .

s : lime . lime oh and did i mention ( in dejected tone ) lime .  750 ml bottle , great label , opens with a champagne like pop , a : pours a deep red umber to brown with an initial three finger head which recedes quickly to a smooth cap of foam , no lace is a surprise . arguably the most authentic belgianesque mouthfeel i 've had in an american made , belgian style beer , reminds me a ton of achel brune in this respect . very impressive .  the feel is between medium and full for the style and enjoyably so . moderate carbonation nails the feel .

the aroma was pleasant , light and floral .  i 've had plenty of these in my day , but this is the first i 've actually sat down with to review ... a - pours a slightly cloudy , orangish copper color , a little darker than alot of ipas . head grows to about 1 inch before settling down to a thin outer layer .  the mouthfeel is notably well contoured . dark and hearty though at times cloying .

aromas of black current , butter , black coffee , some malted milk and alcohol.first thing i notice about this beer is the fact that it is a bit too carbonated for the style . there are way better brews out there .  a pour down the center gave an initial 2 fingers of tan head , which diminished rapidly to a little foam around the edges ... a little disappointing . the dark color is n't opaque , if held to a back light . dark hues of deep red/garnet highlight the edges . no lacing either ( also disappointing ) .  m -- thick , slick d -- very one dimesional brew .

nose is full of pumpkin pie spices with a strong presence of ginger and nutmeg .  dusky brown appearance , with ruby highlights at the edges , very slim and soon gone head , nothing to speak of .  lovely thick aromas of blackstrap molasses , dark bitter chocolate , strong coffee and deep roasted malts ... awesome aromas to this one ... lazy and flat tasting ... strange bitter almost sour taste present ... . not much in common with the aromas ... thick oily mouthfeel is great but i ca n't get by the taste of this one ... drain poured this one ... maybe a bad bottle but as is , a big disappointment ...

the aroma is quite limited but offers some light malt and spicy hops , as well as some light sulfur ( which seems to be characteristic of the brewery ) . the maltiness has an odd , almost musty , bready note that 's fortunately overshadowed by a spicy , but indistinct , hop flavor .  the beer pours a hazy golden orange with a small amount of head .  pretty refreshing , not overwhelmed with carbonation .

s : sweet maltiness , taffy candy maybe , a touch of citrus hops in smell . best part of the brew . t : has a cheap lactose/sweet stout sweetness to it .  2009 375ml bottle a : pours a murky chestnut brown with amber highlights near the edges . bottle gave a muted `` pop '' but not going on with the bubblies ; does n't offer more than a ring and a few swirls of carmel-colored head .  it is medium bodied and smooth in the mouth .

this smells delicious , close to pumpkin pie . some good , some bad on the taste .  besides the color ( pale yellow with a tinge of orange ) , everything else is amazing .  you do n't get much of the sweet malts you get from the aroma so it really confuses the senses and does n't make for an enjoyable experience mouthfeel is heavy and it sticks to your mouth for minutes .
s- it does have a nice smell of oranges .  a super thin collar is all that is left including zero lacing .  mouthfeel is light bodied with good carbonation .

a pretty pleasant smell , although not a lot of hints of much of anything .  expectations were low , as the waitress told me its like killians red . hardly . appearance was not red , but more of a light brown/amber . as far as amber lagers go , this is a good one .  m : medium in both body and carbonation .

smell is hard to detect . pale and caramel malt with a light hop backing .  a - pours a chestnut brown s - toffee , caramelized brown sugar , toasted wheat bread , maple , toasted nuts . t - lots of nutty malt , some light sorghum , notes of caramel , vanilla , dry bread sprinkle with a dash of cocoa powder , hints of over-ripened blueberry . finishes with nutty dry bread aftertaste . very good beer . way better than expected . a standout beer in it 's class .  the carbonation on this beer is very light with a medium body , the beer itself has a sliky relaxing feel with every swallow . its has a mellow feel to it nonetheless . overall this an average beer that im sure has its audience who will think less of it and people like myself who may not dislike it but not exactly like this beer .

the aroma was simply amazing ! i was champing at the bit to drink this . very sweet smelling . reminiscent of belgian candy sugars and granny smith apples . it was n't unpleasant but i did n't expect this from the aroma . overall , an impressive beer .  pours a very clear , pale yellow with almost no head , even trying .  thick and smooth mouthfeel .

smell is nice , slightly sweet malt . right on par .  a hazy dark yellow color with a head that i missed since i looked in another direction ( for 3 seconds ) while rvdoorn poured the beer .  body was medium , and the liquid was fairly smooth overall . 3.03 rdev -19.5 % look : 3.5 | smell : 3 | taste : 3 | feel : 4 | overall : 2.5 1366

served on tap at the gingerman austin aroma : cold coffee sweetened with a touch of malt appearance : clear ruby brown glass barely covered with a thin tan head that left wisps of lace . mouthfeel : medium thin body with low carbonation level overall impression : real ale does it again .  pale orange like an unripe loquat . smells just like a pumpkin pie . taste like a pumpkin pie with a lot of spices .  mouthfeel is very light and well carbonated .

hops subdued on the nose in a slightly citric tang . looks good , smells fine , nice to drink .  great retention and poor lacing .  i like the thick , syrupy mouthfeel as it 's quite comforting but the taste gets old fast and just is n't complex .

aroma is sweet and soft and fruity , full of peaches and melons , among more . hops are actually quite quiet and make little presence upon the palate .  64oz growler poured into tulip glasses : a : pouring into a tulip glass from the growler purchased yesterday at portsmouth brewery , the alt is surprisingly headless . other than that it is a gorgeous ruby red hue .  good , solid creamy feel with enough dryness to get you through .

s - a nice soothing floral aroma , a bit of the odor from those red annuli that come with steaks , and then there is some seltzer water .  it takes a pretty vigorous pour to get much of a head .  m - light to medium carbonation with medium carbonation .

aroma smelled strongly of fresh strawberries ; very nice .  amber brown , perfectly clear , with a single finger of soapy white pilsner-like head that settles to a ring quickly .  '' m - actually a nice and robust mouthfeel , i just do n't really want to feel this beer in my mouth because it tastes kind of terrible .

an excellent cheap beer .  a -- old gold body and a nice medium head .  the flavor that by far took the lead was chocolate ! there 's an overpowering ( and for me , disappointing ) chocolate aftertaste in this beer . mouthfeel- smooth , no complaints here . drinkability- well , the bottle looks cool as you drink from it !

s - it smelled of citrusy hops - mostly orange peel aromas . there was a sweet maltiness to the nose , too .  cloudy yellow with tendencies toward something darker , more orange . the head is a little flat , though .  it was somewhat thick with some carbonation , and had a hot aftertaste .

s - aroma is quite pleasant with lots of wheatyness along with a strong malty sweetness .  a really dark brown with barely any head at all . at first glance this beer looks thin .  notes : brewed with 100 % scottish maris otter malt ( used in distilling ) and fuggle hops , this is quite the unique beer , albeit it is also excessively raw and aggressive in its flavours . the hops are a way too perceived in the flavour and aroma for the `` scottish-style '' , hence the experimental beer placement .
aroma was very pleasant , with yeast/bread , melon , a light orange , honey and some spice .  pours deep brown , with a thin off-white head .  m : nice carbonation and pretty effervescent .

the aroma is bad . i liked saison noire , but this is very disappointing . in the end , this beer is cacophonous with some off flavors and a downright bad aroma .  very faint off-white head that fades quickly over an extremely clear golden to orange colored body .  let me first say that the brugse tripel used to be one of my favorite beers . nowdays its called brugge tripel and the taste changed slowly ... but a lot of small steps make a big one and today this beer is nothing what it used to be . smell of spices and a little hops , not fresh at all and a dull taste make it just a drinkable beer but nothing great like it had in the past .
the smell included subtle notes of nutmeg/pumpkin .  pours a hazy amber with fine carbonation ; not much of a head .  m : medium bodied , good amount of carbonation .

back in the aroma i am digging the rich toasty bready stuff . there is a bit of the aroma 's promise for maybe a quarter second , then , `` wham ! i would imagine that if the flavor held to the aroma this would be a nice red ale that i could drink a ton of , but this one just is n't right .  it tasted kind of dry , rather like champagne with the flavoring of berries and just a hint of carbonation . this was a very good beer from leinenkugel and i will be very happy to buy it again .  mouthfeel is medium , carbonation average-high with some pleasant warming feel .

s = light apple smell with a hint of apple .  a hazy orangeish brown with a small head which quickly receded and left minimal lacing .  m & d - this beer is great on its own , too light and carbonated and malty for me , but suits a nice dinner perfectly , goes well with food and that was its intention so i must review it within its intentions and the style , for which it is very good

nose is molasses and licorice with some hints of smoke ; sweet dried plums and cherries in the background . it looks like a stout . the low taste rating is simply because i did n't enjoy this beer , and i 'm very jealous of the reviewer who managed to taste this on draft because i 'm stuck with five bottles i do n't want : - )  2007 vintage . poured into a snifter . no head after pouring . thick and black . minimal carbonation . the appearance of this one is the only thing that must bring it down in the ranks as the other attributes are top notch .  m - good mouth feel . somewhat unique in feel .
smell is fruity with a nice yeast kick at the end .  pours a clear golden color with a big white head that diminishes quite quickly .  the body is light-medium with good carbonation .

s : some really great aroma here - coconut , vanilla ... not sure how else describe the slight alcohol aroma but reminds me of spiced rum t : big alcohol burn .  pours a clear light amber color with a thin white head that dissipates quickly with no lacing .  m : good mouthfeel .

heady ginger smell , nice . t : heavy ginger and sweet malt , quite medicinal .  pours a less than clear reddish brown . head only lasts a fleeting moment with no lacing to speak of .  big body , low carbonation .

the nose is greeted with notes of sweet molasses , chocolate , and medium roasted grains . aroma is the best thing this stout has going for it .  a - golden amber with a thin off-white head that dissipates quickly .  mouthfeel is round and full , thick and sticky .

the nose was unimpressive , but the flavor was very light , with some nice hops and a bitter finish .  this brew pours a very cloudy , almost milky-white color , topped with a short and airy foam .  there 's moderate carbonation to it as well .

it smells of yeast .  pours black , with some ruby highlights that shine through when held up to the light . small head that did not last , some sporadic lacing . quality brew , only low point is head retention .  amazing . while the style is not my first choice for a beer , i 'd been told that i really needed to try something from unibroue and this one was it . i taste coriander and a lot of other , complex flavors that i am too n00b to identify . as for aromas , just a very pleasant yeast smell .

smells of overly spiced pumpkin pie , which is a good thing . cinnamon and clove come out straight away . the smell was completely misleading ; i think i found pumpkin in this one somewhere , but the spices are glaringly absent ( with the exception of cinnamon which comes through the nose ) it kind of leaves an off flavor behind that i do n't like .  muddy brown color .  mouthfeel : really thick and chewy . this part would be enjoyable in a good-tasting brew .

smell : grainy with a cut grass smell when cold - and almost no smell at all when warm .  poured this 375 ml green bottle into a lindemans flute . the first pour was clear golden with many tiny bubbles clinging to the sides . the second pour was murkier .  mouthfeel is quite decent .

i 've heard things about this one , so was pretty jazzed to get to try it at the firk ' last night . it pours a mostly clear peach juice topped by a finger of off-ecru foam . the nose comprises apricot , light brett , green apple , light caramel , lime , and light toffee .  this beer looks a bit too light for an english ipa .  very tame malt , very little hops , and weak alcohol that 's more like aftershave . definitely not over-carbonated , the texture fits the style . actually the best element of this beer .

i gave it a good rating for smell just because it 's so damn unique . taste is sweet malts , some hops and a bitter finish .  it pours a hazy dark-red orange color , with a small white head that had little retention and mild lacing .  m - pretty thin and definitely refreshing .

smell is very nice and enticing . t - here 's where this one starts letting me down a bit .  this one pours very clear and almost `` light '' looking for an ipa , it 's a rather light amber with a puny head .  it is very finely carbonated , giving a tickle on the tongue .

i watched the last rays of a texas sunset leave the flat wilson co. horizon from the porch of my uncle kenneth 's ranch near lavernia . aroma of unexplainable vinous along with the expected alcoholic and sweet malts . i loved this characteristic but moving on to taste was disapointed in taste .  once it settles down it 's a hazy/cloudy golden hue with bleach-white head that crashes quickly . ( loses points for over-flowing . ) nose is of lovely sour/wild strawberries , a nice toasty or nutty note , and a suggestion of forest floor ( yes , a poetic beer ) .  feels nice in the mouth .

the aroma is very belgian with lots of sour fruit lacto , weaker raspberries and cherries , dusty basement .  extremely cloudy , almost milky thick pale orange golden color .  taste - 3.0/5.0 - light `` summer '' type beer , prob good if really hot , some malt crispness feel - 4.0/5.0 - smooth , light , refreshing drinkability - 2.5/5.0 - would have again , if it was hot , but not enough flavor make this a go-to beer

lots of citrusy , hoppy aromas a bit of good barnyard funk .  the beer pours a dark brown with an off-white head ... small with not a lot of lacing or retention .  m- medium viscosity with a well integrated carbonation .

the aroma was of roasted malt , coffee , smoke and hints of chocolate .  aroma : malt base with some mild floral hop notes appearance : deep gold that looks too light for a bock in my opinion . nice white head , even from the 3rd or 4th pour from the growler , and nice rocky lace .  m : it has a nice mouthfeel .

pleasant , fairly bright aroma - very fruity . hard to tell where , or if , the amarillo begins . musty , funky brett note .  dull orange straw color with a little haze hanging around , the head starts off big but then falls to a thin layer of lace .  the best part of this one is the mouthfeel ; to my surprise , it is rather thick , at least for a beer of this style .
the nose was quite nice : sugary , light malt , soft floral hops .  small amount of head but it dissipated almost completely .  the mouth is pretty nice , feels rich but easy to drink .

very sexy . s - great smell , definitely get a heavy does of burnt chocolate , some roasted coffee and other malts . great example of roasted scents . i would gauge that there was a spectacular effort put into tempering this brew to get these scents from the malts . i like sours but certainly not mixed with this style . very bitter as you will note from almost every review but this one had an almost sour milk character that turned me off during my dinner which was centered around beef .  dark but not opaque .  mouthfeel : light/medium with a tart , crisp finish drinkability : i really do n't crave another of these ; this certainly would n't be a lawnmower beer for me conclusion : just kind of unsorted ( also kind of an odd bitterness on the finish ) ... i tried this a year or two ago and was n't a huge fan ... now that i 'm reviewing it ... i 'm still not .

smell is impressive relative to low expectations - i 'm skeptical of hop-forward beers that are n't locally made and consumed fresh , but this one still has a resiny punch in spite of it 's journey from scandinavia , with a little oxidized biscuit malt as well .  big malt aroma ( munich-type , sort of crystal but with a light roasty component ) with some grainy cereal notes . seems a little light colored for the style , just barely off gold , with a touch of haziness . smallish head that fades after a little while . very nice malty profile . hop bitterness is well in balance but still very subtle . clean fermentation .  this beer tastes like sheep shit . this may appeal to some people , but it 's definitely a very unusual belgian ale . i enjoyed drinking half of this beer for the experience . it 's so pungent i laughed out loud . it 's always fun to be exposed to a radically different flavor profile than you 're used to .

smells of deep , dark chocolate and sweet milky aromas taste is rich and complex of dark rich chocolate . still an enjoyable brew although i was a little bit let down i was expecting a little more from this brew .  12 oz bottle , bottled 06/18/08 a : deep black under a small tan head . no lace , no retention .  mouthfeel is about the only thing going for this one . medium body and appropriate carbonation .

aroma : a great mix of sour and vinegary notes over a sweet malt body . mouthwatering . unfortunately , this is nowhere near as intense as the nose and ends up way too subdued for my tastes .  poured into snifter on 12/9/09 10/6/09 etched the bottle a - dense & hazy copper ; amber highlights . semi-aggressive pour yielded hardly any head . swirling is required to garner any semblance of retention . minimal lacing ; what 's there is sporadic .  m - nice and creamy in the mouth , goes down smooth .

the blueberries floating in it drove the aroma of fruit in the nose , like cereal fake blueberries .  the wee heavy poured into my snifter displays a deep amber/light brown color with a moderate off-white head that very quickly diminished to barely a skim .  the mouthfeel is medium to full with decent carbonation .

the aroma has a promising grapefruit hop note up front .  a : tried to entice a head , but it came out like oil and left a thin deep brown head that lasted for a few minutes .  full body , syrupy like samichlaus . very similar tastes and mouthfeel .

smell : lots and lots of blueberries .  this ale is dark amber in color with a small off-white head .  the mouthfeel is moderately thick and full for a pilsner and has a creamy texture . the citrusy hops create a crisp bite towards the end .

the whisky barrel smell hits you immediately , and like a ton of bricks . it continues from there , slapping you with a mouthful of roasty malt and alcohol . the nastiness continues in the aftertaste , and the best part is when you ca n't taste it any more .  this beer pours a hazy orange-red color . the head is half an inch in height , and recedes quickly into minimal lacing .  body is medium and carbonation is mild .

smell was barely there with a touch of hops .  pours a brown amber color with a fairly weak head and very few lacings but does keep a nice brown film on top .  light body and nice and creamy . moderate carbonation .

smell is the leader of the pack , amazing scent of coffee , cream , smoke . drinkability suffers from the mouthfeel since this is the only non style rating , but i really like this porter .  a - poured a cloudy golden yellow with very little head . lacing was average .  '' the mouthfeel is good . its quite smooth and slightly creamy .

the aroma instantly improved my mood . wonderful complexity . dark fruit , alcohol , plum , rich malts , yeast , a little tawny port , some light diacetyl , and little bit of cola . again , nice nose , but overall this was a huge disappointment .  really a weird pour as it comes out a very nice hazelnut color but with no head at all to speak of .  decently carbonated mouthfeel , and medium-bodied .

a real nice looking beer . very light in the nose . a little bit of floral hops but that 's about it . not too impressed .  a-bright , fluffy white head , 2-finger off the pour , then reducing gradually to a sparse bubble layer . slightly hazed light golden beer showed visible carbonation bubbles rising playfully .  m : about the same consistency as the boston lager .

one strange feature , when poured it fizzes with carbonation like a soda , very unusual and it continues to fizz for some time s-chocolate , molasses and bourbon t-when cold it follows the nose , but as it warms both the smell and tastes become overwhelmingly strong with bourbon , almost too much m-above average , but due to the abv , it 's more like whiskey than stout d-i hate to be contrary to others , but i did n't really care for this , it 's described by others as a `` sipping beer '' and while i appreciate that , if i wanted to drink bourbon i just would , this did n't do it for me  a : medium reddish brown color . light tan / cream colored head , but not much of it .  for a big mouthfeel , this simply does n't have a flavor to match . very nice mouthfeel , good bite up front , a bit of carbonation in middle that emphasises the rye flavors , and a crisp finish that is actual slightly ruined by the lingers smoked flavor .

overall , this beer looked and smelled great , but has too much bite to really enjoy .  a : pours a murky orange/ruby color with a thin cap of fluffy tan head that sits on top .  char davies , the artist in 1998 , made a fully interactive immersive visual/aural virtual artwork called ephemere , which furthers the work begun in osmose started in 1995 and displayed in the national gallery of canada in ottawa on june 26 , 1998. who cares ? this beer is almost close to a champaign ( and i would think that the yeast probably is champaign ) . also there is bitterness , which is nice to know that at least there are some hops to the so called beer . it is not advisable to use apples with fermenting , as the yeast creates funky flavors from apples , but this is much better than expected . although i would not want to drink this beer on a regular bases , thus low score on drinkability , i think it has a great taste like a grandsmith apples i use to eat as a kid .

the aroma is amazing , i must admit . the feel is definitely most disappointing . this thing smells amazing , and tastes good too , but the feel is a bit rough around the edges , and adds some unfortunate difficulty to the drink-ability .  served on a tulip glass . a - hazy straw to pale gold pour , unremarkable head , short retention , fair surface ring and some lacing .  the mouthfeel was the best thing about this beer .

beautiful fresh dry-hop aroma . the malt is not hidden , though , with a pale malt aroma blending in with the floral hop resins .  pours cloudy and warm chestnut under a diminutive cap of slightly pink foam that receeds to a film suddenly and quickly .  a nice mouthfeel with some decent nuttiness and a tasty touch of roast .

i love the vanilla and banana esters given off by most weissbiers , this did n't have those qualities . the only aroma i found was of cereal and grains , even those were weak . refreshing enough , but it lacked a true bite and any character worth mentioning .  appearance : medium carbonation , 1 inch head , dark brown smell : malt , chocolate syrup -- like bosco , and cream taste : chocolate , burnt malt , nut , and cream mouthfeel : sweet , medium bodied , smooth drinkability : this is a surprisingly sessionable stout .  mouthfeel is fine . medium bodied with the right amount of carbonation .

smells of sweet roasted malt , some fruit .  pours a straw yellow from a 12oz bottle to a standard pint glass . dissipating to a half finger head with good lacing .  mouthfeel is solid - fairly light , appropriate carbonation .

really not very notable . mild hops and roasted toffee smell .  pours a pale straw yellow color with a decent looking body and about two fingers of nearly pure white head . ample carbonation and the head is very fizzy , and as such it recedes quickly and leaves not a lick of stick or a trace of lace .  and of the 6ix , cranberry lambic will likely catch your eye first and disappoint you the most . if you are like me the word `` lambic '' leaves you with a dumb look on your face . you can relax because this is not a real lambic . just as champagne is not champagne unless it is bottled in champagne , france : : a lambic is not a lambic unless it is brewed in pajottenland , belgium . aside from that minor detail a lambic is brewed using spontaneous fermentation and possess a clear vinous finish , cranberry lambic does not-and that maybe a good thing . do n't drink this cold-i 'll be honest , this beer is n't great , but it does deserve more credit , the balance between cranberry and yeast is impeccable ; the finish is crisp and light like a wine , less the vinous/lambic feel . it does great before , during and after dinner , this unique `` boston lambic '' is worth an unbiased try .

s - cherries , duh ? but what smelled like very sweet cherries .  ) ..its a pretty average looking ale pale amber , large frothy white head .  the mouthfeel is very nice.. feels heavy , thick , smooth , and not over-carbonated .

smell is rich caramel and roasted maltiness with a distinct dairy sweetness .  appearance : dark brown with a tan , creamy lace . there was a hell of a lot of sediment in the bottle .  m : creamy and spot-on carbonation .

aroma is actually quite good . sweet rasberry aroma , mixed with a nice lager like smell .  a decent sized white head that dissipates quickly over a macro-brew-looking yellow-clearish beer . not a great appearance . but i really , really enjoyed this one despite its underwhelming appearance .  very nice feel .

smells really good for a belgian strong dark so i 'll give it that , but the brett and sour cherry components were just not there as i thought they would be . could have been but the aroma was n't bad so i have my doubts .  this pours a nice dark brown with an off white head . little retention and virtually no lacing .  it has a canned fruit essence to it , but i ca n't pick up what kind of fruit . first couple of sips and i get a strong cherry pie filling flavor . i eat a lot of fresh cherries in the summer so i do n't automatically associate cherries with pie filling . not overly sweet but it does have a tart tang finish . a unique beer that i appreciate as well done , just not to my tastes .

( s ) - plenty of rich molasses & raisin with an even richer vanilla & whiskey-like smokiness . ( t ) - just like the smell with a pronounced raisin & cocoa profile .  a- poured into a glass with a thick 3/4 '' foamy white head , which quickly dissipated , leaving no lacing behind .  m : crisp and clean , moderate levels of carbonation and warmth . medium body .

s - nice hop aroma with a few floral notes .  rusty , deep brown . thin , big-bubbled tan head recedes quickly and leaves negligable lace .  m : the body is medium to full with a fairly high carbonation . this is actually one of the best things about this beer .

smells fig , chocolate pudding , pears , brown sugar , candi-sugar , floral , clean alcohol , and a waft of spicy zip . nice candi-sugar adds depth , as does a spicy belgian yeast zip .  god , that sounds so snobby and like such b/s ... nonetheless , it pours a very nice orange/beige and again had no head mainly because i believe that i poured it wrong . damnit , that 's two meals for me .  m : medium bodied with moderate carbonation .

smell : floral and citrus hops , sweet caramel malt .  `` brewed with 4 gallons of pure maple syrup '' served in a shaker pint , t-town maple brown is a murky , rusty light brown with a thin egg-shell collar .  served in a pint glass mug a : pours a clear bronze color with about an inch of thick head s : a smell provides a nice rye scent with a very sweet undertone contributed by the honey addition t : very nice smooth tasting beer , has a slight hint of honey and perhaps a slight rye note but other than that there isnt much to comment on , smooth and slightly sweet but thats about it m : very smooth in the mouth with a slight bite on the tongue as it is drank d : high level of drinkability , very subdued taste that is great for a hot summer day but leaves the drinking looking for more otherwise .

color seemed consistent with other ipa 's of the high alcohol content variety , and it had a pleasant , slightly fruity smell . regarding taste , you initially get hit with a flavorful mild fruit taste , but it fades into a musty bite that reminds me of the aftertaste of the awful four horsemen .  pours mahogany with 3+ fingers of mocha head . average lacing & head retention s : roasty malt & chocolate , plus a slight iron scent t : chocolate , roasty malt , & some dryness up front .  pretty solid .

sweet fruity aroma with a little bit of maltiness .  a : cloudy yellow/orange color with some suspended solids . broken , thin lacing ; none near the end .  mouthfeel is decent medium bodied and goes down smooth .

the smell reminds me of peaches in a can with syrup and is slightly interesting . the taste is oily hops on top of a decent amount of malts but is just not very good .  i 'll be brief on this one because this is an experience that will be very different from person to person and the bottle temp is as important as its age in evaluating this beer . if you like big beer this is the circus fat lady of big drink it slow and share it with a friend . also this is a good beer to lay down and enjoy aged . malt , malt , malt ! !  the mouthfeel is crisp overall .

the aroma is exceptional as you can smell this ale when you pour it out of the bottle . deep dark fruity ester mingle with a citrussy coriander spiciness make for an excellent aroma , this is the first beer i have tried in which the aroma exceeds the flavor . the rich aroma led me to a letdown as the flavor was much more subdued than i expected . the body of this ale is an immense letdown as a scotch wee heavy imo should have a bit more viscosity and sweetness but this is a rather thin ale in terms of body . the scotch ales always throw me off due to the lack of hops and for some reason i have a hard time enjoying tha malt flavors unless they are balanced by a signifigant amount of hops .  i was unable to have this beer in a glass , so the appearance rating is average .  the mouthfeel is thick and oily with a mild burn going down . have a bottle of this is all i can handle , which is good because the full bottle would have me a little too buzzed .

this one was aged in jd barrels and there is a definite whiskey note on the nose . quite a bit of oak and vanilla .  certainly does n't look overly intresting .  medium full bodied , somewhat creamy .

the pour ... .no ... the pop of the cork ... did n't happen . it 's cloudy partly because of a chill haze i assume . the cork came out too easily and it was n't tight . this brewery makes good beer and this does n't make the cut . i 'm dissappointed .  bomber this one poured out light and orangey with a bit of chill haze . left a delicate lace on the glass .  m : the mouthfeel , on the other hand , was quite good . d : it 's certainly very sessionable , with a low abv and a really nice mouthfeel , but the flavor is just so weak that it 's difficult for me to really recommend it .

the aroma is very nice . taste : sickly sweet . drinkability : the aroma is very promising , but the sweetness destroys it , this went right down the drain - and i had wanted to enjoy it as it was a pain to get .  pours a thick deep black with a very thin tan head . no retention , no lace .  m : easy drinking with medium-body and low-moderate carbonation .

smells `` fresh '' , and lightly hoppy .  light golden color ; a little lighter than expected . smells hoppy ( citric , very grapefruit-like ) with an underlying sweetness . hops are very flavorful ( citric ) and also bring a decent bitterness , but are never harsh at any point . very tasty and drinkable beer that packs a punch .  very creamy and full . very dry .

smells sweet and complex , fruity and slightly sugary .  this bottle pours a hazy amber with little head . carbonation is a bit low , and it 's not the prettiest beer in the world .  this is my first review and hope it looks well , even if not my favorite beer . leaves a malt taste on the roof and tongue . this is the first scottish ale i 've tried . for comparison , i love dark ales , like ommegang abbey belgium ale and founders breakfast stout . bottle serving .

smell : very light hints of malt that was indistinguishable from anything else . it was very watered down .  aesthetically pleasing and making that trademark , `` gloop , gloop '' sound when pouring , it creates a wonderful mood . appearance : a very hazy , earthy copper tone with minimal , fine white head that dissipates quickly , but a ring of foam remained at the glass/beer interface of my st. bernardus goblet throughout the session . unexceptional .  taste : a wink of hops , than the shows over , a surprisingly dry finish mouthfeel : decent - nice restrained carbonation , ever so slightly creamy notes : this is the driest , and least bitter ipa that i have ever experienced .

s - berry and more berry t - strong raspberry flavor , but very little beer flavor . it reminds me of ab wildblue m - thin and watery , nothing particularly special i 'm conflicted on many of my ratings for this beer because on the one hand , many of the attributes of this beer are on purpose ( like the pink color ) but at the same time , it 's not a beer i would pick up again .  very carbonated , a light and bubbly beer . the head fluffs up and then dies down , a shame . the color is a golden white , a bit of a haze .  most everything else about this beer was great , looked good , good mouthfeel , but the taste .

smells not like a red ale at all , very sweet , malt pouring out of the glass , pretty enticing .  kind of cloudy hazy light golden color .  m : the carbonation is pretty much just right , and it 's smooth .

s : a very inviting sweet smell of hops and oranges .  a - poured out a clear , dark burgundy color with a very small , thin head of off-white foam .  mouthfeel : thick and what you would expect from a ris .

the spiciness attacks your olefactory senses with a vengence . aroma reminds me of some winter warmers i 've had .  a - pours with a thin fizzy white head that dissipates quickly .  nice creamy mouthfeel .

very sweet sour nose and gives a consistent very thickish foamy head leaving lots of delicate complex lacing all over the glass .  a - pretty darned black , minimal mocha head that ends fast , lacing thin and unimpressive .  flavor is malty and sweet , and on the finish , bubble gum ! mouthfeel is firm , and drinkability is high .

aroma is strong with caramel malt , toffee , brown sugar , molasses , and a bit of alcohol .  oh , it looks like a euro pils , and to some extent , smells like a pilsner .  mouth feel is smooth and clean , with an average carbonation level . overall , good aroma , blend , body , and feel .

the beer has a very spicy odor , maybe a hint of cloves or something similar in the nose .  poured a 1 finger white head that dissipated to random bubbles . laced in thin broken rings .  moderate hops with lots of body , almost chewy .

aroma was pretty bland .  this beer poured a brown color with very little head .  this is my first , of hopefully many reviews , so bare with me . once they were chilled i poured them into a pint glass and sat back with my favorite tv shows a- pours a dark red almost brownish color s- smells like your average porter , did n't really pick up on too much vanilla t- taste more of chocolate or toffee but with hints of vanilla m- pretty smooth , goes down easy without any bite o- not sure if i would buy a case of it , but its good when thrown in a variety pack

smelled great very rich and malty . unfortunantly that aroma did not carry over in the taste which was on the weak side .  deep brownish-copper color , with tan head . head does not last long , and lacing is minimal .  boiled pasta water finish . good carbonation . twinge of acid is perfect .

aromas are medium bodied , and fill the nose with cherries , roasted malt , and wood elements .  poured into a standard pint glass a : straw yellow and crystal clear . despite this , the beer really has minimal head .  the feel was light , clean and crisp . damn , and after smelling this hefe , it had so much promise .

smell : i could barley get any scent out of this beer , but a light caramel/brown sugar nose did come through . although my scores for appearance and smell are low , i think the taste makes up for it enough for me to buy this for a review in the near future .  a : cloudless goldenrod color with only traces of white head .  mf : soft and medium-bodied . coriander and crispness does n't stand out enough .

s - very nice . the aroma from the pecans is subtle but noticable and mingles well with the expected toasty , caramel , and slightly toffee aromas from the malt .  a : hazy amber , nice small white foamy head .  mouthfeel was good , carbonation was adequate .

s- the smell is strong . its one of those beers that can be smelled half way across the room . there will be no fooling the officers at the check point on your way home from having a glass of this . it has a milky , chocolatey smell with a touch of roast and grain . its appealing and quintessentially stout .  this beer is a fairly brown shade of orange , with almost no head , just a thin white ring .  m - full bodied and chewy with a moderately dry finish with some alcohol noticeable .

a - hazy orange body with a white head on top s - big citrus hop flavor with what smells like a decent malt backbone to stand up to it .  my old foghorn came in a 7 oz bottle warning me about the high strength of the beer . the beer was not highly carbonated either . the color was a light brownish-amber , and was noticably cloudy as well .  mouthfeel is pretty good .

smells heavily of booze dipped dark fruit and straight up alcohol , but not much burn .  pours a transparent light orange with a small white head which eventually disappears . little to no lacing .  buttery thick mouthfeel .

the smell was a bit understated . t- a very nice , crisp taste which , while simple malt at the beginning gave way to some citrus at the end .  appearance- the color reminds me of cedar wood an earthy dark amber/red . mouthfeel- light on palate and definetly lends itself to match with food nicely like breaded shrimp .  flavor was very strong ginger , and this made the mouthfeel quite crisp and pretty good .

a clean wheat smell , but very weak .  12oz bottle a- pours a clear golden yellow color with a fizzy white head that quickly disappears .  taste is mild but the mouthfeel is full pleasantly full and quite nice .

this is the worst nose on an ipa i 've ever encountered . sweet malts dominate .  pours into a slim tumbler with a feeble cap of white foam that fizzles to nothing after a couple minutes . it looks like pale apple juice .  the mouth-feel is thick almost porter-like with the cooling of the alcohol evaporation .

s : a nice roasty bitter chocolate scent upfront followed by some hints of vanilla and raisin . a nice cocoa on the backend . good .  poured a pale yellow colour with absolutely zero head nor lacing .  the mouthfeel was decent , medium with adequate carbonation .

has a solid malt flavor with a huge hop aroma . i could use a tad more bitterness but that is just a personal preference .  poured into a pint glass from the bottle a-has the look of a normal american macro light yellow with no head .  finish is very grainy and `` off '' lol mouthfeel : full-medium , creamy body with moderate carbonation .

smell - citrusy hops off the bat with a little malty sweetness in the background , some earthy notes but pretty one dimensional with hops up front , though i 'm not complaining .  drank this from a bottle then poured into glass mug . the appearenc is more towards a yellow then orangish bud light.the scent.is of course a strong lime eventhough i still recognize the bud light.the tases pretty much is the same as the smell . other notes=eventhough it is very carbonated the head dissapates very quicklyand is not rettained at all.also.there was absolutely nooo lacing whatsoever .  mouthfeel was smooth , slightly thick for a pils , and with a nice carbonation bite .

i like it . t : bitter pine hop flavor hits first with a little bit of relief from the malt , but it never really helps balance the beer altogether .  pours into a pint glass a very light golden yellow with a big foamy , but rapidly receding head . looks like a macro beer looks .  very refreshing in the mouth , its best quality .

s - coffee with with a hint of sweetness . t - a solid coffee taste in the beginning ... and that is where it left off .  1995 lambic bottled in 2000 and drank in 2004 . poured a pale hazy yellow beer with almost no carbonation , which was to be expected .  the mouthfeel was full and sweet .

s- cinnamon scent is ever-present and festive . t- pumpkin and earthy but no hops .  mother lager- magic hat `` you 're never alone with a bone '' mother lager poured a light yellow with no head .  m : medium body , low to medium carbonation . smooth and creamy . d : something does n't quite work for me .

the smell is pretty unimpressive - a bit hoppy , some alcohol .  pale gold with no head .  nice creaminess from the malt . probably the driest amber ale i 've ever had . usually not a bad thing , i like dry beers , but this was too much , there needs to be a little sweetness there to bring it to life . should n't be called an octoberfest and would n't try again .

aroma is malty with pleasant notes of bananas .  this is an easy to drink ale , but there 's nothing really to write home about . be careful not to drink this right out of the refrigerator , as it is really surprisingly bad when cold with a terrible mouthfeel . still , i 'm impressed that goose island has so many beers to i find very drinkable , and they are able to do it in large quantities .  mouthfeel is good and thick , finish is dry with a moderate dose of alcohol present .

aromas are awesome . i can smell this for a couple of feet away .  tons of floaties . poor head retention , no lacing . i do n't mind sediment but this appearance as a whole does nothing for me .  this one is crisp and carbonation is at a good level . body is n't as light as i had expected ; this one 's medium-bodied .
